item.title: 5-HIAA urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will instruct you, if necessary, to stop taking medicines that may interfere with the test.</text><text>Medicines that can increase 5-HIAA measurements include acetaminophen (Tylenol), acetanilide, phenacetin, glyceryl guaiacolate (found in many cough syrups), methocarbamol, and reserpine.</text><text>Medicines that can decrease 5-HIAA measurements include heparin, isoniazid, levodopa, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, methenamine, methyldopa, phenothiazines, and tricyclic antidepressants.</text><text>You will be told not to eat certain foods for 3 days before the test. Foods that can interfere with 5-HIAA measurements include plums, pineapples, bananas, eggplant, tomatoes, avocados, and walnuts.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test measures the level of 5-HIAA in the urine. It is often done to detect certain tumors in the digestive tract ( carcinoid tumors ) and to track a person's condition.</text><text>The urine test may also be used to diagnose a disorder called systemic mastocytosis and some tumors of the hormone.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 2 to 9 mg/24h (10.4 to 46.8 µmol/24h).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Tumors of the endocrine system or carcinoid tumors</detail><detail>Systemic mastocytosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>HIAA</detail><detail> 5-hydroxyindole acetic acid</detail><detail> Serotonin metabolite</detail>

item.title: Quantitative nephelometry test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test provides a rapid and accurate measurement of the amounts of the immunoglobulins IgM, IgG, and IgA.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results for the three immunoglobulins are:</text><detail>IgG: 650 to 1600 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 6.5 to 16.0 grams per liter (g/L)</detail><detail>IgM: 54 to 300 mg/dL, or 540 to 3000 mg/L</detail><detail>IgA: 40 to 350 mg/dL, or 400 to 3500 mg/L</detail><text>The examples above show the common measurements for these test results. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased level of IgG may be due to:</text><detail> Chronic infection or inflammation</detail><detail> Hyperimmunization (higher than normal number of specific antibodies)</detail><detail>IgG multiple myeloma (a type of blood cancer)</detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><text>Decreased levels of IgG may be due to:</text><detail> Agammaglobulinemia (very low levels of immunoglobulins, a very rare disorder)</detail><detail> Leukemia (blood cancer)</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma (bone marrow cancer)</detail><detail> Preeclampsia (high blood pressure during pregnancy)</detail><detail>Treatment with certain chemotherapy drugs </detail><text>Increased levels of IgM may be due to:</text><detail> Mononucleosis </detail><detail>Lymphoma (cancer of the lymph tissue)</detail><detail> Waldenström macroglobulinemia (cancer of the white blood cells)</detail><detail>Multiple myeloma</detail><detail>Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><detail>Infection</detail><text>Decreased levels of IgM may be due to:</text><detail>Agammaglobulinemia (very rare)</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Multiple myeloma </detail><text>Increased levels of IgA may be due to:</text><detail>Chronic infections, especially of the gastrointestinal tract</detail><detail>Inflammatory bowel disease, such as Crohn disease </detail><detail>Multiple myeloma </detail><text>Decreased levels of IgA may be due to:</text><detail>Agammaglobulinemia (very rare)</detail><detail>Hereditary IgA deficiency</detail><detail>Multiple myeloma</detail><detail>Gut disease that leads to protein loss</detail><text>Other tests are needed to confirm or diagnose any of the conditions above.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Quantitative immunoglobulins</detail>

item.title: Knee MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have:</text><detail>An abnormal result on a knee x-ray or bone scan</detail><detail>A feeling that your knee is giving away in the knee joint</detail><detail>Buildup of joint fluid behind the knee ( Baker cyst )</detail><detail>Fluid collecting in the knee joint</detail><detail>Infection of the knee joint</detail><detail>Knee cap injury</detail><detail>Knee pain with fever</detail><detail>Knee locking when you walk or moving</detail><detail>Signs of damage to the knee muscle, cartilage, or ligaments</detail><detail> Knee pain that does not get better with treatment </detail><detail>Instability of the knee</detail><text>You may also have this test to check your progress after knee surgery.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means your knee looks OK.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to a sprain or tear of the ligaments in the knee area.</text><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail>Meniscus or cartilage injuries</detail><detail>Arthritis of the knee</detail><detail> Avascular necrosis (also called osteonecrosis)</detail><detail>Bone tumor or cancer</detail><detail>Broken bone</detail><detail>Buildup of joint fluid behind the knee ( Baker cyst )</detail><detail>Infection in the bone (osteomyelitis)</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Injury of the knee cap </detail><text>Talk to your provider if you have questions or concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI - knee</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - knee</detail>

item.title: Knee CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Some exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be injected into your body before the test. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test to avoid this problem.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps if you are taking this medicine. </detail><text>Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. Ask about the weight limit before the test if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms).</text><text>You will need to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the CT exam.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A CT scan can quickly create more detailed pictures of the knee than standard x-rays. The test may be used to detect:</text><detail> Abscess or infection</detail><detail>Broken bone</detail><detail>Examine fractures and pattern of fractures</detail><detail>The cause of pain or other problems in the knee joint (usually when MRI can't be done)</detail><detail>Masses and tumors, including cancer </detail><detail>Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery</detail><text>A CT scan may also be used to guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abscess (collection of pus)</detail><detail>Arthritis</detail><detail>Broken bone</detail><detail>Bone tumors or cancer </detail><detail>Healing problems or scar tissue after surgery</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - knee</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - knee</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - knee</detail>

item.title: Kidney biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your health care provider:</text><detail>About medicines you are taking, including vitamins and supplements, herbal remedies, and over-the-counter medicines</detail><detail>If you have any allergies</detail><detail>If you have bleeding problems or if you take blood-thinning medicines such as warfarin (Coumadin), clopidogrel (Plavix), dipyridamole (Persantine), fondaparinux (Arixtra), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), or aspirin</detail><detail>If you are or think you might be pregnant</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order a kidney biopsy if you have:</text><detail>An unexplained drop in kidney function</detail><detail> Blood in the urine that does not go away</detail><detail> Protein in the urine found during a urine test</detail><detail>A transplanted kidney, which needs to be monitored using a biopsy </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is when the kidney tissue shows normal structure.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means there are changes in the kidney tissue. This may be due to:</text><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Poor blood flow through the kidney</detail><detail>Connective tissue diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus </detail><detail>Other diseases that may be affecting the kidney, such as diabetes</detail><detail>Kidney transplant rejection , if you had a transplant</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Renal biopsy</detail><detail> Biopsy - kidney</detail>

item.title: Ketones urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may have to follow a special diet. Your provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines that may affect the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Ketone testing is most often done if you have type 1 diabetes and:</text><detail>Your blood sugar is higher than 240 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL)</detail><detail>Nausea or vomiting occur</detail><detail>Pain in the abdomen </detail><text>Ketone testing may also be done if:</text><detail>You have an illness such as pneumonia, heart attack, or stroke</detail><detail>Nausea or vomiting that does not go away</detail><detail>You are pregnant </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test result is normal. </text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means you have ketones in your urine. The results are usually listed as small, moderate, or large as follows:</text><detail>Small: <20 mg/dL</detail><detail>Moderate: 30 to 40 mg/dL</detail><detail>Large: >80 mg/dL </detail><text>Ketones build up when the body needs to break down fats and fatty acids to use as fuel. This is most likely to occur when the body does not get enough sugar or carbohydrates.</text><text>This may be due to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) . DKA is a life-threatening problem that affects people with diabetes. It occurs when the body cannot use sugar (glucose) as a fuel source because there is no insulin or not enough insulin. Fat is used for fuel instead.</text><text>An abnormal result may also be due to: </text><detail>Fasting or starvation: such as with anorexia (an eating disorder)</detail><detail>High protein or low carbohydrate diet</detail><detail>Vomiting over a long period (such as during early pregnancy)</detail><detail>Acute or severe illnesses, such as sepsis or burns</detail><detail>High fevers</detail><detail>The thyroid gland making too much thyroid hormone ( hyperthyroidism )</detail><detail>Nursing a baby, if the mother does not eat and drink enough </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ketone bodies - urine</detail><detail> Urine ketones</detail><detail> Ketoacidosis - urine ketones test</detail><detail> Diabetic ketoacidosis - urine ketones test</detail>

item.title: Ketones blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Ketones are substances produced in the liver when fat cells break down in the blood. This test is used to diagnose ketoacidosis . This is a life-threatening problem that affects people who:</text><detail>Have diabetes. It occurs when the body cannot use sugar (glucose) as a fuel source because there is no insulin or not enough insulin. Fat is used for fuel instead. When fat breaks down, waste products called ketones build up in the body.</detail><detail>Drink large amounts of alcohol.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result is negative. This means there are no ketones in the blood.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A test result is positive if ketones are found in the blood. This may indicate:</text><detail> Alcoholic ketoacidosis </detail><detail> Diabetic ketoacidosis </detail><detail>Starvation</detail><detail>Uncontrolled blood glucose in people with diabetes</detail><text>Other reasons ketones are found in the blood include:</text><detail>A diet low in carbohydrates can increase ketones.</detail><detail>After receiving anesthesia for surgery</detail><detail> Glycogen storage disease (condition in which the body can't break down glycogen, a form of sugar that is stored in the liver and muscles)</detail><detail>Being on a weight-loss diet</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Acetone bodies</detail><detail> Ketones - serum</detail><detail> Nitroprusside test</detail><detail> Ketone bodies - serum</detail><detail> Ketones - blood</detail><detail> Ketoacidosis - ketones blood test</detail>

item.title: Karyotyping
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow the health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test can:</text><detail>Count the number of chromosomes</detail><detail>Look for structural changes in chromosomes </detail><text>This test may be done:</text><detail>On a couple that has a history of miscarriage</detail><detail>To examine any child or baby who has unusual features or developmental delays </detail><text>The bone marrow or blood test can be done to identify the Philadelphia chromosome, which is found in 85% of people with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) .</text><text>The amniotic fluid test is done to check a developing baby for chromosome problems.</text><text>Your provider may order other tests that go together with a karyotype:</text><detail>Microarray: Looks at small changes in the chromosomes</detail><detail>Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): Looks for small mistakes such as deletions in the chromosomes </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results are:</text><detail>Females: 44 autosomes and 2 sex chromosomes (XX), written as 46, XX</detail><detail>Males: 44 autosomes and 2 sex chromosomes (XY), written as 46, XY </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to a genetic syndrome or condition, such as:</text><detail> Down syndrome </detail><detail> Klinefelter syndrome </detail><detail>Philadelphia chromosome</detail><detail> Trisomy 18 </detail><detail> Turner syndrome </detail><text>Chemotherapy may cause chromosome breaks that affect normal karyotyping results.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Chromosome analysis</detail>

item.title: Lymphangiogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must sign a consent form. You may be asked to not eat or drink for several hours before the test. You may wish to empty your bladder just before the test.</text><text>Tell the provider if you are pregnant or you have bleeding problems. Also mention if you have had an allergic reaction to x-ray contrast material or any iodine-containing substance.</text><text>If you are having this test done with sentinel lymph node biopsy (for breast cancer and melanoma), then you will need to prepare for the operating room. A surgeon and anesthesiologist will tell you how to prepare for the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A lymphangiogram is used with lymph node biopsy to determine the possible spread of cancer and the effectiveness of cancer therapy.</text><text>Contrast dye and x-rays are used to help determine the cause of swelling in an arm or leg and check for diseases that may be caused by parasites.</text><text>Additional conditions under which the test may be performed:</text><detail> Hodgkin lymphoma </detail><detail> Non-Hodgkin lymphoma </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Enlarged lymph nodes ( swollen glands ) that have a foamy appearance may be a sign of lymphatic cancer.</text><text>Nodes or parts of the nodes that do not fill with the dye suggest a blockage and may be a sign of cancer spreading through the lymph system. Blockage of the lymph vessels may be caused by tumor , infection, injury, or previous surgery.</text><text>Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Lymphography</detail><detail> Lymphangiography</detail>

item.title: Lymph node culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will instruct you on how to prepare for the lymph node sampling.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have swollen glands and infection is suspected.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there was no growth of microorganisms on the lab dish.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results are a sign of a bacterial, fungal, or viral infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - lymph node</detail>

item.title: Lymph node biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your provider:</text><detail> If you are pregnant </detail><detail> If you have any drug allergies </detail><detail> If you have bleeding problems </detail><detail> What medicines you are taking (including any supplements or herbal remedies) </detail><text>Your provider may ask you to:</text><detail> Stop taking any blood thinners, such as aspirin, heparin, warfarin (Coumadin), or clopidogrel (Plavix) 5 to 10 days before the procedure </detail><detail> Not eat or drink anything after a certain period of time before the biopsy </detail><detail> Arrive at a certain time for the procedure </detail><text>You must sign a consent form.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is used to diagnose cancer, sarcoidosis, or an infection (such as tuberculosis):</text><detail> When you or your provider feel swollen glands and they do not go away </detail><detail> When lymph nodes are present on a CT or MRI scan </detail><detail> For some people with breast cancer or melanoma , to see if the cancer has spread (sentinel lymph node biopsy) </detail><text>The results of the biopsy help your provider decide on further tests and treatments.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>If a lymph node biopsy does not show any signs of cancer, it is more likely that other lymph nodes nearby are also cancer-free. This information can help the provider decide about further tests and treatments.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to many different conditions, from very mild infections to cancer.</text><text>For example, enlarged lymph nodes may be due to:</text><detail> Cancers (breast, lung, oral) </detail><detail> HIV </detail><detail>Cancer of the lymph tissue ( Hodgkin ) or non-Hodgkin lymphoma</detail><detail>Infection (tuberculosis, cat scratch disease )</detail><detail> Inflammation of lymph nodes and other organs and tissues ( sarcoidosis )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - lymph nodes</detail><detail> Open lymph node biopsy</detail><detail> Fine needle aspiration biopsy</detail><detail> Sentinel lymph node biopsy</detail>

item.title: Luteinizing hormone (LH) blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will ask you to temporarily stop medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Hormone therapy</detail><detail>Testosterone</detail><detail>DHEA (a supplement)</detail><text>If you are a woman of childbearing age, the test may need to be done on a specific day of your menstrual cycle. Tell your provider if you have recently been exposed to radioisotopes, such as during a nuclear medicine test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>In women, an increase in LH level at mid-cycle causes release of eggs (ovulation). Your doctor will order this test to see if: </text><detail>You are ovulating, when you are having trouble getting pregnant or have periods that are not regular</detail><detail>You have reached menopause</detail><text>If you are a man, the test may be ordered if you have signs of infertility or lowered sex drive. The test may be ordered if you have signs of a pituitary gland problem.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results for adult women are:</text><detail>Before menopause - 5 to 25 IU/L</detail><detail>Level peaks even higher around the middle of the menstrual cycle</detail><detail>Level then becomes higher after menopause - 14.2 to 52.3 IU/L </detail><text>LH levels are normally low during childhood.</text><text>Normal result for men over 18 years of age is around 1.8 to 8.6 IU/L.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In women, a higher than normal level of LH is seen:</text><detail>When women of childbearing age are not ovulating</detail><detail>When there is an imbalance of female sex hormones (such as with polycystic ovary syndrome )</detail><detail>During or after menopause</detail><detail> Turner syndrome (rare genetic condition in which a female does not have the usual pair of 2 X chromosomes)</detail><detail>When the ovaries produce little or no hormones (ovarian hypofunction) </detail><text>In men, a higher than normal level of LH may be due to:</text><detail>Absence of testes or testes that do not function ( anorchia )</detail><detail>Problem with genes, such as Klinefelter syndrome </detail><detail>Endocrine glands that are overactive or form a tumor ( multiple endocrine neoplasia ) </detail><text>In children, a higher than normal level is seen in early ( precocious ) puberty. </text><text>A lower than normal level of LH may be due to the pituitary gland not making enough hormone ( hypopituitarism ).</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ICSH - blood test</detail><detail> Luteinizing hormone - blood test</detail><detail> Interstitial cell stimulating hormone - blood test</detail>

item.title: Lung plethysmography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Let your doctor know if you are taking any medicines, especially ones for breathing problems. You may have to temporarily stop taking certain medicines before the test.</text><text>Wear loose clothes that allow you to breathe comfortably.</text><text>Avoid smoking and heavy exercise for 6 hours before the test.</text><text>Avoid heavy meals before the test. They can affect your ability to take deep breaths.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to see how much air you can hold in your lungs during rest. It helps your doctor determine if a lung problem is due to damage to the lung structure, or a loss of the lungs' ability to expand (get bigger as air flows in).</text><text>Although this test is the most accurate way to measure how much air you can hold in your lungs, it is not often used because of its technical difficulties.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results depend on your age, height, weight, ethnic background, and gender.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results point to a problem in the lungs. This problem can be due to a breakdown of the lung structure, a problem with the chest wall and its muscles, or a problem with the lungs being able to expand and contract. </text><text>Lung plethysmography will not find the cause of the problem. But it helps the doctor narrow down the list of possible problems.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pulmonary plethysmography</detail><detail> Static lung volume determination</detail><detail> Whole-body plethysmography</detail>

item.title: Lung PET scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan. You will be able to drink water.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if:</text><detail>You are afraid of tight spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you relax and feel less anxious.</detail><detail>You are pregnant or think you might be pregnant.</detail><detail>You have any allergies to injected dye (contrast).</detail><detail>You take insulin for diabetes. You will need special preparation. </detail><text>Tell your provider about the medicines you are taking. These include ones bought without a prescription. Some medicines can interfere with the test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to:</text><detail>Help look for lung cancer, when other imaging tests do not give a clear picture</detail><detail>See if lung cancer has spread to other areas of the lungs or body, when deciding on the best treatment</detail><detail>Help determine if a growth in the lungs (seen on a CT scan) is cancerous or not</detail><detail>Determine how well cancer treatment is working </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the scan did not show any problems in the size, shape, or function of the lungs.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Lung cancer or cancer of another area of the body that has spread to the lungs</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Inflammation of the lungs due to other causes</detail><text>Blood sugar or insulin level may affect the test results in people with diabetes.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Chest PET scan</detail><detail> Lung positron emission tomography</detail><detail> PET - chest</detail><detail> PET - lung</detail><detail> PET - tumor imaging</detail><detail> PET/CT - lung</detail><detail> Solitary pulmonary nodule - PET</detail>

item.title: Lung gallium scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Several hours to 1 day before the scan, you will get an injection of gallium at the place where the testing will be done.</text><text>Just before the scan, remove jewelry, dentures, or other metal objects that can affect the scan. Take off the clothing on the upper half of your body and put on a hospital gown.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is usually done when you have signs of inflammation in the lungs. This is most often due to sarcoidosis or a certain type of pneumonia.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The lungs should appear of normal size and texture, and should take up very little gallium.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If a large amount of gallium is seen in the lungs, it may mean any of the following problems:</text><detail>Sarcoidosis (disease in which inflammation occurs in the lungs and other tissues of the body)</detail><detail>Other respiratory infections, most often a type of pneumonia caused by the fungus Pneumocystis jirovecii </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gallium 67 lung scan</detail><detail> Lung scan</detail><detail> Gallium scan - lung</detail><detail> Scan - lung</detail>

item.title: Lung diffusion testing
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before taking this test:</text><detail>Do not eat a heavy meal before the test.</detail><detail>Do not smoke for at least 4 to 6 hours before the test. </detail><detail>If you use a bronchodilator or other inhaled medicines, ask your health care provider whether or not you can use them before the test.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is used to diagnose certain lung diseases, and to monitor the status of people with established lung disease. Repeatedly measuring the diffusing capacity can help determine whether the disease is improving or getting worse.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal test results depend on a person's:</text><detail> Age </detail><detail> Sex </detail><detail> Height </detail><detail>Hemoglobin (the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen) level</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean that gases do not move normally across the lung tissues into the blood vessels of the lung. This may be due to lung diseases such as:</text><detail> COPD </detail><detail> Interstitial fibrosis </detail><detail> Pulmonary embolism </detail><detail> Pulmonary hypertension </detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail><detail>Bleeding in the lung</detail><detail>Asthma</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Diffusing capacity</detail><detail> DLCO test</detail>

item.title: Lumbosacral spine x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider if you are pregnant. Take off all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Often, the provider will treat a person with low back pain for 4 to 8 weeks before ordering an x-ray.</text><text>The most common reason for lumbosacral spine x-ray is to look for the cause of low back pain that:</text><detail>Occurs after injury</detail><detail>Is severe</detail><detail>Does not go away after 4 to 8 weeks</detail><detail>Is present in an older person </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Lumbosacral spine x-rays may show:</text><detail>Abnormal curves of the spine</detail><detail>Abnormal wear on the cartilage and bones of the lower spine, such as bone spurs and narrowing of the joints between the vertebrae</detail><detail>Cancer (although cancer often cannot be seen on this type of x-ray)</detail><detail> Fractures </detail><detail>Signs of thinning bones ( osteoporosis )</detail><detail> Spondylolisthesis , in which a bone (vertebra) in the lower part of the spine slips out of the proper position onto the bone below it </detail><text>Though some of these findings may be seen on an x-ray, they are not always the cause of back pain. </text><text>Many problems in the spine cannot be diagnosed using a lumbosacral x-ray, including:</text><detail> Sciatica </detail><detail> Slipped or herniated disc </detail><detail> Spinal stenosis - narrowing of the spinal column </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - lumbosacral spine</detail><detail> X-ray - lower spine</detail>

item.title: Lumbosacral spine CT
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should remove all jewelry or other metal objects before the test. This is because they may cause inaccurate and blurry images.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the body. A CT of the lumbosacral spine can evaluate fractures and changes of the spine, such as those due to arthritis or deformities.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>CT of the lumbosacral spine may reveal the following conditions or diseases:</text><detail> Cyst </detail><detail> Herniated disk </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Cancer that has spread to the spine</detail><detail> Osteoarthritis </detail><detail> Osteomalacia (softening of the bones)</detail><detail>Pinched nerve</detail><detail> Tumor </detail><detail>Vertebral fracture (broken spine bone)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Spinal CT</detail><detail> CT - lumbosacral spine</detail><detail> Low back pain - CT</detail><detail> LBP - CT</detail>

item.title: Lumbar spine CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Some exams use a special dye, called contrast that is put into your body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><text>Contrast can be given in different ways.</text><detail>It may be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm.</detail><detail>It may be given as an injection into the space around the spinal cord. </detail><text>If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</text><text>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to avoid this problem.</text><text>If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts.</text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT scans rapidly makes detailed pictures of the lower back. The test may be used to look for:</text><detail>Birth defects of the spine in children</detail><detail>Injury in the lower spine</detail><detail>Spine problems when MRI cannot be used</detail><detail>Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery </detail><text>This test can also be used during or after an x-ray of the spinal cord and spinal nerve roots (myelography) or an x-ray of the disk (discography).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen in the lumbar region in the images.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Birth defects of the spine</detail><detail>Bone problems</detail><detail>Fracture</detail><detail> Lumbar disk herniation </detail><detail>Lumbar spinal stenosis </detail><detail> Spondylolisthesis </detail><detail>Healing or growth of scar tissue after surgery</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - lumbar spine</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - lumbar spine</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - lumbar spine</detail><detail> CT - lower back</detail>

item.title: Lumbar MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need a lumbar MRI if you have:</text><detail>Low back or pelvic pain that does not get better after treatment</detail><detail>Leg weakness, numbness, or other symptoms that do not improve or get worse </detail><text>Your provider may also order a lumbar MRI if you have:</text><detail>Back pain and fever</detail><detail>Birth defects of the lower spine</detail><detail>Injury or trauma to the lower spine</detail><detail>Low back pain and a history or signs of cancer</detail><detail> Multiple sclerosis </detail><detail>Problems controlling or emptying your bladder</detail><detail>Disk herniation</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means your spine and nearby nerves look OK.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Most of the time, abnormal results are due to:</text><detail>Herniated or "slipped" disk ( lumbar radiculopathy )</detail><detail>Narrowing of the spinal column ( spinal stenosis )</detail><detail>Abnormal wearing on the bones and cartilage in the spine (spondylitis) </detail><text>Other abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Ankylosing spondylitis , a type of arthritis</detail><detail> Bone infection </detail><detail>Cauda equina syndrome</detail><detail> Fractures of the lower back due to osteoporosis</detail><detail>Disk inflammation ( diskitis )</detail><detail> Spinal cord abscess </detail><detail> Spinal cord injury </detail><detail> Spinal tumor </detail><detail>Syringomyelia </detail><text>Talk to your provider about your questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Magnetic resonance imaging - lumbar spine</detail><detail> MRI - lower back</detail>

item.title: Liver scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must sign a consent form. You will be asked to remove jewelry, dentures, and other metals that can affect the scanner's functions.</text><text>You may need to wear a hospital gown.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test can provide information about liver and spleen function. It is also used to help confirm other test results.</text><text>The most common use for a liver scan is to diagnose a condition called benign focal nodular hyperplasia, or FNH, which causes a non-cancerous mass in the liver. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The liver and spleen should look normal in size, shape, and location. The radioisotope is absorbed evenly.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate:</text><detail>Focal nodular hyperplasia or adenoma of the liver</detail><detail> Abscess </detail><detail> Budd-Chiari syndrome </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail> Liver disease (such as cirrhosis or hepatitis )</detail><detail> Superior vena cava obstruction </detail><detail> Splenic infarction (tissue death)</detail><detail>Tumors </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Technetium scan</detail><detail> Liver technetium sulfur colloid scan</detail><detail> Liver-spleen radionuclide scan</detail><detail> Nuclear scan - technetium</detail><detail> Nuclear scan - liver or spleen</detail>

item.title: Liver biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your provider about:</text><detail>Bleeding problems</detail><detail>Drug allergies</detail><detail>Medicines you are taking including herbs, supplements, or medicines you bought without a prescription.</detail><detail>Whether you are pregnant </detail><text>You must sign a consent form. Blood tests are sometimes done to test your blood's ability to clot. You will be told not to eat or drink anything for the 8 hours before the test.</text><text>For infants and children:</text><text>The preparation needed for a child depends on the child's age and maturity. Your child's provider will tell you what you can do to prepare your child for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The biopsy helps diagnose many liver diseases . The procedure also helps assess the stage (early, advanced) of liver disease. This is especially important in hepatitis B and C infection.</text><text>The biopsy also helps detect:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Infections</detail><detail>The cause of abnormal levels of liver enzymes that have been found in blood tests</detail><detail>The cause of an unexplained liver enlargement </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The liver tissue is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The biopsy may reveal a number of liver diseases, including cirrhosis , hepatitis , or infections such as tuberculosis . It may also indicate cancer.</text><text>This test also may be performed for:</text><detail> Alcoholic liver disease (fatty liver, hepatitis, or cirrhosis)</detail><detail> Amebic liver abscess </detail><detail> Autoimmune hepatitis </detail><detail> Biliary atresia </detail><detail>Chronic active hepatitis</detail><detail>Chronic persistent hepatitis</detail><detail> Disseminated coccidioidomycosis </detail><detail> Hemochromatosis </detail><detail> Hepatitis B </detail><detail> Hepatitis C </detail><detail> Hepatitis D </detail><detail> Hepatocellular carcinoma </detail><detail> Hodgkin lymphoma </detail><detail>Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease</detail><detail> Non-Hodgkin lymphoma </detail><detail> Primary biliary cirrhosis </detail><detail>Primary biliary cholangitis</detail><detail> Pyogenic liver abscess </detail><detail> Reye syndrome </detail><detail> Sclerosing cholangitis </detail><detail> Wilson disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - liver</detail><detail> Percutaneous biopsy</detail>

item.title: Lipoprotein-a
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked not to eat anything for 12 hours before the test.</text><text>DO NOT smoke before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>High levels of lipoproteins can increase the risk for heart disease. The test is done to check your risk for atherosclerosis , stroke, and heart attack.</text><text>It is not yet clear if this measurement leads to improved benefits for patients. Therefore, many insurance companies DO NOT pay for it. </text><text>The American Heart Association and American College of Cardiology DO NOT recommend the test for most adults who DO NOT have symptoms. It may be useful for people at higher risk because of a strong family history of cardiovascular disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are below 30 mg/dL (milligrams per deciliter), or 1.7 mmol/L.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurements for results of these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher than normal values of Lp(a) are associated with a high risk for atherosclerosis, stroke, and heart attack.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Lp(a)</detail>

item.title: Lipase test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT eat for 8 hours before the test.</text><text>Your health care provider may ask you to stop taking medicines that may affect the test, such as:</text><detail>Bethanechol</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Cholinergic medicines</detail><detail>Codeine</detail><detail>Indomethacin</detail><detail>Meperidine</detail><detail>Methacholine</detail><detail>Morphine</detail><detail>Thiazide diuretics</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check for disease of the pancreas, most often acute pancreatitis .</text><text>Lipase appears in the blood when the pancreas is damaged.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In general, normal results are 0 to 160 units per liter (U/L) or 0 to 2.67 microkat/L (µkat/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.</text><text>Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal levels may be due to:</text><detail> Blockage of the bowel (bowel obstruction)</detail><detail>Celiac disease</detail><detail> Duodenal ulcer </detail><detail> Cancer of the pancreas</detail><detail> Pancreatitis </detail><detail>Pancreatic pseudocyst</detail><text>This test may also be done for familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pancreatitis - blood lipase</detail>

item.title: Limb plethysmography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Do not smoke for at least 30 minutes before the test. You will be asked to remove all clothing from the arm and leg being tested.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to check for narrowing or blockages of blood vessels (arteries) in the arms or legs. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There should be less than a 20 to 30 mm Hg difference in the systolic blood pressure of the leg compared with that of the arm.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Arterial occlusive disease </detail><detail> Blood clots </detail><detail>Blood vessel changes due to diabetes</detail><detail>Injury to an artery</detail><detail>Other blood vessel disease (vascular disease)</detail><text>Other conditions for which the test may be performed:</text><detail> Deep venous thrombosis </detail><text>If you have an abnormal result, you may need to have more testing to find the exact site of the narrowing.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Plethysmography - limb</detail>

item.title: LH response to GnRH blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>GnRH is a hormone made by the hypothalamus gland. LH is made by the pituitary gland. GnRH causes (stimulates) the pituitary gland to release LH.</text><text>This test is used to tell the difference between primary and secondary hypogonadism . Hypogonadism is a condition in which the sex glands make little or no hormones. In men, the sex glands (gonads) are the testes. In women, the sex glands are the ovaries.</text><text>Depending on the type of hypogonadism:</text><detail>Primary hypogonadism starts in the testicle or ovary</detail><detail>Secondary hypogonadism starts in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland</detail><text>This test may also be done to check:</text><detail>Low testosterone level in men</detail><detail>Low estradiol level in women</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased LH response suggests a problem in the ovaries or testes.</text><text>A reduced LH response suggests a problem with the hypothalamus gland or pituitary gland.</text><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail>Pituitary gland problems, such as release of too much hormone ( hyperprolactinemia ) </detail><detail>Large pituitary tumors </detail><detail>Decrease in hormones made by the endocrine glands </detail><detail>Too much iron in the body ( hemochromatosis ) </detail><detail>Eating disorders, such as anorexia </detail><detail>Recent significant weight loss, such as after bariatric surgery </detail><detail>Delayed or absent puberty (Kallmann syndrome) </detail><detail>Lack of periods in women ( amenorrhea ) </detail><detail>Obesity </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Luteinizing hormone response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone</detail>

item.title: Leukocyte esterase urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Leukocyte esterase is a screening test used to detect a substance that suggests there are white blood cells in the urine. This may mean you have a urinary tract infection .</text><text>If this test is positive, the urine should be examined under a microscope for white blood cells and other signs that point to an infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test result is normal.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result indicates a possible urinary tract infection.</text><text>The following may turn the test abnormal even when you do not have a urinary infection:</text><detail>Trichomonas infection (such as trichomoniasis)</detail><detail>Vaginal secretions (such as blood or heavy mucus discharge)</detail><text>The following may turn the test even when you do have an urinary infection:</text><detail>High level of protein</detail><detail>High level of vitamin C</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>WBC esterase</detail>

item.title: Leucine aminopeptidase blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You need to fast for 8 hours before the test. This means you can't eat or drink anything during the 8 hours.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>LAP is a type of protein called an enzyme. This enzyme is normally found in cells of the liver , bile, blood, urine and the placenta.</text><text>Your health care provider may order this test to check if your liver is damaged. Too much LAP is released into your blood when you have a liver tumor or damage to your liver cells.</text><text>This test is not done very often. Other tests, such as gamma-glutamyl transferase , are as accurate and easier to get.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal range is:</text><detail>Male: 80 to 200 U/mL</detail><detail>Female: 75 to 185 U/mL</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may be a sign of:</text><detail>Bile flow from the liver is blocked ( cholestasis )</detail><detail> Cirrhosis </detail><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail>Liver cancer</detail><detail>Liver ischemia (reduced blood flow to the liver)</detail><detail>Liver necrosis (death of liver tissue)</detail><detail> Liver tumor </detail><detail>Use of drugs that are toxic to the liver </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum leucine aminopeptidase</detail><detail> LAP - serum</detail>

item.title: Leucine aminopeptidase - urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you to stop taking any medicines that could affect the test. Drugs that can affect the results of this test include estrogen and progesterone. Never stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test to see if there is liver damage. It may also be done to check for certain tumors.</text><text>This test is only rarely done. Other tests (such as gamma glutamyl transpeptidase) are as accurate and are more easily available.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 2 to 18 units per 24 hours.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased levels of leucine aminopeptidase can be seen in several conditions:</text><detail> Cholestasis </detail><detail> Cirrhosis </detail><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail>Liver cancer</detail><detail>Liver ischemia (reduced blood flow to the liver)</detail><detail>Liver necrosis (death of live tissue)</detail><detail> Liver tumor </detail><detail>Pregnancy (late stage)</detail>

item.title: Lepromin skin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>People with dermatitis or other skin irritations should have the test performed on an unaffected part of the body.</text><text>If your child is to have this test performed, it may be helpful to explain how the test will feel, and even demonstrate on a doll. Explain the reason for the test. Knowing the "how and why" may reduce the anxiety your child feels.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text> Leprosy is a long-term ( chronic ) and potentially disfiguring infection if left untreated. It is caused by Mycobacterium leprae bacteria.</text><text>This test is a research tool that helps classify the different types of leprosy. It is not recommended as the main method to diagnose leprosy.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>People who don't have leprosy will have little or no skin reaction to the antigen. People with a particular type of leprosy, called lepromatous leprosy, will also have no skin reaction to the antigen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive skin reaction may be seen in people with specific forms of leprosy, such as tuberculoid and borderline tuberculoid leprosy. People with lepromatous leprosy will not have a positive skin reaction.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Leprosy skin test</detail><detail> Hansen disease - skin test</detail>

item.title: Leg MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test provides detailed pictures of parts of the leg that are hard to see clearly on CT scans.</text><text>Your provider may order an MRI of the leg if you have:</text><detail>A mass that can be felt on a physical exam</detail><detail>An abnormal finding on an x-ray or bone scan</detail><detail>Birth defects of the leg, ankle, or foot</detail><detail>Bone pain and fever</detail><detail>Broken bone</detail><detail>Decreased motion of the ankle joint</detail><detail>Pain, swelling, or redness in a leg</detail><detail>Redness or swelling of the ankle joint</detail><detail>Leg pain and a history of cancer</detail><detail>Leg, foot, or ankle pain that does not get better with treatment</detail><detail>Instability of your ankle and foot</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means your leg looks OK.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abscess</detail><detail> Achilles tendonitis </detail><detail>Arthritis</detail><detail>Broken bone or fracture</detail><detail>Infection in the bone</detail><detail>Ligament, tendon, or cartilage injury</detail><detail>Muscle damage</detail><detail>Osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis)</detail><detail>Plantar fascia rupture (See: Plantar fascitis )</detail><detail>Posterior tibial tendon dysfunction</detail><detail>Tear or rupture of the Achilles tendon in the ankle area</detail><detail>Tumor or cancer in the bone, muscle, or soft tissue </detail><text>Talk to your provider about your questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI - lower extremity</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - leg</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - lower extremity</detail><detail> MRI - ankle</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - ankle</detail><detail> MRI - femur</detail><detail> MRI - leg</detail>

item.title: Leg CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Some exams use a special dye, called contrast, that is put into your body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to avoid this problem.</detail><detail>Before having the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps before the test if you take this drug. </detail><text>Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. Find out if the CT machine has a weight limit if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms).</text><text>You will wear a hospital gown during the study. You will need to take off all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT scan makes detailed pictures of the body very quickly. The test may help look for:</text><detail>An abscess or infection</detail><detail>A mass that is felt during a physical exam</detail><detail>The cause of pain or other problems in the foot, ankle, or knee joints (usually when an MRI cannot be done)</detail><detail>A broken bone</detail><detail>The pattern of the fractures</detail><detail>Masses and tumors, including cancer </detail><detail>Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery</detail><text>A CT scan may also be used to guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if the leg being examined looks OK.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abscess or infection</detail><detail> Blood clot in the leg (deep venous thrombosis)</detail><detail> Broken or fractured bone</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Damage to the knee, foot, or ankle joint</detail><detail>Noncancerous bone tumor</detail><detail>Healing problems or development of scar tissue after surgery</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - leg</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - leg</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - leg</detail><detail> CT scan - leg</detail>

item.title: Left heart ventricular angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be told not to eat or drink for 6 to 8 hours before the test. The procedure takes place in the hospital. Some people may need to stay in the hospital the night before the test.</text><text>A provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form for the procedure. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Left heart angiography is performed to assess the blood flow through the left side of the heart.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result shows normal blood flow through the left side of the heart. Blood volumes and pressures are also normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>A hole in the heart (ventricular septal defect)</detail><detail>Abnormalities of the left heart valves</detail><detail>An aneurysm of the heart wall</detail><detail>Areas of the heart are not contracting normally</detail><detail>Blood flow problems on the left side of the heart</detail><detail>Heart-related blockages</detail><detail>Weakened pumping function of the left ventricle</detail><text> Coronary angiography may be needed when blockage of the coronary arteries is suspected.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Angiography - left heart</detail><detail> Left ventriculography</detail>

item.title: Left heart catheterization
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>In most cases, you should not eat or drink for 8 hours before the test. (Your provider may give you different directions.)</text><text>The procedure will take place in the hospital. You may be admitted the night before the test, but it is common to come to the hospital the morning of the procedure.</text><text>Your provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The procedure is done to look for:</text><detail>Cardiac valve disease</detail><detail>Cardiac tumors</detail><detail>Heart defects (such as ventricular septal defects )</detail><detail>Problems with heart function</detail><text>The procedure may also be done to evaluate and possibly repair certain types of heart defects, or to open a narrowed heart valve.</text><text>When this procedure is done with coronary angiography , it can open blocked arteries or bypass grafts.</text><text>The procedure can also be used to:</text><detail>Collect blood samples from the heart</detail><detail>Determine pressure and blood flow in the heart’s chambers</detail><detail>Examine the arteries of the heart (coronary angiography)</detail><detail>Take x-ray pictures of the left ventricle (main pumping chamber) of the heart (ventriculography)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the heart is normal in:</text><detail>Size</detail><detail>Motion</detail><detail>Thickness</detail><detail>Pressure</detail><text>The normal result also means arteries are normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign of cardiac disease or heart defects, including:</text><detail> Aortic insufficiency </detail><detail> Aortic stenosis </detail><detail> Coronary artery disease </detail><detail> Heart enlargement </detail><detail> Mitral regurgitation </detail><detail> Mitral stenosis </detail><detail>Ventricular aneurysms </detail><detail> Atrial septal defect </detail><detail> Ventricular septal defect </detail><detail>Heart failure</detail><detail> Cardiomyopathy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Catheterization - left heart</detail>

item.title: Lead levels - blood
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text><text>For children, it may be helpful to explain how the test will feel and why it is done. This may make the child feel less nervous.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to screen people at risk for lead poisoning. This may include industrial workers and children who live in urban areas. The test is also used to measure how well treatment for lead poisoning is working. Lead is common in the environment, so it is often found in the body in low levels.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Small amounts of lead in adults are not thought to be harmful. However, even low levels of lead can be dangerous to infants and children. It can cause lead poisoning that leads to problems in mental development.</text><text>Adults:</text><detail>Less than 10 micrograms per deciliter (µg/dL) or 0.48 micromoles per liter (µmol/L) of lead in the blood </detail><text>Children:</text><detail>Less than 5 µg/dL or 0.24 µmol/L of lead in the blood </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In adults, a blood lead level of 5 µug/dL or 0.24 µumol/L or above is considered elevated. Treatment may be recommended if:</text><detail>Your blood lead level is greater than 80 µg/dL or 3.86 µmol/L</detail><detail>You have symptoms of lead poisoning and your blood lead level is greater than 40 µg/dL or 1.93 µmol/L </detail><text>In children:</text><detail>Blood lead level of 5 µg/dL or 0.24 µmol/L or greater requires further testing and monitoring.</detail><detail>The source of lead must be found and removed.</detail><detail>A lead level greater than 45 µg/dL or 2.17 µmol/L in a child's blood most often indicates the need for treatment.</detail><detail>Treatment may be considered with a level as low as 20 µg/dL or 0.97 µmol/L. </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Blood lead levels</detail>

item.title: LDH isoenzyme blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines before the test.</text><text>Drugs that can increase LDH measurements include:</text><detail>Anesthetics</detail><detail>Aspirin</detail><detail>Clofibrate</detail><detail>Fluorides</detail><detail>Mithramycin</detail><detail>Narcotics</detail><detail>Procainamide </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>LDH is an enzyme found in many body tissues such as the heart, liver, kidney, skeletal muscle, brain, blood cells, and lungs. When body tissue is damaged, LDH is released into the blood.</text><text>The LDH test helps determine the location of tissue damage.</text><text>LDH exists in five forms, which differ slightly in structure.</text><detail>LDH-1 is found primarily in heart muscle and red blood cells.</detail><detail>LDH-2 is concentrated in white blood cells.</detail><detail>LDH-3 is highest in the lung.</detail><detail>LDH-4 is highest in the kidney, placenta, and pancreas.</detail><detail>LDH-5 is highest in the liver and skeletal muscle. </detail><text>All of these can be measured in the blood.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>LDH levels that are higher than normal may suggest:</text><detail> Hemolytic anemia </detail><detail>Hypotension</detail><detail> Infectious mononucleosis </detail><detail>Intestinal ischemia (blood deficiency) and infarction (tissue death)</detail><detail> Ischemic cardiomyopathy </detail><detail>Liver disease such as hepatitis </detail><detail>Lung tissue death</detail><detail>Muscle injury</detail><detail> Muscular dystrophy </detail><detail>Pancreatitis</detail><detail>Lung tissue death</detail><detail> Stroke </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>LD</detail><detail> LDH</detail><detail> Lactic (lactate) dehydrogenase isoenzymes</detail>

item.title: Latex agglutination test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to limit certain foods or medicines shortly before the test. Follow instructions on how to prepare for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is a quick way to determine the absence or presence of an antigen or antibody. Your provider will base any treatment decisions, at least in part, on the results of this test.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If there is an antigen-antibody match, agglutination will occur.</text>

item.title: Laryngoscopy and nasolarynoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Preparation will depend on the type of laryngoscopy you will have. If the exam will be done under general anesthesia, you may be told not to drink or eat anything for several hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test can help your provider diagnose many conditions involving the throat and voice box. Your provider may recommend this test if you have:</text><detail>Bad breath that does not go away</detail><detail>Breathing problems, including noisy breathing (stridor)</detail><detail>Long-term (chronic) cough</detail><detail>Coughing up blood</detail><detail>Difficulty swallowing</detail><detail>Ear pain that does not go away</detail><detail>Feeling that something is stuck in your throat</detail><detail>Long-term upper respiratory problem in a smoker</detail><detail>Mass in the head or neck area with signs of cancer</detail><detail>Throat pain that does not go away</detail><detail>Voice problems that last more than 3 weeks, including hoarseness, weak voice, raspy voice, or no voice</detail><text>A direct laryngoscopy may also be used to:</text><detail>Remove a sample of tissue in the throat for closer examination under a microscope (biopsy)</detail><detail>Remove an object that is blocking the airway (for example, a swallowed a marble or coin)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the throat, voice box, and vocal cords appear normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Acid reflux (GERD) , which can cause redness and swelling of the vocal cords</detail><detail> Cancer of the throat or voice box</detail><detail>Nodules on the vocal cords</detail><detail> Polyps (benign lumps) on the voice box</detail><detail>Inflammation in the throat</detail><detail>Thinning of the muscle and tissue in the voice box (presbylaryngis)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Laryngopharyngoscopy</detail><detail> Indirect laryngoscopy</detail><detail> Flexible laryngoscopy</detail><detail> Mirror laryngoscopy</detail><detail> Direct laryngoscopy</detail><detail> Fiberoptic laryngoscopy</detail><detail> Laryngoscopy using strobe (laryngeal stroboscopy) </detail>

item.title: Lactose tolerance tests
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or do heavy exercise for 8 hours before the test. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order these tests if you have signs of lactose intolerance.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The breath test is considered normal if the increase in hydrogen is less than 12 parts per million over your fasting (pre-test) level.</text><text>The blood test is considered normal if your glucose level rises more than 30 mg/dL (1.6 mmol/L) within 2 hours of drinking the lactose solution. A rise of 20 to 30 mg/dL (1.1 to 1.6 mmol/L) is inconclusive.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign of lactose intolerance.</text><text>A breath test result that shows a rise in hydrogen content of 12 parts per million (ppm) over your pre-test level is considered positive, and means you may have trouble breaking down lactose.</text><text>The blood test is considered abnormal if your glucose level rises less than 20 mg/dL (1.1 mmol/L) within 2 hours of drinking the lactose solution.</text><text>An abnormal test should be followed by a glucose tolerance test to rule out a problem with the body's ability to absorb glucose.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Hydrogen breath test for lactose tolerance</detail>

item.title: Lactic acid test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT exercise for several hours before the test. Exercise can cause a temporary increase in lactic acid levels.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to diagnose lactic acidosis .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>4.5 to 19.8 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) (0.5 to 2.2 millimoles per liter [mmol/L])</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean that body tissues are not getting enough oxygen.</text><text>Conditions that can increase lactic acid levels include:</text><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Lung disease</detail><detail>Not enough blood containing oxygen getting to a certain area of the body</detail><detail>Severe infection that affects the entire body ( sepsis )</detail><detail>Very low levels of oxygen in the blood (hypoxia) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Lactate test</detail>

item.title: Lactate dehydrogenase test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No specific preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>LDH is most often measured to check for tissue damage. LDH is in many body tissues, especially the heart, liver, kidney, muscles, brain, blood cells, and lungs.</text><text>Other conditions for which the test may be done include:</text><detail>Low red blood cell count ( anemia )</detail><detail>Cancer, including blood cancer ( leukemia ) or lymph cancer (lymphoma) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value range is 105 to 333 international units per liter (IU/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level may indicate:</text><detail>Blood flow deficiency (ischemia)</detail><detail> Heart attack </detail><detail> Hemolytic anemia </detail><detail> Infectious mononucleosis </detail><detail>Leukemia or lymphoma</detail><detail> Liver disease (for example, hepatitis )</detail><detail>Low blood pressure</detail><detail>Muscle injury</detail><detail>Muscle weakness and loss of muscle tissue ( muscular dystrophy )</detail><detail>New abnormal tissue formation (usually cancer)</detail><detail>Pancreatitis</detail><detail> Stroke </detail><detail>Tissue death</detail><text>If your LDH level is high, your provider may recommend an LDH isoenzymes test to determine the location of any tissue damage.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>LDH test</detail><detail> Lactic acid dehydrogenase test</detail>

item.title: Myoglobin urine test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Myoglobin is a protein in heart and skeletal muscles. When you exercise, your muscles use up available oxygen. Myoglobin has oxygen attached to it, which provides extra oxygen for the muscles to keep up a high level of activity for a longer period.</text><text>When muscle is damaged, myoglobin in muscle cells is released into the bloodstream. The kidneys help remove myoglobin from the blood into the urine. When the level of myoglobin is too high, it can damage the kidneys.</text><text>This test is ordered when your provider suspects you have muscle damage, such as damage to the heart or skeletal muscle. It may also be ordered if you have acute kidney failure without any clear cause.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal urine sample does not have myoglobin. A normal result is sometimes reported as negative.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Heart attack </detail><detail> Malignant hyperthermia (very rare)</detail><detail> Disorder that causes muscle weakness and loss of muscle tissue ( muscular dystrophy )</detail><detail> Breakdown of muscle tissue that leads to the release of muscle fiber contents into the blood ( rhabdomyolysis )</detail><detail>Skeletal muscle inflammation ( myositis )</detail><detail>Skeletal muscle ischemia (oxygen deficiency)</detail><detail>Skeletal muscle trauma </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine myoglobin</detail><detail> Heart attack - myoglobin urine test</detail><detail> Myositis - myoglobin urine test</detail><detail> Rhabdomyolysis - myoglobin urine test</detail>

item.title: Myoglobin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Myoglobin is a protein in heart and skeletal muscles. When you exercise, your muscles use up available oxygen. Myoglobin has oxygen attached to it, which provides extra oxygen for the muscles to keep at a high level of activity for a longer period.</text><text>When muscle is damaged, myoglobin in muscle cells is released into the bloodstream. The kidneys help remove myoglobin from the blood into the urine. When the level of myoglobin is too high, it can damage the kidneys.</text><text>This test is ordered when your health care provider suspects you have muscle damage, such as of the heart or skeletal muscle.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 25 to 72 ng/mL (1.28 to 3.67 nmol/L).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased level of myoglobin may be due to:</text><detail> Heart attack </detail><detail> Malignant hyperthermia (very rare)</detail><detail> Disorder that causes muscle weakness and loss of muscle tissue ( muscular dystrophy )</detail><detail>Breakdown of muscle tissue that leads to the release of muscle fiber contents into the blood ( rhabdomyolysis )</detail><detail>Skeletal muscle inflammation ( myositis )</detail><detail>Skeletal muscle ischemia (oxygen deficiency)</detail><detail>Skeletal muscle trauma</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum myoglobin</detail><detail> Heart attack - myoglobin blood test</detail><detail> Myositis - myoglobin blood test</detail><detail> Rhabdomyolysis - myoglobin blood test</detail>

item.title: Myocardial biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be told not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test. The procedure takes place in the hospital. Most often, you will be admitted the morning of the procedure, but in some cases, you may need to be admitted the night before.</text><text>A provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form.</text>
