item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This procedure is routinely done after heart transplantation to watch for signs of rejection. </text><text>Your provider may also order this procedure if you have signs of:</text><detail>Alcoholic cardiomyopathy</detail><detail> Cardiac amyloidosis </detail><detail> Cardiomyopathy </detail><detail> Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy </detail><detail>Idiopathic cardiomyopathy</detail><detail> Ischemic cardiomyopathy </detail><detail> Myocarditis </detail><detail> Peripartum cardiomyopathy </detail><detail> Restrictive cardiomyopathy </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no abnormal heart muscle tissue was discovered. However, it does not necessarily mean your heart is normal because sometimes the biopsy can miss abnormal tissue.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means abnormal tissue was found. This test may reveal the cause of cardiomyopathy. Abnormal tissue may be due to:</text><detail>Amyloidosis</detail><detail>Myocarditis</detail><detail>Sarcoidosis</detail><detail> Transplant rejection </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Heart biopsy</detail><detail> Biopsy - heart</detail>

item.title: Mycobacterial culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Preparation depends on how the test is done. Follow your health care provider's instructions.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order this test if you have signs of tuberculosis or a related infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>If there is no disease present, there will be no growth of bacteria in the culture medium.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Mycobacterium tuberculosis or similar bacteria is present in the culture.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - mycobacterial</detail>

item.title: Muscle biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is usually needed. If you will have anesthesia, follow instructions on not eating or drinking anything before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A muscle biopsy may be done to identify or detect:</text><detail>Inflammatory diseases of muscle (such as polymyositis or dermatomyositis )</detail><detail>Diseases of the connective tissue and blood vessels (such as polyarteritis nodosa)</detail><detail>Infections that affect the muscles (such as trichinosis or toxoplasmosis )</detail><detail>Inherited muscle disorders such as muscular dystrophy or congenital myopathy</detail><detail>Metabolic defects of the muscle</detail><detail>Effects of medicines, toxins, or electrolyte disorders </detail><text>A muscle biopsy may also be done to tell the difference between nerve and muscle disorders.</text><text>A muscle that has recently been injured, such as by an EMG needle, or is affected by a pre-existing condition, such as nerve compression, is not a good choice for a biopsy.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the muscle is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A muscle biopsy can help diagnose the following conditions:</text><detail>Loss of muscle mass ( atrophy) </detail><detail>Muscle disease that involves inflammation and a skin rash ( dermatomyositis )</detail><detail>Inherited muscle disorder ( Duchenne muscular dystrophy )</detail><detail>Inflammation of the muscle</detail><detail>Various muscular dystrophies</detail><detail>Destruction of the muscle ( myopathic changes )</detail><detail>Tissue death of the muscle (necrosis) </detail><detail>Disorders that involve inflammation of the blood vessels and affect muscles ( necrotizing vasculitis )</detail><detail>Traumatic muscle damage</detail><detail>Paralyzed muscles</detail><detail>Inflammatory disease causing muscle weakness, swelling tenderness, and tissue damage ( polymyositis )</detail><detail>Nerve problems that affect the muscles</detail><detail>Muscle tissue under the skin (fascia) becomes swollen, inflamed, and thick ( eosinophilic fasciitis ) </detail><text>There are additional conditions under which the test may be performed.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - muscle</detail>

item.title: MRI
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious, or your provider may suggest an open MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Having MRIs with other imaging methods can often help your provider make a diagnosis.</text><text>MRI images taken after a special dye (contrast) is delivered into your body may provide extra information about the blood vessels.</text><text>A magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) , is a form of magnetic resonance imaging that creates 3-dimensional pictures of blood vessels. It is often used when traditional angiography cannot be done.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the body area being studied looks normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Results depend on the part of the body being examined and the nature of the problem. Different types of tissues send back different MRI signals. For example, healthy tissue sends back a slightly different signal than cancerous tissue. Consult your provider with any questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Magnetic resonance imaging</detail><detail> Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) imaging</detail>

item.title: Mononucleosis spot test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The mononucleosis spot test is done when symptoms of mononucleosis are present. Common symptoms include:</text><detail>Fatigue</detail><detail>Fever</detail><detail>Large spleen (possibly)</detail><detail>Sore throat</detail><detail>Tender lymph nodes along the back of the neck </detail><text>This test looks for antibodies called heterophile antibodies which form in the body during the infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test means there were no heterophile antibodies detected. Most of the time this means you do not have infectious mononucleosis.</text><text>Sometimes, the test may be negative because it was done too soon (within 1 to 2 weeks) after the illness started. Your health care provider may repeat the test to make sure you do not have mono.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test means heterophile antibodies are present. These are most often a sign of mononucleosis. Your provider will also consider other blood test results and your symptoms. A small number of people with mononucleosis may never have a positive test.</text><text>The highest number of antibodies occurs 2 to 5 weeks after mono begins. They may be present for up to 1 year.</text><text>In rare cases, the test is positive even though you do not have mono. This is called a false-positive result, and it may occur in people with:</text><detail>Hepatitis</detail><detail>Leukemia or lymphoma</detail><detail>Rubella</detail><detail>Systemic lupus erythematosus</detail><detail> Toxoplasmosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Monospot test</detail><detail> Heterophile antibody test</detail><detail> Heterophile agglutination test</detail><detail> Paul-Bunnell test</detail><detail> Forssman antibody test</detail>

item.title: Microalbuminuria test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>People with diabetes have a high risk of kidney damage. The "filters" in the kidneys, called nephrons, slowly thicken and become scarred over time. The nephrons begin to leak protein into the urine. This kidney damage can also happen years before any diabetes symptoms begin. In the early stages of kidney problems, blood tests may be normal.</text><text>If you have diabetes, you should have this test each year. The test checks for signs of early kidney problems .</text><text>If this test shows that you are starting to have a kidney problem, you can get treatment before the problem gets worse. People with severe kidney damage may need dialysis. They may eventually need a new kidney ( kidney transplant ).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, albumin stays in the body. There is little or no albumin in the urine sample. Normal albumin levels in the urine are less than 30 mg/24 hours.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the test finds a high level of albumin in your urine, your doctor may have you repeat the test.</text><text>Abnormal results may mean your kidneys are starting to get damaged . But the damage may not yet be bad. </text><text>Abnormal results may also be reported as:</text><detail>Range of 20 to 200 mcg/min</detail><detail>Range of 30 to 300 mg/24 hours </detail><text>You will need more tests to confirm a problem and show how severe the kidney damage may be.</text><text>The most common cause of a high level of albumin in the urine is diabetes . Controlling your blood sugar level may lower the albumin level in your urine.</text><text>A high albumin level may also occur with: </text><detail>Some immune and inflammatory disorders affecting the kidney</detail><detail>Some genetic disorders</detail><detail>Rare cancers</detail><detail>High blood pressure</detail><detail>Narrowed artery of the kidney</detail><detail>Fever or exercise</detail><text>Healthy people may have a higher level of protein in the urine after exercise. People who are dehydrated may also have a higher level.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Diabetes - microalbuminuria</detail><detail> Diabetic nephropathy - microalbuminuria</detail><detail> Kidney disease - microalbuminuria</detail><detail> Proteinuria - microalbuminuria</detail>

item.title: MIBG scintiscan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need to sign an informed consent form. You will be asked to wear a hospital gown or loose-fitting clothes. You will need to remove jewelry or metal objects before each scan. Many drugs interfere with the test. Ask your health care provider which of your regular medicines you may need to stop taking before the test. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to help diagnose pheochromocytoma. It is done when an abdominal CT scan does not give a definite answer. It is also used to help diagnose neuroblastoma and can be used for carcinoid tumors.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There are no signs of a tumor.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The test may be done to:</text><detail>Locate pheochromocytoma (most common usage)</detail><detail>Detect multiple tumors</detail><detail>Detect tumors that are located outside the adrenal tissues</detail><detail>Detect multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) II </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Adrenal medullary imaging</detail><detail> Meta-iodobenzylguanidine scintiscan</detail><detail> Pheochromocytoma - MIBG</detail><detail> Neuroblastoma - MIBG</detail><detail> Carcinoid MIBG</detail>

item.title: Methylmalonic acid blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Methylmalonic acid is a substance produced when proteins, called amino acids, in the body break down.</text><text>The health care provider may order this test if there are signs of certain genetic disorders, such as methylmalonic acidemia . Testing for this disorder is often done as part of a newborn screening exam .</text><text>This test may also be done with other tests to check for a vitamin B12 deficiency .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are 0.07 to 0.27 micromoles per liter.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal value may be due to vitamin B12 deficiency or methylmalonic acidemia.</text>

item.title: Methylene blue test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is required for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>There are several types of oxygen-carrying proteins in the blood. One of them is methemoglobin. Normal methemoglobin level in blood are usually 1%. If the level is higher, you can become sick because the protein is not carrying oxygen. This can make your blood look brown instead of red. </text><text>Methemoglobinemia has several causes, many of which are genetic (problem with your genes). This test is used to tell the difference between methemoglobinemia caused by the lack of a protein called cytochrome b5 reductase and other types that are passed down through families (inherited). Your doctor will use the results of this test to help determine your treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, methylene blue quickly lowers the level of methemoglobin in the blood.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>You may have a rare form of methemoglobinemia if this test does not significantly lower the blood level of methemoglobin.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Methemoglobinemia - methylene blue test</detail>

item.title: Methanol test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see if you have a toxic level of methanol in your body. You should not drink methanol. However, some people accidentally drink methanol, or drink it on purpose as a substitute for grain alcohol (ethanol).</text><text>Methanol can be very poisonous if you eat or drink it in toxic amounts. Methanol poisoning mainly affects the digestive system, nervous system, and eyes.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is below a toxic cut-off level.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means you may have methanol poisoning.</text>

item.title: Mesenteric angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test.</text><text>You will be asked to wear a hospital gown and sign a consent form for the procedure. Remove jewelry from the area being imaged.</text><text>Tell your provider:</text><detail>If you are pregnant</detail><detail>If you have ever had any allergic reactions to x-ray contrast material, shellfish, or iodine substances</detail><detail>If you are allergic to any medicines</detail><detail>Which medicines you are taking (including any herbal preparations)</detail><detail>If you have ever had any bleeding problems </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done:</text><detail>When there are symptoms of a narrowed or blocked blood vessel in the intestines</detail><detail>To find the source of bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract</detail><detail>To find the cause of ongoing abdominal pain and weight loss when no cause can be identified</detail><detail>When other studies do not provide enough information about abnormal growths along the intestinal tract</detail><detail>To look at blood vessel damage after an abdominal injury </detail><text>A mesenteric angiogram may be performed after more sensitive nuclear medicine scans have identified active bleeding. The radiologist can then pinpoint and treat the source.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are normal if the examined arteries are normal in appearance.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A common abnormal finding is narrowing and hardening of the arteries that supply the large and small intestine. This is called mesenteric ischemia. The problem occurs when fatty material (plaque) builds up on the walls of your arteries.</text><text>Abnormal results may also be due to bleeding in the small and large intestine . This may be caused by:</text><detail> Angiodysplasia of the colon </detail><detail>Blood vessel rupture from injury </detail><text>Other abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Blood clots </detail><detail> Cirrhosis </detail><detail> Tumors </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Abdominal arteriogram</detail><detail> Arteriogram - abdomen</detail><detail> Mesenteric angiogram</detail>

item.title: Mental status testing
item.NormalResults: <text>Most tests are divided into sections, each with its own score. The results help show which part of someone's thinking and memory may be affected.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A number of health conditions can affect mental status. The provider will discuss these with you. An abnormal mental status test alone does not diagnose the cause. However, poor performance on such tests can be due to medical illness, brain disease such as dementia, Parkinson disease, or to mental illness. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Mental status exam</detail><detail> Neurocognitive testing</detail><detail> Dementia-mental status testing</detail>

item.title: Mediastinoscopy with biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must sign an informed consent form. You will not be able to have food or fluid for 8 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This procedure is done to look at and then biopsy lymph nodes or any other abnormal growths in the front part of the mediastinum, near your chest wall.</text><detail>The most common reason is to see if lung cancer (or another cancer) has spread to these lymph nodes. This is called staging.</detail><detail>This procedure is also done for certain infections (tuberculosis, sarcoidosis) and autoimmune disorders . </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Biopsies of lymph node tissues are normal and do not show signs of cancer or infection.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal findings may indicate:</text><detail> Hodgkin disease </detail><detail> Lung cancer </detail><detail> Lymphoma or other tumors</detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail><detail>The spread of disease from one body part to another</detail><detail> Tuberculosis </detail>

item.title: Mammogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT use deodorant, perfume, powders, or ointments under your arms or on your breasts on the day of the mammogram. These substances may hide the images. Remove all jewelry from your neck and chest area.</text><text>Tell your provider and the x-ray technologist if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, or if you've had a breast biopsy.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>When and how often to have a screening mammogram is a choice you must make. Different expert groups do not fully agree on the best timing for this test.</text><text>Before having a mammogram, talk to your provider about the pros and cons of having the test. Ask about:</text><detail>Your risk for breast cancer </detail><detail>Whether screening decreases your chance of dying from breast cancer</detail><detail>Whether there is any harm from breast cancer screening, such as side effects from testing or overtreatment of cancer when it's discovered </detail><text>Mammography is performed to screen women to detect early breast cancer when it is more likely to be cured. Mammography is generally recommended for:</text><detail>Women starting at age 40, repeated every 1 to 2 years. (This is not recommended by all expert organizations.)</detail><detail>All women starting at age 50, repeated every 1 to 2 years.</detail><detail>Women with a mother or sister who had breast cancer at a younger age should consider yearly mammograms. They should begin earlier than the age at which their youngest family member was diagnosed. </detail><text>Mammography is also used to:</text><detail>Follow a woman who has had an abnormal mammogram.</detail><detail>Evaluate a woman who has symptoms of a breast disease. These symptoms may include a lump, nipple discharge, breast pain , dimpling of the skin on the breast, changes of the nipple, or other findings. </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Breast tissue that shows no signs of a mass or calcifications is considered normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Most abnormal findings on a screening mammogram turn out to be benign (not cancer) or nothing to worry about. New findings or changes must be further evaluated.</text><text>A radiology doctor (radiologist) may see the following types of findings on a mammogram:</text><detail>A well-outlined, regular, clear spot (this is more likely to be a noncancerous condition, such as a cyst)</detail><detail>Masses or lumps</detail><detail>Dense areas in the breast that can be breast cancer or hide breast cancer</detail><detail>Calcifications, which are caused by tiny deposits of calcium in the breast tissue (most calcifications are not a sign of cancer) </detail><text>At times, the following tests are also needed to further examine mammogram findings:</text><detail>Additional mammogram views, called magnification or compression views</detail><detail>Breast ultrasound</detail><detail> Breast MRI exam (less commonly done) </detail><text>Comparing your current mammogram to your past mammograms helps the radiologist tell whether you had an abnormal finding in the past and whether it has changed.</text><text>When mammogram or ultrasound results look suspicious, a biopsy is done to test the tissue and see if it is cancerous. Types of biopsies include:</text><detail> Stereotactic </detail><detail> Ultrasound </detail><detail> Open </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Mammography</detail><detail> Breast cancer - mammography</detail><detail> Breast cancer - screening mammography</detail><detail> Breast lump - mammogram</detail><detail> Breast tomosynthesis</detail>

item.title: Magnetic resonance angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI. In open MRI, the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Artificial heart valve</detail><detail> Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Insulin or chemotherapy port</detail><detail>Intrauterine device (IUD)</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Neurostimulator</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Vascular stent </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes)</detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner. Avoid carrying items such as:</text><detail>Pocketknives, pens, and eyeglasses</detail><detail>Watches, credit cards, jewelry, and hearing aids</detail><detail>Hairpins, metal zippers, pins, and similar items</detail><detail>Removable dental implants</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>MRA is used to look at the blood vessels in all parts of the body. The test may be done for the head, heart, abdomen, lungs, kidneys, and legs.</text><text>It may be used to diagnose or evaluate conditions such as:</text><detail> Arterial aneurysm (an abnormal widening or ballooning of a part of an artery due to weakness in the wall of the blood vessel) </detail><detail> Aortic coarctation </detail><detail> Aortic dissection </detail><detail> Stroke </detail><detail> Carotid artery disease </detail><detail> Atherosclerosis of the arms or legs </detail><detail> Heart disease, including congenital heart disease </detail><detail> Mesenteric artery ischemia </detail><detail> Renal artery stenosis (narrowing of the blood vessels in the kidneys) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the blood vessels do not show any signs of narrowing or blockage.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result suggests a problem with one or more blood vessels. This may suggest:</text><detail> Atherosclerosis </detail><detail>Trauma</detail><detail>Congenital disease</detail><detail>Other vascular condition</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRA</detail><detail> Angiography - magnetic resonance</detail>

item.title: Magnesium blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done when your health care provider suspects you have an abnormal level of magnesium in your blood.</text><text>About half of the body's magnesium is found in bone. The other half is found inside cells of body tissues and organs.</text><text>Magnesium is needed for many chemical processes in the body. It helps maintain normal muscle and nerve function, and keeps the bones strong. Magnesium is also needed for the heart to function normally and to help regulate blood pressure. Magnesium also helps the body control blood sugar level and helps support the body's defense (immune) system.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range for blood magnesium level is 1.7 to 2.2 mg/dL (0.85 to 1.10 mmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high magnesium level may indicate:</text><detail>The adrenal glands are not producing enough hormones ( Addison disease )</detail><detail>Loss of kidney function ( chronic renal failure )</detail><detail>Loss of body fluids ( dehydration )</detail><detail>Diabetic ketoacidosis, a life-threatening problem in people with diabetes</detail><detail>Producing less urine than usual ( oliguria )</detail><text>A low magnesium level may indicate:</text><detail> Alcoholism or severe alcohol withdrawal ( delirium tremens )</detail><detail>Long-term (chronic) diarrhea </detail><detail>Treatment to remove waste from the blood ( hemodialysis )</detail><detail>Scarring of the liver and loss of liver function ( cirrhosis )</detail><detail>Adrenal gland produces too much of the hormone aldosterone ( hyperaldosteronism )</detail><detail>Parathyroid glands do not produce enough parathyroid hormone ( hypoparathyroidism )</detail><detail>Inflammation of the pancreas ( pancreatitis )</detail><detail>Too much insulin</detail><detail>High blood pressure and protein in the urine in a pregnant woman ( preeclampsia )</detail><detail>Inflammation of the lining of the large intestine and rectum ( ulcerative colitis )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Magnesium - blood</detail>

item.title: Nuclear ventriculography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be told not to eat or drink for several hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test will show how well the blood is pumping through different parts of the heart.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results show that the heart squeezing function is normal. The test can check the overall squeezing strength of the heart (ejection fraction). A normal value is above 50% to 55%.</text><text>The test also can check the motion of different parts of the heart. If one part of the heart is moving poorly while the others move well, it may mean that there has been damage to that part of the heart. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Blockages in the coronary arteries ( coronary artery disease ) </detail><detail>Heart valve disease</detail><detail>Other cardiac disorders that weaken the heart (reduced pumping function)</detail><detail>Past heart attack ( myocardial infarction )</detail><text>The test may also be performed for:</text><detail> Dilated cardiomyopathy </detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Idiopathic cardiomyopathy</detail><detail> Peripartum cardiomyopathy </detail><detail>Ischemic cardiomyopathy</detail><detail>Testing whether a medicine has affected heart function </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cardiac blood pooling imaging</detail><detail> Heart scan - nuclear</detail><detail> Radionuclide ventriculography (RNV)</detail><detail> Multiple gate acquisition scan (MUGA)</detail><detail> Nuclear cardiology</detail><detail> Cardiomyopathy - nuclear ventriculography</detail>

item.title: Nuclear stress test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should wear comfortable clothes and shoes with non-skid soles. You may be asked not to eat or drink after midnight. You will be allowed to have a few sips of water if you need to take medicines.</text><text>You will need to avoid caffeine for 24 hours before the test. This includes:</text><detail>Tea and coffee</detail><detail>All sodas, even ones that are labeled caffeine-free</detail><detail>Chocolates, and certain pain relievers that contain caffeine </detail><text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your doctor first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to see if your heart muscle is getting enough blood flow and oxygen when it is working hard (under stress).</text><text>Your provider may order this test to find out:</text><detail>How well a treatment (medicines, angioplasty, or heart surgery) is working.</detail><detail>If you are at high risk for heart disease or complications.</detail><detail>If you are planning to start an exercise program or have surgery.</detail><detail>The cause of new chest pain or worsening angina.</detail><detail>What you can expect after you have had a heart attack . </detail><text>The results of a nuclear stress test can help:</text><detail>Determine how well your heart is pumping</detail><detail>Determine the proper treatment for coronary heart disease </detail><detail>Diagnose coronary artery disease</detail><detail>See whether your heart is too large </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test most often means that you were able to exercise as long as or longer than most people of your age and gender. You also did not have symptoms or changes in blood pressure, your ECG or the images of your heart that caused concern.</text><text>A normal result means blood flow through the coronary arteries is probably normal.</text><text>The meaning of your test results depends on the reason for the test, your age, and your history of heart and other medical problems.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Reduced blood flow to a part of the heart. The most likely cause is a narrowing or blockage of one or more of the arteries that supply your heart muscle.</detail><detail>Scarring of the heart muscle due to a previous heart attack. </detail><text>After the test you may need:</text><detail> Angioplasty and stent placement </detail><detail>Changes in your heart medicines</detail><detail> Coronary angiography </detail><detail> Heart bypass surgery </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Sestamibi stress test</detail><detail> MIBI stress test</detail><detail> Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy</detail><detail> Dobutamine stress test</detail><detail> Persantine stress test</detail><detail> Thallium stress test</detail><detail> Stress test - nuclear</detail><detail> Adenosine stress test</detail><detail> Regadenoson stress test</detail><detail> CAD - nuclear stress</detail><detail> Coronary artery disease - nuclear stress</detail><detail> Angina - nuclear stress</detail><detail> Chest pain - nuclear stress</detail>

item.title: Nuchal translucency test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text> Having a full bladder will give the best ultrasound picture. You may be asked to drink 2 to 3 glasses of liquid an hour before the test. DO NOT urinate before your ultrasound. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may advise this test to screen your baby for Down syndrome. Many pregnant women decide to have this test.</text><text>Nuchal translucency is usually done between the 11th and 14th week of pregnancy. It can be done earlier in pregnancy than amniocentesis . This is another test that checks for birth defects.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal amount of fluid in the back of the neck during ultrasound means it is very unlikely your baby has Down syndrome or another genetic disorder.</text><text>Nuchal translucency measurement increases with gestational age. This is the period between conception and birth. The higher the measurement compared to babies the same gestational age, the higher the risk is for certain genetic disorders. </text><text>The measurements below are considered low risk for genetic disorders:</text><detail>At 11 weeks -- up to 2 mm</detail><detail>At 13 weeks, 6 days -- up to 2.8 mm </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>More fluid than normal in the back of the neck means there is a higher risk for Down syndrome, trisomy 18, trisomy 13, Turner syndrome, or congenital heart disease. But it does not tell for certain that the baby has Down syndrome or another genetic disorder. </text><text>If the result is abnormal, other tests can be done. Most of the time, the other test done is amniocentesis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Nuchal translucency screening</detail><detail> NT</detail><detail> Nuchal fold test</detail><detail> Nuchal fold scan</detail><detail> Prenatal genetic screening</detail><detail> Down syndrome - nuchal translucency</detail>

item.title: Nitroblue tetrazolium blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to screen for chronic granulomatous disease . This disorder is passed down in families. In people who have this disease, certain immune cells do not help protect the body from infections.</text><text>People who have frequent infections in the bones, skin, joints, lungs, and other parts of the body may have this test done.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, the white blood cells turn blue when NBT is added. This means that the cells should be able to kill bacteria and protect the person from infections.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly from one lab to another. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the sample does not change color when NBT is added, the white blood cells are missing the substance needed to kill bacteria. This may be due to chronic granulomatous disease.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>NBT test</detail>

item.title: Newborn screening tests
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no preparation needed for newborn screening tests. The tests are most often done before leaving the hospital when the baby is between 24 hours and 7 days old. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Screening tests do not diagnose illnesses. They show which babies need more testing to confirm or rule out illnesses.</text><text>If follow-up testing confirms that the child has a disease, treatment can be started, before symptoms appear.</text><text>Blood screening tests are used to detect a number of disorders. Some of these may include:</text><detail>Amino acid metabolism disorders</detail><detail>Biotinidase deficiency</detail><detail> Congenital adrenal hyperplasia </detail><detail>Congenital hypothyroidism</detail><detail> Cystic fibrosis </detail><detail>Fatty acid metabolism disorders</detail><detail>Galactosemia</detail><detail> Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD) </detail><detail>Human immunodeficiency disease (HIV)</detail><detail>Organic acid metabolism disorders</detail><detail>Phenylketonuria (PKU)</detail><detail>Sickle cell disease and other hemoglobin disorders and traits</detail><detail>Toxoplasmosis </detail>
item.NormalResults: Normal values for each screening test may vary depending on how the test is performed.Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that the child should have additional testing to confirm or rule out the condition.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Infant screening tests</detail><detail> Neonatal screening tests</detail><detail> The PKU test</detail>

item.title: Nerve conduction velocity
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must stay at a normal body temperature. Being too cold slows nerve conduction.</text><text>Tell your doctor if you have a cardiac defibrillator or pacemaker. Special steps will need to be taken before the test if you have one of these devices.</text><text>Do not wear any lotions, sunscreen, perfume, or moisturizer on your body on the day of the test. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to diagnose nerve damage or destruction. The test may sometimes be used to evaluate diseases of nerve or muscle, including: </text><detail>Myopathy</detail><detail>Lambert-Eaton syndrome</detail><detail>Myasthenia gravis</detail><detail>Carpal tunnel syndrome</detail><detail>Tarsal tunnel syndrome</detail><detail>Diabetic neuropathy</detail><detail>Bell palsy</detail><detail>Guillain-Barré syndrome</detail><detail>Brachial plexopathy</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>NCV is related to the diameter of the nerve and the degree of myelination (the presence of a myelin sheath on the axon) of the nerve. Newborn infants have values that are approximately half that of adults. Adult values are normally reached by age 3 or 4.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Most often, abnormal results are due to nerve damage or destruction, including:</text><detail>Axonopathy (damage to the long portion of the nerve cell)</detail><detail>Conduction block (the impulse is blocked somewhere along the nerve pathway)</detail><detail>Demyelination (damage and loss of the fatty insulation surrounding the nerve cell) </detail><text>The nerve damage or destruction may be due to many different conditions, including:</text><detail>Alcoholic neuropathy</detail><detail>Diabetic neuropathy</detail><detail>Nerve effects of uremia (from kidney failure)</detail><detail>Traumatic injury to a nerve</detail><detail>Guillain-Barré syndrome</detail><detail>Diphtheria</detail><detail>Carpal tunnel syndrome</detail><detail>Brachial plexopathy</detail><detail>Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (hereditary)</detail><detail>Chronic inflammatory polyneuropathy</detail><detail>Common peroneal nerve dysfunction</detail><detail>Distal median nerve dysfunction</detail><detail>Femoral nerve dysfunction</detail><detail>Friedreich ataxia</detail><detail>General paresis</detail><detail>Mononeuritis multiplex</detail><detail>Primary amyloidosis</detail><detail>Radial nerve dysfunction</detail><detail>Sciatic nerve dysfunction</detail><detail>Secondary systemic amyloidosis</detail><detail>Sensorimotor polyneuropathy</detail><detail>Tibial nerve dysfunction</detail><detail>Ulnar nerve dysfunction </detail><text>Any peripheral neuropathy can cause abnormal results. Damage to the spinal cord and disk herniation (herniated nucleus pulposus) with nerve root compression can also cause abnormal results.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>NCV</detail>

item.title: Nerve biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Nerve biopsy may be done to help diagnose:</text><detail>Axon degeneration (destruction of the axon portion of the nerve cell)</detail><detail>Damage to the small nerves</detail><detail> Demyelination (destruction of parts of the myelin sheath covering the nerve) </detail><detail>Inflammatory nerve conditions (neuropathies)</detail><text>Conditions for which the test may be done include any of the following:</text><detail> Alcoholic neuropathy (damage to nerves from excessive drinking of alcohol)</detail><detail> Axillary nerve dysfunction (damage to the shoulder nerve that leads to a loss of movement or sensation in the shoulder)</detail><detail> Brachial plexopathy (damage to the brachial plexus, an area on each side of the neck where nerve roots from the spinal cord split into each arm's nerves)</detail><detail> Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (inherited group of disorders that affect the nerves outside the brain and spine)</detail><detail> Common peroneal nerve dysfunction (damage to the peroneal nerve leading to loss of movement or sensation in the foot and leg)</detail><detail> Distal median nerve dysfunction (damage to the median nerve leading to loss of movement or sensation in the hands)</detail><detail> Mononeuritis multiplex (disorder that involves damage to at least two separate nerve areas)</detail><detail> Necrotizing vasculitis (group of disorders that involve inflammation of the blood vessel walls)</detail><detail> Neurosarcoidosis (complication of sarcoidosis, in which inflammation occurs in the brain, spinal cord, and other areas of the nervous system)</detail><detail> Radial nerve dysfunction (damage to the radial nerve leading to loss of movement or sensation in the arm, wrist or hand)</detail><detail> Tibial nerve dysfunction (damage to the tibial nerve leading to loss of movement or sensation in the foot)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the nerve appears normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Amyloidosis (sural nerve biopsy is most often used)</detail><detail>Demyelination</detail><detail> Inflammation of the nerve </detail><detail> Leprosy </detail><detail>Loss of axon tissue</detail><detail> Metabolic neuropathies (nerve disorders that occur with diseases that disrupt the chemical processes in the body)</detail><detail> Necrotizing vasculitis </detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - nerve</detail>

item.title: Neonatal cystic fibrosis screening test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Cystic fibrosis is a disease passed down through families. CF causes thick, sticky mucus to build up in the lungs and digestive tract. It can lead to breathing and digestive problems.</text><text>Children with CF who are diagnosed early in life and start treatment at a young age may have better nutrition, growth, and lung function. This screening test helps doctors identify children with CF before they have symptoms.</text><text>Some states include this test in the routine newborn screening tests that are done before the baby leaves the hospital.</text><text>If you live in a state that does not perform routine CF screening, your health care provider will explain whether testing is needed.</text><text>Other tests that look for genetic changes known to cause CF may also be used to screen for CF.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>If the test result is negative, the child likely does not have CF. If the test result is negative but the baby has symptoms of CF, further testing will likely be done.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) result suggests that your child may have CF. But it is important to remember that a positive screening test does not diagnose CF. If your child's test is positive, more tests will be done to confirm the possibility of CF.</text><detail> Sweat chloride test is the standard diagnostic test for CF. A high salt level in the person's sweat is a sign of the disease.</detail><detail>Genetic testing may also be done.</detail><text>Not all children with a positive result have CF.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cystic fibrosis screening - neonatal</detail><detail> Immunoreactive trypsinogen</detail><detail> IRT test</detail><detail> CF - screening</detail>

item.title: Neck x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider if you are or think you may be pregnant. Also tell your provider if you have had surgery or have implants around your neck, jaw, or mouth.</text><text>Remove all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The x-ray is used to evaluate neck injuries and numbness, pain, or weakness that does not go away. A neck x-ray can also be used to help see if air passages are blocked by swelling in the neck or something stuck in the airway.</text><text>Other tests, such as MRI , may be used to look for disk or nerve problems.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A neck x-ray can detect:</text><detail>Bone joint that is out of position (dislocation)</detail><detail> Breathing in a foreign object </detail><detail>Broken bone (fracture)</detail><detail>Disk problems (disks are the cushion-like tissue that separate the vertebrae)</detail><detail>Extra bone growths (bone spurs) on the neck bones (for example, due to osteoarthritis)</detail><detail>Infection that causes swelling of the vocal cords (croup)</detail><detail>Inflammation of the tissue that covers the windpipe (epiglottitis)</detail><detail>Problem with the curve of the upper spine, such as kyphosis </detail><detail>Thinning of the bone ( osteoporosis )</detail><detail>Wearing away of the neck vertebrae or cartilage </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - neck</detail><detail> Cervical spine x-ray</detail><detail> Lateral neck x-ray</detail>

item.title: Nasopharyngeal culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test identifies viruses and bacteria that cause upper respiratory tract symptoms. These include:</text><detail>Bordetella pertussis, the bacteria that cause whooping cough </detail><detail>Neisseria meningitidis, the bacteria that cause meningococcal meningitis </detail><detail>Staphylococcus aureus, the bacteria that cause staph infections </detail><detail>Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus</detail><detail>Viral infections such as influenza or respiratory syncytial virus</detail><text>The culture may be used to help determine which antibiotic is appropriate to treat an infection due to bacteria.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The presence of organisms commonly found in the nasopharynx is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The presence of any disease-causing virus, bacteria, or fungus means these organisms may be causing your infection. </text><text>Sometimes, organisms like Staphylococcus aureus can be present without causing disease. This test can help identify resistant strains of this organism (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA ) so that people can be isolated when necessary.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - nasopharyngeal</detail><detail> Swab for respiratory viruses</detail><detail> Swab for staph carriage</detail>

item.title: Nasal mucosal biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed. You may be asked to fast for a few hours before the biopsy.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Nasal mucosal biopsy is most often done when abnormal tissue is seen during examination of the nose. It may also be done when the health care provider suspects you have a problem affecting the mucosal tissue of the nose.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The tissue in the nose is normal.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Infections, such as tuberculosis</detail><detail> Necrotizing granuloma , a type of tumor</detail><detail> Nasal polyps </detail><detail> Nasal tumors </detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail><detail> Granulomatosis with polyangiitis </detail><detail>Primary ciliary dyskinesia</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - nasal mucosa</detail><detail> Nose biopsy</detail>

item.title: Nasal endoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You DO NOT need to do anything to prepare for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have a nasal endoscopy to figure out what is causing problems in your nose and sinuses.</text><text>During the procedure, your provider may:</text><detail>Look at the inside of your nose and sinuses</detail><detail>Take a sample of tissue for a biopsy</detail><detail>Do small surgeries to remove polyps, excess mucus, or other masses</detail><text>Your provider may recommend nasal endoscopy if you are having:</text><detail>A lot of sinus infections</detail><detail>Lots of drainage from your nose</detail><detail>Face pain or pressure</detail><detail>Sinus headaches</detail><detail>A hard time breathing through your nose</detail><detail>Nose bleeds</detail><detail>Loss of sense of smell</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The inside of the nose and bones look normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Nasal endoscopy helps with the diagnosis of:</text><detail>Polyps</detail><detail>Blockages</detail><detail>Sinusitis</detail><detail>Swollen and runny nose that will not go away</detail><detail>Nasal masses or tumors</detail><detail>A foreign object (like a marble) in the nose or sinus</detail><detail>Deviated septum (many insurance plans require a nasal endoscopy prior to surgery to correct it)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Rhinoscopy</detail>

item.title: Ovulation home test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT drink large amounts of fluids before using the test.</text><text>Drugs that can decrease LH levels include estrogens, progesterone, and testosterone. Estrogens and progesterone may be found in birth control pills and hormone replacement therapy.</text><text>The drug clomiphene citrate (Clomid) can increase LH levels. This drug is used to help trigger ovulation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to determine when a woman will ovulate to assist in difficulty in getting pregnant. For women with a 28-day menstrual cycle, this release normally occurs between days 11 and 14.</text><text>If you have an irregular menstrual cycle, the kit can help you tell when you are ovulating.</text><text>The ovulation home test may also be used to help you adjust doses of certain medicines such as infertility drugs.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A positive result indicates an "LH surge." This is a sign that ovulation may soon occur. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Luteinizing hormone urine test (home test)</detail><detail> Ovulation prediction test</detail><detail> Ovulation predictor kit</detail><detail> Urinary LH immunoassays</detail><detail> At-home ovulation prediction test</detail><detail> LH urine test</detail>

item.title: Osmotic fragility test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to detect conditions called hereditary spherocytosis and thalassemia . Hereditary spherocytosis and thalassemia cause red blood cells more fragile than normal.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result is called a negative result.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may indicate one of these conditions:</text><detail>Thalassemia</detail><detail>Hereditary spherocytosis</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Spherocytosis - osmotic fragility</detail><detail> Thalassemia - osmotic fragility</detail>

item.title: Osmolality blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow any instructions from your health care provider about not eating before the test. Your provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that may interfere with test results. Such medicines may include water pills (diuretics).</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test helps check your body's water balance. Your doctor may order this test if you have signs of any of the following:</text><detail>Low sodium ( hyponatremia ) or water loss</detail><detail>Poisoning from harmful substances such as ethanol , methanol , or ethylene glycol </detail><detail>Problems producing urine </detail><text>In healthy people, when osmolality in the blood becomes high, the body releases antidiuretic hormone (ADH).</text><text>This hormone causes the kidneys to reabsorb water. This results in more concentrated urine. The reabsorbed water dilutes the blood. This allows blood osmolality to fall back to normal.</text><text>Low blood osmolality suppresses ADH. This reduces how much water the kidneys reabsorb. Dilute urine is passed to get rid of the excess water, which increases blood osmolality back toward normal.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 275 to 295 mOsm/kg (275 to 295 mmol/kg).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level may be due to:</text><detail> Diabetes insipidus </detail><detail>High blood sugar level ( hyperglycemia )</detail><detail>High level of nitrogen waste products in the blood ( uremia )</detail><detail>High sodium level (hypernatremia)</detail><detail> Stroke or head trauma resulting in decreased ADH secretion</detail><detail>Water loss ( dehydration ) </detail><text>Lower than normal levels may be due to:</text><detail>ADH oversecretion</detail><detail>Adrenal gland not working normally</detail><detail>Conditions linked to lung cancer </detail><detail>Drinking too much water or fluid</detail><detail>Low sodium level (hyponatremia)</detail><detail>Underactive thyroid gland ( hypothyroidism )</detail>

item.title: Oropharynx lesion biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If a simple painkiller or local numbing medicine is to be used, there is no special preparation. If the test is part of a growth removal or if general anesthesia is used, you will likely be asked not to eat for 6 to 8 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to determine the cause of a sore (lesion) in the throat.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>This test is only done when there is an abnormal tissue area.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean:
Abnormal results may mean: Cancer (such as squamous cell carcinoma )Benign lesions (such as papilloma)
Fungal infections (such as candida) Histoplasmosis Oral lichen planus Precancerous sore (leukoplakia)Viral infections (such as Herpes simplex)
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Throat lesion biopsy</detail><detail> Biopsy - mouth or throat</detail><detail> Mouth lesion biopsy</detail><detail> Oral cancer - biopsy</detail>

item.title: Orbit CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before the test:</text><detail>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</detail><detail>If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. </detail><text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage) because you may need to take extra precautions.</detail><detail>Before the scan, let your provider know if you have poor kidney function. This is because the contrast may not be able to be used. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is helpful for diagnosing diseases that affect the following areas:</text><detail>Blood vessels</detail><detail>Eye muscles</detail><detail>Eyes</detail><detail>Nerves supplying the eyes (optic nerves)</detail><detail>Sinuses </detail><text>An orbit CT scan may also be used to detect:</text><detail>Abscess (infection) of the eye area</detail><detail>Broken eye socket bone</detail><detail>Foreign object in the eye socket </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean:</text><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Broken eye socket bone</detail><detail> Graves disease </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail> Tumor </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CT scan - orbital</detail><detail> Eye CT scan</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - orbit</detail>

item.title: Ophthalmoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Indirect ophthalmoscopy and slit-lamp ophthalmoscopy are often performed after eyedrops are placed to widen (dilate) the pupils. Direct ophthalmoscopy and slit-lamp ophthalmoscopy can be performed with or without the pupil dilated.</text><text>You should tell your provider if you:</text><detail>Are allergic to any medicines</detail><detail>Are taking any medicines</detail><detail>Have glaucoma or a family history of glaucoma </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Ophthalmoscopy is done as part of a routine physical or complete eye examination.</text><text>It is used to detect and evaluate symptoms of retinal detachment or eye diseases such as glaucoma.</text><text>Ophthalmoscopy may also be done if you have signs or symptoms of high blood pressure, diabetes, or other diseases that affect the blood vessels.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The retina, blood vessels, and the optic disc appear normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be seen on ophthalmoscopy with any of the following conditions:</text><detail>Viral inflammation of the retina ( CMV retinitis )</detail><detail>Diabetes</detail><detail>Glaucoma</detail><detail>High blood pressure</detail><detail>Loss of sharp vision due to macular degeneration </detail><detail> Melanoma of the eye </detail><detail>Optic nerve problems</detail><detail>Separation of the light-sensitive membrane (retina) in the back of the eye from its supporting layers (retinal tear or detachment )</detail><text>Ophthalmoscopy is considered to be 90% to 95% accurate. It can detect the early stages and effects of many serious diseases. For conditions that cannot be detected by ophthalmoscopy, there are other techniques and devices that may be helpful.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Funduscopy</detail>

value.img_name: Side view of the eye (cut section)

item.title: Open pleural biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should tell the health care provider if you are pregnant, allergic to any medicines, or if you have a bleeding problem. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take, including herbs, supplements, and those bought without a prescription. </text><text>Follow your surgeon's instructions for not eating or drinking before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This procedure is used when the surgeon needs a larger piece of tissue than can be removed with a pleural needle biopsy . The test is most often done to rule out mesothelioma , a type of lung tumor.</text><text>It is also done when there is fluid in the chest cavity, or when a direct view of the pleura and the lungs is needed.</text><text>This procedure may also be done to examine a metastatic pleural tumor .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The pleura will be normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal findings may be due to:</text><detail>Abnormal tissue growth ( neoplasms )</detail><detail>Disease due to a virus, fungus, or parasite</detail><detail>Mesothelioma</detail><detail> Tuberculosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - open pleura</detail>

item.title: Open lung biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should tell the health care provider if you are pregnant, allergic to any medicines, or if you have a bleeding problem. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take, including herbs, supplements, and those bought without a prescription. </text><text>Follow your surgeon's instructions for not eating or drinking before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The open lung biopsy is done to evaluate lung problems seen on x-ray or CT scan .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The lungs and lung tissue will be normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Benign (not cancerous) tumors</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Certain infections (bacterial, viral, or fungal)</detail><detail>Lung diseases (fibrosis) </detail><text>The procedure may help diagnose a number of different conditions, such as:</text><detail> Rheumatoid lung disease </detail><detail> Sarcoidosis (inflammation that affects the lungs and other body tissues)</detail><detail> Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (inflammation of the blood vessels)</detail><detail> Pulmonary hypertension (high blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - open lung</detail>

item.title: Pyruvate kinase blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text><text>If your child is having this test, it may help to explain how the test will feel and even demonstrate on a doll. Explain the reason for the test. Knowing the "how and why" may reduce your child's anxiety.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to detect an abnormally low level of pyruvate kinase. Without enough of this enzyme, red blood cells break down faster than normal. This is called hemolytic anemia . </text><text>This test helps diagnose pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results vary depending on the testing method used. In general, a normal value is 179 ± 16 units per 100 mL of red blood cells.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A low level of pyruvate kinase confirms PKD.</text>

item.title: Pulmonary angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test.</text><text>You will be asked to wear a hospital gown and sign a consent form for the procedure. Remove jewelry from the area being imaged.</text><text>Tell your health care provider:</text><detail>If you are pregnant</detail><detail>If you have ever had any allergic reactions to x-ray contrast material, shellfish, or iodine substances</detail><detail>If you are allergic to any medicines</detail><detail>Which medicines you are taking (including any herbal preparations)</detail><detail>If you have ever had any bleeding problems </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is used to detect blood clots ( pulmonary embolism ) and other blockages in the blood flow in the lung. Most of the time, your provider will have tried other tests to diagnose a blood clot in the lungs.</text><text>Pulmonary angiography may also be used to help diagnose:</text><detail> AV malformations of the lung </detail><detail>Congenital (present from birth) narrowing of the pulmonary vessels</detail><detail>Pulmonary artery aneurysms</detail><detail> Pulmonary hypertension , high blood pressure in the arteries of the lungs</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The x-ray will show normal structures for the age of the person.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Aneurysms of pulmonary vessels</detail><detail>Blood clot in the lungs (pulmonary embolism)</detail><detail>Narrowed blood vessel</detail><detail> Primary pulmonary hypertension </detail><detail>Tumor in the lung </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pulmonary arteriography</detail><detail> Pulmonary angiogram</detail><detail> Angiogram of the lungs</detail>

item.title: Prothrombin time (PT)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines can change blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test. This may include aspirin, heparin, antihistamines, and vitamin C.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail><text>Also tell your provider if you're taking any herbal remedies.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The most common reason to perform this test is to monitor your levels when you are taking a blood-thinning medicine called warfarin. You are likely taking this medicine to prevent blood clots.</text><text>Your provider will check your PT regularly.</text><text>You may also need this test to:</text><detail>Find the cause of abnormal bleeding or bruising</detail><detail>Check how well your liver is working</detail><detail>Look for signs of a blood clotting or bleeding disorder </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>PT is measured in seconds. Most of the time, results are given as what is called INR (international normalized ratio).</text><text>If you are not taking blood thinning medicines, such as warfarin, the normal range for your PT results is: </text><detail>11 to 13.5 seconds</detail><detail>INR of 0.8 to 1.1 </detail><text>If you are taking warfarin to prevent blood clots, your provider will most likely choose to keep your INR between 2.0 and 3.0. </text><text>Ask your provider what result is right for you.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: If you are not taking blood thinning medicines, such as warfarin, an INR result above 1.1 means your blood is clotting more slowly than normal. This may be due to:Bleeding disorders, a group of conditions in which there is a problem with the body's blood clotting process.Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation ).Liver disease.Low level of vitamin K . If you are taking warfarin to prevent clots, your provider will most likely choose to keep your INR between 2.0 and 3.0: Depending on why you are taking the blood thinner, the desired level may be different.Even when your INR stays between 2.0 and 3.0, you are more likely to have bleeding problems.INR results higher than 3.0 may put you at even higher risk for bleeding.INR results lower than 2.0 may put you at risk for developing a blood clot. A PT result that is too high or too low in someone who is taking warfarin (Coumadin) may be due to:The wrong dose of medicineDrinking alcoholTaking certain over-the-counter (OTC) medicines, vitamins, supplements, cold medicines, antibiotics, or other medicinesEating food that changes the way the blood-thinning medicine works in your body Your provider will teach you about taking warfarin (Coumadin) the proper way.
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>PT</detail><detail> Pro-time</detail><detail> Anticoagulant-prothrombin time</detail><detail> Clotting time: protime</detail><detail> INR</detail><detail> International normalized ratio</detail>

item.title: Protein urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Different medicines can change the result of this test. Before the test, tell your provider which medicines you are taking. DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>The following may also interfere with test results:</text><detail> Dehydration </detail><detail>Dye (contrast media) if you have a radiology scan within 3 days before the urine test</detail><detail>Strenuous exercise</detail><detail>Urinary tract infection</detail><detail>Urine contaminated with fluids from the vagina</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done when your provider suspects you have kidney disease. It may be used as a screening test.</text><text>Although small amounts of protein are normally in urine, a routine dipstick test may not detect them. A urine microalbumin test can be performed to detect small amounts of albumin in the urine that may not be detected on dipstick testing. If the kidney is diseased, proteins may be detected on a dipstick test, even if blood protein levels are normal.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>For a random urine sample, normal values are 0 to 20 mg/dL.</text><text>For a 24-hour urine collection, the normal value is less than 80 mg per 24 hours.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Larger amounts of protein in the urine may be due to:</text><detail>Heart failure</detail><detail>Kidney problems, such as kidney damage , diabetic kidney disease , and kidney cysts </detail><detail>Loss of body fluids (dehydration)</detail><detail>Problems during pregnancy, such as seizures due to eclampsia or high blood pressure caused by preeclampsia </detail><detail>Urinary tract problems, such as a bladder tumor or infection</detail><detail>Multiple myeloma</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine protein</detail><detail> Albumin - urine</detail><detail> Urine albumin</detail><detail> Proteinuria</detail><detail> Albuminuria</detail>

item.title: Protein S blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines can change blood test results:</text><detail>Tell your health care provider about all the medicines you take.</detail><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test. This may include drugs that prevent blood clots (blood thinners).</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have an unexplained blood clot, or a family history of blood clots. Protein S helps control blood clotting. A lack of this protein or problem with the function of this protein may cause blood clots to form in veins.</text><text>The test is also used to screen relatives of persons who are known to have protein S deficiency .</text><text>Sometimes, this test is done to find the cause of repeated miscarriages . </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are 60% to 150% inhibition.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A lack (deficiency) of protein S can lead to excess clotting. These clots tend to form in veins, not arteries.</text><text>A protein S deficiency may be inherited. It can also develop due to pregnancy or certain diseases, including:</text><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail> HIV/AIDS infection </detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Long-term antibiotic use</detail><detail>Warfarin (Coumadin) use</detail><text>Protein S level rises with age, but this does not cause any health problems.</text>

item.title: Protein electrophoresis - serum
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink for 12 hours before this test.</text><text>Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Proteins are made from amino acids and are important parts of all cells and tissues. There are many different kinds of proteins in the body, and they have many different functions. Examples of proteins include enzymes, certain hormones, hemoglobin , low-density lipoprotein (LDL, or bad cholesterol), and others.</text><text>Serum proteins are classified as albumin or globulins. Albumin is the most abundant protein in the serum. It carries many small molecules. It is also important for keeping fluid from leaking out from the blood vessels into the tissues.</text><text>Globulins are divided into alpha-1, alpha-2, beta, and gamma globulins. In general, alpha and gamma globulin protein levels increase when there is inflammation in the body.</text><text>Lipoprotein electrophoresis determines the amount of proteins made up of protein and fat, called lipoproteins (such as LDL cholesterol).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges are:</text><detail>Total protein: 6.4 to 8.3 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 64 to 83 grams per liter (g/L)</detail><detail>Albumin: 3.5 to 5.0 g/dL or 35 to 50 g/L</detail><detail>Alpha-1 globulin: 0.1 to 0.3 g/dL or 1 to 3 g/L</detail><detail>Alpha-2 globulin: 0.6 to 1.0 g/dL or 6 to 10 g/L</detail><detail>Beta globulin: 0.7 to 1.2 g/dL or 7 to 12 g/L</detail><detail>Gamma globulin: 0.7 to 1.6 g/dL or 7 to 16 g/L</detail><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased total protein may indicate:</text><detail>Abnormal loss of protein from the digestive tract or the inability of the digestive tract to absorb proteins ( protein-losing enteropathy )</detail><detail> Malnutrition </detail><detail>Kidney disorder called nephrotic syndrome </detail><detail>Scarring of the liver and poor liver function ( cirrhosis ) </detail><text>Increased alpha-1 globulin proteins may be due to:</text><detail>Acute inflammatory disease</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Chronic inflammatory disease (for example, rheumatoid arthritis , SLE ) </detail><text>Decreased alpha-1 globulin proteins may be a sign of:</text><detail> Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency </detail><text>Increased alpha-2 globulin proteins may indicate a:</text><detail>Acute inflammation</detail><detail>Chronic inflammation </detail><text>Decreased alpha-2 globulin proteins may indicate:</text><detail>Breakdown of red blood cells ( hemolysis ) </detail><text>Increased beta globulin proteins may indicate:</text><detail>A disorder in which the body has problems breaking down fats (for example, hyperlipoproteinemia, familial hypercholesterolemia )</detail><detail>Estrogen therapy </detail><text>Decreased beta globulin proteins may indicate:</text><detail>Abnormally low level of LDL cholesterol </detail><detail>Malnutrition </detail><text>Increased gamma globulin proteins may indicate:</text><detail>Blood cancers, including multiple myeloma, Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia , lymphomas, and chronic lymphocytic leukemias </detail><detail>Chronic inflammatory disease (for example, rheumatoid arthritis )</detail><detail>Acute infection</detail><detail>Chronic liver disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>SPEP</detail>

item.title: Protein C blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines can change blood test results.</text><detail>Tell your health care provider about all the medicines you take.</detail><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test. This may include drugs that prevent blood clots (blood thinners).</detail><detail>Do not stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have an unexplained blood clot, or a family history of blood clots. Protein C helps control blood clotting. A lack of this protein or problem with the function of this protein may cause blood clots to form in veins.</text><text>The test is also used to screen relatives of persons who are known to have protein C deficiency . It may also be done to find the reason for repeated miscarriages.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are 60% to 150% inhibition.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A lack (deficiency) of protein C can lead to excess clotting. These clots tend to form in veins, not arteries.</text><text>Protein C deficiency can be passed down through families (inherited). It can also develop with other conditions, such as:</text><detail>Chemotherapy use</detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Long-term antibiotic use</detail><detail>Warfarin (Coumadin) use</detail><text>A problem such as a sudden blood clot in the lung may reduce the protein C level.</text><text>Protein C level rises with age, but this does not cause any health problems.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Autoprothrombin IIA</detail>

item.title: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Make sure your health care provider knows all the medicines you are taking. Some drugs cause your PSA level to be falsely low. </text><text>In most cases, no other special steps are needed to prepare for this test.
