You should abstain from ejaculation for 3 days prior to the blood test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Reasons for a PSA test:</text><detail>This test may be done to screen for prostate cancer.</detail><detail>It is also used to follow people after prostate cancer treatment to see if the cancer has come back.</detail><detail>If a provider feels the prostate gland is not normal during physical exam. </detail><text>MORE ABOUT SCREENING FOR PROSTATE CANCER</text><text>Measuring the PSA level can increase the chance of finding prostate cancer when it is very early. But there is debate over the value of the PSA test for detecting prostate cancer. No single answer fits all men.</text><text>For some men 55 through 69 years old, screening may help reduce the chance of death from prostate cancer. However, for many men, screening and treatment can be harmful instead of beneficial.</text><text>Before having the test, talk to your provider about the pros and cons of having a PSA test. Ask about:</text><detail>Whether screening decreases your chance of dying from prostate cancer</detail><detail>Whether there is any harm from prostate cancer screening, such as side-effects from testing or overtreatment of cancer when discovered</detail><text>Men younger than age 55 have a higher chance of developing prostate cancer and should talk with their provider about PSA screening if they:</text><detail>Have a family history of prostate cancer (especially a brother or father)</detail><detail>Are African American</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The PSA test result cannot diagnose prostate cancer. Only a prostate biopsy can diagnose this cancer.</text><text>Your provider will look at your PSA result and consider your age, ethnicity, medicines you are taking, and other things to decide whether your PSA is normal and whether you need more tests.</text><text>A normal PSA level is considered to be 4.0 nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL) of blood.</text><detail>For men in their 50s or younger, a PSA level should be below 2.5 in most cases.</detail><detail>Older men often have slightly higher PSA levels than younger men. </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high PSA level has been linked to an increased chance of having prostate cancer.</text><text>PSA testing is an important tool for detecting prostate cancer, but it is not foolproof. Other conditions can cause a rise in PSA, including:</text><detail>A larger prostate</detail><detail>Prostate infection (prostatitis)</detail><detail>Urinary tract infection</detail><detail>Recent tests on your bladder (cystoscopy) or prostate (biopsy)</detail><detail>Catheter tube recently placed into your bladder to drain urine</detail><detail>Recent intercourse or ejaculation </detail><text>Your provider will consider the following things when deciding on the next step:</text><detail>Your age</detail><detail>If you had a PSA test in the past and how much and how fast your PSA level has changed</detail><detail>If a prostate lump was found during your exam</detail><detail>Other symptoms you may have</detail><detail>Other risk factors for prostate cancer, such as ethnicity and family history </detail><text>Men at high risk may need to have more tests. These may include:</text><detail>Repeating your PSA test, most often sometime within 3 months. You may receive treatment for a prostate infection first.</detail><detail>A prostate biopsy will be done if the first PSA level is high, or if the level keeps rising when the PSA is measured again.</detail><detail>A follow-up test called a free PSA (fPSA). The lower the level of this test, the more likely it is that prostate cancer is present. </detail><text>Other tests may also be done. The exact role of these tests in deciding on treatment is unclear.</text><detail>A urine test called PCA-3.</detail><detail>A blood test called the Prostate Health Index (PHI).</detail><detail>An MRI of the prostate may help identify cancer in an area of the prostate that is hard to reach during a biopsy. </detail><text>If you have been treated for prostate cancer, the PSA level can show if treatment is working or if the cancer has come back. Often, PSA level rises before there are any symptoms. This may happen months or years beforehand.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Prostate-specific antigen</detail><detail> Prostate cancer screening test</detail><detail> PSA</detail>

item.title: Prostate biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will inform you about the risks and benefits of the biopsy. You may have to sign a consent form.</text><text>Several days before the biopsy, your provider may tell you to stop taking any:</text><detail>Anticoagulants (blood thinning drugs) such as warfarin, (Coumadin), clopidogrel (Plavix), apixaban (Eliquis), dabigatran (Pradaxa), edoxaban (Savaysa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), or aspirin</detail><detail>NSAIDs, such as aspirin and ibuprofen</detail><detail>Herbal supplements</detail><detail>Vitamins</detail><text>Continue to take any prescription medicines unless your provider tells you not to take them.</text><text>Your provider may ask you to:</text><detail>Eat only light meals the day before the biopsy.</detail><detail>Do an enema at home before the procedure to cleanse your rectum.</detail><detail>Take antibiotics the day before or on the day of your biopsy.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A biopsy is done to check for prostate cancer or to find the cause of an enlarged prostate.</text><text>Your provider may recommend a prostate biopsy if:</text><detail>A blood test shows that you have a higher than normal prostate specific antigen (PSA) level</detail><detail>Your provider discovers a lump or abnormality in your prostate during a digital rectal exam</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results from the biopsy suggest that no cancer cells have been found.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive biopsy result means that cancer cells have been found. The lab will give the cells a grade called a Gleason score . This helps predict how fast the cancer will grow. Your doctor will talk to you about your treatment options.</text><text>The biopsy may also show cells that look abnormal, but may or may not be cancer. Your provider will talk with you about what steps to take. You may need another biopsy.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Prostate gland biopsy</detail><detail> Transrectal prostate biopsy</detail><detail> Fine needle biopsy of the prostate</detail><detail> Core biopsy of the prostate</detail><detail> Targeted prostate biopsy</detail><detail> Prostate biopsy - transrectal ultrasound (TRUS)</detail><detail> Stereotactic transperineal prostate biopsy (STPB)</detail>

item.title: Prolactin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Prolactin is a hormone released by the pituitary gland The pituitary is a small gland at the base of the brain. It regulates the body's balance of many hormones.</text><text>Prolactin stimulates breast development and milk production in women. There is no known normal function for prolactin in men.</text><text>Prolactin is usually measured when checking for pituitary tumors and the cause of:</text><detail>Breast milk production that is not related to childbirth (galactorrhea)</detail><detail>Decreased sex drive (libido) in men and women</detail><detail> Erection problems in men </detail><detail>Not able to get pregnant ( infertility )</detail><detail>Irregular or no menstrual periods ( amenorrhea ) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal values for prolactin are:</text><detail>Males: less than 20 ng/dL (425 mIU/L )</detail><detail>Nonpregnant females: 5 to 40 ng/dL (106 to 850 mIU/L)</detail><detail>Pregnant women: 80 to 400 ng/dL (1,700 to 8,500 mIU/L)</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>People with the following conditions may have high prolactin levels:</text><detail>Chest wall injury or irritation</detail><detail>Disease of an area of the brain called the hypothalamus </detail><detail>Thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone ( hypothyroidism )</detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail>Pituitary tumor that makes prolactin (prolactinoma)</detail><detail>Other pituitary tumors and diseases in the area of the pituitary </detail><text>Certain medicines can also raise prolactin levels, including:</text><detail>Antidepressants</detail><detail>Butyrophenones</detail><detail>Estrogens</detail><detail>H2 blockers</detail><detail>Methyldopa</detail><detail>Metoclopramide</detail><detail>Phenothiazines</detail><detail>Reserpine</detail><detail>Risperidone</detail><detail>Verapamil </detail><text>If your prolactin level is high, the test may be repeated in the early morning after an 8-hour fast.</text><text>The following can temporarily increase prolactin levels:</text><detail>Emotional or physical stress (occasionally)</detail><detail>High-protein meals</detail><detail>Intense breast stimulation</detail><detail>Recent breast exam</detail><detail>Recent exercise </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>PRL</detail><detail> Galactorrhea - prolactin test</detail><detail> Infertility - prolactin test</detail><detail> Amenorrhea - prolactin test</detail><detail> Breast leakage - prolactin test</detail><detail> Prolactinoma - prolactin test</detail><detail> Pituitary tumor - prolactin test </detail>

item.title: Pregnancy test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to:</text><detail>Determine if you are pregnant</detail><detail>Diagnose abnormal conditions that can raise HCG levels</detail><detail>Watch the development of the pregnancy during the first 2 months (quantitative test only) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>HCG level rises rapidly during the first trimester of pregnancy and then slightly declines.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>HCG level should almost double every 48 hours in the beginning of a pregnancy. HCG level that does not rise appropriately may indicate a problem with your pregnancy. Problems related to an abnormal rising HCG level include miscarriage and ectopic (tubal) pregnancy .</text><text>An extremely high level of HCG may suggest a molar pregnancy or more than one fetus, for example, twins.</text><text>Your provider will discuss the meaning of your HCG level with you.</text>

item.title: PPD skin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for this test.</text><text>Tell your provider if you have ever had a positive PPD skin test. If so, you should not have a repeat PPD test, except under unusual circumstances.</text><text>Tell your provider if you have a medical condition or if you take certain medicines, such as steroids, which can affect your immune system. These situations may lead to inaccurate test results.</text><text>Tell your provider if you have received the BCG vaccine and if so, when you received it. (This vaccine is only given outside of the United States).</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to find out if you have ever come in contact with the bacteria that cause TB. </text><text>TB is an easily spread (contagious) disease. It most often affects the lungs. The bacteria can remain inactive (dormant) in the lungs for many years. This situation is called latent TB. </text><text>Most people in the United States who are infected with the bacteria do not have signs or symptoms of active TB. </text><text>You are most likely to need this test if you:</text><detail>May have been around someone with TB</detail><detail>Work in health care</detail><detail>Have a weakened immune system, due to certain medicines or disease (such as cancer or HIV/AIDS) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative reaction usually means you have never been infected with the bacteria that cause TB. </text><text>With a negative reaction, the skin where you received the PPD test is not swollen, or the swelling is very small. This measurement is different for children, people with HIV, and other high-risk groups.</text><text>The PPD skin test is not a perfect screening test. A few people infected with the bacteria that cause TB may not have a reaction. Also, diseases or medicines that weaken the immune system may cause a false-negative result. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) result means you have been infected with the bacteria that cause TB. You may need treatment to lower the risk of the disease coming back (reactivation of the disease). A positive skin test does not mean that a person has active TB. More tests must be done to check whether there is active disease. </text><text>A small reaction (5 mm of firm swelling at the site) is considered to be positive in people:</text><detail>Who have HIV/AIDS</detail><detail>Who have received an organ transplant</detail><detail>Who have a suppressed immune system or are taking steroid therapy (about 15 mg of prednisone per day for 1 month)</detail><detail>Who have been in close contact with a person who has active TB</detail><detail>Who have changes on a chest x-ray that look like past TB </detail><text>Larger reactions (larger than or equal to 10 mm) are considered positive in:</text><detail>People with a known negative test in the past 2 years</detail><detail>People with diabetes, kidney failure, or other conditions that increase their chance of getting active TB</detail><detail>Health care workers</detail><detail>Injection drug users</detail><detail>Immigrants who have moved from a country with a high TB rate in the past 5 years</detail><detail>Children under age 4</detail><detail>Infants, children, or adolescents who are exposed to high-risk adults</detail><detail>Students and employees of certain group living settings, such as prisons, nursing homes, and homeless shelters </detail><text>In people with no known risks of TB, 15 mm or more of firm swelling at the site indicates a positive reaction.</text><text>People who were born outside the United States who have had a vaccine called BCG may have a false-positive test result. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Purified protein derivative standard</detail><detail> TB skin test</detail><detail> Tuberculin skin test</detail><detail> Mantoux test</detail>

item.title: Potassium urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may ask you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that may affect the test results. Tell your provider about all the medicines you take, including:</text><detail>Corticosteroids</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail>Potassium supplements</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics) </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a condition that affects body fluids, such as dehydration, vomiting, or diarrhea.</text><text>It may also be done to diagnose or confirm disorders of the kidneys or adrenal glands .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The usual range for a person on a regular diet is 25 to 125 mEq/L per day. Lower or higher urinary level may occur depending on the amount of potassium in your diet and the amount of potassium in your body.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal urine potassium level may be due to:</text><detail> Diabetic acidosis and other forms of metabolic acidosis</detail><detail>Eating disorders (anorexia, bulimia)</detail><detail>Kidney problems, such as damage to kidney cells called tubule cells ( acute tubular necrosis )</detail><detail>Low blood magnesium level (hypomagnesemia)</detail><detail>Muscle damage (rhabdomyolysis) </detail><text>Low urine potassium level may be due to:</text><detail>Certain medicines, including beta blockers, lithium, trimethoprim, potassium-sparing diuretics, or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail> Adrenal glands releasing too little hormone (hypoaldosteronism) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine potassium</detail>

item.title: Potassium test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is a regular part of a basic or comprehensive metabolic panel.</text><text>You may have this test to diagnose or monitor kidney disease. The most common cause of high potassium level is kidney disease.</text><text>Potassium is important to heart function.</text><detail>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of high blood pressure or heart problems.</detail><detail>Small changes in potassium levels can have a big effect on the activity of nerves and muscles, especially the heart.</detail><detail>Low levels of potassium can lead to an irregular heartbeat or other electrical malfunction of the heart.</detail><detail>High levels cause decreased heart muscle activity.</detail><detail>Either situation can lead to life-threatening heart problems. </detail><text>It may also be done if your provider suspects metabolic acidosis (for example, caused by uncontrolled diabetes) or alkalosis (for example, caused by excess vomiting).</text><text>Sometimes, the potassium test may be done in people who are having an attack of paralysis .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 3.7 to 5.2 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L) 3.70 to 5.20 millimoles per liter (millimol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High levels of potassium ( hyperkalemia ) may be due to:</text><detail> Addison disease (rare)</detail><detail>Blood transfusion</detail><detail>Certain medicines</detail><detail>Crushed tissue injury</detail><detail> Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis </detail><detail>Hypoaldosteronism (very rare)</detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail>Metabolic or respiratory acidosis </detail><detail>Red blood cell destruction</detail><detail>Too much potassium in your diet </detail><text>Low levels of potassium ( hypokalemia ) may be due to:</text><detail>Chronic diarrhea</detail><detail> Cushing syndrome (rare)</detail><detail>Diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide, furosemide, and indapamide</detail><detail> Hyperaldosteronism </detail><detail> Hypokalemic periodic paralysis </detail><detail>Not enough potassium in the diet</detail><detail>Renal artery stenosis</detail><detail> Renal tubular acidosis (rare)</detail><detail>Vomiting </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Hypokalemia test</detail><detail> K+</detail>

item.title: Porphyrins blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat for 12 to 14 hours before this test. You may drink water right before the test. Your test results may be affected if you do not follow these instructions. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to diagnose porphyrias . This is a group of rare disorders often passed down through family members.</text><text>It may also be used along with other tests to diagnose lead poisoning and certain nervous system and skin disorders.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>This test specifically measures total porphyrin levels. But, reference values (a range of values seen in a group of healthy people) for the individual components are also included:</text><detail>Total porphyrin levels: 0 to 1.0 mcg/dL (0 to 15 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Coproporphyrin level: <2 mcg/dL (<30 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Protoporphyrin level: 16 to 60 mcg/dL (0.28 to 1.07 µmol/L)</detail><detail>Uroporphyrin level: <2 mcg/dL (<2.4 nmol/L) </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased levels of coproporphyrins may be a sign of:</text><detail> Congenital erythropoietic porphyria </detail><detail>Hepatic coproporphyria</detail><detail>Sideroblastic anemia </detail><detail>Variegate porphyria</detail><text>An increased protoporphyrin level may be a sign of:</text><detail> Anemia of chronic disease </detail><detail>Congenital erythropoietic protoporphyria </detail><detail>Increased erythropoiesis</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail> Iron deficiency anemia </detail><detail> Lead poisoning </detail><detail>Sideroblastic anemia</detail><detail> Thalassemia </detail><detail>Variegate porphyria</detail><text>An increased uroporphyrin level may be a sign of:</text><detail>Congenital erythropoietic porphyria</detail><detail>Porphyria cutanea tarda</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Protoporphyrin levels</detail><detail> Porphyrins - total</detail><detail> Coproporphyrin levels</detail><detail> PROTO test</detail>

item.title: Porphyrins - urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test results. These may include:</text><detail>Antibiotics and anti-fungal drugs</detail><detail>Anti-anxiety drugs</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Diabetes medicines</detail><detail>Pain medicines</detail><detail>Sleep medicines</detail><text>Do not stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider will order this test if you have signs of porphyria or other disorders that can cause abnormal urine porphyrins.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results vary depending on the type of porphyrin tested. In general, for a 24-hour urine test of total porphyrins, the range is about 20 to 120 µg/L (25 to 144 nmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Liver cancer </detail><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail> Lead poisoning </detail><detail>Porphyria (several types)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine uroporphyrin</detail><detail> Urine coproporphyrin</detail><detail> Porphyria - uroporphyrin</detail>

item.title: Polysomnography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Whether the test is at a sleep study center or at home, you prepare the same way. Unless directed to do so by your doctor, do not take any sleep medicine and do not drink alcohol or caffeinated beverages before the test. They can interfere with your sleep.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test helps diagnose possible sleep disorders , including obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Your provider may think you have OSA because you have these symptoms:</text><detail> Daytime sleepiness (falling asleep during the day) </detail><detail> Loud snoring </detail><detail> Periods of holding your breath while you sleep, followed by gasps or snorts </detail><detail> Restless sleep </detail><text>Polysomnography can also diagnose other sleep disorders:</text><detail> Narcolepsy </detail><detail>Periodic limb movements disorder (moving your legs often during sleep)</detail><detail>REM behavior disorder (physically "acting out" your dreams during sleep)</detail>
item.NormalResults: A sleep study tracks:How often you stop breathing for at least 10 seconds (called apnea)How often your breathing is partly blocked for 10 seconds (called hypopnea)Your brain waves and muscle movements during sleepMost people have short periods during sleep where their breathing stops or is partly blocked. The Apnea-Hypopnea Index (AHI) is the number of apnea or hypopnea measured during a sleep study. AHI results are used to diagnose obstructive sleep apnea.Normal test result show:Few or no episodes of stopping breathing. An AHI of less than 5 is considered normal.Normal patterns of brain waves and muscle movements during sleep.
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In adults, test results above 5 may mean you have sleep apnea:</text><detail>5 to 15 is mild sleep apnea</detail><detail>15 to 30 is moderate sleep apnea</detail><detail>More than 30 is severe sleep apnea </detail><text>To make a diagnosis and decide on treatment, the sleep specialist must also look at:</text><detail>Other findings from the sleep study</detail><detail>Your medical history and sleep-related complaints</detail><detail>Your physical exam </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Sleep study</detail><detail> Polysomnogram</detail><detail> Rapid eye movement studies</detail><detail> Split night polysomnography</detail><detail> PSG</detail><detail> OSA - sleep study</detail><detail> Obstructive sleep apnea - sleep study</detail><detail> Sleep apnea - sleep study</detail>

item.title: Pleural needle biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will have blood tests before the biopsy. You will likely have a chest x-ray .</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Pleural biopsy is usually done to find the cause of a collection of fluid around the lung ( pleural effusion ) or other abnormality of the pleural membrane. Pleural biopsy can diagnose tuberculosis , cancer, and other diseases.</text><text>If this type of pleural biopsy is not enough to make a diagnosis, you may need a surgical biopsy of the pleura .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Pleural tissues appear normal, without signs of inflammation, infection, or cancer.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may reveal cancer (including primary lung cancer , malignant mesothelioma , and metastatic pleural tumor ), tuberculosis, other infections, or collagen vascular disease.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Closed pleural biopsy</detail><detail> Needle biopsy of the pleura</detail>

item.title: Pleural fluid smear
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed before the test. A chest x-ray will be performed before and after the test.</text><text>DO NOT cough, breathe deeply, or move during the test to avoid injury to the lung.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed if you have a pleural effusion and its cause is not known, especially if the provider suspects an infection or cancer.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, no bacteria, fungi, or cancer cells are present in the pleural fluid.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Positive results may indicate that infection, or cancer cells, are present. Other tests can help identify the specific type of infection or cancer. Sometimes, the test may show abnormalities (such as special types of cells) from conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus .</text>

item.title: Pleural fluid culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed before the test. A chest x-ray will be performed before and after the test.</text><text>DO NOT cough, breathe deeply, or move during the test to avoid injury to the lung.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a certain infection or if a chest x-ray or CT scan of the chest shows you have too much fluid in the space around the lungs. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no bacteria or fungi were seen in the test sample.</text><text>A normal value is no growth of any bacteria. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate:</text><detail> Empyema (collection of pus in the pleural space)</detail><detail>Lung abscess (collection of pus in a lung)</detail><detail> Pneumonia </detail><detail> Tuberculosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - pleural fluid</detail>

item.title: Pleural fluid analysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed before the test. An ultrasound, CT scan, or chest x-ray will be performed before and after the test.</text><text>DO NOT cough, breathe deeply, or move during the test to avoid injury to the lung.</text><text>Tell your provider if you take medicines to thin the blood.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed to determine the cause of a pleural effusion. It is also done to relieve the shortness of breath that a large pleural effusion can cause.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally the pleural cavity contains less than 20 milliliters (4 teaspoons) of clear, yellowish (serous) fluid.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate possible causes of pleural effusion, such as:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail> Cirrhosis </detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Severe malnutrition </detail><detail>Trauma</detail><detail>Abnormal connections between the pleural space and other organs (for example, the esophagus) </detail><text>If the provider suspects an infection, a culture of the fluid is done to check for bacteria and other microbes.</text><text>The test may also be performed for hemothorax . This is a collection of blood in the pleura.</text>

item.title: Platelet count
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time you do not need to take special steps before this test. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The number of platelets in your blood can be affected by many diseases. Platelets may be counted to monitor or diagnose diseases, or to look for the cause of too much bleeding or clotting. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal number of platelets in the blood is 150,000 to 400,000 platelets per microliter (mcL) or 150 to 400 × 10<sup>9</sup>/L.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly. Some lab use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about your test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>LOW PLATELET COUNT</text><text>A low platelet count is below 150,000 (150 × 10<sup>9</sup>/L). If your platelet count is below 50,000 (50 × 10<sup>9</sup>/L), your risk of bleeding is high. Even every day activities can cause bleeding.</text><text>A lower-than-normal platelet count is called thrombocytopenia . Low platelet count can be divided into 3 main causes: </text><detail>Not enough platelets are being made in the bone marrow</detail><detail>Platelets are being destroyed in the bloodstream</detail><detail>Platelets are being destroyed in the spleen or liver </detail><text>Three of the more common causes of this problem are:</text><detail>Cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy or radiation </detail><detail> Drugs and medicines </detail><detail> Autoimmune disorders , in which the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys healthy body tissue, such as platelets </detail><text>If your platelets are low, talk to your health care provider about how to prevent bleeding and what to do if you are bleeding.</text><text>HIGH PLATELET COUNT</text><text>A high platelet count is 400,000 (400 × 10<sup>9</sup>/L) or above</text><text>A higher-than-normal number of platelets is called thrombocytosis. It means your body is making too many platelets. Causes may include:</text><detail>A type of anemia in which red blood cells in the blood are destroyed earlier than normal ( hemolytic anemia )</detail><detail> Anemia due to low iron , sickle cell disease </detail><detail>After certain infections, major surgery or trauma</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Certain medicines</detail><detail>Bone marrow disease called polycythemia vera </detail><detail>Bone marrow making too many platelets without a known cause ( primary thrombocythemia )</detail><detail>Recent spleen removal </detail><text>Some people with high platelet counts may be at risk of forming blood clots . Blood clots can lead to serious medical problems</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thrombocyte count</detail>

item.title: Platelet antibodies blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>An antibody is a protein produced by your body's immune system to attack harmful substances, called antigens. Examples of antigens include bacteria and viruses.</text><text>Antibodies may be produced when your immune system mistakenly considers healthy tissue to be a harmful substance. In the case of platelet antibodies, your body created antibodies to attack platelets. As a result, you will have a lower than normal number of platelets in your body. This condition is called thrombocytopenia , and it can cause too much bleeding.</text><text>This test is often ordered because you have a bleeding problem.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test is normal. This means that you do not have anti-platelet antibodies in your blood.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results show that you have anti-platelet antibodies. Anti-platelet antibodies may appear in the blood due to any of the following:</text><detail>For unknown reasons (idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, or ITP )</detail><detail>Side effect of certain drugs such as gold, heparin, quinidine, and quinine</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thrombocytopenia - platelet antibody</detail><detail> Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura - platelet antibody</detail>

item.title: Platelet aggregation test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Antibiotics</detail><detail>Antihistamines</detail><detail>Antidepressants</detail><detail>Blood thinners, such as aspirin, that make it hard for the blood to clot</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail>Statin drugs for cholesterol </detail><text>Also tell your provider about any vitamins or herbal remedies you take.</text><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a bleeding disorder or a low platelet count . It may also be ordered if a member of your family is known to have a bleeding disorder due to platelet dysfunction.</text><text>The test can help diagnose problems with platelet function and determine whether the problem is due to your genes, another disorder, or a side effect of medicine.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal time it takes for platelets to clump depends on temperature, and may vary from laboratory to laboratory.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased platelet aggregation may be due to:</text><detail> Autoimmune disorders that produce antibodies against platelets</detail><detail> Fibrin degradation products </detail><detail> Inherited platelet function defects </detail><detail>Medicines that block platelet aggregation</detail><detail>Bone marrow disorders</detail><detail> Uremia (a result of kidney failure )</detail><detail> Von Willebrand disease (a bleeding disorder)</detail>

item.title: Plasma amino acids
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The person having the test should not eat 4 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to measure the level of amino acids in the blood.</text><text>An increased level of a particular amino acid is a strong sign. This shows that there is a problem with the body's ability to break down (metabolize) that amino acid.</text><text>The test may also be used to look for decreased levels of amino acids in the blood.</text><text>Increased or decreased levels of amino acids in the blood may occur with fevers, inadequate nutrition, and certain medical conditions.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>All measurements are in micromoles per liter (µmol/L). Normal values may vary between different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about your specific test results.</text><text>Alanine:</text><detail>Children: 200 to 450</detail><detail>Adults: 230 to 510</detail><text>Alpha-aminoadipic acid:</text><detail>Children: not measured</detail><detail>Adults: not measured</detail><text>Alpha-amino-N-butyric acid:</text><detail>Children: 8 to 37</detail><detail>Adults: 15 to 41</detail><text>Arginine:</text><detail>Children: 44 to 120</detail><detail>Adults: 13 to 64</detail><text>Asparagine:</text><detail>Children: 15 to 40</detail><detail>Adults: 45 to 130</detail><text> Aspartic acid :</text><detail>Children: 0 to 26</detail><detail>Adults: 0 to 6</detail><text>Beta-alanine:</text><detail>Children: 0 to 49</detail><detail>Adults: 0 to 29</detail><text>Beta-amino-isobutyric acid:</text><detail>Children: not measured</detail><detail>Adults: not measured</detail><text>Carnosine:</text><detail>Children: not measured</detail><detail>Adults: not measured</detail><text>Citrulline:</text><detail>Children: 16 to 32</detail><detail>Adults: 16 to 55</detail><text>Cystine:</text><detail>Children: 19 to 47</detail><detail>Adults: 30 to 65</detail><text>Glutamic acid:</text><detail>Children: 32 to 140</detail><detail>Adults: 18 to 98</detail><text>Glutamine:</text><detail>Children: 420 to 730</detail><detail>Adults: 390 to 650</detail><text>Glycine:</text><detail>Children: 110 to 240</detail><detail>Adults: 170 to 330</detail><text>Histidine:</text><detail>Children: 68 to 120</detail><detail>Adults: 26 to 120</detail><text>Hydroxyproline:</text><detail>Children: 0 to 5</detail><detail>Adults: not measured</detail><text>Isoleucine:</text><detail>Children: 37 to 140</detail><detail>Adults: 42 to 100</detail><text>Leucine:</text><detail>Children: 70 to 170</detail><detail>Adults: 66 to 170</detail><text>Lysine:</text><detail>Children: 120 to 290</detail><detail>Adults: 150 to 220</detail><text>Methionine:</text><detail>Children: 13 to 30</detail><detail>Adults: 16 to 30</detail><text>1-methylhistidine:</text><detail>Children: not measured</detail><detail>Adults: not measured</detail><text>3-methylhistidine:</text><detail>Children: 0 to 52</detail><detail>Adults: 0 to 64</detail><text>Ornithine:</text><detail>Children: 44 to 90</detail><detail>Adults: 27 to 80</detail><text> Phenylalanine :</text><detail>Children: 26 to 86</detail><detail>Adults: 41 to 68</detail><text>Phosphoserine:</text><detail>Children: 0 to 12</detail><detail>Adults: 0 to 12</detail><text>Phosphoethanolamine:</text><detail>Children: 0 to 12</detail><detail>Adults: 0 to 55</detail><text>Proline:</text><detail>Children: 130 to 290</detail><detail>Adults: 110 to 360</detail><text>Serine:</text><detail>Children: 93 to 150</detail><detail>Adults: 56 to 140</detail><text>Taurine:</text><detail>Children: 11 to 120</detail><detail>Adults: 45 to 130</detail><text>Threonine:</text><detail>Children: 67 to 150</detail><detail>Adults: 92 to 240</detail><text>Tyrosine:</text><detail>Children: 26 to 110</detail><detail>Adults: 45 to 74</detail><text>Valine:</text><detail>Children: 160 to 350</detail><detail>Adults: 150 to 310</detail><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increase in the total level of amino acids in the blood may be due to:</text><detail>Eclampsia</detail><detail>Fructose intolerance</detail><detail>Ketoacidosis (from diabetes)</detail><detail>Kidney failure</detail><detail>Reye syndrome</detail><detail>Laboratory error </detail><text>A decrease in the total level of amino acids in the blood may be due to:</text><detail>Adrenal cortical hyperfunction</detail><detail>Fever</detail><detail>Hartnup disease</detail><detail>Huntington's chorea</detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail>Nephrotic syndrome</detail><detail>Phlebotomus fever</detail><detail>Rheumatoid arthritis</detail><detail>Laboratory error </detail><text>High or low amounts of individual plasma amino acids must be considered with other information. Abnormal results may be due to diet, hereditary problems, or effects of a medicine.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Amino acids blood test</detail>

item.title: Pinworm test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is performed to check for pinworms, which can cause itching in the anal area.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If adult pinworms or eggs are found, the person has a pinworm infection. Usually the whole family needs to be treated with medicine. This is because pinworms are easily passed back and forth between family members.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Oxyuriasis test</detail><detail> Enterobiasis test</detail><detail> Tape test</detail>

item.title: Phosphorus blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test. These medicines include water pills (diuretics), antacids, and laxatives. </text><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Phosphorus is a mineral the body needs to build strong bones and teeth. It is also important for nerve signaling and muscle contraction.</text><text>This test is ordered to see how much phosphorus is in your blood. Kidney, liver, and certain bone diseases can cause abnormal phosphorus levels.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from:</text><detail>Adults: 2.8 to 4.5 mg/dL</detail><detail>Children: 4.0 to 7.0 mg/dL</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level (hyperphosphatemia) may be due to many different health conditions. Common causes include:</text><detail> Diabetic ketoacidosis (life-threatening condition that may occur in people with diabetes)</detail><detail> Hypoparathyroidism (parathyroid glands do not make enough of their hormone)</detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail>Too much vitamin D</detail><detail>Too much phosphate in your diet</detail><detail>Use of certain medicines such as laxatives that have phosphate in them </detail><text>A lower than normal level (hypophosphatemia) may be due to:</text><detail>Alcoholism</detail><detail>Hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the body)</detail><detail> Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid glands make too much of their hormone)</detail><detail>Too little dietary intake of phosphate</detail><detail>Very poor nutrition</detail><detail>Too little vitamin D, resulting in bone problems such as rickets (childhood) or osteomalacia (adult) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Phosphorus - serum</detail><detail> HPO4<sup>-2</sup></detail><detail> PO4<sup>-3</sup></detail><detail> Inorganic phosphate</detail><detail> Serum phosphorus</detail>

item.title: PET scan for breast cancer
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan. You will be able to drink water.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if:</text><detail>You are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious.</detail><detail>You are pregnant or think you might be pregnant.</detail><detail>You are breastfeeding.</detail><detail>You have any allergies to injected dye (contrast).</detail><detail>You take insulin for diabetes. You will need special preparation.</detail><text>Always tell your provider about the medicines you're taking, including those bought without a prescription. Sometimes, medicines can interfere with the test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A PET scan is most often used when other tests, such as MRI scan or CT scan, DO NOT provide enough information.</text><text>A breast PET scan is used only after a woman has been diagnosed with breast cancer. It is done to see if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body, such as the lymph nodes, liver, lung, or bones.</text><text>If you have breast cancer, your doctor may order this scan:</text><detail>Soon after your diagnosis to see if the cancer has spread</detail><detail>After treatment if there is concern that the cancer has come back</detail><detail>During treatment to see if the cancer is responding to treatment</detail><text>A PET scan is not used to screen for, or diagnose, breast cancer.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there are no areas outside the breast in which the radiotracer has abnormally collected. This result most likely means the breast cancer has not spread to other parts of the body.</text><text>Very small areas of breast cancer may not show up on a PET scan.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean that the breast cancer has spread.</text><text>Blood sugar or insulin level may affect the test results in people with diabetes.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Breast positron emission tomography</detail><detail> PET - breast</detail><detail> PET - tumor imaging - breast</detail>

item.title: PET scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan. You will be able to drink water but not other beverages including coffee. If you have diabetes, your provider will tell you not to take your diabetes medicine before the test. These medicines will interfere with the results.</text><text>Tell your provider if:</text><detail>You are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious.</detail><detail>You are pregnant or think you might be pregnant.</detail><detail>You have any allergies to injected dye (contrast). </detail><text>Always tell your provider about the medicines you are taking. Let your provider know about the medicines you bought without a prescription. Sometimes, medicines may interfere with the test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A PET scan can reveal the size, shape, position, and some function of organs.</text><text>The most common use for a PET scan is for cancer, when it may be done:</text><detail>To see how far cancer has spread. This helps to select the best treatment approach.</detail><detail>To check how well your cancer is responding, either during treatment or after treatment is completed. </detail><text>This test can also be used to:</text><detail>Check brain function</detail><detail> Identify the source of epilepsy in the brain </detail><detail>Show areas in which there is poor blood flow to the heart </detail><detail>Determine if a mass in your lung is cancerous or harmless </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there were no problems seen in the size, shape, or position of an organ. There are no areas in which the tracer has abnormally collected.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results depend on the part of the body being studied. Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Change in the size, shape, or position of an organ</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Problem with organ function </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Positron emission tomography</detail><detail> Tumor imaging - PET</detail><detail> PET/CT</detail>

item.title: Peritoneal fluid culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Empty your bladder before your abdominal tap procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to find out if there is an infection in the peritoneal space.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Peritoneal fluid is a sterile fluid, so normally no bacteria or fungi are present.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The growth of any microorganism, such as bacteria or fungi, from peritoneal fluid is abnormal and indicates peritonitis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - peritoneal fluid</detail>

item.title: Peritoneal fluid analysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Let your provider know if you:</text><detail>Are taking any medicines (including herbal remedies)</detail><detail>Have any allergies to medicines or numbing medicine</detail><detail>Have any bleeding problems</detail><detail>Might be pregnant </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to:</text><detail>Detect peritonitis </detail><detail>Find the cause of fluid in the abdomen</detail><detail>Remove large amounts of fluid from the peritoneal space in people who have liver disease. (This is done to make breathing comfortable.)</detail><detail>See whether an injury to the abdomen has caused internal bleeding</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean:</text><detail>Bile-stained fluid may mean you have a gallbladder or liver problem.</detail><detail>Bloody fluid may be a sign of tumor or injury.</detail><detail>High white blood cell counts may be a sign of peritonitis .</detail><detail>Milk-colored peritoneal fluid may be a sign of carcinoma , cirrhosis of the liver, lymphoma , tuberculosis, or infection. </detail><text>Other abnormal test results may be due to a problem in the intestines or organs of the abdomen. Large differences between the amount of albumin in the peritoneal fluid and in your blood may point to heart, liver, or kidney failure. Small differences may be a sign of cancer or infection.</text>

item.title: Pericardiocentesis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may not be able to eat or drink for 6 hours before the test. You must sign a consent form.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to remove and examine fluid that is pressing on the heart. It is most often done to find the cause of a chronic or recurrent pericardial effusion .</text><text>It may also be done to treat cardiac tamponade , which is a life-threatening condition.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There is normally a small amount of clear, straw-colored fluid in the pericardial space.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal findings may indicate the cause of pericardial fluid accumulation, such as:</text><detail> Cancer </detail><detail>Cardiac perforation</detail><detail>Cardiac trauma</detail><detail> Congestive heart failure </detail><detail> Pericarditis </detail><detail>Renal failure</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Rupture of a ventricular aneurysm </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pericardial tap</detail><detail> Percutaneous pericardiocentesis</detail><detail> Pericarditis - pericardiocentesis</detail><detail> Pericardial effusion - pericardiocentesis</detail>

item.title: Pericardial fluid Gram stain
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked not to eat or drink anything for several hours before the test. A chest x-ray or ultrasound may be done before the test to identify the area of fluid collection.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a heart infection ( myocarditis ) or a pericardial effusion (fluid buildup of the pericardium) with an unknown cause.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no bacteria are seen in the stained fluid sample.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If bacteria are present, you may have an infection of the pericardium or heart. Blood tests and bacterial culture can help identify the specific organism causing the infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gram stain of pericardial fluid</detail>

item.title: Pericardial fluid culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked not to eat or drink anything for several hours before the test. You may have a chest x-ray or ultrasound before the test to identify the area of fluid collection.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a heart sac infection or if you have pericardial effusion .</text><text>The test may also be done if you have pericarditis .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no infectious organisms are found in the fluid sample.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to an infection of the pericardium. The specific organism causing the infection may be identified. More tests may be needed to determine the most effective treatments.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - pericardial fluid</detail>

item.title: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Inform your provider if you are pregnant. You will be given a hospital gown to wear and you will be asked to remove all jewelry.</text><text>You will be asked not to eat or drink anything for 6 hours prior to the exam.</text><text>Tell your provider if you are taking any blood thinners such as Warfarin (coumadin), Plavix (clopidrogrel), Pradaxa, or Xarelto.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test can help diagnose the cause of a bile duct blockage. </text><text>Bile is a liquid released by the liver. It contains cholesterol, bile salts, and waste products. Bile salts help your body break down (digest) fats. A blockage of the bile duct can lead to jaundice (yellow discoloration of the skin), itching of the skin, or infection of the liver, gallbladder or pancreas.</text><text>When it is performed, PTCA is most often the first part of a two-step process to relieve or treat a blockage.</text><detail>The PTCA makes a "roadmap" of the bile ducts, which can be used to plan the treatment.</detail><detail>After the roadmap is done, the blockage can be treated by either placing a stent or a thin tube called a drain.</detail><detail>The drain or stent will help the body get rid of the bile from the body. That process is called Percutaneous Biliary Drainage (PTBD). </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bile ducts are normal in size and appearance for the age of the person.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The results may show that the ducts are enlarged. This may mean the ducts are blocked. The blockage may be caused by scarring or stones. It may also indicate cancer in the bile ducts, liver, pancreas, or region of the gallbladder.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>PTCA</detail><detail> Cholangiogram - PTCA</detail><detail> PTC</detail><detail> PBD - Precutaneous Biliary drainage</detail>

item.title: Pelvis x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider if you are pregnant. Remove all jewelry. You will wear a hospital gown.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The x-ray is used to look for:</text><detail> Fractures </detail><detail>Tumors</detail><detail>Degenerative conditions of bones in the hips, pelvis, and upper legs</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may suggest:</text><detail>Pelvic fractures</detail><detail>Arthritis of the hip joint</detail><detail>Tumors of the bones of the pelvis</detail><detail>Sacroiliitis (inflammation of the area where the sacrum joins the ilium bone)</detail><detail> Ankylosing spondylitis (abnormal stiffness of the spine and joint)</detail><detail>Arthritis of the lower spine</detail><detail>Abnormality of the shape of your pelvis or hip joint</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - pelvis</detail>

item.title: Pelvis MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you relax and be less anxious. Or your provider may suggest an open MRI in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Vascular stents </detail><detail>Pain pumps</detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done if a female has any of the following signs or symptoms:</text><detail>Abnormal vaginal bleeding</detail><detail>A mass in the pelvis (felt during a pelvic exam or seen on another imaging test)</detail><detail>Fibroids</detail><detail>A pelvic mass that occurs during pregnancy</detail><detail>Endometriosis (usually only done after ultrasound)</detail><detail>Pain in the lower belly (abdominal) area</detail><detail>Unexplained infertility (usually only done after ultrasound)</detail><detail>Unexplained pelvic pain (usually only done after ultrasound) </detail><text>This test may be done if a male has any of the following signs or symptoms:</text><detail>Lumps or swelling in the testicles or scrotum</detail><detail>Undescended testicle (unable to be seen using ultrasound)</detail><detail>Unexplained pelvic or lower abdominal pain</detail><detail>Unexplained urination problems, including trouble starting or stopping urinating </detail><text>A pelvic MRI may be done in both males and females who have:</text><detail>Abnormal findings on an x-ray of the pelvis</detail><detail>Birth defects of the hips</detail><detail>Injury or trauma to the hip area</detail><detail>Unexplained hip pain </detail><text>A pelvic MRI is also often done to see if certain cancers have spread to other areas of the body. This is called staging. Staging helps guide future treatment and follow-up and gives you some idea of what to expect in the future. A pelvic MRI may be used to help stage cervical, uterine, bladder, rectal, prostate and testicular cancers.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means your pelvic area appears normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results in a woman may be due to:</text><detail> Adenomyosis of the uterus</detail><detail> Bladder cancer </detail><detail> Cervical cancer </detail><detail> Colorectal cancer </detail><detail>Congenital defect of the reproductive organs</detail><detail> Endometrial cancer </detail><detail> Endometriosis </detail><detail> Ovarian cancer </detail><detail> Ovarian growths </detail><detail>Problem with the structure of the reproductive organs, such as the fallopian tubes</detail><detail> Uterine fibroids </detail><text>Abnormal results in a man may be due to:</text><detail> Bladder cancer </detail><detail> Colorectal cancer </detail><detail> Prostate cancer </detail><detail> Testicular cancer </detail><text>Abnormal results in both males and females may be due to:</text><detail>Avascular necrosis of the hip</detail><detail>Birth defects of the hip joint</detail><detail>Bone tumor</detail><detail>Hip fracture</detail><detail>Osteoarthritis</detail><detail>Osteomyelitis </detail><text>Talk to your provider if you have questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI - pelvis</detail><detail> MRI - hips</detail><detail> Pelvic MRI with prostate probe</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - pelvis</detail>

item.title: Pelvic ultrasound - abdominal
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>A pelvic ultrasound may be done with a full bladder. Having a full bladder can help with looking at organs, such as the womb (uterus), within your pelvis. You may be asked to drink a few glasses of water to fill your bladder. You should wait until after the test to urinate.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A pelvic ultrasound is used during pregnancy to check the baby.</text><text>A pelvic ultrasound also may be done for the following:</text><detail>Cysts, fibroid tumors , or other growths or masses in the pelvis found when your doctor examines you</detail><detail>Bladder growths or other problems</detail><detail>Kidney stones</detail><detail> Pelvic inflammatory disease , an infection of a woman's uterus, ovaries, or tubes</detail><detail>Abnormal vaginal bleeding</detail><detail>Menstrual problems</detail><detail> Problems becoming pregnant (infertility)</detail><detail>Normal pregnancy</detail><detail> Ectopic pregnancy , a pregnancy that occurs outside the uterus</detail><detail>Pelvic pain </detail><text>Pelvic ultrasound is also used during a biopsy to help guide the needle. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The pelvic structures or fetus are normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may be due to many conditions. Some problems that may be seen include:</text><detail>Abscess in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or pelvis</detail><detail> Birth defects of the womb or vagina </detail><detail>Cancers of the bladder , cervix , uterus , ovaries , vagina , and other pelvic structures</detail><detail>Growths in or around the uterus and ovaries (such as cysts or fibroids)</detail><detail>Twisting of the ovaries</detail><detail> Enlarged lymph nodes </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ultrasound pelvis</detail><detail> Pelvic ultrasonography</detail><detail> Pelvic sonography</detail><detail> Pelvic scan</detail><detail> Lower abdomen ultrasound</detail><detail> Gynecologic ultrasound</detail><detail> Transabdominal ultrasound</detail>

item.title: Pelvic CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast media, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. The contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. Or you may be asked to drink a liquid form of contrast. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage) because you may need to take extra precautions. </detail><text>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you have kidney problems. You may not be able to get IV contrast if this is the case.</text><text>If you weigh more than 300 pounds (136 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can damage the scanner's working parts.</text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text><text>You may be asked to drink an oral contrast solution.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the body, including the pelvis and areas near the pelvis. The test may be used to diagnose or detect:</text><detail>Masses or tumors, including cancer</detail><detail>The cause of pelvic pain</detail><detail>Injury to the pelvis</detail><text>This test may also help:</text><detail>Guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy or other procedures</detail><detail>Your provider plan for surgery</detail><detail>Plan radiation treatment for cancer</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if the organs of the pelvis that are being examined are normal in appearance.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abscess (collection of pus)</detail><detail> Bladder stones </detail><detail>Broken bone</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail> Diverticulitis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - pelvis</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - pelvis</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - pelvis</detail><detail> CT scan - pelvis</detail>

item.title: PBG urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Antibiotics and anti-fungal drugs</detail><detail>Anti-anxiety drugs</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Diabetes medicines</detail><detail>Pain medicines</detail><detail>Sleep medicines </detail><text>Never stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done if your provider suspects porphyria or another disorder associated with an abnormal PBG level. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>For a random urine sample, a negative test result is considered normal.</text><text>If the test is done on a 24-hour urine sample, the normal value is less than 4 milligrams per 24 hours (18 micromoles per 24 hours).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased level of PBG in the urine may be due to:</text><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail> Lead poisoning </detail><detail> Liver cancer </detail><detail>Porphyria (several types)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Porphobilinogen test</detail><detail> Porphyria - urine</detail><detail> PBG</detail>

item.title: Partial thromboplastin time (PTT)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. Also tell your provider about any herbal remedies you take.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have problems with bleeding or your blood does not clot properly. When you bleed, a series of actions involving many different proteins (clotting factors) take place in the body that help the blood clot. This is called the coagulation cascade. The PTT test looks at some of the proteins or factors involved in this process and measures their ability to help blood clot.</text><text>The test may also be used to monitor patients who are taking heparin, a blood thinner.</text><text>A PTT test is usually done with other tests, such as the prothrombin test.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In general, clotting should occur within 25 to 35 seconds. If the person is taking blood thinners, clotting takes up to 2 ½ times longer.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different labs. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (too long) PTT result may also be due to:</text><detail> Bleeding disorders , a group of conditions in which there is a problem with the body's blood clotting process</detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation ) </detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Difficulty absorbing nutrients from food ( malabsorption )</detail><detail>Low level of vitamin K</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>APTT</detail><detail> PTT</detail><detail> Activated partial thromboplastin time</detail>

item.title: Parathyroid hormone-related protein blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to find out whether a high blood calcium level is caused by an increase in PTH-related protein.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No detectable (or minimal) PTH-like protein is normal.</text><text>Women who are breastfeeding may have detectable PTH-related protein values. </text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased level of PTH-related protein with a high blood calcium level is usually caused by cancer.</text><text>PTH-related protein can be produced by many different kinds of cancers, including those of the lung, breast, head, neck, bladder, and ovaries. In about two thirds of people with cancer who have a high calcium level, a high level of PTH-related protein is the cause. This condition is called humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM) or paraneoplastic hypercalcemia.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>PTHrp</detail><detail> PTH-related peptide</detail>

item.title: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Ask your health care provider if you should stop eating or drinking for some period of time before the test. Most often, you will not need to fast or stop drinking.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>PTH is released by the parathyroid glands. The 4 small parathyroid glands are located in the neck, near or attached to the back side of the thyroid gland. The thyroid gland is located in the neck, just above where your collarbones meet in the middle.</text><text>PTH controls calcium, phosphorus, and vitamin D levels in the blood. It is important for regulating bone growth. Your provider may order this test if: </text><detail>You have a high calcium level or low phosphorus level in your blood.</detail><detail>You have severe osteoporosis that cannot be explained or does not respond to treatment.</detail><detail>You have kidney disease.</detail><text>To help understand whether your PTH is normal, your provider will measure your blood calcium at the same time.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are 10 to 55 picograms per milliliter (pg/mL). </text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level may occur with:</text><detail>Disorders that increase phosphate or phosphorous levels in the blood, such as long-term (chronic) kidney disease </detail><detail>Failure of the body to respond to PTH (pseudohypoparathyroidism)</detail><detail>Lack of calcium, which may be due to not eating enough calcium, not absorbing calcium in the gut, or losing too much calcium in your urine</detail><detail>Pregnancy or breastfeeding (uncommon)</detail><detail>Swelling in the parathyroid glands, called primary hyperparathyroidism </detail><detail> Tumors in the parathyroid gland , called adenomas</detail><detail>Vitamin D disorders, including not enough sunlight in older adults and problems absorbing, breaking down, and using vitamin D in the body </detail><text>A lower-than-normal level may occur with:</text><detail>Accidental removal of parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery</detail><detail>Autoimmune destruction of the parathyroid gland</detail><detail>Cancers that start in another part of the body (such as the breast, lungs, or colon) and spread to the bone</detail><detail> Excess calcium over a long period of time usually from excess calcium supplements or certain antacids, that contain calcium carbonate or sodium bicarbonate (baking soda)</detail><detail>Parathyroid glands do not produce enough PTH ( hypoparathyroidism )</detail><detail> Low levels of magnesium in the blood </detail><detail>Radiation to the parathyroid glands</detail><detail> Sarcoidosis and tuberculosis</detail><detail> Excess vitamin D intake </detail><text>Other conditions for which the test may be ordered include:</text><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) I </detail><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) II </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Parathormone</detail><detail> Parathormone (PTH) intact molecule</detail><detail> Intact PTH</detail><detail> Hyperparathyroidism - PTH blood test</detail><detail> Hypoparathyroidism - PTH blood test</detail>

item.title: Parathyroid biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your provider if you have any drug allergies or bleeding problems, or if you are pregnant.</text><text>Make sure the provider knows about all the medicines you're taking, including any herbs or supplements. Tell your provider if you're taking any blood thinning drugs (aspirin, heparin, Lovenox, warfarin). You may have to stop taking them a few days before the procedure. Do NOT stop any medicines on your own. Ask your provider first.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The parathyroid glands release PTH. This hormone controls the level of calcium in the body.</text><text>This procedure is most often done to rule out the cause of a high parathyroid hormone level.</text><text>It may also be done if an ultrasound exam shows an enlarged parathyroid gland.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There is no swelling, PTH level is normal, and cells from the tissue sample are normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The test confirms that a parathyroid gland is enlarged if PTH level is too high or cells from the sample are abnormal.</text><text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Noncancerous tumor of the parathyroid gland ( parathyroid adenoma )</detail><detail> Parathyroid cancer (rare)</detail><detail>Enlargement of all 4 parathyroid glands ( parathyroid hyperplasia )</detail><detail>Disorder in which one or more of the endocrine glands are overactive or form a tumor (multiple endocrine neoplasia) ([ MEN I ] or [ MEN II ])</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - parathyroid</detail>

item.title: Quantitative Bence-Jones protein test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Bence-Jones proteins are a part of regular antibodies called light chains. These proteins are not normally in urine. Sometimes, when your body makes too many antibodies, the level of light chains also rises. Bence-Jones proteins are small enough to be filtered out by the kidneys. The proteins then spill into the urine. </text><text>Your provider may order this test:</text><detail>To diagnose conditions that lead to protein in the urine</detail><detail>If you have a lot of protein in your urine</detail><detail>If you have signs of a blood cancer called multiple myeloma </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no Bence-Jones proteins are found in your urine.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Bence-Jones proteins are rarely found in urine. If they are, it is usually associated with multiple myeloma .</text><text>An abnormal result may also be due to:</text><detail>An abnormal buildup of proteins in tissues and organs ( amyloidosis )</detail><detail>Blood cancer called chronic lymphocytic leukemia </detail><detail>Lymph system cancer (lymphoma)</detail><detail>Buildup in the blood of a protein called M-protein (monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance; MGUS)</detail><detail>Chronic renal failure</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Immunoglobulin light chains - urine</detail><detail> Urine Bence-Jones protein</detail>

item.title: RSV antibody test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to identify someone who has been infected by RSV recently or in the past.</text><text>This test does not detect the virus itself. If the body has produced antibodies against RSV, then either a current or past infection has occurred.</text><text>In infants, RSV antibodies that have been passed from mother to baby may also be detected.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test means the person does not have antibodies to RSV in their blood. This means the person has never had an RSV infection.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test means the person has antibodies to RSV in their blood. These antibodies may be present because:</text><detail>A positive test in people older than infants means there is a current or past infection with RSV. Most adults and older children have had an RSV infection.</detail><detail>Infants may have a positive test because antibodies were passed from their mother to them before they were born. This may mean they have not had a true RSV infection.</detail><detail>Some children younger than 24 months get a shot with antibodies to RSV to protect them. These children will also have a positive test. </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Respiratory syncytial virus antibody test</detail><detail> RSV serology</detail><detail> Bronchiolitis - RSV test</detail>

item.title: RPR test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is usually needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The RPR test can be used to screen for syphilis. It is used to screen people who have symptoms of sexually transmitted infections and is routinely used to screen pregnant women for the disease.</text><text>Several states also require that couples be screened for syphilis before getting a marriage license.</text><text>The test is also used to see how treatment for syphilis is working. After treatment with antibiotics, the levels of syphilis antibodies should fall. These levels can be monitored with another RPR test. Unchanged or rising levels can mean a persistent infection.</text><text>The test is similar to the venereal disease research laboratory ( VDRL ) test.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test result is considered normal. However, the body does not always produce antibodies specifically in response to the syphilis bacteria, so the test is not always accurate. False-negatives may occur in people with early- and late-stage syphilis. More testing may be needed before ruling out syphilis.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test result may mean that you have syphilis. If the screening test is positive, the next step is to confirm the diagnosis with a more specific test for syphilis, such as FTA-ABS .
