The FTA-ABS test will help distinguish between syphilis and other infections or conditions.</text><text>How well the RPR test can detect syphilis depends on the stage of the infection. The test is most sensitive (almost 100%) during the middle stages of syphilis. It is less sensitive during the earlier and later stages of the infection.</text><text>Some conditions may cause a false-positive test, including:</text><detail>IV drug use</detail><detail> Lyme disease </detail><detail>Certain types of pneumonia</detail><detail> Malaria </detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus and some other autoimmune disorders</detail><detail>Tuberculosis (TB)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Rapid plasma reagin test</detail><detail> Syphilis screening test</detail>

item.title: Routine sputum culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Drinking a lot of water and other fluids the night before the test may make it easier to cough up the sputum. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test helps identify the bacteria or other type of germs that are causing an infection in the lungs or airways (bronchi). </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In a normal sputum sample there will be no disease-causing germs. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the sputum sample is abnormal, the results are called "positive." Identifying the bacteria, fungus, or virus may help diagnose the cause of:</text><detail> Bronchitis (swelling and inflammation in the main passages that carry air to the lungs)</detail><detail>Lung abscess (collection of pus in the lung)</detail><detail> Pneumonia </detail><detail> Tuberculosis </detail><detail>Flare up of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or cystic fibrosis </detail><detail>Sarcoidosis</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Sputum culture</detail>

item.title: Rotavirus antigen test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Rotavirus is the leading cause of gastroenteritis ("stomach flu") in children. This test is done to diagnose a rotavirus infection .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, rotavirus is not found in the stool.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Rotavirus in the stool indicates a rotavirus infection is present.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gastroenteritis - rotavirus antigen</detail>

item.title: Right heart ventriculography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will not be allowed to eat or drink for 6 to 8 hours before the test. The procedure takes place in the hospital. Generally, you will be admitted the morning of the procedure. However, you may need to be admitted the night before.</text><text>A health care provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Right heart angiography is performed to assess the blood flow through the right side of the heart.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results include:</text><detail>Cardiac index is 2.8 to 4.2 liters per minute per square meter (of body surface area)</detail><detail>Pulmonary artery systolic pressure is 17 to 32 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg)</detail><detail>Pulmonary artery mean pressure is 9 to 19 mm Hg</detail><detail>Pulmonary diastolic pressure is 4 to 13 mm Hg</detail><detail>Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 4 to 12 mm Hg</detail><detail>Right atrial pressure is 0 to 7 mm Hg</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to: </text><detail>Abnormal connections between the right and left side of the heart</detail><detail>Abnormalities of the right atrium, such as atrial myxoma (rarely)</detail><detail>Abnormalities of the valves on the right side of the heart</detail><detail>Abnormal pressures or volumes</detail><detail>Weakened pumping function of the right ventricle (this could be due to many causes)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Angiography - right heart</detail>

item.title: Rheumatoid factor (RF)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time, you do not need to take special steps before this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often used to help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis or Sjögren syndrome .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are usually reported in one of two ways:</text><detail>Value, normal less than 15 IU/mL</detail><detail>Titer, normal less than 1:80 (1 to 80)</detail><text>If the result is above the normal level, it is positive. A low number (negative result) most often means you do not have rheumatoid arthritis or Sjögren syndrome. However, some people who do have these conditions still have a negative or low RF.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means the test is positive, which means a higher level of rheumatoid factor has been detected in your blood.</text><detail>Most people with rheumatoid arthritis or Sjögren syndrome have positive RF tests.</detail><detail>The higher the level, the more likely one of these conditions is present. There are also other tests for these disorders that help make the diagnosis.</detail><detail>Not everyone with a higher level of RF has rheumatoid arthritis or Sjögren syndrome. </detail><text>Your provider may do another blood test (anti-CCP antibody), to help diagnose rheumatoid arthritis.</text><text>People with the following diseases may also have higher levels of RF:</text><detail>Hepatitis C</detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus </detail><detail> Dermatomyositis and polymyositis</detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail><detail>Mixed cryoglobulinemia</detail><detail>Mixed connective tissue disease</detail><text>Higher-than-normal levels of RF may be seen in people with other medical problems. However, these higher RF levels cannot be used to diagnose these other conditions:</text><detail> AIDS , hepatitis , influenza , infectious mononucleosis , and other viral infections</detail><detail>Certain kidney diseases</detail><detail> Endocarditis , tuberculosis, and other bacterial infections</detail><detail>Parasite infections</detail><detail> Leukemia , multiple myeloma , and other cancers</detail><detail>Chronic lung disease</detail><detail>Chronic liver disease </detail><text>In some cases, people who are healthy and have no other medical problem will have a higher-than-normal RF level.</text>

item.title: Retrograde cystography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must sign an informed consent form. You must empty your bladder before the test. You will be asked questions to determine if you may have an allergic reaction to the contrast dye, or if you have a current infection that could make inserting the catheter difficult.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test to examine your bladder for problems such as holes or tears, or to find out why you have repeated bladder infections. It is also used to look for problems such as: </text><detail>Abnormal connections between bladder tissue and a nearby structure (bladder fistulae)</detail><detail>Bladder stones</detail><detail>Pouch-like sacs called diverticula on the walls of the bladder or urethra</detail><detail>Tumor of the bladder</detail><detail> Urinary tract infection </detail><detail> Vesicoureteric reflux </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bladder appears normal. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Bladder stones </detail><detail> Blood clots </detail><detail>Diverticula</detail><detail>Infection or inflammation</detail><detail>Lesions</detail><detail>Vesicoureteric reflux </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cystography - retrograde</detail><detail> Cystogram</detail>

item.title: Reticulocyte count
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to determine if red blood cells are being created in the bone marrow at an appropriate rate. The number of reticulocytes in the blood is a sign of how quickly they are being produced and released by the bone marrow.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result for healthy adults who are not anemic is around 0.5% (0.005 × 10<sup>-3</sup>) to 2.5% (0.025 × 10<sup>-3</sup>).</text><text>The normal range depends on your level of hemoglobin. Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. The range is higher if hemoglobin is low, from bleeding or if red cells are destroyed.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal reticulocytes count may indicate:</text><detail>Anemia due to red blood cells being destroyed earlier than normal ( hemolytic anemia )</detail><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Blood disorder in a fetus or newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis)</detail><detail>Kidney disease, with increased production of a hormone called erythropoietin </detail><text>A lower than normal reticulocyte count may indicate:</text><detail>Bone marrow failure (for example, from a certain drug, tumor, radiation therapy, or infection)</detail><detail> Cirrhosis of the liver </detail><detail>Anemia caused by low iron levels, or low levels of vitamin B12 or folate</detail><detail> Chronic kidney disease </detail><text>Reticulocyte count may be higher during pregnancy.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Anemia - reticulocyte</detail>

item.title: Renin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Medicines that can affect renin measurements include:</text><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Blood pressure drugs</detail><detail>Medicines that dilate blood vessels (vasodilators). These are usually used to treat high blood pressure or heart failure.</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics) </detail><text>Your provider may instruct you to limit your sodium intake before the test.</text><text>Be aware that renin level can be affected by pregnancy, as well as the time of day and the body position when blood is drawn.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Renin is a protein ( enzyme ) released by special kidney cells when you have a decreased salt (sodium) level or low blood volume.</text><text>If you have high blood pressure , your doctor may order a renin and aldosterone test to help determine the cause of your elevated blood pressure. Test results can help guide your doctor in choosing the correct treatment. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>For normal sodium diet, normal value range is 0.6 to 4.3 ng/mL/hour (0.6 to 4.3 µg/L/hour). For low sodium diet, normal value range is 2.9 to 24 ng/mL/hour (2.9 to 24 µg/L/hour).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high level of renin may be due to:</text><detail>Adrenal glands that do not make enough hormones ( Addison disease or other adrenal gland insufficiency)</detail><detail>Bleeding (hemorrhage)</detail><detail>Heart failure</detail><detail>High blood pressure caused by narrowing of the kidney arteries ( renovascular hypertension )</detail><detail>Liver scarring and poor liver function ( cirrhosis )</detail><detail>Loss of body fluid (dehydration)</detail><detail>Kidney damage that creates nephrotic syndrome </detail><detail> Kidney tumors that produce renin </detail><detail>Sudden and very high blood pressure ( malignant hypertension ) </detail><text>A low level of renin may be due to:</text><detail>Adrenal glands that release too much aldosterone hormone ( hyperaldosteronism )</detail><detail>High blood pressure that is salt-sensitive</detail><detail> Treatment with antidiuretic hormone (ADH)</detail><detail>Treatment with steroid medicines that cause the body to retain salt </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Plasma renin activity</detail><detail> Random plasma renin</detail><detail> PRA</detail>

item.title: Renal venogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be told to avoid food and drinks for about 8 hours before the test. Your provider may tell you to stop taking aspirin or other blood thinners before the test. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text><text>You will be asked to wear hospital clothing and to sign a consent form for the procedure. You will need to remove any jewelry from the area that is being studied. </text><text>Tell the provider if you:</text><detail>Are pregnant</detail><detail>Have allergies to any medicine, contrast dye, or iodine </detail><detail>Have a history of bleeding problems </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is not done very often anymore. It has largely been replaced by CT scan and MRI. In the past, the test was used to measure levels of kidney hormones. </text><text>Rarely, the test may be used to detect blood clots , tumors , and vein problems. Its most common use today is as part of an exam to treat varicose veins of the testicles or ovaries.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There should not be any clots or tumors in the kidney vein. The dye should flow quickly through the vein and not back up to the testes or ovaries. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Blood clot that partially or completely blocks the vein </detail><detail> Kidney tumor </detail><detail>Vein problem </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Venogram - renal</detail><detail> Venography</detail><detail> Venogram - kidney</detail><detail> Renal vein thrombosis - venogram</detail>

item.title: Renal scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your provider if you take any nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or blood pressure medicines. These drugs might affect the test.</text><text>You may be asked to drink additional fluids before the scan.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A renal scan tells your provider how your kidneys work. It also shows their size, position, and shape. It may be done if: </text><detail>You cannot have other x-rays using contrast (dye) material because you are sensitive or allergic to them, or you have reduced kidney function</detail><detail>You have had a kidney transplant and your doctor wants to check how well the kidney is working and look for signs of rejection</detail><detail>You have high blood pressure and your doctor wants to see how well your kidneys are working </detail><detail>Your provider needs to confirm if a kidney that looks swollen or blocked on another x-ray is losing function</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results are a sign of reduced kidney function. This may be due to:</text><detail>Acute or chronic kidney failure</detail><detail>Chronic kidney infection (pyelonephritis)</detail><detail>Complications of a kidney transplant</detail><detail> Glomerulonephritis </detail><detail>Hydronephrosis</detail><detail> Injury of the kidney and ureter </detail><detail>Narrowing or blockage of the arteries that carry blood to the kidney</detail><detail>Obstructive uropathy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Renogram</detail><detail> Kidney scan</detail>

item.title: Renal perfusion scintiscan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked to drink plenty of water before the test.</text><text>If you are currently taking an ACE inhibitor for high blood pressure , you may be asked to stop taking your medicine before the exam. Always talk to your provider before you stop any of your medicines.</text><text>You may be asked to wear a hospital gown. Remove all jewelry and metallic objects before the scan.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test evaluates blood flow to the kidneys. It is used to diagnose narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys. This is a condition called renal artery stenosis. Significant renal artery stenosis may be a cause of high blood pressure and kidney problems.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Blood flow to the kidneys appears normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal findings on the scan may be a sign of renal artery stenosis. A similar study that does not use an ACE inhibitor can be done to confirm the diagnosis. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Renal perfusion scintigraphy</detail><detail> Radionuclide renal perfusion scan</detail><detail> Perfusion scintiscan - renal</detail><detail> Scintiscan - renal perfusion</detail>

item.title: Renal arteriography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider if:</text><detail>You are pregnant</detail><detail>You have ever had any bleeding problems</detail><detail>You currently take blood thinners, including daily aspirin</detail><detail>You ever had any allergic reactions , especially those related to x-ray contrast material or iodine substances</detail><detail>You have ever been diagnosed with kidney failure or poorly functioning kidneys </detail><text>You must sign a consent form. DO NOT eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test. You will be given a hospital gown to wear and asked to remove all jewelry. You may be given a pain pill (sedative) before the procedure or IV sedatives during the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Renal arteriography is often needed to help decide on the best treatment after other tests are done first. These include duplex ultrasound , CT abdomen, or a CT angiogram. These tests may show the following problems.</text><detail>Abnormal widening of an artery, called an aneurysm </detail><detail>Abnormal connections between veins and arteries ( fistulas )</detail><detail> Blood clot blocking an artery supplying the kidney </detail><detail>Unexplained high blood pressure thought to be due to narrowing of the blood vessels of the kidneys </detail><detail>Benign tumors and cancers involving the kidneys</detail><detail>Active bleeding from the kidney </detail><text>This test is often used to examine donors and recipients before a kidney transplant. The result determines the number of arteries and veins on each kidney.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results may vary. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Renal angiography may show the presence of tumors, narrowing of the artery or aneurysms (widening of the vein or artery), blood clots, fistulas, or bleeding in the kidney.</text><text>The test may also be done with the following conditions: </text><detail> Blockage of an artery by a blood clot </detail><detail>Renal artery stenosis</detail><detail> Renal cell cancer </detail><detail>Angiomyolipomas (noncancerous tumors of the kidney) </detail><text>Some of these problems can be treated with techniques done at the same time the arteriogram is performed.</text><detail>Angioplasty is a procedure to open a narrowed or blocked blood vessels that supply blood to your kidneys.</detail><detail>A stent is a small, metal mesh tube that keeps the artery open. It may be placed to keep a narrowed artery open.</detail><detail>Cancers and noncancerous tumors can be treated using a process called embolization. This involves using substances that block blood flow in order to kill or shrink the tumor. Sometimes, this is performed in combination with surgery.</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Renal angiogram</detail><detail> Angiography - kidney</detail><detail> Renal angiography</detail><detail> Renal artery stenosis - arteriography</detail>

item.title: Refraction
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If you wear contact lenses, ask the doctor if you need to remove them and for how long before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test can be done as part of a routine eye exam . The purpose is to determine whether you have a refractive error (a need for glasses or contact lenses).</text><text>For people over age 40 who have normal distance vision but difficulty with near vision, a refraction test can determine the right power of reading glasses.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>If your uncorrected vision (without glasses or contact lenses) is normal, then the refractive error is zero (plano) and your vision should be 20/20 (or 1.0).</text><text>A value of 20/20 (1.0) is normal vision. This means you can read 3/8-inch (1 centimeter) letters at 20 feet (6 meters). A small type size is also used to determine normal near vision.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>You have a refractive error if you need a combination of lenses to see 20/20 (1.0). Glasses or contact lenses should give you good vision. If you have a refractive error, you have a "prescription." Your prescription is a series of numbers that describe the powers of the lenses needed to make you see clearly.</text><text>If your final vision is less than 20/20 (1.0), even with lenses, then there is probably another, non-optical problem with your eye.</text><text>The vision level you achieve during the refraction test is called the best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA).</text><text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Astigmatism (abnormally curved cornea causing blurred vision)</detail><detail> Hyperopia (farsightedness)</detail><detail> Myopia (nearsightedness)</detail><detail> Presbyopia (inability to focus on near objects that develops with age) </detail><text>Other conditions under which the test may be performed:</text><detail> Corneal ulcers and infections </detail><detail>Loss of sharp vision due to macular degeneration </detail><detail> Retinal detachment (separation of the light-sensitive membrane (retina) in the back of the eye from its supporting layers)</detail><detail> Retinal vessel occlusion (blockage in a small artery that carries blood to the retina)</detail><detail> Retinitis pigmentosa (an inherited disorder of the retina)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Eye exam - refraction</detail><detail> Vision test - refraction</detail><detail> Refraction</detail>

item.title: Rectal culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The health care provider does a rectal exam and collects the specimen.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done if your provider suspects that you have an infection of the rectum, such as gonorrhea . It may also be done instead of a fecal culture if it is not possible to get a specimen of feces.</text><text>The rectal culture may also be performed in a hospital or nursing home setting. This test shows if someone carries vancomycin-resistant enterococcus (VRE) in their intestine. This germ can be spread to other patients.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Finding bacteria and other germs that are commonly found in the body is normal.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different labs. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean you have an infection. This may be:</text><detail>Bacterial infection</detail><detail>Parasitic enterocolitis</detail><detail> Gonorrhea</detail><text>Sometimes a culture shows that you are a carrier, but you may not have an infection.</text><text>A related condition is proctitis .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - rectal</detail>

item.title: Rectal biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may get a laxative, enema, or other preparation before the biopsy so that you can completely empty your bowel. This will allow the doctor a clear view of the rectum.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A rectal biopsy is used to determine the cause of abnormal growths found during anoscopy, sigmoidoscopy, or other tests. It can also be used to confirm the diagnosis of amyloidosis .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The anus and rectum appear normal in size, color, and shape. There should be no evidence of: </text><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Polyps</detail><detail> Hemorrhoids </detail><detail>Other abnormalities </detail><text>No problems are seen when the biopsy tissue is examined under a microscope.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>This test is a common way to determine the specific causes of abnormal conditions of the rectum, such as:</text><detail> Abscesses </detail><detail> Colorectal polyps </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Tumors</detail><detail>Amyloidosis</detail><detail> Crohn disease </detail><detail> Hirschsprung disease in infants</detail><detail> Ulcerative colitis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - rectum</detail><detail> Rectal bleeding - biopsy</detail><detail> Rectal polyps - biopsy</detail><detail> Amyloidosis - rectal biopsy</detail><detail> Crohn disease - rectal biopsy</detail><detail> Colorectal cancer - biopsy</detail><detail> Hirschsprung disease - rectal biopsy</detail>

item.title: RBC urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done as part of a urinalysis test .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is 4 red blood cells per high power field (RBC/HPF) or less when the sample is examined under a microscope.</text><text>The example above is a common measurement for a result of this test. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal number of RBCs in the urine may be due to:</text><detail>Kidney and other urinary tract problems, such as infection, tumor , or stones </detail><detail> Kidney injury </detail><detail>Prostate problems</detail><detail>Bladder or kidney cancer </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Red blood cells in urine</detail><detail> Hematuria test</detail><detail> Urine - red blood cells</detail>

item.title: RBC nuclear scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need to sign a consent form. You put on a hospital gown and take off jewelry or metallic objects before the scan.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to find the site of bleeding. It is done in people who have blood loss from the colon or other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.</text><text>A similar test called a ventriculogram may be done to check heart function.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal exam shows no rapid bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>There is active bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Bleeding scan, Tagged RBC scan</detail><detail> Hemorrhage - RBC scan</detail>

item.title: RBC indices
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Hemoglobin transports oxygen. RBCs carry hemoglobin and oxygen to our body's cells. The RBC indices test measures how well the RBCs do this. The results are used to diagnose different types of anemia .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>These test results are in the normal range:</text><detail>MCV: 80 to 100 femtoliter</detail><detail>MCH: 27 to 31 picograms/cell</detail><detail>MCHC: 32 to 36 grams/deciliter (g/dL) or 320 to 360 grams per liter (g/L)</detail><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>These test results indicate the type of anemia:</text><detail>MCV below normal. Microcytic anemia (may be due to low iron levels, lead poisoning, or thalassemia ).</detail><detail>MCV normal. Normocytic anemia (may be due to sudden blood loss, long-term diseases, kidney failure , aplastic anemia , or man-made heart valves).</detail><detail>MCV above normal. Macrocytic anemia (may be due to low folate or B12 levels, or chemotherapy ).</detail><detail>MCH below normal. Hypochromic anemia (often due to low iron levels).</detail><detail>MCH normal. Normochromic anemia (may be due to sudden blood loss, long-term diseases, kidney failure, aplastic anemia, or man-made heart valves).</detail><detail>MCH above normal. Hyperchromic anemia (may be due to low folate or B12 levels, or chemotherapy). </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Erythrocyte indices</detail><detail> Blood indices</detail><detail> Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH)</detail><detail> Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)</detail><detail> Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)</detail><detail> Red blood cell indices</detail>

item.title: RBC count
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The RBC count is almost always part of a complete blood count ( CBC ) test.</text><text>The test can help diagnose different kinds of anemia (low number of RBCs) and other conditions affecting red blood cells.</text><text>Other conditions that may require an RBC count are:</text><detail>Disease that damages kidney blood vessels ( Alport syndrome )</detail><detail>White blood cell cancer ( Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia )</detail><detail>Disorder in which red blood cells break down earlier than normal ( paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria )</detail><detail>Bone marrow disorder in which the marrow is replaced by scar tissue (myelofibrosis) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal RBC ranges are:</text><detail>Male: 4.7 to 6.1 million cells per microliter (cells/mcL)</detail><detail>Female: 4.2 to 5.4 million cells/mcL</detail><text>The ranges above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher than normal numbers of RBCs may be due to:</text><detail>Cigarette smoking</detail><detail>Problem with heart's structure and function that is present at birth ( congenital heart disease )</detail><detail>Failure of the right side of the heart ( cor pulmonale )</detail><detail> Dehydration (for example, from severe diarrhea)</detail><detail>Kidney tumor (renal cell carcinoma)</detail><detail>Low blood oxygen level (hypoxia)</detail><detail>Scarring or thickening of the lungs ( pulmonary fibrosis )</detail><detail>Bone marrow disease that causes abnormal increase in RBCs ( polycythemia vera ) </detail><text>Your RBC count will increase for several weeks when you are in a higher altitude.</text><text>Drugs that can increase the RBC count include:</text><detail>Gentamicin</detail><detail>Methyldopa </detail><text>Lower-than-normal numbers of RBCs may be due to:</text><detail> Anemia </detail><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Bone marrow failure (for example, from radiation, toxins, or tumor)</detail><detail>Deficiency of a hormone called erythropoietin (caused by kidney disease)</detail><detail>RBC destruction ( hemolysis ) due to transfusion, blood vessel injury, or other cause</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail>Bone marrow cancer called multiple myeloma </detail><detail>Too little iron, copper , folic acid, vitamin B6 , or vitamin B12 in the diet</detail><detail>Too much water in the body (overhydration)</detail><detail>Pregnancy </detail><text>Drugs that can decrease the RBC count include:</text><detail>Chemotherapy drugs</detail><detail>Chloramphenicol</detail><detail>Hydantoins</detail><detail>Quinidine </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Erythrocyte count</detail><detail> Red blood cell count</detail><detail> Anemia - RBC count</detail>

item.title: Radionuclide cystogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation needed. You will need to sign a consent form. You will be asked to wear a hospital gown. Remove jewelry and metal objects before the scan.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see how your bladder empties and fills. It can be used to check for urine reflux or a blockage in urine flow. It is most often done to evaluate people with urinary tract infections, particularly children.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value is no reflux or other abnormal urine flow, and no obstruction to the flow of urine. The bladder empties completely.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abnormal bladder response to pressure. This could be due to a nerve problem or other disorder.</detail><detail>Back flow of urine (vesicoureteric reflux) </detail><detail>Blockage of the urethra ( urethral obstruction ). This is most commonly due to an enlarged prostate gland. </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Nuclear bladder scan</detail>

item.title: Radionuclide cisternogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time, you do not need to prepare for this test. Your health care provider may give you a medicine to calm your nerves if you are very anxious. You will sign a consent form before the test.</text><text>You will wear a hospital gown during the scan so the doctors have access to your spine. You will also need to remove jewelry or metallic objects before the scan.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed to detect problems with flow of spinal fluid and spinal fluid leaks. In some cases, there may be a concern the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) fluid is leaking after a trauma to the head or a surgery in the head. This test will be done to diagnose the leak.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value indicates normal circulation of CSF through all parts of the brain and spinal cord.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result indicates disorders of CSF circulation. These disorders may include:</text><detail> Hydrocephalus or dilated spaces in your brain due to an obstruction</detail><detail> CSF leak </detail><detail> Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) </detail><detail>Whether or not a CSF shunt is open or blocked </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CSF flow scan</detail><detail> Cisternogram</detail>

item.title: Radioactive iodine uptake
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions about not eating before the test. You may be told not to eat after midnight the night before your test.</text><text>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking medicines before the test that may affect your test results. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text><text>Tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Diarrhea (may decrease absorption of the radioactive iodine)</detail><detail>Had recent CT scans using intravenous or oral iodine-based contrast (within the past 2 weeks)</detail><detail>Too little or too much iodine in your diet </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check thyroid function. It is often done when blood tests of thyroid function show that you may have an overactive thyroid gland.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>These are normal results at 6 and 24 hours after swallowing the radioactive iodine:</text><detail>At 6 hours: 3% to 16%</detail><detail>At 24 hours: 8% to 25% </detail><text>Some testing centers measure only at 24 hours. Values may vary depending on the amount of iodine in your diet. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different labs. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal uptake may be due to an overactive thyroid gland. The most common cause is Graves disease .</text><text>Other conditions can cause some areas of higher-than-normal uptake in the thyroid gland. These include:</text><detail>An enlarged thyroid gland that contains nodules producing too much thyroid hormone ( toxic nodular goiter )</detail><detail>A single thyroid nodule that is producing too much thyroid hormone (toxic adenoma) </detail><text>These conditions often result in normal uptake, but the uptake is concentrated into a few (hot) areas while the rest of the thyroid gland does not take up any iodine (cold areas). This can only be determined if the scan is done along with the uptake test.</text><text>Lower-than-normal uptake may be due to:</text><detail> Factitious hyperthyroidism (taking too much thyroid hormone medicine or supplements)</detail><detail>Iodine overload</detail><detail> Subacute thyroiditis (swelling or inflammation of the thyroid gland)</detail><detail> Silent (or painless) thyroiditis </detail><detail>Amiodarone (medicine to treat some kinds of heart disease) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thyroid uptake</detail><detail> Iodine uptake test</detail><detail> RAIU</detail>

item.title: Synovial fluid analysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Normally, no special preparation is needed. Tell your provider if you are taking a blood thinner, such as aspirin, warfarin (Coumadin) or clopidogrel (Plavix). These medicines can affect test results or your ability to take the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test can help diagnose the cause of pain, redness, or swelling in joints.</text><text>Sometimes, removing the fluid can also help relieve joint pain.</text><text>This test may be used when your doctor suspects:</text><detail>Bleeding in the joint after a joint injury</detail><detail> Gout and other types of arthritis</detail><detail>Infection in a joint</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal joint fluid may look cloudy or abnormally thick.</text><text>The following found in joint fluid can be a sign of a health problem:</text><detail>Blood -- injury in the joint or a body-wide bleeding problem</detail><detail>Pus -- infection in the joint</detail><detail>Too much joint fluid -- osteoarthritis or cartilage injury</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Joint fluid analysis</detail><detail> Joint fluid aspiration</detail>

item.title: Synovial biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your health care provider's instructions on how to prepare. This may include not eating and drinking anything for several hours before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Synovial biopsy helps diagnose gout and bacterial infections, or rule out other infections. It can be used to diagnose autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, or uncommon infections like tuberculosis. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The synovial membrane structure is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean:
Synovial biopsy may identify the following conditions:Chronic synovitis (inflammation of the synovial membrane) Coccidioidomycosis (a fungal infection) Fungal arthritis Gout Hemochromatosis (abnormal buildup of iron deposits) Systemic lupus erythematosus (autoimmune disease that affects the skin, joints, and other organs)
 Tuberculosis Synovial cancer  (very rare type of soft tissue cancer) Rheumatoid arthritis
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - synovial membrane</detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis - synovial biopsy</detail><detail> Gout - synovial biopsy</detail><detail> Joint infection - synovial biopsy</detail><detail> Synovitis - synovial biopsy</detail>

item.title: Sweat electrolytes test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed before this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Sweat testing is the standard method for diagnosing cystic fibrosis. People with cystic fibrosis have higher amounts of sodium and chloride in their sweat that are detected by the test.</text><text>Some people are tested because of symptoms they are having. In the United States, newborn screening programs test for cystic fibrosis. The sweat test is used to confirm these results.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results include:</text><detail>A sweat chloride test result of less than or equal to 39 mmol/L in an infant over 6 months old probably means cystic fibrosis is very unlikely.</detail><detail>A result between 40 to 59 mmol/L does not give a clear diagnosis. Further testing is needed.</detail><detail>If the result is 60 mmol/L or greater, cystic fibrosis is present. </detail><text>Note: mmol/L = millimole per liter</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>Some conditions, such as dehydration or swelling (edema) can affect the test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal test may mean that the child has cystic fibrosis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Sweat test</detail><detail> Sweat chloride</detail><detail> Iontophoretic sweat test</detail><detail> CF - sweat test</detail><detail> Cystic fibrosis - sweat test</detail>

item.title: Swan-Ganz - right heart catheterization
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink anything for 8 hours before the test starts. You may need to stay in the hospital the night before the test. Otherwise, you will check in to the hospital the morning of the test.</text><text>You will wear a hospital gown. You must sign a consent form before the test. Your provider will explain the procedure and its risks.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The procedure is done to evaluate how the blood moves (circulates) in people who have:</text><detail>Abnormal pressures in the heart arteries</detail><detail> Burns </detail><detail> Congenital heart disease </detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail> Leaky heart valves </detail><detail>Lung problems</detail><detail> Shock </detail><text>It may also be done to monitor for complications of a heart attack . It also shows how well certain heart medicines are working.</text><text>Swan-Ganz catheterization can also be used to detect abnormal blood flow between two areas of the heart that are not normally connected.</text><text>Conditions that can also be diagnosed or evaluated with Swan-Ganz catheterization include:</text><detail> Cardiac tamponade </detail><detail> Pulmonary hypertension </detail><detail> Restrictive cardiomyopathy </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results for this test are:</text><detail>Cardiac index is 2.8 to 4.2 liters per minute per square meter (of body surface area)</detail><detail>Pulmonary artery systolic pressure is 17 to 32 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg)</detail><detail>Pulmonary artery mean pressure is 9 to 19 mm Hg</detail><detail>Pulmonary diastolic pressure is 4 to 13 mm Hg</detail><detail>Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is 4 to 12 mm Hg</detail><detail>Right atrial pressure is 0 to 7 mm Hg</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Blood flow problems, such as heart failure or shock</detail><detail>Heart valve disease</detail><detail>Lung disease</detail><detail>Structural problems with the heart, such as a shunt from an atrial or ventricular septal defect </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Right heart catheterization</detail><detail> Catheterization - right heart</detail>

item.title: Sugar-water hemolysis test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation needed for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may recommend this test if you have signs or symptoms of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) or hemolytic anemia of unknown cause. Hemolytic anemia is a condition in which red blood cells die before they should. PNH red blood cells are very likely to be harmed by the body's complement system. The complement system is proteins that move through the bloodstream. These proteins work with the immune system.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result is called a negative result. A normal result shows that less than 5% of red blood cells break down when tested. This breakdown is called hemolysis.</text><text>A negative test does not rule out PNH. False-negative results may occur if the fluid part of blood (serum) lacks complement. </text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test result means the results are abnormal. In a positive test, more than 10% of red blood cells break down. It could indicate the person has PNH.</text><text>Certain conditions can make the test results appear positive (called "false positive"). These conditions are autoimmune hemolytic anemias and leukemia.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Sucrose hemolysis test</detail><detail> Hemolytic anemia sugar water hemolysis test</detail><detail> Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria sugar water hemolysis test</detail><detail> PNH sugar water hemolysis test</detail>

item.title: String test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 12 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed when your health care provider suspects that you have a parasite infection. Usually a stool sample is tested first. A string test is done if the stool sample is negative. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No blood, parasites, fungi, or abnormal cells is normal.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign parasite infection such as giardia .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Duodenal parasites test</detail><detail> Giardia - string test</detail>

item.title: Stress echocardiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Ask your provider if you should take any of your routine medicines on the day of the test. Some medicines may interfere with test results. Never stop taking any medicine without first talking to your doctor.</text><text>It is important to tell your doctor if you have taken any of the following medicines within the past 24 hours (1 day):</text><detail>Sildenafil citrate (Viagra)</detail><detail>Tadalafil (Cialis)</detail><detail>Vardenafil (Levitra) </detail><text>DO NOT eat or drink for at least 3 hours before the test.</text><text>Wear loose, comfortable clothing. You will be asked to sign a consent form before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed to see whether your heart muscle is getting enough blood flow and oxygen when it is working hard (under stress).</text><text>Your doctor may order this test if you:</text><detail>Have new symptoms of angina or chest pain</detail><detail>Have angina that is getting worse</detail><detail>Have recently had a heart attack</detail><detail>Are going to have surgery or begin an exercise program, if you are at high risk for heart disease</detail><detail>Have heart valve problems </detail><text>The results of this stress test can help your provider:</text><detail>Determine how well a heart treatment is working and change your treatment, if needed</detail><detail>Determine how well your heart is pumping</detail><detail>Diagnose coronary artery disease</detail><detail>See whether your heart is too large </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test will most often mean that you were able to exercise as long as or longer than most people of your age and gender. You also did not have symptoms or concerning changes in blood pressure and your ECG. Your heart pictures show that all parts of your heart respond to increased stress by pumping harder.</text><text>A normal result means that blood flow through the coronary arteries is probably normal.</text><text>The meaning of your test results depends on the reason for the test, your age, and your history of heart and other medical problems.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: Abnormal results may be due to:Reduced blood flow to a part of the heart. The most likely cause is a narrowing or blockage of the arteries that supply your heart muscle.Scarring of the heart muscle due to a past heart attack.After the test you may need: Angioplasty and stent placement Changes in your heart medicines Coronary angiography Heart bypass surgery
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Echocardiography stress test</detail><detail> Stress test - echocardiography</detail><detail> CAD - stress echocardiography</detail><detail> Coronary artery disease - stress echocardiography</detail><detail> Chest pain - stress echocardiography</detail><detail> Angina - stress echocardiography</detail><detail> Heart disease - stress echocardiography</detail>

item.title: Streptococcal screen
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation. Tell your health care provider if you are taking antibiotics, or have recently taken them.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may recommend this test if you have signs of strep throat, which include:</text><detail>Fever</detail><detail>Sore throat</detail><detail>Tender and swollen glands at the front of your neck</detail><detail>White or yellow spots on your tonsils </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative strep screen most often means group A streptococcus is not present. It is unlikely that you have strep throat.</text><text>If your provider still thinks that you may have strep throat, a throat culture will be done in children and adolescents.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive strep screen most often means group A streptococcus is present, and confirms that you have strep throat.</text><text>Sometimes, the test may be positive even if you do not have strep. This is called a false-positive result.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Rapid strep test</detail>

item.title: Stool ova and parasites exam
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of parasites, diarrhea that does not go away, or other intestinal symptoms.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There are no parasites or eggs in the stool sample.</text><text>Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means parasites or eggs are present in the stool. This is a sign of a parasitic infection, such as: </text><detail> Amebiasis </detail><detail> Giardiasis </detail><detail> Strongyloidiasis </detail><detail> Taeniasis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Parasites and stool ova exam</detail><detail> Amebiasis - ova and parasites</detail><detail> Giardiasis - ova and parasites</detail><detail> Strongyloidiasis - ova and parasites</detail><detail> Taeniasis - ova and parasites</detail>

item.title: Stool Gram stain
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test to help diagnose an intestinal infection or illness, sometimes involving diarrhea .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means only normal or "friendly" bacteria were seen on the stained slide. Everyone has friendly bacteria in their intestines.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that an intestinal infection may be present. Stool cultures and other tests can also help diagnose the cause of the infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gram stain of stool</detail><detail> Feces Gram stain</detail>

item.title: Stool C difficile toxin
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There are many ways to collect the samples. </text><detail>You can catch the stool on plastic wrap that is loosely placed over the toilet bowl and held in place by the toilet seat. Then you put the sample in a clean container. </detail><detail>A test kit is available that supplies a special toilet tissue that you use to collect the sample. After collecting the sample, you put it in a container.</detail><text>Do not mix urine, water, or toilet tissue with the sample.</text><text>For children wearing diapers:</text><detail>Line the diaper with plastic wrap. </detail><detail>Position the plastic wrap so that it will prevent urine and stool from mixing. This will provide a better sample.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test if your health care provider thinks that diarrhea is caused by the antibiotic medicines you have taken recently. Antibiotics change the balance of bacteria in the colon. This sometimes leads to too much growth of C difficile.</text><text>Diarrhea caused by C difficile after antibiotic use often occurs in people who are in the hospital. It also can occur in people who have not recently taken antibiotics. This condition is called pseudomembranous colitis .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No C difficile toxin is detected.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean that toxins produced by C difficile are seen in the stool and are causing diarrhea.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Antibiotic associated colitis - toxin</detail><detail> Colitis - toxin</detail><detail> Pseudomembranous - toxin</detail><detail> Necrotizing colitis - toxin</detail><detail> C difficile - toxin</detail>

item.title: Stomach acid test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked not to eat or drink for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may recommend this test for the following reasons:</text><detail>To check if anti-ulcer medicines are working</detail><detail>To check if material is coming back up from the small intestine</detail><detail>To test for the cause of ulcers </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal volume of the stomach fluid is 20 to 100 mL and the pH is acidic (1.5 to 3.5). These numbers are converted to actual acid production in units of milliequivalents per hour (mEq/hr) in some cases.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly depending on the lab doing the test. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate:</text><detail>Increased levels of gastrin can cause increased release of acid and may lead to ulcers ( Zollinger-Ellison syndrome ).</detail><detail>The presence of bile in the stomach indicates material is backing up from the small intestine ( duodenum ). This may be normal. It may also happen after part of the stomach is removed with surgery.</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gastric acid secretion test</detail>

item.title: Standard eye exam
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Make an appointment with an eye doctor (some take walk-in patients). Avoid eye strain on the day of the test. If you wear glasses or contacts, bring them with you. You may need someone to drive you home if the doctor uses eye drops to dilate your pupils.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>All children should have vision screening in a pediatrician's or family practitioner's office around the time when they learn the alphabet, and then every 1 to 2 years afterward. Screening should begin sooner if any eye problems are suspected.</text><text>Between ages 20 and 39:</text><detail> A complete eye exam should be done every 5 to 10 years </detail><detail> Adults who wear contact lenses need yearly eye exams </detail><detail> Certain eye symptoms or disorders may require more frequent exams </detail><text>Adults over age 40 who have no risk factors or ongoing eye conditions should be screened:</text><detail> Every 2 to 4 years for adults ages 40 to 54 </detail><detail> Every 1 to 3 years for adults ages 55 to 64 </detail><detail> Every 1 to 2 years for adults age 65 and older </detail><text>Depending on your risk factors for eye diseases and your current symptoms or illnesses, your eye doctor may recommend that you have exams more often.</text><text>Eye and medical problems that can be found by a routine eye test include:</text><detail>Clouding of the lens of the eye ( cataracts )</detail><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail> Glaucoma </detail><detail> High blood pressure </detail><detail>Loss of sharp, central vision ( age-related macular degeneration , or ARMD)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results of a routine eye exam are normal when the eye doctor finds you have:</text><detail>20/20 (normal) vision</detail><detail>Ability to identify different colors</detail><detail>Full visual field</detail><detail>Proper eye muscle coordination</detail><detail>Normal eye pressure</detail><detail>Normal eye structures (cornea, iris, lens) </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to any of the following:</text><detail>ARMD</detail><detail> Astigmatism (abnormally curved cornea)</detail><detail> Blocked tear duct </detail><detail>Cataracts</detail><detail>Color blindness</detail><detail> Corneal abrasion (or dystrophy)</detail><detail> Corneal ulcers and infections </detail><detail>Damaged nerves or blood vessels in the eye</detail><detail>Diabetes-related damage in the eye ( diabetic retinopathy )</detail><detail> Hyperopia (farsightedness)</detail><detail>Glaucoma</detail><detail>Injury of the eye</detail><detail> Lazy eye (amblyopia)</detail><detail> Myopia (nearsightedness)</detail><detail> Presbyopia (inability to focus on near objects that develops with age)</detail><detail> Strabismus (crossed eyes)</detail><text>This list may not include all possible causes of abnormal results.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Standard ophthalmic exam</detail><detail> Routine eye examination</detail><detail> Eye exam - standard</detail><detail> Annual eye exam</detail>

item.title: Sputum stain for mycobacteria
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Drinking a lot of fluids the night before the test helps your lungs produce phlegm. It makes the test more accurate if it is done first thing in the morning.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed when the doctor suspects tuberculosis or other mycobacterium infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are normal when no mycobacterial organisms are found.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results show that the stain is positive for:</text><detail>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</detail><detail>Mycobacterium avium-intracellular</detail><detail>Other mycobacteria or acid-fast bacteria</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Acid fast bacilli stain</detail><detail> AFB stain</detail><detail> Tuberculosis smear</detail><detail> TB smear</detail>

item.title: Sputum Gram stain
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Drinking a lot of fluids the night before the test helps your lungs produce phlegm. It makes the test more accurate if it is done first thing in the morning.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have a persistent or prolonged cough, or if you are coughing up material that has a foul odor or unusual color. The test may also be done if you have other signs and symptoms of respiratory disease or infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means that few to no white blood cells and no bacteria were seen in the sample. The sputum is clear, thin, and odorless.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that bacteria is seen in the test sample. You may have a bacterial infection. A culture is needed to confirm the diagnosis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gram stain of sputum</detail>

item.title: Sputum fungal smear
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have symptoms or signs of a lung infection, such as if you have a weakened immune system due to certain medicines or diseases such as cancer or HIV/AIDS. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal (negative) result means no fungus was seen in the test sample. </text><text>Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign of a fungal infection. Such infections include:</text><detail> Aspergillosis </detail><detail> Blastomycosis </detail><detail> Coccidioidomycosis </detail><detail> Cryptococcosis </detail><detail> Histoplasmosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>KOH test</detail><detail> Fungal smear - sputum</detail><detail> Fungal wet prep</detail><detail> Wet prep - fungal</detail>

item.title: Sputum direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If coughing does not produce sputum, a breathing treatment may be given before the test to trigger sputum production.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order this test if you have signs of certain lung infections.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, there is no antigen-antibody reaction.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to an infection such as:</text><detail> Legionnaire disease </detail><detail> Pneumonia due to certain bacteria</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Direct immunofluorescence test</detail><detail> Direct fluorescent antibody - sputum</detail>

item.title: Sodium urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that may affect the test result. Tell your provider about all the medicines you take, including:</text><detail>Corticosteroids</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail>Prostaglandins (used to treat conditions such as glaucoma or stomach ulcers)</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics) </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is often used to help determine the cause of an abnormal sodium blood level. It also checks whether your kidneys are removing sodium from the body. It may be used to diagnose or monitor many types of kidney diseases.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>For adults, normal urine sodium values are generally 20 mEq/L in a random urine sample and 40 to 220 mEq/L per day. Your result depends on how much fluid and salt you take in.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal urine sodium level may be due to:</text><detail>Certain medicines, such as water pills (diuretics)</detail><detail>Low function of the adrenal glands </detail><detail>Inflammation of the kidney that results in salt loss (salt-losing nephropathy)</detail><detail>Too much salt in the diet </detail><text>A lower than normal urine sodium level may be a sign of:</text><detail> Adrenal glands releasing too much hormone ( hyperaldosteronism )</detail><detail>Not enough fluid in the body (dehydration)</detail><detail>Diarrhea and fluid loss</detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Kidney problems, such as long-term (chronic) kidney disease or kidney failure </detail><detail>Scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis ) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urinary 24 hours sodium</detail><detail> Urine Na+</detail>

item.title: Sodium blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test. These include:</text><detail>Antibiotics</detail><detail>Antidepressants</detail><detail>Some high blood pressure medicines</detail><detail>Lithium</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics)</detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Sodium is a substance that the body needs to work properly. Sodium is found in most foods. The most common form of sodium is sodium chloride, which is table salt. </text><text>This test is usually done as part of an electrolyte or basic metabolic panel blood test . </text><text>Your blood sodium level represents a balance between the sodium and water in the food and drinks you consume and the amount in your urine. A small amount is lost through stool and sweat. </text><text>Many things can affect this balance. Your provider may order this test if you:</text><detail>Have had a recent injury, surgery, or serious illness</detail><detail>Consume large or small amounts of salt or fluid</detail><detail>Receive intravenous (IV) fluids</detail><detail>Take diuretics (water pills) or certain other medicines, including the hormone aldosterone </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range for blood sodium levels is 135 to 145 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal sodium level can be due to many different conditions. </text><text>Higher than normal sodium level is called hypernatremia. It may be due to:</text><detail>Increased fluid loss due to excessive sweating, diarrhea, burns, or use of diuretics</detail><detail>Adrenal gland problems such as Cushing syndrome or hyperaldosteronism </detail><detail> Diabetes insipidus (type of diabetes in which kidneys are not able to conserve water)</detail><detail>Too much salt or sodium bicarbonate in the diet</detail><detail>Use of certain medicines, including corticosteroids, laxatives, lithium, and medicines such as ibuprofen or naproxen </detail><text>Lower than normal sodium level is called hyponatremia. It may be due to:</text><detail>Use of medicines such as diuretics (water pills), morphine, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressants</detail><detail>Increased fluid loss from body, vomiting, or diarrhea</detail><detail>Increase in total body water seen in those with heart failure, certain kidney diseases, or cirrhosis of the liver</detail><detail>Adrenal glands not making enough of their hormones ( Addison disease )</detail><detail>Buildup in urine of waste product from fat breakdown (ketonuria)</detail><detail> Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (antidiuretic hormone is released from an abnormal place in the body)</detail><detail>Too much of the hormone vasopressin </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum sodium</detail><detail> Sodium - serum</detail>

item.title: Smear of duodenal fluid aspirate
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Do not eat or drink anything for 12 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to look for infection of the small bowel. However, it is not often needed. In most cases, this test is only done when a diagnosis cannot be made with other tests. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There should be no disease-causing organisms in the duodenum. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The results may show the presence of giardia protozoa, the intestinal parasite strongyloides, or another infectious organism.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Duodenal aspirated fluid smear</detail>

item.title: Small intestine aspirate and culture
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs of too much bacteria growing in the intestinal tract. In most cases, other tests are done first.</text><text>Normally, small amounts of bacteria are present in the small intestine and they do not cause disease. However, the test may be done when your doctor suspects that excess growth of intestinal bacteria is causing diarrhea.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No bacteria should be found.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign of infection.</text>

item.title: Small bowel tissue smear
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need to have an EGD procedure for the sample to be taken. Prepare for this procedure in the way your health care provider recommends.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test to look for an infection or other disease of the small intestine. In most cases, this test is done only when a diagnosis could not be made using stool and blood tests.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means that there were no indicators of disease when the sample was examined under the microscope.</text><text>The small intestine normally contains certain healthy bacteria and yeast. Their presence is not a sign of disease.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that certain microorganisms, such as the parasites giardia or strongyloides were seen in the tissue sample. It may also mean that there were changes in the structure (anatomy) of the tissue.</text>

item.title: Slit-lamp exam
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to examine the: </text><detail> Conjunctiva (the thin membrane that covers the inner surface of the eyelid and the white part of the eyeball)</detail><detail>Cornea (the clear outer lens on the front of the eye)</detail><detail>Eyelids</detail><detail> Iris (colored part of the eye between the cornea and lens)</detail><detail>Lens</detail><detail> Sclera (the white outer coating of the eye)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Structures in the eye are found to be normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The slit lamp exam may detect many diseases of the eye, including:</text><detail>Clouding of the lens of the eye ( cataract )</detail><detail> Injury to the cornea </detail><detail> Dry eye syndrome </detail><detail>Loss of sharp vision due to macular degeneration </detail><detail>Separation of the retina from its supporting layers ( retinal detachment )</detail><detail>Blockage in a small artery or vein that carries blood to or from the retina ( retinal vessel occlusion )</detail><detail>Inherited degeneration of the retina ( retinitis pigmentosa )</detail><detail>Swelling and irritation of the uvea ( uveitis ), the middle layer of the eye </detail><text>This list does not include all possible diseases of the eye.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biomicroscopy</detail>

item.title: Skull x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the health care provider if you are pregnant or think you are pregnant. Remove all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order this x-ray if you have injured your skull. You may also have this x-ray if you have symptoms or signs of a structural problem inside the skull, such as a tumor or bleeding.</text><text>A skull x-ray is also used to evaluate an unusually shaped child's head.</text><text>Other conditions for which the test may be performed include:</text><detail>Teeth are not aligned properly ( malocclusion of teeth )</detail><detail>Infection of the mastoid bone ( mastoiditis )</detail><detail> Occupational hearing loss </detail><detail>Middle ear infection ( otitis media )</detail><detail>Abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that causes hearing loss ( otosclerosis )</detail><detail> Pituitary tumor </detail><detail>Sinus infection ( sinusitis ) </detail><text>Sometimes skull x-rays are used to screen for foreign bodies that may interfere with other tests, such as an MRI scan .</text><text>A CT scan of the head is usually preferred to a skull x-ray to evaluate most head injuries or brain disorders. Skull x-rays are rarely used as the main test to diagnose such conditions. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Fracture</detail><detail>Tumor</detail><detail>Breakdown ( erosion ) or calcium loss of the bone</detail><detail>Movement of the soft tissues inside the skull </detail><text>A skull x-ray may detect increased intracranial pressure and unusual skull structures that are present at birth (congenital).</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - head</detail><detail> X-ray - skull</detail><detail> Skull radiography</detail><detail> Head x-ray</detail>

item.title: Skin lesion KOH exam
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to diagnose a fungal infection of the skin.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No fungus is present.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Fungus is present. The fungus may be related to ringworm , athlete's foot , jock itch , or another fungal infection.</text><text>If the results are uncertain, a skin biopsy may need to be done.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Potassium hydroxide examination of skin lesion</detail>

item.title: Skin lesion biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text> Tell your provider:</text><detail>About the medicines you are taking, including vitamins and supplements, herbal remedies, and over-the-counter medicines</detail><detail>If you have any allergies </detail><detail>If you have bleeding problems or take a blood thinner drug such as aspirin, warfarin, clopidogrel, dabigatran, apixaban, or other drugs</detail><detail>If you are or think you might be pregnant</detail><text>Follow your provider's instructions on how to prepare for the biopsy.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: Your provider may order a skin biopsy:To diagnose the cause of a skin rashTo make sure a skin growth or skin lesion is not skin cancer
item.NormalResults: The tissue that was removed is examined under a microscope. Results are most often returned in a few days to a week or more.If a skin lesion is benign (not cancer), you may not need any further treatment. If the whole skin lesion was not removed at the time of biopsy, you and your provider may decide to completely remove it.
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Once the biopsy confirms the diagnosis, your provider will start a treatment plan. A few of the skin problems that may be diagnosed are:</text><detail> Psoriasis or dermatitis</detail><detail>Infection from bacteria or fungus</detail><detail> Melanoma </detail><detail> Basal cell skin cancer </detail><detail> Squamous cell skin cancer </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Skin biopsy</detail><detail> Shave biopsy - skin</detail><detail> Punch biopsy - skin</detail><detail> Excisional biopsy - skin</detail><detail> Incisional biopsy - skin</detail><detail> Skin cancer - biopsy</detail><detail> Melanoma - biopsy</detail><detail> Squamous cell cancer - biopsy</detail><detail> Basal cell cancer - biopsy</detail><detail> Mohs microsurgery</detail>

item.title: Sinus x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the doctor or x-ray technologist if you are or think you are pregnant. You will be asked to remove all jewelry. You may be asked to change into a gown.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The sinuses are located behind the forehead, nasal bones, cheeks, and eyes. When the sinus openings become blocked or too much mucus builds up, bacteria and other germs can grow. This can lead to an infection and inflammation of the sinuses called sinusitis .</text><text>A sinus x-ray is ordered when you have any of the following:</text><detail>Symptoms of sinusitis</detail><detail>Other sinus disorders, such as a deviated septum (crooked or bent septum, the structure that separates the nostrils)</detail><detail>Symptoms of another infection of that area of the head</detail><text>These days, a sinus x-ray is not often ordered. This is because a CT scan of the sinuses shows more detail.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The x-ray may detect an infection, blockages, bleeding or tumors.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Paranasal sinus radiography</detail><detail> X-ray - sinuses</detail>

item.title: Sinus MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before the test, tell the radiologist if you have kidney problems. This may affect whether you can have IV contrast.</text><text>If you fear confined spaces (have claustrophobia), tell your doctor before the exam. You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your health care provider may also recommend an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>The strong magnetic fields created during an MRI can interfere with pacemakers and other implants. People with most cardiac pacemakers cannot have an MRI and should not enter an MRI area.</text><text>You may not be able to have an MRI if you have any of the following metallic objects in your body:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents</detail><detail>Pain pumps</detail><text>Tell your provider if you have one of these devices when scheduling the test, so the exact type of metal can be determined.</text><text>Before an MRI, sheet metal workers or people that may have been exposed to small metal fragments should receive a skull x-ray. This is to check for metal in the eyes.</text><text>Because the MRI contains a magnet, metal-containing objects such as pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room. This can be dangerous, so they are not allowed into the scanner area.</text><text>Other metallic objects are also not allowed into the room:</text><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test provides detailed pictures of the sinuses.
