Your doctor may order this test if you have:</text><detail>Abnormal nasal drainage</detail><detail>An abnormal finding on an x-ray or nasal endoscopy</detail><detail>Birth defect of the sinuses</detail><detail> Loss of smell </detail><detail>Nasal airway blockage that does not get better with treatment</detail><detail>Repeated bloody noses ( epistaxis )</detail><detail>Signs of injury to the sinus area</detail><detail>Unexplained headaches</detail><detail>Unexplained sinus pain that does not get better with treatment </detail><text>Your provider may also order this test to:</text><detail>Determine if nasal polyps have spread beyond the nose area</detail><detail>Evaluate an infection or abscess</detail><detail>Identify a mass or tumor, including cancer</detail><detail>Plan sinus surgery or monitor your progress after surgery </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if the organs and structures being examined are normal in appearance.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Different types of tissues send back different MRI signals. Healthy tissue will send back a slightly different signal than cancerous tissue.</text><text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Cancer or tumor</detail><detail>Infection in the bones of the sinuses (osteomyelitis)</detail><detail>Infection of the tissues surrounding the eye (orbital cellulitis)</detail><detail>Nasal polyps</detail><detail>Sinusitis -- acute</detail><detail>Sinusitis -- chronic</detail><text>Talk to your provider if you have questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI of the sinuses</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - sinuses</detail><detail> Maxillary sinus MRI</detail>

item.title: Sinus CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>For some tests, you will need to have a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays. </text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.</detail><detail>Let your provider know if you have kidney problems. Contrast may not be used if this is the case.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps to prepare. </detail><text>If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. </text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the scan. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the sinuses. The test may diagnose or detect:</text><detail>Birth defects in the sinuses</detail><detail>Infection in the bones of the sinuses ( osteomyelitis )</detail><detail>Injury to the face over the sinuses from trauma</detail><detail>Masses and tumors, including cancer</detail><detail> Nasal polyps </detail><detail>The cause of repeated bloody noses ( epistaxis )</detail><detail>Sinus infection ( sinusitis ) </detail><text>The results from this test may also help your provider plan for sinus surgery.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen in the sinuses. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Birth defects</detail><detail>Bone fractures</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail> Polyps in the sinuses</detail><detail>Sinus infection (sinusitis)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - sinus</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - sinus</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - sinus</detail><detail> CT scan - sinus</detail>

item.title: Sigmoidoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you how to prepare for the exam. You will use an enema to empty your bowels. This is usually done 1 hour before the sigmoidoscopy. Often, a second enema may be recommended. Or, your provider may recommend a liquid laxative the night before.</text><text>On the morning of the procedure, you may be asked to fast with the exception of certain medicines. Be sure to discuss this with your provider well in advance. Sometimes, you are asked to follow a clear liquid diet the day before, and sometimes a regular diet is allowed. Again, discuss this with your provider well in advance of your test date.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may recommend this test to look for the cause of:</text><detail>Abdominal pain</detail><detail> Diarrhea , constipation, or other changes in bowel habits</detail><detail>Blood, mucus, or pus in the stool</detail><detail>Weight loss that can't be explained</detail><text>This test can also be used to:</text><detail>Confirm findings of another test or x-rays</detail><detail> Screen for colorectal cancer or polyps </detail><detail>Take a biopsy of a growth</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result will show no problems with the color, texture, and size of the lining of the sigmoid colon, rectal mucosa, rectum, and anus. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results can indicate:</text><detail> Anal fissures </detail><detail> Anorectal abscess </detail><detail>Blockage of the large intestine ( Hirschsprung disease )</detail><detail> Cancer </detail><detail> Colorectal polyps </detail><detail>Diverticulosis (abnormal pouches on the lining of the intestines)</detail><detail> Hemorrhoids </detail><detail>Inflammatory bowel disease</detail><detail>Inflammation or infection ( proctitis and colitis) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Flexible sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Sigmoidoscopy - flexible</detail><detail> Proctoscopy</detail><detail> Proctosigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Rigid sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Colon cancer sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Colorectal sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Rectal sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Gastrointestinal bleeding - sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Rectal bleeding - sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Melena - sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Blood in stool - sigmoidoscopy</detail><detail> Polyps - sigmoidoscopy</detail>

item.title: Sickle cell test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to tell if a person has abnormal hemoglobin that causes sickle cell disease and sickle cell trait. Hemoglobin is a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen.</text><text>In sickle cell disease, a person has two abnormal hemoglobin S genes. A person with sickle cell trait has only one of these abnormal genes and no symptoms, or only mild ones.</text><text>This test does not tell the difference between these two conditions. Another test, called hemoglobin electrophoresis , will be done to tell which condition someone has.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result is called a negative result.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal test result indicates the person might have one of these:</text><detail>Sickle cell disease</detail><detail>Sickle cell trait </detail><text>Iron deficiency or blood transfusions within the past 3 months can cause a false negative result. This means the person might have the abnormal hemoglobin for sickle cell, but these other factors are making their test results appear negative (normal).</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Sickledex</detail><detail> Hgb S test</detail>

value.img_name: Red blood cells, multiple sickle cells
Red blood cells, sickle and Pappenheimer

item.title: Sialogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the health care provider if you are:</text><detail>Pregnant</detail><detail>Allergic to x-ray contrast material or any iodine substance</detail><detail> Allergic to any drugs </detail><text>You must sign a consent form. You will need to rinse your mouth with germ-killing (antiseptic) solution before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A sialogram may be done when your provider thinks you might have a disorder of the salivary ducts or glands.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may suggest: </text><detail>Narrowing of the salivary ducts </detail><detail> Salivary gland infection or inflammation </detail><detail> Salivary duct stones </detail><detail> Salivary duct tumor </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ptyalography</detail><detail> Sialography</detail>

item.title: Shoulder MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your doctor if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious (sedative). Your doctor may also suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your health care provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail> Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed in the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>MRI is useful for diagnosing and evaluating sports injuries. It can provide clear pictures of parts of the shoulder (such as soft tissues) that are hard to see clearly on CT scans.</text><text>Your provider may order this test if you have:</text><detail>A mass that can be felt during a physical exam</detail><detail>An abnormal finding on an x-ray or bone scan</detail><detail>Shoulder pain and fever</detail><detail>Decreased motion of the shoulder joint</detail><detail>Fluid buildup in the shoulder joint</detail><detail>Redness or swelling of the shoulder joint</detail><detail>Shoulder instability</detail><detail>Shoulder weakness</detail><detail>Shoulder pain and a history of cancer</detail><detail>Shoulder pain that does not get better with treatment </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no problems were seen in your shoulder and surrounding tissue in the images.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Some possible causes of abnormal results may be:</text><detail>Abscess</detail><detail>Bone infection (osteomyelitis)</detail><detail>Broken or fractured shoulder bone</detail><detail>Bursitis in the shoulder area</detail><detail>Biceps tear</detail><detail>Abnormal Osteonecrosis (vascular necrosis)</detail><detail>Rotator cuff tear</detail><detail>Rotator cuff tendinitis</detail><detail>Shoulder inflammation (frozen shoulder)</detail><detail>Tumor (including cancer)</detail><detail>Labral tear</detail><detail>Cyst in the shoulder </detail><text>This list does not include all possible problems. Talk to your provider with any questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI - shoulder</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - shoulder</detail>

item.title: Shoulder CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage) because you may need to take extra precautions. </detail><text>If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts.</text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the shoulder. The test may help diagnose or detect:</text><detail>A dislocation , fracture , or other shoulder injury</detail><detail>Evaluate the soft tissue such as rotator cuff tendons</detail><detail> Abscess or infection</detail><detail>The cause of pain or other problems in the shoulder joint when MRI cannot be done</detail><detail>Masses and tumors, including cancer </detail><detail>Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery</detail><text>This test may also help guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy in the shoulder area.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if the shoulder being examined is normal in appearance.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Abscess (collection of pus)</detail><detail>Bone tumors or cancer</detail><detail> Dislocated shoulder</detail><detail>Shoulder fracture</detail><detail>Rotator cuff tears</detail><detail>Failure to heal or development of scar tissue after surgery</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - shoulder</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - shoulder</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - shoulder</detail><detail> CT scan - shoulder</detail>

item.title: Serum progesterone
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to:</text><detail>Determine if a woman is ovulating</detail><detail>Evaluate a woman with repeated miscarriages (other tests are used more commonly)</detail><detail>Determine the risk for miscarriage or ectopic pregnancy early in pregnancy</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Progesterone levels vary, depending on the timing when the test is done. Blood progesterone levels start to rise midway through the menstrual cycle. It continues to rise for about 6 to 10 days, and then falls if the egg is not fertilized.</text><text>Levels continue to rise in early pregnancy.</text><text>The following are normal ranges based upon certain phases of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy:</text><detail>Female (pre-ovulation): less than 1 nanogram per mililiter (ng/mL) or 3.18 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)</detail><detail>Female (mid-cycle): 5 to 20 ng/mL or 15.90 to 63.60 nmol/L</detail><detail>Male: less than 1 ng/mL or 3.18 nmol/L</detail><detail>Postmenopausal: less than 1 ng/mL or 3.18 nmol/L</detail><detail>Pregnancy 1st trimester: 11.2 to 90.0 ng/mL or 35.62 to 286.20 nmol/L</detail><detail>Pregnancy 2nd trimester: 25.6 to 89.4 ng/mL or 81.41 to 284.29 nmol/L</detail><detail>Pregnancy 3rd trimester: 48 to 150 to 300 or more ng/mL or 152.64 to 477 to 954 or more nmol/L</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal levels may be due to:</text><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>Adrenal cancer</detail><detail> Ovarian cancer </detail><detail> Congenital adrenal hyperplasia </detail><text>Lower-than-normal levels may be due to:</text><detail>Amenorrhea (no periods as result of anovulation [ovulation does not occur])</detail><detail> Ectopic pregnancy </detail><detail>Irregular periods</detail><detail> Fetal death </detail><detail>Miscarriage</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Progesterone blood test (serum)</detail>

item.title: Serum phenylalanine screening
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>For help preparing your baby for the test, see infant test or procedure preparation (birth to 1 year).</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to screen infants for PKU, a fairly rare condition that occurs when the body lacks a substance needed to breakdown the amino acid phenylalanine.</text><text>If PKU is not detected early, increasing phenylalanine levels in the baby will cause intellectual disability. When discovered early, changes in the diet can help prevent the severe side effects of PKU.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result means that phenylalanine levels are normal and the child does not have PKU.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your baby's test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the screening test results are abnormal, PKU is a possibility. Further testing will be done if the phenylalanine levels in your baby's blood are too high.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Phenylalanine - blood test</detail><detail> PKU - phenylalanine</detail>

item.title: Serum iron test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Iron level can change, depending on how recently you ingested iron. Your health care provider will likely have you do this test in the morning or after fasting.</text><text>Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Medicines that can affect the test result include:</text><detail>Antibiotics</detail><detail>Birth control pills and estrogens</detail><detail>Blood pressure drugs</detail><detail>Cholesterol drugs</detail><detail>Deferoxamine (removes excess iron from the body)</detail><detail>Gout drugs</detail><detail>Testosterone </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may recommend this test if you have:</text><detail>Signs of low iron (iron deficiency)</detail><detail>Signs of too much iron</detail><detail>Anemia caused by a chronic disease</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value range is:</text><detail>Iron: 60 to 170 micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL), or 10.74 to 30.43 micromoles per liter (micromol/L)</detail><detail>Total iron binding capacity ( TIBC ): 240 to 450 mcg/dL, or 42.96 to 80.55 micromol/L</detail><detail>Transferrin saturation: 20% to 50%</detail><text>The numbers above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal iron level may be a sign of:</text><detail>Too much iron in the body ( hemochromatosis )</detail><detail>Anemia due to red blood cells being destroyed too quickly ( hemolytic anemia )</detail><detail>Liver tissue death</detail><detail>Inflammation of the liver ( hepatitis )</detail><detail> Iron poisoning </detail><detail>Frequent blood transfusions</detail><text>Lower-than-normal level may be a sign of:</text><detail>Long-term digestive tract bleeding</detail><detail>Heavy menstrual bleeding</detail><detail>Intestinal conditions that cause poor absorption of iron</detail><detail>Not enough iron in the diet</detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Fe+2</detail><detail> Ferric ion</detail><detail> Fe++</detail><detail> Ferrous ion</detail><detail> Iron - serum</detail><detail> Anemia - serum iron</detail><detail> Hemochromatosis - serum iron</detail>

item.title: Serum herpes simplex antibodies
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to find out whether a person has ever been infected with oral or genital herpes . It looks for antibodies to herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) and herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2). An antibody is a substance made by the body's immune system when it detects harmful substances such as the herpes virus. This test does not detect the virus itself.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative (normal) test most often means you have not been infected with HSV-1 or HSV-2.</text><text>If the infection occurred very recently (within a few weeks to 3 months), the test may be negative, but you may still be infected. This is called a false negative. It can take up to 3 months after a possible herpes exposure for this test to be positive.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test means you have been infected with HSV recently or at some point in the past.</text><text>Tests can be done to help determine if you have a recent infection.</text><text>About 70% of adults have been infected by HSV-1 and have antibodies against the virus. About 20 to 50% of adults will have antibodies against the HSV-2 virus, which causes genital herpes.</text><text>HSV stays in your system once you have been infected. It may be "asleep" (dormant), and cause no symptoms, or it may flare up and cause symptoms. This test cannot tell whether you are having a flare-up.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Herpes serology</detail><detail> HSV blood test</detail>

item.title: Serum globulin electrophoresis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions on whether or not you need to fast before this test.</text><text>Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. Do not stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to look at globulin proteins in the blood. Identifying the types of globulins can help diagnose certain medical problems.</text><text>Globulins are roughly divided into three groups: alpha, beta, and gamma globulins. Gamma globulins include various types of antibodies such as immunoglobulins (Ig) M, G, and A.</text><text>Certain diseases are associated with producing too many immunoglobulins. For example, Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia is a cancer of certain white blood cells. It is linked with producing too many IgM antibodies.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges are:</text><detail>Serum globulin: 2.0 to 3.5 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 20 to 35 grams per liter (g/L) </detail><detail>IgM component: 75 to 300 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or 750 to 3,000 milligrams per liter (mg/L)</detail><detail>IgG component: 650 to 1,850 mg/dL or 6.5 to 18.50 g/L</detail><detail>IgA component: 90 to 350 mg/dL or 900 to 3,500 mg/L</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased gamma globulin proteins may indicate:</text><detail> Acute infection</detail><detail>Blood and bone marrow cancers including multiple myeloma , and some lymphomas and leukemias</detail><detail>Long-term ( chronic ) inflammatory disease (for example, rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus )</detail><detail> Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Quantitative immunoglobulins</detail>

item.title: Serum free hemoglobin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Hemoglobin (Hb) is the main component of red blood cells. It is a protein that carries oxygen. This test is done to diagnose or monitor how severe hemolytic anemia is. This is a disorder in which a low red blood cell count is caused by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Plasma or serum in someone who does not have hemolytic anemia may contain up to 5 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or 0.05 grams per liter (g/L) hemoglobin.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level may indicate:</text><detail>A hemolytic anemia (due to any cause including autoimmune and non-immune causes, such as thalassemia )</detail><detail>Condition in which red blood cells break down when the body is exposed to certain drugs or the stress of infection ( G6PD deficiency )</detail><detail>Low red blood cell count due to red blood cells breaking down sooner than normal</detail><detail>Blood disorder in which red blood cells are destroyed when they go from cold to warm temperatures ( paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria )</detail><detail> Sickle cell disease </detail><detail> Transfusion reaction </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Blood hemoglobin</detail><detail> Serum hemoglobin</detail><detail> Hemolytic anemia - free hemoglobin</detail>

item.title: Serotonin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Serotonin is a chemical produced by nerve cells.</text><text>This test may be done to diagnose carcinoid syndrome . Carcinoid syndrome is a group of symptoms associated with carcinoid tumors. These are tumors of the small intestine, colon, appendix, and bronchial tubes in the lungs. People with carcinoid syndrome often have high levels of serotonin in the blood.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 50 to 200 ng/mL (0.28 to 1.14 µmol/L).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level may indicate carcinoid syndrome.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>5-HT level</detail><detail> 5-hydroxytryptamine level</detail><detail> Serotonin test</detail>

item.title: Serology for brucellosis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Brucellosis is an infection that occurs from coming into contact with animals that carry brucella bacteria.</text><text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs or symptoms of brucellosis. People working in jobs where they often come in contact with animals or meat, such as slaughterhouse workers, farmers, and veterinarians, are most likely to get this disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal (negative) result usually means you have not come in contact with the bacteria that causes brucellosis. However, this test may not detect the disease at an early stage. Your provider may have you come back for another test in 10 days to 3 weeks.</text><text>Infection with other bacteria, such as yersinia, francisella, and vibrio, and certain immunizations can cause false-positive results.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) result usually means you have come in contact with the bacteria that causes brucellosis.</text><text>However, this positive result does not mean that you have an active infection. Your provider will have you repeat the test after a few weeks to see if the test result increases. This increase is more likely to be a sign of a current infection. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Brucella serology</detail><detail> Brucella antibody test or titer</detail>

item.title: Sensitivity analysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for the method used to obtain the culture.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test shows which antibiotic drugs should be used to treat an infection.</text><text>Many organisms are resistant to certain antibiotics. Sensitivity tests are important in helping find the right antibiotic for you. Your provider may start you on one antibiotic, but later change you to another because of the results of sensitivity analysis.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the organism shows resistance to the antibiotics used in the test, those antibiotics will not be effective treatment.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Antibiotic sensitivity testing</detail><detail> Antimicrobial susceptibility testing</detail>

item.title: Semen analysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>In order to have an adequate sperm count, do not have any sexual activity that causes ejaculation for 2 to 3 days before the test. However, this time should not be longer than 5 days, after which the quality can diminish. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Semen analysis is one of the first tests done to evaluate a man's fertility. It can help determine if a problem in sperm production or quality of the sperm is causing infertility . About half of couples unable to have children have a male infertility problem.</text><text>The test may also be used after a vasectomy to make sure there are no sperm in the semen. This can confirm the success of the vasectomy.</text><text>The test may also be performed for the following condition:</text><detail> Klinefelter syndrome </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A few of the common normal values are listed below.</text><detail>The normal volume varies from 1.5 to 5.0 milliliter per ejaculation.</detail><detail>The sperm count varies from 20 to 150 million sperm per milliliter.</detail><detail>At least 60% of the sperm should have a normal shape and show normal forward movement (motility). </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text><text>It is not completely clear how these values and other results from a semen analysis should be interpreted. An abnormal result does not always mean there is a problem with a man's ability to have children.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may suggest a male infertility problem. For example, if the sperm count is very low or very high, a man may be less fertile. The acidity of the semen and the presence of white blood cells (suggesting infection) may affect fertility. Testing may reveal abnormal shapes or abnormal movements of the sperm.</text><text>However, there are many unknowns in male infertility. Further testing may be needed if abnormalities are found. </text><text>Many of these problems are treatable. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Male fertility test</detail><detail> Sperm count</detail><detail> Infertility - semen analysis</detail>

item.title: Secretin stimulation test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked to not eat or drink anything, including water, for 12 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Secretin causes the pancreas to release a fluid that contains digestive enzymes. These enzymes break down food and help the body absorb nutrients.</text><text>The secretin stimulation test is done to check the digestive function of the pancreas. The following diseases may prevent the pancreas from working properly:</text><detail>Chronic pancreatitis</detail><detail> Cystic fibrosis </detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><text>In these conditions, there may be a lack of digestive enzymes or other chemicals in the fluid that comes from the pancreas. This can reduce the body's ability to digest food and absorb nutrients.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly depending on the lab doing the test. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal values may mean that the pancreas is not working properly.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pancreatic function test</detail>

item.title: Scrotal ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A testicle ultrasound is done to: </text><detail>Help determine why one or both testicles have become larger</detail><detail>Look at a mass or lump in one or both of the testicles</detail><detail>Find the reason for pain in the testicles</detail><detail>Show how blood flows through the testicles </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The testicles and other areas in the scrotum appear normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Possible causes of abnormal results include:</text><detail> Collection of very small veins, called a varicocele </detail><detail> Infection or abscess </detail><detail> Noncancerous (benign) cyst </detail><detail> Twisting of the testicle that blocks blood flow, called testicular torsion </detail><detail> Testicular tumor </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Testicular ultrasound</detail><detail> Testicular sonogram</detail>

item.title: Screening and diagnosis for HIV
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Testing for HIV infection is done for many reasons, including for:</text><detail>People who want to be tested</detail><detail>People in high-risk groups (men who have sex with men, injection drug users and their sexual partners, and commercial sex workers)</detail><detail>People with certain conditions and infections (such as Kaposi sarcoma or Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia)</detail><detail>Pregnant women, to help prevent them from passing the virus to the baby</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test result is normal. People with early HIV infection may have a negative test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive result on a screening test does not confirm that the person has HIV infection. More tests are needed to confirm HIV infection.</text><text>A negative test result does not rule out HIV infection. There is a period of time, called the window period, between HIV infection and the appearance of anti-HIV antibodies. During this period, antibodies and antigen may not be measured.</text><text>If a person might have acute or primary HIV infection and is in the window period, a negative screening test doesn't rule out HIV infection. Follow-up tests for HIV are needed.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>HIV testing</detail><detail> HIV screening</detail><detail> HIV screening test</detail><detail> HIV confirmatory test</detail>

item.title: Schirmer test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked to remove your glasses or contact lenses before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used when the eye doctor suspects you have dry eye. Symptoms include dryness of the eyes or excessive watering of the eyes.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>More than 10 mm of moisture on the filter paper after 5 minutes is a sign of normal tear production. Both eyes normally release the same amount of tears.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Dry eyes may result from:</text><detail>Aging</detail><detail>Swelling or inflammation of the eyelids ( blepharitis )</detail><detail>Climate changes</detail><detail> Corneal ulcers and infections </detail><detail>Eye infections (for example, conjunctivitis )</detail><detail> Laser vision correction </detail><detail> Leukemia </detail><detail>Lymphoma (cancer of the lymph system)</detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><detail>Previous eyelid or facial surgery</detail><detail> Sjögren syndrome </detail><detail> Vitamin A deficiency </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Tear test</detail><detail> Tearing test</detail><detail> Dry eye test</detail><detail> Basal secretion test</detail><detail> Sjögren - Schirmer</detail><detail> Schirmer's test</detail>

item.title: Salivary gland biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for a needle biopsy. However, you may be asked not to drink or eat anything for a few hours before the test.</text><text>For surgical removal of a tumor, preparation is the same as for any major surgery. You will not be able to eat anything for 6 to 8 hours before the surgery.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to find the cause of abnormal lumps or growths of the salivary glands. It is also done to diagnose Sjogren syndrome.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The salivary gland tissue is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate:</text><detail> Salivary gland tumors or infection</detail><detail>Sjogren syndrome </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - salivary gland</detail>

item.title: Tympanometry
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not move, speak, or swallow during the test. Such movements can change the pressure in the middle ear and give incorrect test results.</text><text>The sounds heard during the test may be loud. This may be startling. You will need to try very hard to stay calm and not get startled during the test. If your child is to have this test done, it may be helpful to show how the test is done using a doll. The more your child knows what to expect and why the test is done, the less nervous your child will be.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test measures how your ear reacts to sound and different pressures.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The pressure inside the middle ear can vary by a very small amount. The eardrum should look smooth.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Tympanometry may reveal any of the following:</text><detail>A tumor in the middle ear</detail><detail>Fluid in the middle ear</detail><detail>Impacted ear wax </detail><detail>Lack of contact between the conduction bones of the middle ear</detail><detail>Perforated eardrum</detail><detail>Scarring of the eardrum</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Tympanogram</detail><detail> Otitis media - tympanometry</detail><detail> Effusion - tympanometry</detail><detail> Immittance testing</detail>

item.title: Tularemia blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This blood test is done when tularemia is suspected.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is no antibodies specific for F tularensis are found in the serum.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If antibodies are detected, there has been exposure to F tularensis.</text><text>If antibodies are found, it means you either have a current or past infection with F tularensis. In some cases, a single high level of antibodies that are specific to F tularensis means you have an infection.</text><text>During the early stage of an illness, few antibodies may be detected. Antibody production increases during the course of an infection. For this reason, this test may be repeated several weeks after the first test.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Tularemia test</detail><detail> Serology for Francisella tularensis </detail>

item.title: TSI test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is usually necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may recommend this test if you have signs or symptoms of an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism), including symptoms of:</text><detail> Graves disease </detail><detail> Toxic multinodular goiter </detail><detail>Thyroiditis (swelling of the thyroid gland caused by an overactive immune system) </detail><text>The test is also done during the last 3 months of pregnancy to predict Graves disease in the baby.</text><text>The TSI test is most commonly done if you have signs or symptoms of hyperthyroidism but are unable to have a test called thyroid uptake and scan .</text><text>This test is not commonly done because it is expensive. Most of the time, another test called TSH receptor antibody test is ordered instead.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are less than 130% of basal activity.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level may indicate:</text><detail>Graves disease (most common)</detail><detail>Hashitoxicosis (very rare)</detail><detail>Neonatal thyrotoxicosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>TSH receptor stimulating antibody</detail><detail> Thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin</detail><detail> Hypothyroidism - TSI</detail><detail> Hyperthyroidism - TSI</detail><detail> Goiter - TSI</detail><detail> Thyroiditis - TSI </detail>

item.title: TSH test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no preparation needed for this test. Ask your health care provider about any medicines you are taking that may affect the test results. DO NOT stop taking any medicines without first asking your provider.</text><text>Medicines you may need to stop for a short time include:</text><detail>Amiodarone</detail><detail>Dopamine</detail><detail>Lithium</detail><detail>Potassium iodide</detail><detail>Prednisone or other glucocorticoid medicines </detail><text>The vitamin biotin (B7) can affect the results of the TSH test. If you take biotin, talk to your provider before you have any thyroid function tests.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider will order this test if you have symptoms or signs of an overactive or underactive thyroid gland. It is also used to monitor treatment of these conditions.</text><text>Your provider may also check your TSH level if you are planning to get pregnant.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 0.5 to 5 microunits per milliliter (µU/mL).</text><text>TSH values can vary during the day. It is best to have the test early in the morning. Experts do not fully agree on what the upper number should be when diagnosing thyroid disorders.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>If you are being treated for a thyroid disorder, your TSH level will likely be kept between 0.5 and 4.0 µU/mL, except when:</text><detail>A pituitary disorder is the cause of the thyroid problem. A low TSH may be expected.</detail><detail>You have a history of certain types of thyroid cancer. A TSH value below the normal range may be best to prevent the thyroid cancer from coming back.</detail><detail>A woman is pregnant. The normal range for TSH is different for women who are pregnant. Your provider may suggest that you take thyroid hormone, even if your TSH is in the normal range. </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal TSH level is most often due to an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism). There are many causes of this problem.</text><text>A lower-than-normal level may be due to an overactive thyroid gland, which can be caused by:</text><detail> Graves disease </detail><detail> Toxic nodular goiter or multinodular goiter</detail><detail>Too much iodine in the body (due to receiving iodine contrast used during imaging tests, such as CT scan)</detail><detail>Taking too much thyroid hormone medicine or prescribed natural or over-the-counter supplements that contain thyroid hormone </detail><text>Use of certain medicines may also cause a lower-than-normal TSH level. These include glucocorticoids/steroids, dopamine, certain chemotherapy drugs, and opioid painkillers such as morphine.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thyrotropin</detail><detail> Thyroid stimulating hormone</detail><detail> Hypothyroidism - TSH</detail><detail> Hyperthyroidism - TSH</detail><detail> Goiter - TSH</detail>

item.title: Trypsinogen test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There are no special preparations.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to detect diseases of the pancreas.</text><text>The test is also used to screen newborn babies for cystic fibrosis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased levels of trypsinogen may be due to:</text><detail>Abnormal production of pancreatic enzymes</detail><detail>Acute pancreatitis</detail><detail>Cystic fibrosis</detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><text>Low or normal levels may be seen in chronic pancreatitis .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum trypsin</detail><detail> Trypsin-like immunoreactivity</detail><detail> Serum trypsinogen</detail><detail> Immunoreactive trypsin</detail>

item.title: Trypsin and chymotrypsin in stool
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will provide you with the supplies needed to collect the stool.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>These tests are simple ways of finding out whether you have a decrease in pancreas function. This is most often due to chronic pancreatitis .</text><text>These tests are most often done in young children who are thought to have cystic fibrosis .</text><text>Note: This test is used as a screening tool for cystic fibrosis, but it does not diagnose cystic fibrosis. Other tests are needed to confirm a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The result is normal if there is a normal amount of trypsin or chymotrypsin in the stool.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means the trypsin or chymotrypsin levels in your stool are below the normal range. This may mean that your pancreas is not working properly. Other tests may be done to confirm that there is a problem with your pancreas.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Stool - trypsin and chymotrypsin</detail>

item.title: Troponin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed to prepare, most of the time. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The most common reason to perform this test is to see if a heart attack has occurred. Your health care provider will order this test if you have chest pain and other signs of a heart attack. The test is usually repeated two more times over the next 6 to 24 hours.</text><text>Your provider may also order this test if you have angina that is getting worse, but no other signs of a heart attack. (Angina is chest pain thought to be from a part of your heart not getting enough blood flow.) </text><text>The troponin test may also be done to help detect and evaluate other causes of heart injury.</text><text>The test may be done along with other cardiac marker tests, such as CPK isoenzymes or myoglobin .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Cardiac troponin levels are normally so low they cannot be detected with most blood tests.</text><text>Having normal troponin levels 12 hours after chest pain has started means a heart attack is unlikely.</text><text>A normal value range may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements (for example, "high sensitivity troponin test") or test different samples. Also, some labs have different cutoff points for "normal" and "probable myocardial infarction." Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Even a slight increase in the troponin level will often mean there has been some damage to the heart. Very high levels of troponin are a sign that a heart attack has occurred.</text><text>Most patients who have had a heart attack have increased troponin levels within 6 hours. After 12 hours, almost everyone who has had a heart attack will have raised levels.</text><text>Troponin levels may remain high for 1 to 2 weeks after a heart attack.</text><text>Increased troponin levels may also be due to:</text><detail>Abnormally fast heartbeat</detail><detail>High blood pressure in lung arteries ( pulmonary hypertension )</detail><detail>Blockage of a lung artery by a blood clot, fat, or tumor cells ( pulmonary embolus )</detail><detail>Congestive heart failure</detail><detail> Coronary artery spasm </detail><detail>Inflammation of the heart muscle usually due to a virus ( myocarditis )</detail><detail>Prolonged exercise (for example, due to marathons or triathlons)</detail><detail>Trauma that injures the heart, such as a car accident</detail><detail>Weakening of the heart muscle ( cardiomyopathy )</detail><detail>Long-term kidney disease </detail><text>Increased troponin levels may also result from certain medical procedures such as: </text><detail>Cardiac angioplasty/stenting</detail><detail>Heart defibrillation or electrical cardioversion (purposeful shocking of the heart by medical personnel to correct an abnormal heart rhythm)</detail><detail>Open heart surgery</detail><detail>Radiofrequency ablation of the heart </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>TroponinI</detail><detail> TnI</detail><detail> TroponinT</detail><detail> TnT</detail><detail> Cardiac-specific troponin I</detail><detail> Cardiac-specific troponin T</detail><detail> cTnl</detail><detail> cTnT</detail>

item.title: Triglyceride level
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat for 8 to 12 hours before the test.</text><text>Alcohol and some medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Make sure your health care provider knows what medicines you take, including over-the-counter drugs and supplements.</detail><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test. </detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Triglycerides are usually measured together with other blood fats. Often it is done to help determine your risk of developing heart disease. A high triglyceride level may lead to atherosclerosis , which increases your risk of heart attack and stroke.</text><text>A high triglyceride level may also cause swelling of your pancreas (called pancreatitis).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results may indicate:</text><detail>Normal: Less than 150 mg/dL</detail><detail>Borderline high: 150 to 199 mg/dL</detail><detail>High: 200 to 499 mg/dL</detail><detail>Very high: 500 mg/dL or above</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High triglyceride levels may be due to:</text><detail> Cirrhosis or liver damage</detail><detail>Diet low in protein and high in carbohydrates </detail><detail> Underactive thyroid </detail><detail> Nephrotic syndrome (a kidney disorder)</detail><detail>Other medicines such as female hormones</detail><detail>Poorly controlled diabetes </detail><detail>Disorder passed down through families in which there are high amounts of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood. </detail><text>Overall, the treatment of elevated triglyceride levels focuses on increased exercise and changes in the diet. Drugs to lower triglyceride levels may be used to prevent pancreatitis for levels above 500 mg/dL.</text><text>Low triglyceride levels may be due to:</text><detail>Low fat diet</detail><detail> Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid)</detail><detail> Malabsorption syndrome (conditions in which the small intestine does not absorb fats well)</detail><detail>Malnutrition </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Triacylglycerol test</detail>

item.title: Transvaginal ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked to undress, usually from the waist down. A transvaginal ultrasound is done with your bladder empty or partly filled.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Transvaginal ultrasound may be done for the following problems:</text><detail>Abnormal findings on a physical exam, such as cysts, fibroid tumors, or other growths</detail><detail>Abnormal vaginal bleeding and menstrual problems</detail><detail>Certain types of infertility </detail><detail> Ectopic pregnancy </detail><detail>Pelvic pain</detail><text> Transvaginal ultrasound is also used during pregnancy .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The pelvic structures or fetus is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may be due to many conditions. Some problems that may be seen include:</text><detail>Birth defects</detail><detail>Cancers of the uterus, ovaries, vagina, and other pelvic structures</detail><detail>Infection, including pelvic inflammatory disease</detail><detail>Growths in or around the uterus and ovaries (such as cysts or fibroids)</detail><detail>Twisting of the ovaries</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Endovaginal ultrasound</detail><detail> Ultrasound - transvaginal</detail><detail> Fibroids - transvaginal ultrasound</detail><detail> Vaginal bleeding - transvaginal ultrasound</detail><detail> Uterine bleeding - transvaginal ultrasound</detail><detail> Menstrual bleeding - transvaginal ultrasound</detail><detail> Infertility - transvaginal ultrasound</detail><detail> Ovarian - transvaginal ultrasound</detail><detail> Abscess - transvaginal ultrasound</detail>

item.title: Transillumination
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done along with other tests to diagnose:</text><detail> Hydrocephalus in newborns or infants</detail><detail>Fluid-filled sac in the scrotum ( hydrocele ) or a tumor in the testicle</detail><detail>Breast lesions or cysts in women </detail><text>In newborns, a bright halogen light may be used to transilluminate the chest cavity if there are signs of a collapsed lung or air around the heart. (Transillumination through the chest is only possible on small newborns.)</text><text>In general, transillumination is not an accurate enough test to rely on. Further tests, such as an x-ray, CT, or ultrasound, are needed to confirm the diagnosis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal findings depend on the area being evaluated and the normal tissue of that area.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Areas filled with abnormal air or fluid light up when they should not. For example, in a darkened room, the head of a newborn with possible hydrocephalus will light up when this procedure is done.</text><text>When done on the breast:</text><detail>Internal areas will be dark to black if there is a lesion and bleeding has occurred (because blood does not transilluminate).</detail><detail> Benign tumors tend to appear red.</detail><detail>Malignant tumors are brown to black. </detail>

item.title: Toxoplasma blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done when the health care provider suspects that you have toxoplasmosis . The infection is a danger to a developing baby if a pregnant woman gets infected. It is also dangerous in people with HIV/AIDS .</text><text>In pregnant women, the test is done to:</text><detail>Check if a woman has a current infection or had an infection in the past.</detail><detail>Check if the baby has the infection.</detail><text>The presence of antibodies before pregnancy probably protects a developing baby against toxoplasmosis at birth. But antibodies that develop during pregnancy may mean the mother and baby are infected. This infection during pregnancy increases the risk for miscarriage or birth defects.</text><text>This test may also be done if you have:</text><detail>An unexplained lymph node swelling</detail><detail>An unexplained rise in the blood white cell (lymphocyte) count</detail><detail>HIV and have symptoms of a toxoplasmosis of the brain (including headache, seizures, weakness, and speech or vision problems)</detail><detail>Inflammation of the back part of the eye (chorioretinitis)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results mean you have likely never had a toxoplasma infection. </text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean that you have probably been infected with the parasite. Two types of antibodies are measured, IgM and IgG:</text><detail>If level of IgM antibodies is raised, you likely became infected in the recent past.</detail><detail>If level of IgG antibodies is raised, you became infected sometime in the past.</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Toxoplasma serology</detail><detail> Toxoplasma antibody titer</detail>

item.title: Toxicology screen
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed. If you are able, tell your health care provider what drugs (including over-the-counter medicines) you have taken, including when you took them and how much you consumed.</text><text>This test is sometimes part of an investigation for drug use or abuse. Special consents, handling and labeling of specimens, or other procedures may be required.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is often done in emergency medical situations. It can be used to evaluate possible accidental or intentional overdose or poisoning. It may help determine the cause of acute drug toxicity, monitor drug dependency, and determine the presence of substances in the body for medical or legal purposes.</text><text>Additional reasons the test may be performed include:</text><detail> Alcoholism </detail><detail> Alcohol withdrawal state </detail><detail>Altered mental state</detail><detail> Analgesic nephropathy (kidney poisoning)</detail><detail> Complicated alcohol abstinence (delirium tremens) </detail><detail> Delirium </detail><detail> Dementia </detail><detail>Drug abuse monitoring</detail><detail>Fetal alcohol syndrome</detail><detail>Intentional overdose</detail><detail>Seizures</detail><detail>Stroke caused by cocaine use</detail><detail>Suspected sexual assault</detail><detail>Unconsciousness </detail><text>If the test is used as a drug screen, it must be done within a certain amount of time after the drug was taken, or while forms of the drug can still be detected in the body. Examples are below:</text><detail>Alcohol: 3 to 10 hours</detail><detail>Amphetamines: 24 to 48 hours</detail><detail>Barbiturates: up to 6 weeks</detail><detail>Benzodiazepines: up to 6 weeks with high level use</detail><detail>Cocaine: 2 to 4 days; up to 10 to 22 days with heavy use</detail><detail>Codeine: 1 to 2 days</detail><detail>Heroin: 1 to 2 days</detail><detail>Hydromorphone: 1 to 2 days</detail><detail>Methadone: 2 to 3 days</detail><detail>Morphine: 1 to 2 days</detail><detail>Phencyclidine (PCP): 1 to 8 days</detail><detail>Propoxyphene: 6 to 48 hours</detail><detail>Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC): 6 to 11 weeks with heavy use </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges for over-the-counter or prescription medicines may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>A negative value most often means that alcohol, prescription medicines that have not been prescribed, and illegal drugs have not been detected.</text><text>A blood toxicology screen can determine the presence and level (amount) of a drug in your body.</text><text>Urine sample results are often reported as positive (substance is found) or negative (no substance is found).</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Elevated levels of alcohol or prescription drugs can be a sign of intentional or accidental intoxication or overdose.</text><text>The presence of illegal drugs or drugs not prescribed for the person indicates illicit drug use .</text><text>Some legal prescription and over the counter medicines may interact with the testing chemicals and false results in urine tests. Your provider will be aware of this possibility.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Barbiturates - screen</detail><detail> Benzodiazepines - screen</detail><detail> Amphetamines - screen</detail><detail> Analgesics - screen</detail><detail> Antidepressants - screen</detail><detail> Narcotics - screen</detail><detail> Phenothiazines - screen</detail><detail> Drug abuse screen</detail><detail> Blood alcohol test</detail>

item.title: Total protein
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is often done to diagnose nutritional problems, kidney disease or liver disease .</text><text>If total protein is abnormal, you will need to have more tests to look for the exact cause of the problem.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 6.0 to 8.3 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 60 to 83 g/L.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal levels may be due to:</text><detail> Chronic inflammation or infection, including HIV and hepatitis B or C</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><detail> Waldenstrom disease </detail><text>Lower-than-normal levels may be due to:</text><detail> Agammaglobulinemia </detail><detail>Bleeding (hemorrhage)</detail><detail> Burns (extensive)</detail><detail> Glomerulonephritis </detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail> Malabsorption </detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail>Nephrotic syndrome</detail><detail>Protein-losing enteropathy </detail>

item.title: Total iron binding capacity
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for 8 hours before the test.</text><text>Certain medicines may affect the result of this test. Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Medicines that can affect the test result include:</text><detail>Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Chloramphenicol</detail><detail>Fluorides </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may recommend this test if:</text><detail>You have signs or symptoms of anemia due to low iron.</detail><detail>Other lab tests suggest you have anemia due to low iron levels </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value range is:</text><detail>Iron: 60 to 170 micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL) or 10.74 to 30.43 micromoles per liter (micromol/L)</detail><detail>TIBC: 240 to 450 mcg/dL or 42.96 to 80.55 micromol/L</detail><detail>Transferrin saturation: 20% to 50% </detail><text>The numbers above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>TIBC is usually higher than normal when the body's iron supplies are low. This can occur with:</text><detail> Iron deficiency anemia </detail><detail>Pregnancy (late)</detail><text>Lower-than-normal TIBC may mean:</text><detail>Anemia due to red blood cells being destroyed too quickly ( hemolytic anemia )</detail><detail>Lower-than-normal level of protein in the blood (hypoproteinemia)</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Liver disease, such as cirrhosis </detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail>Decrease in red blood cells from the intestines not properly absorbing vitamin B12 ( pernicious anemia )</detail><detail> Sickle cell anemia </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>TIBC</detail><detail> Anemia -TIBC</detail>

item.title: TORCH screen
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>For more information about how you can prepare your child, see infant test or procedure preparation .</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>If a woman becomes infected with certain germs during her pregnancy, the baby may also become infected while still in the womb. The baby is more sensitive to harm from infection during the first 3 to 4 months of the pregnancy.</text><text>This test is used to screen infants for TORCH infections. These infections may lead to the following problems in the baby:</text><detail>Birth defects</detail><detail> Growth delay </detail><detail>Brain and nervous system problems</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values mean there is no sign of infection in the newborn.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If high levels of antibodies called immunoglobulins (IgM) against a certain germ are found in the infant, there may be an infection. Your provider may order more tests to confirm a diagnosis.</text>

item.title: Tonometry
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Remove contact lenses before the exam. The dye can permanently stain contact lenses.</text><text>Tell your provider if you have a history of corneal ulcers or eye infections , or a history of glaucoma in your family. Always tell your provider what medicines you are taking.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Tonometry is a test to measure the pressure inside your eyes. The test is used to screen for glaucoma.</text><text>People over age 40, especially African Americans, have the highest risk for developing glaucoma. Regular eye exams can help detect glaucoma early. If it is detected early, glaucoma can be treated before too much damage is done.</text><text>The test may also be done before and after eye surgery.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means your eye pressure is within the normal range. The normal eye pressure range is 10 to 21 mm Hg.</text><text>The thickness of your cornea can affect measurements. Normal eyes with thick corneas have higher readings, and normal eyes with thin corneas have lower readings. A thin cornea with a high reading may be very abnormal (the actual eye pressure will be higher than shown on the tonometer).</text><text>A corneal thickness measurement (pachymetry) is needed to get a correct pressure measurement.</text><text>Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Glaucoma</detail><detail> Hyphema (blood in the front chamber of the eye)</detail><detail>Inflammation in the eye</detail><detail>Injury to the eye or head </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement</detail><detail> Glaucoma test</detail><detail> Goldmann applanation tonometry (GAT)</detail>

item.title: Tongue biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be told not to eat or drink anything for several hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to find the cause of abnormal growths or suspicious-looking areas of the tongue.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The tongue tissue is normal when examined. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean:</text><detail>Amyloidosis</detail><detail> Tongue (oral) cancer </detail><detail>Viral ulcer</detail><detail>Benign tumors</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - tongue</detail>

item.title: Thyroid ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A thyroid ultrasound is usually done when physical exam shows any of these findings:</text><detail>You have a growth on your thyroid gland, called a thyroid nodule .</detail><detail>The thyroid feels big or irregular, called a goiter .</detail><detail>You have abnormal lymph nodes near your thyroid.</detail><text>Ultrasound is also often used to guide the needle in biopsies of:</text><detail> Thyroid nodules or the thyroid gland -- In this test, a needle draws out a small amount of tissue from the nodule or thyroid gland. This is a test to diagnose thyroid disease or thyroid cancer.</detail><detail>The parathyroid gland.</detail><detail>Lymph nodes in the area of the thyroid.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result will show that the thyroid has a normal size, shape, and position.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Cysts (nodules filled with fluid)</detail><detail>Enlargement of the thyroid gland ( goiter )</detail><detail>Thyroid nodules </detail><detail>Thyroiditis, or inflammation of the thyroid (if a biopsy is done)</detail><detail> Thyroid cancer (if a biopsy is done) </detail><text>Your health care provider can use these results and the results of other tests to direct your care.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ultrasound - thyroid</detail><detail> Thyroid sonogram</detail><detail> Thyroid echogram</detail><detail> Thyroid nodule - ultrasound</detail><detail> Goiter - ultrasound</detail>

item.title: Thyroid scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions about not eating before the test. You may be told not to eat after the midnight before your scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are taking anything that contains iodine because it may affect your test results. This includes some medicines, including thyroid drugs. Supplements such as kelp also contain iodine.</text><text>Also tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Diarrhea (may decrease absorption of the radioactive iodine)</detail><detail>Had recent CT scans using intravenous or oral iodine-based contrast (within the past 2 weeks)</detail><detail>Too little or too much iodine in your diet </detail><text>Remove jewelry, dentures, or other metals because they may interfere with the image.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to:</text><detail>Evaluate thyroid nodules or goiter </detail><detail>Find the cause of an overactive thyroid gland </detail><detail>Check for thyroid cancer (rarely, since other tests are more accurate for this) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal test results will show that the thyroid appears to be the correct size, shape, and in the proper location. It is an even gray color on the computer image without darker or lighter areas.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A thyroid that is enlarged or pushed off to one side could be a sign of a tumor . </text><text>Nodules absorb more or less iodine and this will make them look darker or lighter on the scan. A nodule is usually lighter if it has not taken up the iodine. If part of the thyroid appears lighter, it could be a thyroid problem. Nodules that are darker have taken up more iodine. They can be overactive and may be the cause of an overactive thyroid.</text><text>The computer will also show the percentage of iodine that has collected in your thyroid gland (radioiodine uptake). If your gland collects too much iodine, it may be due to an overactive thyroid. If your gland collects too little iodine, it may be due to an inflammation or other damage to the thyroid.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Scan - thyroid</detail><detail> Radioactive iodine uptake and scan test - thyroid</detail><detail> Nuclear scan - thyroid</detail><detail> Thyroid nodule - scan</detail><detail> Goiter - scan</detail><detail> Hyperthyroidism - scan</detail>

item.title: Throat swab culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT use antiseptic mouthwash before this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done when a throat infection is suspected, particularly strep throat. A throat culture can also help your provider determine which antibiotic will work best for you.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal or negative result means no bacteria or other germs that may cause a sore throat were found.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal or positive result means bacteria or other germs that can cause a sore throat were seen on the throat swab.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Throat culture and sensitivity</detail><detail> Culture - throat</detail>

item.title: Thoracic spine x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider if you are pregnant. Also tell the provider if you have had surgery in your chest, abdomen, or pelvis.</text><text>Remove all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The x-ray helps evaluate:</text><detail>Bone injuries</detail><detail>Cartilage loss</detail><detail>Diseases of the bone</detail><detail>Tumors of the bone </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The test can detect:</text><detail>Bone spurs</detail><detail>Deformities of the spine</detail><detail>Disk narrowing</detail><detail>Dislocations</detail><detail> Fractures </detail><detail>Thinning of the bone ( osteoporosis )</detail><detail>Wearing away (degeneration) of the vertebrae </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Vertebral radiography</detail><detail> X-ray - spine</detail><detail> Thoracic x-ray</detail><detail> Spine x-ray</detail><detail> Thoracic spine films</detail><detail> Back films</detail>

item.title: Thoracic spine CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast. Contrast is delivered into the body before the test starts. This helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><text>Contrast can be given in several ways. It may be given as an injection through:</text><detail>A vein (IV) in your hand or forearm.</detail><detail>Your back into the space surrounding the spinal cord.</detail><text>If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</text><text>Before receiving the contrast, tell your health care provider if:</text><detail>You have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test to safely receive the dye.</detail><detail>You take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps if you take this medicine.</detail><text>Find out if the CT machine has a weight limit if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms). Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner.</text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the thoracic spine. The test may help diagnose or detect:</text><detail>Birth defects of the spine in children</detail><detail>Bone fracture in the spine</detail><detail>Arthritis of the spine</detail><detail>Curvature of the spine</detail><detail>Tumor of the spine</detail><detail>Other spinal injury </detail><text>Thoracic CT scan can also be used during or after:</text><detail>Myelography: An x-ray of the spinal cord and spinal nerve roots</detail><detail>Discography: An x-ray of the disk</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are normal if the thoracic spine looks normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Birth defects of the spine</detail><detail>Bone problems</detail><detail>Fracture</detail><detail> Herniated (slipped) disk </detail><detail>Infection of the spine</detail><detail>Narrowing of the spine ( spinal stenosis )</detail><detail> Scoliosis </detail><detail>Tumor</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - thoracic spine</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - thoracic spine</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - thoracic spine</detail><detail> CT scan - upper back</detail>

item.title: Thoracentesis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed before the test. A chest x-ray or ultrasound will be done before and after the test.</text><text>DO NOT cough, breathe deeply, or move during the test to avoid injury to the lung.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Normally, very little fluid is in the pleural space. A buildup of too much fluid between the layers of the pleura is called a pleural effusion .</text><text>The test is performed to determine the cause of the extra fluid, or to relieve symptoms from the fluid buildup.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally the pleural cavity contains only a very small amount of fluid.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Testing the fluid will help your provider determine the cause of pleural effusion. Possible causes include:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Liver failure</detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Low protein levels</detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail>Trauma or post-surgery</detail><detail>Asbestos-related pleural effusion</detail><detail>Collagen vascular disease (class of diseases in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues)</detail><detail>Drug reactions</detail><detail>Collection of blood in the pleural space (hemothorax)</detail><detail> Lung cancer </detail><detail>Swelling and inflammation of the pancreas ( pancreatitis )</detail><detail>Pneumonia</detail><detail>Blockage of an artery in the lungs (pulmonary embolism)</detail><detail>Severely underactive thyroid gland </detail><text>If your provider suspects that you have an infection, a culture of the fluid may be done to test for bacteria.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pleural fluid aspiration</detail><detail> Pleural tap</detail>
