item.title: Therapeutic drug levels
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need to prepare for some drug level tests.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to change the times you take any of your medicines.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>With most medicines, you need a certain level of the drug in your blood to get the proper effect. Some medicines are harmful if the level rises too high and do not work if the levels are too low.</text><text>Monitoring the amount of the drug found in your blood allows your provider to make sure the drug levels are in the proper range.</text><text>Drug level testing is important in people taking drugs such as:</text><detail>Flecainide, procainamide or digoxin, which are used to treat abnormal beating of the heart</detail><detail>Phenytoin or valproic acid, which are used to treat seizures</detail><detail>Gentamicin or amikacin, which are antibiotics used to treat infections</detail><text>Testing may also be done to determine how well your body breaks down the drug or how it interacts with other drugs you need.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Following are some of the drugs that are commonly checked and the normal target levels:</text><detail>Acetaminophen: varies with use</detail><detail>Amikacin: 15 to 25 mcg/mL (25.62 to 42.70 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Aminophylline: 10 to 20 mcg/mL (55.50 to 111.00 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Amitriptyline: 120 to 150 ng/mL (432.60 to 540.75 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Carbamazepine: 5 to 12 mcg/mL (21.16 to 50.80 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Cyclosporine: 100 to 400 ng/mL (83.20 to 332.80 nmol/L) (12 hours after dose)</detail><detail>Desipramine: 150 to 300 ng/mL (563.10 to 1126.20 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Digoxin: 0.8 to 2.0 ng/mL (1.02 to 2.56 nanomol/L)</detail><detail>Disopyramide: 2 to 5 mcg/mL (5.89 to 14.73 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Ethosuximide: 40 to 100 mcg/mL (283.36 to 708.40 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Flecainide: 0.2 to 1.0 mcg/mL (0.5 to 2.4 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Gentamicin: 5 to 10 mcg/mL (10.45 to 20.90 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Imipramine: 150 to 300 ng/mL (534.90 to 1069.80 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Kanamycin: 20 to 25 mcg/mL (41.60 to 52.00 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Lidocaine: 1.5 to 5.0 mcg/mL (6.40 to 21.34 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Lithium: 0.8 to 1.2 mEq/L (0.8 to 1.2 mmol/L)</detail><detail>Methotrexate: varies with use </detail><detail>Nortriptyline: 50 to 150 ng/mL (189.85 to 569.55 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Phenobarbital: 10 to 30 mcg/mL (43.10 to 129.30 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Phenytoin: 10 to 20 mcg/mL (39.68 to 79.36 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Primidone: 5 to 12 mcg/mL (22.91 to 54.98 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Procainamide: 4 to 10 mcg/mL (17.00 to 42.50 micomol/L)</detail><detail>Quinidine: 2 to 5 mcg/mL (6.16 to 15.41 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Salicylate: varies with use</detail><detail>Sirolimus: 4 to 20 ng/mL (4 to 22 nmol/L) (12 hours after dose; varies with use)</detail><detail>Tacrolimus: 5 to 15 ng/mL (4 to 25 nmol/L) (12 hours after dose)</detail><detail>Theophylline: 10 to 20 mcg/mL (55.50 to 111.00 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Tobramycin: 5 to 10 mcg/mL (10.69 to 21.39 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Valproic acid: 50 to 100 mcg/mL (346.70 to 693.40 micromol/L)</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Values outside the target range may be due to minor changes or be a sign that you need to adjust your dosages. Your provider may tell you to skip a dose if the values measured are too high.</text><text>Following are toxic levels for some of the drugs that are commonly checked:</text><detail>Acetaminophen: greater than 250 mcg/mL (1653.50 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Amikacin: greater than 25 mcg/mL (42.70 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Aminophylline: greater than 20 mcg/mL (111.00 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Amitriptyline: greater than 500 ng/mL (1802.50 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Carbamazepine: greater than 12 mcg/mL (50.80 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Cyclosporine: greater than 400 ng/mL (332.80 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Desipramine: greater than 500 ng/mL (1877.00 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Digoxin: greater than 2.4 ng/mL (3.07 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Disopyramide: greater than 5 mcg/mL (14.73 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Ethosuximide: greater than 100 mcg/mL (708.40 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Flecainide: greater than 1.0 mcg/mL (2.4 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Gentamicin: greater than 12 mcg/mL (25.08 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Imipramine: greater than 500 ng/mL (1783.00 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Kanamycin: greater than 35 mcg/mL (72.80 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Lidocaine: greater than 5 mcg/mL (21.34 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Lithium: greater than 2.0 mEq/L (2.00 millimol/L)</detail><detail>Methotrexate: greater than 10 mcmol/L (10,000 nmol/L) over 24-hours</detail><detail>Nortriptyline: greater than 500 ng/mL (1898.50 nmol/L)</detail><detail>Phenobarbital: greater than 40 mcg/mL (172.40 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Phenytoin: greater than 30 mcg/mL (119.04 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Primidone: greater than 15 mcg/mL (68.73 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Procainamide: greater than 16 mcg/mL (68.00 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Quinidine: greater than 10 mcg/mL (30.82 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Salicylate: greater than 300 mcg/mL (2172.00 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Theophylline: greater than 20 mcg/mL (111.00 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Tobramycin: greater than 12 mcg/mL (25.67 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Valproic acid: greater than 100 mcg/mL (693.40 micromol/L)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Therapeutic drug monitoring</detail>

item.title: Tests for H. pylori
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Testing is most often done to diagnose H. pylori infection:</text><detail>If you currently have a stomach or duodenal ulcer</detail><detail>If you had a stomach or duodenal ulcer in the past, and were never tested for H. pylori</detail><detail>After treatment for H. pylori infection, to make sure there are no more bacteria</detail><text>Testing may also be done if you need to take long-term ibuprofen or other NSAID medicines. Your health care provider can tell you more.</text><text>The test may also be recommended for a condition called dyspepsia (indigestion). This is upper abdominal discomfort. Symptoms include a feeling of fullness or of heat, burning, or pain in the area between the navel and the lower part of the breastbone during or after eating. Testing for H. pylori without endoscopy is most often done only when the discomfort is new, the person is younger than 55, and there are no other symptoms.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results mean there is no sign that you have an H. pylori infection.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean that you have an H. pylori infection. Your provider will discuss treatment with you.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Peptic ulcer disease - H. pylori</detail><detail> PUD - H. pylori</detail>

item.title: Testosterone
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The health care provider may advise you to stop taking medicines that may affect the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done if you have symptoms of abnormal male hormone (androgen) production.</text><text>In males, the testicles produce most of the testosterone in the body. Levels are most often checked to evaluate signs of abnormal testosterone such as:</text><detail>Early or late puberty (in boys)</detail><detail>Infertility, erectile dysfunction , low level of sexual interest, thinning of the bones (in men) </detail><text>In females, the ovaries produce most of the testosterone. The adrenal glands can also produce too much of other androgens that are converted to testosterone. Levels are most often checked to evaluate signs of higher testosterone levels, such as:</text><detail>Acne, oily skin</detail><detail>Change in voice</detail><detail>Decreased breast size</detail><detail>Excess hair growth (dark, coarse hairs in the area of the moustache, beard, sideburns, chest, buttocks, inner thighs)</detail><detail>Increased size of the clitoris</detail><detail>Irregular or absent menstrual periods</detail><detail>Male-pattern baldness or hair thinning </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal measurements for these tests:</text><detail>Male: 300 to 1,000 nanograms per deciliter (ng/dL) or 10.41 to 34.70 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)</detail><detail>Female: 15 to 70 ng/dL or 0.52 to 2.43 nmol/L</detail><text>The examples above are common measurements for results for these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Certain health conditions, medicines, or injury can lead to low testosterone . Testosterone level also naturally drops with age. Low testosterone can affect sex drive, mood, and the body in men.</text><text>Decreased total testosterone may be due to:</text><detail>Chronic illness</detail><detail> The pituitary gland does not produce normal amounts of some or all of its hormones</detail><detail>Problem with areas of the brain that control hormones</detail><detail>Low thyroid function</detail><detail>Delayed puberty</detail><detail>Diseases of the testicles (trauma, cancer, infection, immune)</detail><detail>Benign tumor of the pituitary cells that produce too much of the hormone prolactin</detail><detail>Too much body fat (obesity)</detail><text>Increased total testosterone level may be due to:</text><detail>Resistance to the action of male hormones (androgen resistance)</detail><detail>Tumor of the ovaries</detail><detail>Cancer of the testes</detail><detail> Congenital adrenal hyperplasia </detail><detail>Taking medicines or drugs that increase testosterone level</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum testosterone</detail>

item.title: Testicular self-exam
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A testicular self-exam is done to check for testicular cancer .</text><text>Testicles have blood vessels and other structures that can make the exam confusing. If you notice any lumps or changes in a testicle, contact your health care provider right away.</text><text>Your provider may recommend that you do a testicular self-exam every month if you have any of the following risk factors:</text><detail>Family history of testicular cancer</detail><detail>Past testicular tumor</detail><detail> Undescended testicle </detail><text>However, if a man has no risk factors or symptoms, experts do not know if doing testicular self-exam lowers the chance of dying of this cancer.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Each testicle should feel firm, but not rock hard. One testicle may be lower or slightly larger than the other.</text><text>Talk to your provider if you have questions.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If you find a small, hard lump (like a pea), have an enlarged testicle, or notice any other differences that do not seem normal, see your provider right away.</text><text>Call your provider if:</text><detail>You cannot find one or both testicles. The testicles may not have descended properly in the scrotum.</detail><detail>There is a soft collection of thin tubes above the testicle. This may be a collection of widened veins ( varicocele ).</detail><detail>You have pain or swelling in the scrotum. This may be an infection or a fluid-filled sac ( hydrocele ) causing a blockage of blood flow to the area. It may be difficult to feel the testicle if there is fluid in the scrotum.</detail><text>Sudden, severe (acute) pain in the scrotum or testicle that lasts for more than a few minutes is an emergency. If you have this type of pain, seek medical attention right away.</text><text>A lump in the testicle is often the first sign of testicular cancer. If you find a lump, see a provider right away. Most testicular cancers are very treatable. Keep in mind that some cases of testicular cancer do not show symptoms until they reach an advanced stage.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Screening - testicular cancer - self-exam</detail><detail> Testicular cancer - screening - self-exam </detail>

item.title: Testicular biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you not to take aspirin or medicines that contain aspirin for 1 week before the procedure. Always ask your provider before stopping any medicines.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is most often done to find the cause of male infertility . It is done when a semen analysis suggests that there is abnormal sperm and other tests have not found the cause. In some cases, sperm obtained from a testicular biopsy can be used to fertilize a woman's egg in the lab. This process is called in vitro fertilization.</text><text>Testicular biopsy may also be done if you have found a lump during testicular self-examination . If tests such as testicular ultrasound suggest that the lump may be in the testicle, surgery may be needed to look at the testicle more closely. </text><text>A biopsy to determine whether the lump is cancerous or noncancerous (benign) may be done. If cancer is found or suspected, the entire testicle is removed.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Sperm development appears normal. No cancerous cells are found.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean a problem with sperm or hormone function. Biopsy may be able to find the cause of the problem.</text><text>In some cases, the sperm development appears normal in the testicle, but semen analysis shows no sperm or reduced sperm. This may indicate a blockage of the tube through which the sperm travel from the testes to the urethra. This blockage can sometimes be repaired with surgery.</text><text>Other causes of abnormal results:</text><detail>A cyst-like lump filled with fluid and dead sperm cells (spermatocele)</detail><detail> Orchitis </detail><detail> Testicular cancer </detail><text>Your provider will explain and discuss all abnormal results with you.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - testicle</detail>

item.title: Tensilon test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is usually necessary. Follow your provider's instructions about how to prepare.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test helps:</text><detail>Diagnose myasthenia gravis</detail><detail>Tell the difference between myasthenia gravis and other similar brain and nervous system conditions</detail><detail>Monitor treatment with oral anticholinesterase drugs </detail><text>The test may also be done for conditions such as Lambert-Eaton syndrome . This is a disorder in which faulty communication between nerves and muscles leads to muscle weakness.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In many people with myasthenia gravis, the muscles will improve right after receiving Tensilon. The improvement lasts only a few minutes. For some types of myasthenia, Tensilon can make the weakness worse.</text><text>When the disease gets worse enough to need treatment (myasthenic crisis), there is a brief improvement in muscle strength.</text><text>When there is an overdose of anticholinesterase (cholinergic crisis), Tensilon will make the person even weaker.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Myasthenia gravis - tensilon</detail>

item.title: TBG blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain drugs and medicines can affect test results. Your health care provider may tell you to stop taking a certain medicine for a short time before the test. Never stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text><text>These medicines and drugs can increase TBG level:</text><detail>Estrogens, found in birth control pills and estrogen replacement therapy</detail><detail>Heroin</detail><detail>Methadone</detail><detail>Phenothiazines (certain antipsychotic drugs)</detail><text>The following medicines can decrease TBG levels: </text><detail>Depakote or depakene (also called valproic acid)</detail><detail>Dilantin (also called phenytoin)</detail><detail>High doses of salicylates, including aspirin</detail><detail>Male hormones, including androgens and testosterone</detail><detail>Prednisone</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to diagnose problems with your thyroid.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal range is 13 to 39 micrograms per deciliter (µg/dL), or 150 to 360 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased TBG level may be due to:</text><detail> Acute intermittent porphyria (a rare metabolic disorder)</detail><detail>Hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid)</detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail>Pregnancy (TBG levels normally increased during pregnancy) </detail><text>Note: TBG levels are normally high in newborns.</text><text>Decreased TBG levels may be due to:</text><detail> Acute illness</detail><detail> Acromegaly (disorder caused by too much growth hormone)</detail><detail> Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid)</detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail> Nephrotic syndrome (symptoms that show kidney damage is present)</detail><detail>Stress from surgery </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum thyroxine binding globulin</detail><detail> TBG level</detail><detail> Serum TBG level</detail><detail> Hypothyroidism - TBG</detail><detail> Hyperthyroidism - TBG</detail><detail> Underactive thyroid - TBG</detail><detail> Overactive thyroid - TBG</detail>

item.title: T3RU test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before the test that may affect your test result. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text><text>Some drugs that can increase T3RU levels include:</text><detail>Anabolic steroids</detail><detail>Heparin</detail><detail>Phenytoin</detail><detail>Salicylates (high dose)</detail><detail>Warfarin </detail><text>Some drugs that can decrease T3RU levels include:</text><detail>Antithyroid medicines</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Clofibrate</detail><detail>Estrogen</detail><detail>Thiazides </detail><text>Pregnancy can also decrease T3RU levels.</text><text>These things can increase thyroxin binding globulin (TBG) levels (see below section "Why the Test is Performed" for more about TBG):</text><detail>Male hormones (androgens)</detail><detail>Serious illness</detail><detail>Kidney disease </detail><text>Other medicines that bind to protein in the blood can also affect test results</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check your thyroid function. Thyroid function depends on the action of many different hormones, including thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), T3, and T4.</text><text>This test helps check the amount of T3 that thyroxin binding globulin (TBG) is able to bind. TBG is a protein that carries most of the T3 and T4 in the blood.</text><text>Your provider may recommend a T3RU test if you have signs of a thyroid disorder, including:</text><detail> Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid)</detail><detail> Hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid)</detail><detail> Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (muscle weakness caused by high levels of thyroid hormone in the blood) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 24% to 37%.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal levels may indicate:</text><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail>Overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)</detail><detail> Nephrotic syndrome </detail><detail> Protein malnutrition </detail><text>Lower-than-normal levels may indicate:</text><detail>Acute hepatitis (liver disease)</detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail> Hypothyroidism </detail><detail>Use of estrogen </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to an inherited condition of high TBG levels. Usually thyroid function is normal in people with this condition.</text><text>This test may also be done for:</text><detail> Chronic thyroiditis (swelling or inflammation of the thyroid gland, including Hashimoto disease)</detail><detail>Drug-induced hypothyroidism</detail><detail> Graves disease </detail><detail> Subacute thyroiditis </detail><detail>Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis</detail><detail> Toxic nodular goiter </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Resin T3 uptake</detail><detail> T3 resin uptake</detail><detail> Thyroid hormone-binding ratio</detail>

item.title: T3 test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before the test that may affect your test result. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text><text>Drugs that can increase T3 measurements include:</text><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Clofibrate</detail><detail>Estrogens</detail><detail>Methadone</detail><detail>Certain herbal remedies </detail><text>Drugs that can decrease T3 measurements include:</text><detail>Amiodarone</detail><detail>Anabolic steroids</detail><detail>Androgens</detail><detail>Antithyroid drugs (for example, propylthiouracil and methimazole)</detail><detail>Lithium</detail><detail>Phenytoin</detail><detail>Propranolol </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check your thyroid function. Thyroid function depends on the action of T3 and other hormones, including thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and T4.</text><text>Sometimes it can be useful to measure both T3 and T4 when evaluating thyroid function.</text><text>The total T3 test measures the T3 that is both attached to proteins and floating free in the blood.</text><text>The free T3 test measures the T3 that is floating free in the blood. The tests for free T3 are generally less accurate than for total T3.</text><text>Your provider may recommend this test if you have signs of a thyroid disorder, including:</text><detail> The pituitary gland does not produce normal amounts of some or all of its hormone ( hypopituitarism )</detail><detail> Overactive thyroid gland ( hyperthyroidism )</detail><detail> Underactive thyroid gland ( hypothyroidism )</detail><detail>Taking medicines for hypothyroidism</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The range for normal values are:</text><detail>Total T3 -- 60 to 180 nanograms per deciliter (ng/dL), or 0.92 to 2.76 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)</detail><detail>Free T3 -- 130 to 450 picgrams per deciliter (pg/dL), or 2.0 to 7.0 picomoles per liter (pmol/L)</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>Normal values are age specific for people less than age 20. Check with your provider about your specific results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level of T3 may be a sign of:</text><detail>Overactive thyroid gland (for example, Graves disease )</detail><detail>T3 thyrotoxicosis (rare)</detail><detail> Toxic nodular goiter </detail><detail>Taking thyroid medicines or certain supplements (common)</detail><detail>Liver disease </detail><text>A high level of T3 may occur in pregnancy (especially with morning sickness at the end of the first trimester) or with the use of birth control pills or estrogen.</text><text>A lower-than-normal level may be due to:</text><detail>Severe short-term or some long-term illnesses</detail><detail>Thyroiditis (swelling or inflammation of the thyroid gland -- Hashimoto disease is the most common type)</detail><detail>Starvation</detail><detail>Underactive thyroid gland </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Triiodothyronine</detail><detail> T3 radioimmunoassay</detail><detail> Toxic nodular goiter - T3</detail><detail> Thyroiditis - T3</detail><detail> Thyrotoxicosis - T3</detail><detail> Graves disease - T3</detail>

item.title: T-cell count
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>T cells are a type of lymphocyte. Lymphocytes are white blood cells. They make up part of the immune system. T cells help the body fight diseases or harmful substances, such as bacteria or viruses.</text><text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs of a weak immune system ( immunodeficiency disorder ). It may also be ordered if you have a disease of the lymph nodes. Lymph nodes are small glands that make white blood cells. The test is also used to monitor how well treatment for these types of diseases is working.</text><text>One type of T cell is the CD4 cell, or "helper cell." People with HIV/AIDS have regular T-cell tests to check their CD4 cell counts. The results help the provider monitor the disease and its treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results vary depending on the type of T-cell tested.</text><text>In adults, a normal CD4 cell count ranges from 500 to 1,200 cells/mm<sup>3</sup> (0.64 to 1.18 × 10<sup>9</sup>/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher than normal T-cell levels may be due to:</text><detail>Cancer, such as acute lymphocytic leukemia or multiple myeloma </detail><detail>Infections, such as hepatitis or mononucleosis </detail><text>Lower than normal T-cell levels may be due to: </text><detail> Acute viral infections</detail><detail>Aging</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Immune system diseases, such as HIV/AIDS</detail><detail> Radiation therapy </detail><detail>Steroid treatment </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thymus derived lymphocyte count</detail><detail> T-lymphocyte count</detail><detail> T cell count</detail>

item.title: Uroflowmetry
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may ask you to temporarily stop taking medicines that can affect the test results.</text><text>Uroflowmetry is best done when you have a full bladder. DO NOT urinate for 2 hours before the test. Drink extra fluids so you will have plenty of urine for the test. The test is the most accurate if you urinate at least 5 ounces (150 milliliters) or more.</text><text>DO NOT place any toilet tissue in the test machine.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is useful in evaluating the function of the urinary tract. In most cases, a person having this test will report urination that is too slow.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values vary depending on age and sex. In men, urine flow declines with age. Women have less change with age.</text><detail>Ages 4 to 7 -- The average flow rate for both males and females is 10 mL/sec. </detail><detail>Ages 8 to 13 -- The average flow rate for males is 12 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 15 mL/sec. </detail><detail>Ages 14 to 45 -- The average flow rate for males is 21 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 18 mL/sec. </detail><detail>Ages 46 to 65 -- The average flow rate for males is 12 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 18 mL/sec. </detail><detail>Ages 66 to 80 -- The average flow rate for males is 9 mL/sec. The average flow rate for females is 18 mL/sec. </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Results are compared with your symptoms and physical exam. A result that may need treatment in one person may not need treatment in another person.</text><text>Several circular muscles around the urethra normally regulate urine flow. If any of these muscles becomes weak or stops working, you may have an increase in urine flow or urinary incontinence .</text><text>If there is a bladder outlet obstruction or if the bladder muscle is weak, you may have a decrease in urine flow. The amount of urine that remains in your bladder after urinating can be measured with ultrasound. </text><text>Your provider should explain and discuss any abnormal results with you.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Uroflow</detail>

item.title: Urine specific gravity test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that may affect the test results. These may include dextran and sucrose. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Also tell your provider if you recently received intravenous dye (contrast medium) for an x-ray. Contrast dye can also affect test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test helps evaluate your body's water balance and urine concentration.</text>
item.NormalResults: Osmolality is a more specific test for urine concentration. The urine specific gravity test is easier and more convenient, and is usually part of a routine urinalysis . The osmolality test may not be needed.Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased urine specific gravity may be due to conditions such as:</text><detail>Loss of body fluids ( dehydration )</detail><detail>Diarrhea that causes dehydration</detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Sugar (glucose) in the urine</detail><detail> Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) </detail><text>Decreased urine specific gravity may be due to:</text><detail>Damage to kidney tubule cells ( renal tubular necrosis )</detail><detail> Diabetes insipidus </detail><detail>Drinking too much fluid</detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine density</detail>

item.title: Urine protein electrophoresis test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you to stop taking certain medicines that could interfere with the test. Medicines that can affect test results include:</text><detail>Chlorpromazine</detail><detail>Corticosteroids</detail><detail>Isoniazid</detail><detail>Neomycin</detail><detail>Phenacemide</detail><detail>Salicylates</detail><detail>Sulfonamides</detail><detail>Tolbutamide </detail><text>Do not stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Normally there is no protein, or only a small amount of protein in the urine. An abnormally high amount of protein in the urine can be a sign of many different disorders.</text><text>UPEP may be recommended to help determine the cause of protein in the urine. Or it may be done as a screening test to measure the various amounts of different types of proteins in urine. UPEP detects 2 types of protein: albumin and globulins.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No significant amount of globulins are found in the urine. Urine albumin is less than 5 mg/dL.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the urine sample has a significant amount of globulins or higher than normal level of albumin, it may mean any of the following:</text><detail> Acute inflammation</detail><detail>Abnormal protein buildup in tissues and organs ( amyloidosis )</detail><detail>Decreased kidney function</detail><detail> Kidney disease due to diabetes ( diabetic nephropathy )</detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail> A type of blood cancer called multiple myeloma </detail><detail> Group of symptoms that include protein in the urine, low protein level in the blood, swelling ( nephrotic syndrome )</detail><detail>Acute urinary tract infection </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine protein electrophoresis</detail><detail> UPEP</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma - UPEP</detail><detail> Waldenström macroglobulinemia - UPEP</detail><detail> Amyloidosis - UPEP </detail>

item.title: Urine pH test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you to stop taking certain medicines that can affect the results of the test. These may include:</text><detail>Acetazolamide</detail><detail>Ammonium chloride</detail><detail>Methenamine mandelate</detail><detail>Potassium citrate</detail><detail>Sodium bicarbonate</detail><detail>Thiazide diuretic </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Eat a normal, balanced diet for several days before the test. Note that:</text><detail>A diet high in fruits, vegetables, or non-cheese dairy products can increase your urine pH.</detail><detail>A diet high in fish, meat products, or cheese can decrease your urine pH.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test to check for changes in your urine acid levels. It may be done to see if you:</text><detail>Are at risk of kidney stones . Different types of stones can form depending on how acidic your urine is.</detail><detail>Need to take certain medicines to treat urinary tract infections. Some medicines are more effective when urine is acidic or non-acidic (alkaline).</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal values range from pH 4.6 to 8.0.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high urine pH may be due to:</text><detail>Kidneys that do not properly remove acids (kidney tubular acidosis, also known as renal tubular acidosis)</detail><detail>Kidney failure</detail><detail>Stomach pumping (gastric suction)</detail><detail>Urinary tract infection</detail><detail>Vomiting</detail><text>A low urine pH may be due to:</text><detail>Diabetic ketoacidosis</detail><detail>Diarrhea</detail><detail>Too much acid in the body fluids ( metabolic acidosis ), such as diabetic ketoacidosis </detail><detail>Starvation</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>pH - urine</detail>

item.title: Urine drug screen
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed to detect the presence of illegal and some prescription drugs in your urine. Their presence may indicate that you recently used these drugs. Some drugs may remain in your system for several weeks, so the drug test needs to be interpreted carefully.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No drugs in the urine, unless you are taking medicines prescribed by your provider.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the test result is positive, another test called gas-chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS) may be done to confirm the results. The GC-MS will help tell the difference between a false positive and a true positive. </text><text>In some cases, a test will indicate a false positive. This can result from interfering factors such as some foods, prescription medicines, and other drugs. Your provider will be aware of this possibility.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Drug screen - urine</detail>

item.title: Urine culture - catheterized specimen
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Do not urinate for at least 1 hour before the test. If you don't have the urge to urinate, you may be instructed to drink a glass of water 15 to 20 minutes before the test. Otherwise, there is no preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done:</text><detail>To get a sterile urine sample in a person who cannot urinate on their own</detail><detail>If you might have a urinary tract infection</detail><detail>If you cannot empty your bladder (urinary retention)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values depend on the test being performed. Normal results are reported as "no growth" and are a sign that there is no infection.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A "positive" or abnormal test means germs, such as bacteria or yeast, are found in the urine sample. This likely means that you have a urinary tract infection or a bladder infection. If there is only a small amount of germs, your health care provider may not recommend treatment.</text><text>Sometimes, bacteria that do not cause urinary tract infections may be found in the culture. This is called a contaminant. You may not need to be treated.</text><text>People who have a urinary catheter in all of the time may have bacteria in their urine sample, but it does not cause a true infection. This is called being colonized.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - urine - catheterized specimen</detail><detail> Urine culture - catheterization</detail><detail> Catheterized urine specimen culture</detail>

item.title: Urine culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If possible, collect the sample when urine has been in your bladder for 2 to 3 hours.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have symptoms of a urinary tract infection or bladder infection, such as pain or burning when urinating.</text><text>You also may have a urine culture after you have been treated for an infection. This is to make sure that all of the bacteria are gone.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>"Normal growth" is a normal result. This means that there is no infection.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A "positive" or abnormal test is when bacteria or yeast are found in the culture. This likely means that you have a urinary tract infection or bladder infection.</text><text>Other tests may help your provider know which bacteria or yeast are causing the infection and which antibiotics will best treat it.</text><text>Sometimes more than one type of bacteria, or only a small amount, may be found in the culture.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture and sensitivity - urine </detail>

item.title: Urine concentration test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Eat a normal, balanced diet for several days before the test. Your provider will give you instructions for water loading or water deprivation.</text><text>Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop any medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take, including dextran and sucrose. DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Also tell your provider if you recently received intravenous dye (contrast medium) for an imaging test such as a CT scan. The dye can also affect test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done if your doctor suspects central diabetes insipidus . The test can help tell that disease from nephrogenic diabetes insipidus .</text><text>This test may also be done if you have signs of syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In general, normal values for specific gravity are as follows:</text><detail>1.005 to 1.030 (normal specific gravity)</detail><detail>1.001 after drinking excessive amounts of water</detail><detail>More than 1.030 after avoiding fluids</detail><detail>Concentrated after receiving ADH </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased urine concentration may be due to different conditions, such as:</text><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Loss of body fluids (dehydration) from diarrhea or excessive sweating</detail><detail>Narrowing of the kidney artery (renal arterial stenosis)</detail><detail> Sugar, or glucose, in the urine </detail><detail>Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion ( SIADH )</detail><detail>Vomiting</detail><text>Decreased urine concentration may indicate:</text><detail>Diabetes insipidus</detail><detail>Drinking too much fluid</detail><detail> Kidney failure (loss of ability to reabsorb water)</detail><detail>Severe kidney infection (pyelonephritis)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Water loading test</detail><detail> Water deprivation test</detail>

item.title: Urine collection - infants
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no preparation for the test. If you collect the urine at home, have some extra collection bags available.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed to get a urine sample from an infant.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values depend on what tests will be performed on the urine after it is collected.</text>

item.title: Urine 24-hour volume
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain drugs can also affect the test results. Your provider may tell you to stop taking certain medicines before the test. Never stop taking medicine without first talking to your provider.</text><text>The following may also affect test results:</text><detail>Dehydration</detail><detail>Any type of x-ray exam with dye (contrast material) within 3 days before the urine test</detail><detail>Fluid from the vagina that gets into the urine</detail><detail>Emotional stress</detail><detail>Heavy exercise</detail><detail>Urinary tract infection </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test if there are signs of damage to your kidney function on blood, urine, or imaging tests.</text><text>Urine volume is normally measured as part of a test that measures the amount of a substances passed in your urine in a day, such as:</text><detail> Creatinine </detail><detail> Sodium </detail><detail> Potassium </detail><detail> Urea nitrogen </detail><detail> Protein </detail><text>This test may also be done if you have polyuria (abnormally large volumes of urine), such as is seen in people with diabetes insipidus .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range for 24-hour urine volume is 800 to 2,000 milliliters per day (with a normal fluid intake of about 2 liters per day). </text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Disorders that cause reduced urine volume include dehydration, not enough fluid intake, or some types of chronic kidney disease.</text><text>Some of the conditions that cause increased urine volume include:</text><detail> Diabetes insipidus - renal </detail><detail>Diabetes insipidus - central</detail><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail>High fluid intake</detail><detail>Some forms of kidney disease</detail><detail>Use of diuretic medicines </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine volume</detail><detail> 24-hour urine collection</detail><detail> Urine protein - 24 hour</detail>

item.title: Urinary casts
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test to see if your kidneys are working properly. It may also be ordered to check for certain conditions, such as: </text><detail> Glomerular disease </detail><detail> Interstitial kidney disease </detail><detail>Kidney infections </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The absence of cellular casts or presence of a few hyaline casts is normal. The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may include:</text><detail> Fatty casts are seen in people who have lipids in urine. This is most often a complication of nephrotic syndrome .</detail><detail> Granular casts are a sign of many types of kidney diseases.</detail><detail> Red blood cell casts mean there is a microscopic amount of bleeding from the kidney. They are seen in many kidney diseases.</detail><detail> Renal tubular epithelial cell casts reflect damage to tubule cells in the kidney. These casts are seen in conditions such as renal tubular necrosis , viral disease (such as CMV nephritis ), and kidney transplant rejection .</detail><detail> Waxy casts can be found in people with advanced kidney disease and long-term (chronic) kidney failure .</detail><detail> White blood cell (WBC) casts are common with acute kidney infections and interstitial nephritis. </detail><text>Your provider will tell you more about your results.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Hyaline casts</detail><detail> Granular casts</detail><detail> Renal tubular epithelial casts</detail><detail> Waxy casts</detail><detail> Casts in the urine</detail><detail> Fatty casts</detail><detail> Red blood cell casts</detail><detail> White blood cell casts</detail>

item.title: Urinalysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines change the color of urine, but this is not a sign of disease. Your provider may tell you to stop taking any medicines that can affect test results.</text><text>Medicines that can change your urine color include:</text><detail>Chloroquine</detail><detail>Iron supplements</detail><detail>Levodopa</detail><detail>Nitrofurantoin</detail><detail>Phenazopyridine</detail><detail>Phenothiazine</detail><detail>Phenytoin</detail><detail>Riboflavin</detail><detail>Triamterene </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A urinalysis may be done:</text><detail>As part of a routine medical exam to screen for early signs of disease</detail><detail>If you have signs of diabetes or kidney disease, or to monitor you if you are being treated for these conditions</detail><detail>To check for blood in the urine </detail><detail>To diagnose a urinary tract infection </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal urine varies in color from almost colorless to dark yellow. Some foods, such as beets and blackberries, may turn urine red.</text><text>Usually, glucose, ketones, protein, and bilirubin are not detectable in urine. The following are not normally found in urine:</text><detail>Hemoglobin</detail><detail>Nitrites</detail><detail>Red blood cells</detail><detail>White blood cells </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean you have an illness, such as:</text><detail> Urinary tract infection </detail><detail> Kidney stones </detail><detail> Poorly controlled diabetes </detail><detail> Bladder or kidney cancer </detail><text>Your provider can discuss the results with you.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine appearance and color</detail><detail> Routine urine test</detail><detail> Cystitis - urinalysis</detail><detail> Bladder infection - urinalysis</detail><detail> UTI - urinalysis</detail><detail> Urinary tract infection - urinalysis</detail><detail> Hematuria - urinalysis</detail>

item.title: Uric acid urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may ask you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Aspirin or aspirin-containing medicines</detail><detail> Gout medicines</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen)</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics) </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Be aware that alcoholic drinks, vitamin C, and x-ray dye can also affect test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to help determine the cause of a high uric acid level in the blood. It may also be done to monitor people with gout, and to choose the best medicine to lower the uric acid level in the blood.</text><text>Uric acid is a chemical created when the body breaks down substances called purines. Most uric acid dissolves in blood and travels to the kidneys, where it passes out in urine. If your body produces too much uric acid or does not remove enough of it, you may get sick. A high level of uric acid in the body is called hyperuricemia and it can lead to gout or kidney damage.</text><text>This test may also be done to check whether a high uric acid level is causing kidney stones.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 250 to 750 mg/24 hours (1.48 to 4.43 mmol/24 hours).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high uric acid level in the urine may be due to:</text><detail>Body not being able to process purine ( Lesch-Nyhan syndrome)</detail><detail>Certain cancers that have spread (metastasized)</detail><detail>Disease that results in breakdown of muscle fibers ( rhabdomyolysis )</detail><detail>Disorders that affect the bone marrow (myeloproliferative disorder)</detail><detail> Disorder of the kidney tubes in which certain substances normally absorbed into the bloodstream by the kidneys are released into the urine instead ( Fanconi syndrome )</detail><detail>Gout</detail><detail>High-purine diet </detail><text>A low uric acid level in the urine may be due to:</text><detail>Kidney that is not able to get rid of uric acid well, which can lead to gout or kidney damage</detail><detail>Kidneys that are not able to filter fluids and waste normally (chronic glomerulonephritis )</detail><detail> Lead poisoning </detail><detail>Long-term (chronic) alcohol use </detail>

item.title: Uric acid - blood
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink anything for 4 hours before the test unless told otherwise. </text><text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see if you have a high level of uric acid in your blood. High levels of uric acid can sometimes cause gout or kidney disease.</text><text>You may have this test if you have had or are about to have certain types of chemotherapy. Rapid weight loss, which may occur with such treatments, can increase the amount of uric acid in your blood.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range between 3.5 to 7.2 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement range for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Greater-than-normal levels of uric acid (hyperuricemia) may be due to:</text><detail> Acidosis </detail><detail> Alcoholism </detail><detail>Chemotherapy-related side effects</detail><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail>Excessive exercise</detail><detail>Gout</detail><detail> Hypoparathyroidism </detail><detail> Lead poisoning </detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Medullary cystic kidney disease</detail><detail> Nephrolithiasis </detail><detail> Polycythemia vera </detail><detail>Purine-rich diet</detail><detail> Renal failure </detail><detail> Toxemia of pregnancy </detail><text>Lower-than-normal levels of uric acid may be due to:</text><detail> Fanconi syndrome </detail><detail>Low purine diet</detail><detail> Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion </detail><detail> Wilson disease </detail><text>Other reasons this test may be performed include:</text><detail> Chronic gouty arthritis </detail><detail>Chronic kidney disease</detail><detail> Injury of the kidney and ureter </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gout - uric acid in blood</detail><detail> Hyperuricemia - uric acid in blood</detail>

item.title: Urethral discharge culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT urinate for 1 hour before the test. Urinating washes away some of the germs needed for accurate test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The provider often orders the test when there is a discharge from the urethra. This test can detect sexually transmitted infections (STIs), such as gonorrhea and chlamydia .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative culture, or no growth appearing in the culture, is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results can be a sign of infection in the genital tract. These infections can include gonorrhea or chlamydia.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture of urethral discharge</detail><detail> Genital exudate culture</detail><detail> Culture - genital discharge or exudate</detail><detail> Urethritis - culture</detail>

item.title: Ureteral retrograde brush biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may not be able to eat or drink anything for about 6 hours before the test. Your health care provider will tell you how you need to prepare.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to take a sample of tissue from the kidney or ureter. It is performed when an x-ray or other test has shown a suspicious area (lesion). This can also be done if there is blood or abnormal cells in the urine.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The tissue appears normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may show cancer cells ( carcinoma ). This test is often used to tell the difference between cancerous (malignant) and noncancerous ( benign ) lesions.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - brush - urinary tract</detail><detail> Retrograde ureteral brush biopsy cytology</detail><detail> Cytology - ureteral retrograde brush biopsy</detail>

item.title: Urea nitrogen urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is mainly used to check a person's protein balance and the amount of food protein needed by severely ill people. It is also used to determine how much protein a person takes in.</text><text>Urea is excreted by the kidneys. The test measures the amount of urea the kidneys excrete. The result can show how well the kidneys are working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 12 to 20 grams per 24 hours (428.4 to 714 mmol/day).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Low levels usually indicate:</text><detail>Kidney problems</detail><detail>Malnutrition (inadequate protein in diet ) </detail><text>High levels usually indicate:</text><detail>Increased protein breakdown in the body</detail><detail>Too much protein intake</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine urea nitrogen</detail>

item.title: Upper GI and small bowel series
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may have to change your diet for 2 or 3 days before the test. In most cases, you will not be able to eat for a period of time before the test.</text><text>Be sure to ask your health care provider if you need to change how you take any of your medicines. Often you can continue taking the medicines you take by mouth. Never make any changes in your medicines without first talking to your provider.</text><text>You will be asked to remove all jewelry on your neck, chest, or abdomen before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to look for a problem in the structure or function of your esophagus, stomach, or small intestine.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result shows that the esophagus, stomach, and small intestine are normal in size, shape, and movement.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary depending on the lab doing the test. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results in the esophagus may indicate the following problems:</text><detail> Achalasia </detail><detail> Diverticula </detail><detail> Esophageal cancer </detail><detail> Esophageal narrowing (stricture) - benign </detail><detail> Hiatal hernia </detail><detail> Ulcers </detail><text>Abnormal results in the stomach may indicate the following problems:</text><detail> Gastric cancer </detail><detail> Gastric ulcer - benign</detail><detail> Gastritis </detail><detail>Polyps (a tumor that is usually noncancerous and grows on the mucus membrane )</detail><detail> Pyloric stenosis (narrowing)</detail><text>Abnormal results in the small intestine may indicate the following problems:</text><detail> Malabsorption syndrome</detail><detail>Swelling and irritation of the small intestines</detail><detail>Tumors</detail><detail>Ulcers</detail><text>The test may also be done for the following conditons:</text><detail> Annular pancreas </detail><detail> Duodenal ulcer </detail><detail> Gastroesophageal reflux disease </detail><detail> Gastroparesis </detail><detail> Intestinal obstruction </detail><detail> Lower esophageal ring </detail><detail> Primary or idiopathic intestinal pseudo-obstruction </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>GI series</detail><detail> Barium swallow x-ray</detail><detail> Upper GI series</detail>

item.title: Upper airway biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT eat for 6 to 12 hours before the test. </text><text>Tell your provider if you take a blood thinner, such as aspirin, plavix or coumadin, when you schedule the biopsy. You may need to stop taking them for a little while. Never stop taking any medicines without first talking to your provider. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done if your provider thinks there is a problem with your upper airway. It may also be done with a bronchoscopy .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The upper airway tissues are normal, with no abnormal growths.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Disorders or conditions that may be discovered include:</text><detail>Benign (noncancerous) cysts or masses</detail><detail> Cancer </detail><detail>Certain infections</detail><detail> Granulomas and related inflammation (may be caused by tuberculosis )</detail><detail>Autoimmune disorders, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis </detail><detail> Necrotizing vasculitis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - upper airway</detail>

item.title: Voiding cystourethrogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must sign a consent form. You will be given a gown to wear.</text><text>Remove all jewelry before the test. Inform the provider if you are:</text><detail>Allergic to any medicines</detail><detail>Allergic to x-ray contrast material</detail><detail>Pregnant</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to diagnose the cause of urinary tract infections, especially in children who have had more than one urinary tract or bladder infection.</text><text>It is also used to diagnose and evaluate:</text><detail>Difficulty emptying the bladder</detail><detail>Birth defects with the bladder or urethra</detail><detail>Narrowing of the tube that carries urine out of the bladder ( urethral stricture ) in males</detail><detail>Urinary reflux from the bladder up into the kidney</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bladder and urethra will be normal in size and function.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate the following:</text><detail>Bladder does not empty properly because of a brain or nerve problem (neurogenic bladder) </detail><detail> Large prostate gland </detail><detail>Narrowing or scarring of the urethra</detail><detail>Pouch-like sacs (diverticula) on the walls of the bladder or urethra</detail><detail> Ureterocele </detail><detail> Urinary reflux nephropathy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cystourethrogram - voiding</detail>

item.title: VLDL test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test to help assess your risk for heart disease. Increased levels of VLDL are linked to atherosclerosis . This condition can lead to coronary heart disease .</text><text>This test may be included in a coronary risk profile.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal VLDL cholesterol level is between 2 and 30 mg/dL.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high VLDL cholesterol level may be associated with a higher risk for heart disease and stroke. However, VLDL cholesterol level is rarely targeted when treatment for high cholesterol is done. Instead, LDL cholesterol level is more often the main target of therapy.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Very low density lipoprotein test</detail>

item.title: Vitamin B12 level
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for about 6 to 8 hours before the test.</text><text>Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Medicines that can affect the test result include:</text><detail>Colchicine</detail><detail>Neomycin</detail><detail>Para-aminosalicylic acid</detail><detail>Phenytoin</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done when other blood tests suggest a condition called megaloblastic anemia. Pernicious anemia is a form of megaloblastic anemia caused by poor vitamin B12 absorption. This can occur when the stomach makes less of the substance the body needs to properly absorb vitamin B12.</text><text>Your provider may also recommend a vitamin B12 test if you have certain nervous system symptoms. A low level of B12 can cause numbness or tingling in the arms and legs, weakness, and loss of balance.</text><text>Other conditions for which the test may be done include:</text><detail>Sudden severe confusion ( delirium )</detail><detail>Loss of brain function ( dementia )</detail><detail> Dementia due to metabolic causes </detail><detail>Nerve abnormalities, such as peripheral neuropathy </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are 160 to 950 picograms per milliliter (pg/mL), or 118 to 701 picomole per liter (pmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about what your specific test results mean.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Values of less than 160 pg/mL (118 pmol/L) are a possible sign of a vitamin B12 deficiency. People with this deficiency are likely to have or develop symptoms. </text><text>Older adults with a vitamin B12 level less than 100 pg/mL (74 pmol/L) may also have symptoms. Deficiency should be confirmed by checking the level of a substance in the blood called methylmalonic acid. A high level indicates a true B12 deficiency.</text><text>Causes of vitamin B12 deficiency include:</text><detail>Not enough vitamin B12 in diet (rare, except with a strict vegetarian diet)</detail><detail>Diseases that cause malabsorption (for example, celiac disease and Crohn disease )</detail><detail>Lack of intrinsic factor , a protein that helps the intestine absorb vitamin B12</detail><detail>Above normal heat production (for example, with hyperthyroidism )</detail><detail>Pregnancy </detail><text>An increased vitamin B12 level is uncommon. Usually, excess vitamin B12 is removed in the urine.</text><text>Conditions that can increase B12 level include:</text><detail>Liver disease (such as cirrhosis or hepatitis )</detail><detail> Myeloproliferative disorders (for example, polycythemia vera and chronic myelogenous leukemia ) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cobalamin test</detail><detail> Pernicious anemia - vitamin B12 level</detail>

item.title: Vitamin A blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your health care provider's instructions about not eating or drinking anything for up to 24 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check if you have too much or too little vitamin A in your blood. (These conditions are uncommon in the United States.)</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 15 to 60 micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL) or 0.52 to 2.09 micromoles per liter (micromol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A lower than normal value means you do not have enough vitamin A in your blood. This may cause:</text><detail>Bone or teeth problems in young children</detail><detail>Dry or inflamed eyes</detail><detail> Night blindness </detail><detail>Recurring infections</detail><detail>Skin rashes</detail><detail>Reduced growth</detail><detail>Dry skin </detail><text>A higher than normal value means you have excess vitamin A in your blood (toxic levels). This may cause:</text><detail>Hair loss</detail><detail>Loss of appetite</detail><detail>Bone and muscle pain</detail><detail>Increased pressure in the brain (pseudotumor cerebri)</detail><detail>Anemia</detail><detail>Double vision</detail><detail>Liver and spleen enlargement</detail><detail>Nausea</detail><detail>Diarrhrea</detail><detail>Lack of muscle coordination (ataxia) </detail><text>Vitamin A deficiency may occur if your body has trouble absorbing fats through the digestive tract. This may occur if you have:</text><detail>Chronic lung disease called cystic fibrosis </detail><detail>Pancreas problems, such as swelling and inflammation ( pancreatitis ) or the organ not producing enough enzymes (pancreatic insufficiency)</detail><detail>Small intestine disorder called celiac disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Retinol test</detail>

item.title: Visual field
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This eye exam will show whether you have a loss of vision anywhere in your visual field. The pattern of vision loss will help your provider diagnose the cause.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The peripheral vision is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to diseases or central nervous system (CNS) disorders, such as tumors that damage or press on (compress) the parts of the brain that deal with vision.</text><text>Other diseases that may affect the visual field of the eye include:</text><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail> Glaucoma (increased eye pressure)</detail><detail>High blood pressure</detail><detail> Macular degeneration (eye disorder that slowly destroys sharp, central vision)</detail><detail> Multiple sclerosis (disorder that affects the CNS)</detail><detail> Optic glioma (tumor of the optic nerve)</detail><detail> Overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism)</detail><detail>Pituitary gland disorders</detail><detail> Retinal detachment (separation of the retina in the back of the eye from its supporting layers)</detail><detail> Stroke </detail><detail> Temporal arteritis (inflammation and damage to the blood vessels that supply blood to the head) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Perimetry</detail><detail> Tangent screen exam</detail><detail> Automated perimetry exam</detail><detail> Goldmann visual field exam</detail><detail> Humphrey visual field exam</detail>

item.title: Visual acuity test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The visual acuity test is a routine part of an eye examination or general physical examination, particularly if there is a change in vision or a problem with vision.</text><text>In children, the test is performed to screen for vision problems. Vision problems in young children can often be corrected or improved. Undetected or untreated problems may lead to permanent vision damage.</text><text>There are other ways to check vision in very young children, or in people who do not know their letters or numbers.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Visual acuity is expressed as a fraction.</text><detail>The top number refers to the distance you stand from the chart. This is often 20 feet (6 meters).</detail><detail>The bottom number indicates the distance at which a person with normal eyesight could read the same line you correctly read.</detail><text>For example, 20/20 is considered normal. 20/40 indicates that the line you correctly read at 20 feet (6 meters) away can be read by a person with normal vision from 40 feet (12 meters) away. Outside of the United States, the visual acuity is expressed as a decimal number. For example, 20/20 is 1.0, 20/40 is 0.5, 20/80 is 0.25, 20/100 is 0.2, and so on.</text><text>Even if you miss one or two letters on the smallest line you can read, you are still considered to have vision equal to that line.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign that you need glasses or contacts. Or it may mean that you have an eye condition that needs further evaluation by a provider.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Eye test - acuity</detail><detail> Vision test - acuity</detail><detail> Snellen test</detail>

item.title: Virtual colonoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your bowels need to be completely empty and clean for the exam. A problem in your large intestine that needs to be treated may be missed if your intestines are not cleaned out. </text><text>Your health care provider will give you the steps for cleansing your bowel. This is called bowel preparation. Steps may include: </text><detail>Using enemas</detail><detail>Not eating solid foods for 1 to 3 days before the test</detail><detail>Taking laxatives </detail><text>You need to drink plenty of clear liquids for 1 to 3 days before the test. Examples of clear liquids are:</text><detail>Clear coffee or tea</detail><detail>Fat-free bouillon or broth</detail><detail>Gelatin</detail><detail>Sports drinks without added color</detail><detail>Strained fruit juices</detail><detail>Water </detail><text>You will likely be told to stop taking aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen, or other blood-thinning medicines for several days before the test. Keep taking your other medicines unless your doctor tells you otherwise. </text><text>You will ask your provider if you need to stop taking iron pills or liquids a few days before the test, unless your provider tells you it is OK to continue. Iron can make your stool dark black. This makes it harder for the doctor to view inside your bowel. </text><text>CT and MRI scanners are very sensitive to metals. Do not wear jewelry the day of your exam. You will be asked to change out of your street clothes and wear a hospital gown for the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>VC may be done for the following reasons:</text><detail>Follow-up on colon cancer or polyps</detail><detail>Abdominal pain, changes in bowel movements, or weight loss</detail><detail> Anemia due to low iron</detail><detail>Blood in the stool or black, tarry stools</detail><detail>Screen for cancer of the colon or rectum (should be done every 5 years) </detail><text>Your doctor may want to do a regular colonoscopy instead of a VC. The reason is that VC does not allow the doctor to remove tissue samples or polyps.</text><text>Other times, a VC is done if your doctor was not able to move the flexible tube all the way through the colon during a regular colonoscopy.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal findings are images of a healthy intestinal tract.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal test results may mean any of the following:</text><detail>Colorectal cancer</detail><detail>Abnormal pouches on the lining of the intestines, called diverticulosis </detail><detail>Colitis (a swollen and inflamed intestine) due to Crohn disease , ulcerative colitis , infection, or lack of blood flow</detail><detail>Lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding</detail><detail> Polyps </detail><detail>Tumor </detail><text>Regular colonoscopy may be done (on a different day) after a VC if:</text><detail>No cause for bleeding or other symptoms were found. VC can miss some smaller problems in the colon.</detail><detail>Problems that need a biopsy were seen on a VC. </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Colonoscopy - virtual</detail><detail> CT colonography</detail><detail> Computed tomographic colonography</detail><detail> Colography - virtual</detail>

item.title: Venogram - leg
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will wear hospital clothing during this procedure. You will be asked to sign a consent form for the procedure. Remove all jewelry from the area being imaged.</text><text>Tell the provider:</text><detail>If you are pregnant</detail><detail>If you have allergies to any medicines </detail><detail>Which medicines you are taking (including any herbal preparations)</detail><detail>If you have ever had any allergic reactions to x-ray contrast material or iodine substance</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to identify and locate blood clots in the veins of the legs.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Free flow of the blood through the vein is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to a blockage. The blockage can be caused by:</text><detail> Blood clot </detail><detail>Tumor</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Phlebogram - leg</detail><detail> Venography - leg</detail><detail> Angiogram - leg</detail>

item.title: Venipuncture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The steps you need to take before the test will depend on the kind of blood test you are having. Many tests do not require special steps.</text><text>In some cases, your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test or if you need to be fasting. Do not stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Blood is made up of two parts:</text><detail>Fluid (plasma or serum)</detail><detail>Cells</detail><text>Plasma is the fluid part that contains substances such as glucose, electrolytes, proteins, and water. Serum is the fluid part that remains after the blood is allowed to clot in a test tube.</text><text>Cells in the blood include red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets .</text><text>Blood helps move oxygen, nutrients, waste products, and other materials through the body. It helps control body temperature, fluid balance, and the body's acid-base balance.</text><text>Tests on blood or parts of blood may give your provider important clues about your health.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results vary with the specific test.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results vary with the specific test.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Blood-draw</detail><detail> Phlebotomy</detail>

item.title: VDRL test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to screen for syphilis. The bacteria that cause syphilis is called Treponema pallidum.</text><text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs and symptoms of a sexually transmitted illness (STI).</text><text>Syphilis screening is a routine part of prenatal care during pregnancy. Several states also require screening for syphilis prior to obtaining a marriage license.</text><text>This test is similar to the newer rapid plasma reagin ( RPR ) test.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test is normal. It means that no antibodies to syphilis have been seen in your blood sample.</text><text>The screening test is most likely to be positive in the secondary and latent stages of syphilis. This test may give a false-negative result during early- and late-stage syphilis. This test must be confirmed with another blood test to make the diagnosis of syphilis.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test result means you may have syphilis. If the test is positive, the next step is to confirm the results with an FTA-ABS test, which is a more specific syphilis test.</text><text>The VDRL test's ability to detect syphilis depends on the stage of the disease. The test's sensitivity to detect syphilis nears 100% during the middle stages; it is less sensitive during the earlier and later stages.</text><text>Some conditions may cause a false-positive test, including:</text><detail>HIV/AIDS</detail><detail>Lyme disease</detail><detail>Certain types of pneumonia</detail><detail>Malaria</detail><detail>Systemic lupus erythematosus</detail><text>The body does not always produce antibodies specifically in response to the syphilis bacteria, so this test is not always accurate.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Venereal disease research laboratory test</detail><detail> Syphilis - VDRL</detail>

item.title: Vasoactive intestinal peptide test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink anything for 4 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to measure VIP level in the blood. A very high level is usually caused by a VIPoma . This is an extremely rare tumor that releases VIP.</text><text>VIP is a substance found in cells throughout the body. The highest levels are normally found in cells in the nervous system and gut.
