VIP has many functions, including relaxing certain muscles, triggering release of hormones from the pancreas, gut, and hypothalamus, and increasing the amount of water and electrolytes secreted from the pancreas and gut.</text><text>VIPomas produce and release VIP into the blood. This blood test checks the amount of VIP in the blood to see if a person has a VIPoma.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from less than 70 pg/mL (20.7 pmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level, along with symptoms of watery diarrhea and flushing, may be a sign of a VIPoma.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>VIPoma - vasoactive intestinal polypeptide test</detail>

item.title: Vaginitis test - wet mount
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow any instructions from your provider on preparing for the test. This may include:</text><detail>In the 2 days before the test, DO NOT use creams or other medicines in the vagina.</detail><detail>DO NOT douche. (You should never douche. Douching can cause infection of the vagina or uterus.) </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test looks for the cause of vaginal irritation and discharge.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result means there are no signs of an infection.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean there is an infection. The most common infections are due to one or a combination of the following:</text><detail>Bacterial vaginosis. Bacteria that normally live in the vagina overgrow, causing a heavy, white, fishy-smelling discharge and possibly a rash, painful intercourse, or odor after intercourse.</detail><detail> Trichomoniasis , a sexually transmitted disease.</detail><detail> Vaginal yeast infection . </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Wet prep - vaginitis</detail><detail> Vaginosis - wet mount</detail><detail> Trichomoniasis - wet mount</detail><detail> Vaginal candida - wet mount</detail>

item.title: X-ray - skeleton
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the health care provider if you are pregnant. You must remove all jewelry before the x-ray.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to look for:</text><detail>Fractures or broken bone</detail><detail>Cancer that has spread to other areas of the body</detail><detail> Osteomyelitis (inflammation of the bone caused by an infection)</detail><detail>Bone damage due to trauma (such as an auto accident) or degenerative conditions</detail><detail>Abnormalities in the soft tissue around the bone</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal findings include:</text><detail>Fractures</detail><detail> Bone tumors </detail><detail>Degenerative bone conditions</detail><detail>Osteomyelitis</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Skeletal survey</detail>

item.title: X-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before the x-ray, tell your health care team if you are pregnant, may be pregnant, or if you have an IUD inserted.</text><text>You will need to remove all jewelry. Metal can cause unclear images. You may need to wear a hospital gown.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Radiography</detail>

item.title: 5'-nucleotidase
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you to stop taking some medicines that could interfere with the test. Drugs that may affect results include:</text><detail>Acetaminophen (Tylenol)</detail><detail>Halothane</detail><detail>Isoniazid</detail><detail>Methyldopa</detail><detail>Nitrofurantoin </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a liver problem. It is used mostly to tell if the high protein level is due to liver damage or skeletal muscle damage.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal value is 2 to 17 units per liter.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Greater than normal levels may indicate:</text><detail> Cholestasis (when bile, which is made by the liver to help digest fats, is blocked from flowing out of the liver</detail><detail>Destruction of liver cells</detail><detail> Hepatitis (liver inflammation)</detail><detail> Liver ischemia (loss of blood and oxygen to the liver)</detail><detail> Liver tumor </detail><detail>Use of a liver-damaging drug </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>5'-NT</detail>

item.title: 25-hydroxy vitamin D test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Usually, you will not need to fast. But, this depends on the laboratory and the testing method used. So, follow any instructions for not eating before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to determine if you have too much or too little vitamin D in your blood. Screening of all adults, even when pregnant, for low vitamin D levels, is generally not recommended.</text><text>However, screening may be done on people who are at high risk for vitamin D deficiency, such as those who:</text><detail>Are obese</detail><detail>Are taking certain medicines, such as phenytoin</detail><detail>Have osteoporosis or thin bones</detail><detail>Have limited sun exposure</detail><detail>Have problems absorbing vitamins and nutrients in their intestines, such as those with ulcerative colitis, Crohn disease, or celiac disease</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range of vitamin D is measured as nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL). Many experts recommend a level between 20 and 40 ng/mL. Others recommend a level between 30 and 50 ng/mL.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some laboratories use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results, and whether you may need vitamin D supplements.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A lower-than-normal level can be due to a vitamin D deficiency, which can result from:</text><detail>Lack of skin exposure to sunlight, dark skin, or constant use of high SPF sunscreen</detail><detail>Lack of enough vitamin D in the diet</detail><detail>Liver and kidney diseases</detail><detail>Poor food absorption</detail><detail>Use of certain medicines, including phenytoin, phenobarbital, and rifampin </detail><detail>Poor vitamin D absorption due to advanced age, weight-loss surgery, or conditions in which fat is not absorbed well</detail><text>A low vitamin D level is more common in African American children (especially in the winter), as well as in infants who are breastfed only.</text><text>A higher-than-normal level may be due to excess vitamin D, a condition called hypervitaminosis D . This is most commonly caused by taking too much vitamin D. It can result in too much calcium in the body ( hypercalcemia ). This leads to many symptoms and kidney damage.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>25-OH vitamin D test</detail><detail> Calcidiol</detail><detail> 25-hydroxycholecalciferol test</detail>

item.title: 24-hour urine protein
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will tell you, if needed, to stop taking any medicines that may interfere with the test results. </text><text>A number of medicines can change the test results. Make sure your provider knows about all medicines, herbs, vitamins, and supplements you are taking.</text><text>The following may also affect test results:</text><detail>A lack of fluid (dehydration)</detail><detail>Any type of x-ray exam with dye (contrast material) within 3 days before the urine test</detail><detail>Fluid from the vagina that gets into the urine</detail><detail>Severe emotional stress</detail><detail>Strenuous exercise</detail><detail>Urinary tract infection </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if blood, urine, or imaging tests find signs of damage to kidney function.</text><text>To avoid a 24-hour urine collection, your provider may be able to order a test that is done on just one urine sample (protein-to-creatinine ratio). </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal value is less than 100 milligrams per day or less than 10 milligrams per deciliter of urine.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>A group of diseases in which a protein called amyloid builds up in the organs and tissues ( amyloidosis )</detail><detail>Bladder tumor</detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>High blood pressure during pregnancy ( preeclampsia )</detail><detail>Kidney disease caused by diabetes, high blood pressure, autoimmune disorders, a blockage in the kidney system, certain medicines, toxins, a blockage of blood vessels, or other causes</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><text>Healthy people may have higher than normal urine protein level after strenuous exercise or when they are dehydrated. Some foods may affect urine protein levels.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine protein - 24 hour</detail><detail> Chronic kidney disease - urine protein</detail><detail> Kidney failure - urine protein</detail>

item.title: 24-hour urine copper test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test. Extra collection bags may be needed if the sample is being taken from an infant.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of Wilson disease , a genetic disorder that affects how the body processes copper.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 10 to 30 micrograms per 24 hours.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means you have a higher than normal level of copper. This may be due to:</text><detail>Biliary cirrhosis </detail><detail>Chronic active hepatitis</detail><detail>Wilson disease</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Quantitative urinary copper</detail>

item.title: 24-hour urinary aldosterone excretion test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may ask you to stop taking certain medicines a few days before the test so that they don't affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>High blood pressure medicines</detail><detail>Heart medicines</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail>Antacid and ulcer medicines</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics) </detail><text>Do not stop taking any medicine before talking to your doctor.</text><text>Be aware that other factors can affect aldosterone measurements, including:</text><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>High- or low-sodium diet</detail><detail>Eating large amounts of black licorice</detail><detail>Strenuous exercise</detail><detail>Stress </detail><text>Do not drink coffee, tea, or cola during the day the urine is collected. Your provider will likely recommend that you eat no more than 3 grams of salt (sodium) per day for at least 2 weeks before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to see how much aldosterone is released into your urine. Aldosterone is a hormone released by the adrenal gland that helps the kidney control salt, water, and potassium balance.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results depend on:</text><detail>How much sodium is in your diet</detail><detail>Whether your kidneys work properly</detail><detail>The condition being diagnosed</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level of aldosterone may be due to:</text><detail>Abuse of diuretics</detail><detail>Liver cirrhosis </detail><detail>Adrenal gland problems, including adrenal tumors that produce aldosterone</detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Laxative abuse </detail><text>Lower than normal levels may indicate Addison disease , a disorder in which the adrenal glands do not produce enough hormones.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Aldosterone - urine</detail><detail> Addison disease - urine aldosterone</detail><detail> Cirrhosis - serum aldosterone</detail>

item.title: 17-OH progesterone
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>Do not stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The main use of this test is to check infants for an inherited disorder that affects the adrenal gland, called congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). It is often done on infants who are born with outer genitals that do not clearly look like those of a boy or a girl.</text><text>This test is also used to identify people who develop symptoms of CAH later in life, a condition called nonclassical adrenal hyperplasia. </text><text>A provider may recommend this test for women or girls who have male traits such as:</text><detail>Excess hair growth in places where adult men grow hair</detail><detail>Deep voice or an increase in muscle mass</detail><detail>Absence of menses</detail><detail>Infertility</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal and abnormal values differ for babies born with low birth weight. In general, normal results are as follows:</text><detail>Babies more than 24 hours old - less than 400 to 600 nanograms per deciliter (ng/dL) or 12.12 to 18.18 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)</detail><detail>Children before puberty around 100 ng/dL or 3.03 nmol/L</detail><detail>Adults - less than 200 ng/dL or 6.06 nmol/L</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results of these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high level of 17-OH progesterone may be due to:</text><detail> Tumors of the adrenal gland </detail><detail> Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)</detail><text>In infants with CAH, the 17-OHP level ranges from 2,000 to 40,000 ng/dL or 60.6 to 1212 nmol/L. In adults, a level greater than 200 ng/dL or 6.06 nmol/L may be due to nonclassical adrenal hyperplasia.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>17-hydroxyprogesterone</detail><detail> Progesterone - 17-OH</detail>

item.title: 17-Ketosteroids urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop any medicines that may affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Antibiotics</detail><detail>Aspirin (if you are on long-term aspirin)</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Diuretics (water pills)</detail><detail>Estrogen </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a disorder associated with abnormal levels of androgens.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are as follows:</text><detail>Male: 7 to 20 mg per 24 hours</detail><detail>Female: 5 to 15 mg per 24 hours</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased levels of 17-ketosteroids may be due to:</text><detail>Adrenal gland problems such as tumor, Cushing syndrome </detail><detail>Imbalance of sex hormones in females ( polycystic ovary syndrome )</detail><detail> Ovarian cancer </detail><detail> Testicular cancer </detail><detail>Overactive thyroid</detail><detail>Obesity</detail><detail>Stress</detail><text>Decreased levels of 17-ketosteroids may be due to:</text><detail>Adrenal glands not making enough of their hormones ( Addison disease )</detail><detail>Kidney damage</detail><detail>Pituitary gland not making enough of its hormones ( hypopituitarism )</detail><detail>Removal of the testicles (castration) </detail>

item.title: 17-hydroxycorticosteroids urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The provider will instruct you, if necessary, to stop medicines that may interfere with the test. These may include:</text><detail>Birth control pills that contain estrogen</detail><detail>Certain antibiotics</detail><detail>Glucocorticoids</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>17-OHCS is a product formed when the liver and other body tissues break down the steroid hormone cortisol.</text><text>This test can help determine if the body is producing too much cortisol. The test may be used to diagnose Cushing syndrome . This is a disorder that occurs when the body has a high level of cortisol.</text><text>The urine volume and urine creatinine are often done with 17-OHCS test at the same time. This helps the provider interpret the test.</text><text>This test is not done often now. The cortisol urine test is a better screening test.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values:</text><detail>Male: 3 to 9 mg/24 hours (8.3 to 25 µmol/24 hours)</detail><detail>Female: 2 to 8 mg/24 hours (5.5 to 22 µmol/24 hours)</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level of 17-OHCS may indicate:</text><detail>A type of Cushing syndrome caused by a tumor in the adrenal gland that produces cortisol</detail><detail>Depression</detail><detail>Hydrocortisone therapy</detail><detail> Malnutrition </detail><detail> Obesity </detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>Severe high blood pressure </detail><detail>Severe physical or emotional stress</detail><detail> Tumor in the pituitary gland or elsewhere in the body that releases a hormone called adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) </detail><text>A lower than normal level of 17-OHCS may indicate:</text><detail> Adrenal glands are not producing enough of their hormones </detail><detail> Pituitary gland is not producing enough of its hormones </detail><detail>Hereditary enzyme deficiency</detail><detail>Previous surgery to remove the adrenal gland </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>17-OH corticosteroids</detail><detail> 17-OHCS</detail>

item.title: Joint fluid Gram stain
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will tell you how to prepare for the procedure. No special preparation is needed. But, tell your provider if you're taking a blood thinner, such as aspirin, warfarin (Coumadin) or clopidogrel (Plavix). These medicines can affect test results or your ability to take the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed when there is unexplained swelling, joint pain , and inflammation of a joint, or to check for suspected joint infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no bacteria are present on the Gram stain.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean bacteria were seen on the Gram stain. This may be a sign of a joint infection, for example, gonococcal arthritis or arthritis due to bacteria called Staphylococcus aureus. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gram stain of joint fluid</detail>

item.title: Audiometry
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test can detect hearing loss at an early stage. It may also be used when you have hearing problems from any cause.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results include:</text><detail>The ability to hear a whisper, normal speech, and a ticking watch is normal.</detail><detail>The ability to hear a tuning fork through air and bone is normal.</detail><detail>In detailed audiometry, hearing is normal if you can hear tones from 250 to 8,000 Hz at 25 dB or lower.</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>There are many kinds and degrees of hearing loss. In some types, you only lose the ability to hear high or low tones, or you lose only air or bone conduction. The inability to hear pure tones below 25 dB indicates some hearing loss.</text><text>The amount and type of hearing loss may give clues to the cause, and chances of recovering your hearing.</text><text>The following conditions may affect test results:</text><detail> Acoustic neuroma </detail><detail>Acoustic trauma from a very loud or intense blast sound</detail><detail> Age-related hearing loss </detail><detail> Alport syndrome </detail><detail>Chronic ear infections</detail><detail> Labyrinthitis </detail><detail> Ménière disease </detail><detail>Ongoing exposure to loud noise, such as at work or from music </detail><detail> Abnormal bone growth in the middle ear, called otosclerosis </detail><detail>Ruptured or perforated eardrum </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Audiometry</detail><detail> Hearing test</detail><detail> Audiography (audiogram)</detail>

item.title: Aspergillosis precipitin
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs of an aspergillosis infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result means you do not have aspergillus antibodies.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive result means antibodies to the fungus have been detected. This result means you have been exposed to the fungus at some point, but it does not necessarily mean you have an active infection.</text><text>False-negative results are possible. For example, invasive aspergillosis often does not produce a positive result, even though aspergillus is present.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Aspergillus immunodiffusion test</detail><detail> Test for precipitating antibodies</detail>

item.title: Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>AST is an enzyme found in high levels in the liver, heart, and muscles. It is also found in lesser amounts in other tissues. An enzyme is a protein that causes a specific chemical change in the body.</text><text>This test is mainly done along with other tests (such as ALT , ALP , and bilirubin ) to diagnose and monitor liver disease .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 10 to 34 U/L (0.17 to 0.57 µkat/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased AST level is often a sign of liver disease. Liver disease is even more likely when the levels of substances checked by other liver blood tests have also increased. </text><text>An increased AST level may be due to any of the following:</text><detail>Scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis ) </detail><detail>Death of liver tissue</detail><detail> Heart attack </detail><detail>Too much iron in the body ( hemochromatosis )</detail><detail>Swollen and inflamed liver ( hepatitis )</detail><detail>Lack of blood flow to the liver (liver ischemia)</detail><detail>Liver cancer or tumor</detail><detail>Use of drugs that are toxic to the liver</detail><detail> Mononucleosis ("mono")</detail><detail>Muscle disease or trauma</detail><detail>Swollen and inflamed pancreas ( pancreatitis ) </detail><text>AST level may also increase after:</text><detail>Burns (deep)</detail><detail>Heart procedures</detail><detail>Seizure</detail><detail>Surgery</detail><text>Pregnancy and exercise may also cause an increased AST level.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Aspartate aminotransferase</detail><detail> Serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase</detail><detail> SGOT</detail>

item.title: Arteriogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>How you should prepare depends on the part of the body being examined. Your health care provider may tell you to stop taking certain drugs that could affect the test, or blood thinning medicines. In most cases, you may not be able to eat or drink anything for a few hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: An arteriogram is done to see how blood moves through the arteries. It is also used to check for blocked or damaged arteries. It can be used to visualize tumors or find a source of bleeding. Usually, an arteriogram is performed at the same time as a treatment. If no treatment is planned, in many areas of the body it has been replaced with CT arteriography.
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Angiogram</detail><detail> Angiography</detail>

item.title: Arm MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test provides clear pictures of parts of the arm that are hard to see clearly on CT scans.</text><text>Your provider may order this test if you have:</text><detail>A mass that can be felt on a physical exam</detail><detail>An abnormal finding on an x-ray or bone scan</detail><detail>Arm pain and a history of cancer</detail><detail>Arm or wrist pain that does not get better with treatment</detail><detail>Bone infection (osteomyelitis)</detail><detail>Bone pain and fever</detail><detail>Broken bone</detail><detail>Decreased motion or "locking up" of the wrist or elbow joint</detail><detail>Redness or swelling of the wrist or elbow joints </detail><detail>Injuries to the cartilage and ligaments</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means your arm looks OK.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abscess</detail><detail> Bursitis of the elbow or wrist</detail><detail> Broken bone or fracture</detail><detail>Ganglion cyst in the wrist</detail><detail>Infection in the bone</detail><detail>Ligament, tendon, or cartilage injury in the wrist or elbow</detail><detail>Muscle damage</detail><detail>Osteonecrosis (avascular necrosis)</detail><detail>Tumor or cancer in the bone, muscle, or soft tissue </detail><text>Talk to your provider if you have questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI - arm</detail><detail> Wrist MRI</detail><detail> MRI - wrist</detail><detail> Elbow MRI</detail><detail> MRI - elbow</detail>

item.title: Arm CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>For some tests, you will need to have a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes drug metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take special steps if you are on this medicine. </detail><text>If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts.</text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the body, including the arms. The test may help detect or diagnose:</text><detail>An abscess or infection</detail><detail>The cause of pain or other problems in the wrist, shoulder or elbow joints (usually when MRI cannot be done)</detail><detail>A broken bone</detail><detail>Masses and tumors, including cancer </detail><detail>Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery</detail><text>A CT scan may also be used to guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen in the images.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abscess (collection of pus)</detail><detail>Blood clot in the arm (deep venous thrombosis)</detail><detail>Bone tumors</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail> Broken or fractured bone</detail><detail>Damage to the hand, wrist, or elbow joints</detail><detail>Cyst </detail><detail>Healing problems or development of scar tissue after surgery</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - arm</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - arm</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - arm</detail><detail> CT scan - arm</detail>

item.title: Apolipoprotein CII
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be told not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>ApoCII measurements can help determine the type or cause of high blood fats. It is not clear whether the test results improve treatment. Because of this, most health insurance companies will not pay for the test. If you DO NOT have high cholesterol or heart disease or a family history of these conditions, this test may not be recommended for you.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 3 to 5 mg/dL. However, apoCII results are usually reported as present or absent.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High levels of apoCII may be due to a family history of lipoprotein lipase deficiency . This is a condition in which the body does not break down fats normally.</text><text>ApoCII levels are also seen in people with a rare condition called familial apoprotein CII deficiency. This causes chylomicronemia syndrome , another condition in which the body does not break down fats normally.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ApoCII</detail><detail> Apoprotein CII</detail><detail> ApoC2</detail><detail> Lipoprotein lipase deficiency - apolipoprotein CII</detail><detail> Chylomicronemia syndrome - apolipoprotein CII</detail>

item.title: Apolipoprotein B100
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Most often, this test is done to help determine the cause or specific type of high blood cholesterol. It is not clear whether the information helps improve treatment. Because of this, most health insurance companies DO NOT pay for the test. If you DO NOT have a diagnosis of high cholesterol or heart disease, this test may not be recommended for you.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is about 50 to 150 mg/dL.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may mean you have high lipid (fat) levels in your blood. A medical term for this is hyperlipidemia .</text><text>Other disorders that may be associated with high apoB100 levels include atherosclerotic vascular disease such as angina pectoris (chest pain that occurs with activity or stress) and heart attack .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ApoB100</detail><detail> Apoprotein B100</detail><detail> Hypercholesterolemia - apolipoprotein B100</detail>

item.title: Apgar score
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to determine whether a newborn needs help breathing or is having heart trouble. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The Apgar score is based on a total score of 1 to 10. The higher the score, the better the baby is doing after birth. </text><text>A score of 7, 8, or 9 is normal and is a sign that the newborn is in good health. A score of 10 is very unusual, since almost all newborns lose 1 point for blue hands and feet, which is normal for after birth.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Any score lower than 7 is a sign that the baby needs medical attention. The lower the score, the more help the baby needs to adjust outside the mother's womb. </text><text>Most of the time a low Apgar score is caused by:</text><detail>Difficult birth</detail><detail>C-section</detail><detail>Fluid in the baby's airway </detail><text>A baby with a low Apgar score may need:</text><detail>Oxygen and clearing out the airway to help with breathing</detail><detail>Physical stimulation to get the heart beating at a healthy rate </detail><text>Most of the time, a low score at 1 minute is near-normal by 5 minutes. </text><text>A lower Apgar score does not mean a child will have serious or long-term health problems. The Apgar score is not designed to predict the future health of the child. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Newborn scoring</detail><detail> Delivery - Apgar</detail>

item.title: Aortic angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test.</text><text>You will wear a hospital gown and sign a consent form for the procedure. Remove jewelry from the area being studied.</text><text>Tell your health care provider:</text><detail>If you are pregnant</detail><detail>If you have ever had any allergic reactions to x-ray contrast material, shellfish, or iodine substances</detail><detail>If you are allergic to any medicines</detail><detail>Which medicines you are taking (including any herbal preparations)</detail><detail>If you have ever had any bleeding problems </detail><text>You will be awake during the test. You may feel a sting as the numbing medicine is given and some pressure as the catheter is inserted. You may feel a warm flushing when the contrast dye flows through the catheter. This is normal and most often goes away in a few seconds.</text><text>You may have some discomfort from lying on the hospital table and staying still for a long time.</text><text>In most cases, you can resume normal activity the day after the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may ask for this test if there are signs or symptoms of a problem with the aorta or its branches, including:</text><detail>Aortic aneurysm</detail><detail> Aortic dissection </detail><detail>Congenital (present from birth) problems</detail><detail>AV malformation</detail><detail> Double aortic arch </detail><detail> Coarctation of the aorta </detail><detail> Vascular ring </detail><detail>Injury to the aorta</detail><detail> Takayasu arteritis </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Abdominal aortic aneurysm </detail><detail>Aortic dissection</detail><detail> Aortic regurgitation </detail><detail>Congenital (present from birth) problems</detail><detail>Double aortic arch</detail><detail>Coarctation of the aorta</detail><detail>Vascular ring</detail><detail>Injury to the aorta</detail><detail> Mesenteric ischemia </detail><detail>Peripheral artery disease</detail><detail> Renal artery stenosis </detail><detail> Takayasu arteritis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Angiography - aorta</detail><detail> Aortography</detail><detail> Abdominal aorta angiogram</detail><detail> Aortic arteriogram</detail><detail> Aneurysm - aortic arteriogram</detail>

item.title: Antithyroid microsomal antibody
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to confirm the cause of thyroid problems, including Hashimoto thyroiditis .</text><text>The test is also used to find out if an immune or autoimmune disorder is damaging the thyroid.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test means the result is normal.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test may be due to:</text><detail> Granulomatous thyroiditis (an immune reaction of the thyroid gland that often follows an upper respiratory infection)</detail><detail> Hashimoto thyroiditis (a reaction of the immune system against the thyroid gland)</detail><text>High levels of these antibodies have also been linked with an increased risk of:</text><detail>Miscarriage</detail><detail> Preeclampsia (high blood pressure and protein in the urine after the 20th week of pregnancy)</detail><detail>Premature birth</detail><detail> In vitro fertilization failure </detail><text>Important: A positive result does not always mean that you have a thyroid condition or that you need treatment for your thyroid. A positive result may mean that you have a higher chance of developing thyroid disease in the future. This is often associated with a family history of thyroid disease.</text><text>Antithyroid microsomal antibodies may be seen in your blood if you have other autoimmune conditions, including:</text><detail> Autoimmune hemolytic anemia </detail><detail> Autoimmune hepatitis </detail><detail>Autoimmune adrenal disease</detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><detail> Sjögren syndrome </detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thyroid antimicrosomal antibody</detail><detail> Antimicrosomal antibody</detail><detail> Microsomal antibody</detail><detail> Thyroid peroxidase antibody</detail><detail> TPOAb</detail><detail> Anti-TPO antibody</detail>

item.title: Antithyroglobulin antibody test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be told not to eat or drink anything for several hours (usually overnight). Your health care provider may monitor you or tell you to stop taking certain medicines for a short time before the test because they may affect the test results. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test helps detect possible thyroid problems. </text><text>Antithyroglobulin antibodies can be a sign of thyroid gland damage caused by the immune system. They may be measured if thyroiditis is suspected.</text><text>Measuring thyroglobulin antibody levels after treatment for thyroid cancer can help your provider decide what the best test is to monitor you for a recurrence of the cancer.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test result is a normal result. It means no antibodies to thyroglobulin are found in your blood.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test means antithyroglobulin antibodies are found in your blood. They may be present with:</text><detail> Graves disease or overactive thyroid </detail><detail> Hashimoto thyroiditis </detail><detail> Subacute thyroiditis </detail><detail> Underactive thyroid </detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus </detail><detail> Type 1 diabetes </detail><text>Pregnant women and relatives of those with autoimmune thyroiditis may also test positive for these antibodies.</text><text>If you have a positive test for antithyroglobulin antibodies, this may make it harder to measure your thyroglobulin level accurately. Thyroglobulin level is an important blood test to determine risk that thyroid cancer will recur.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thyroglobulin antibody</detail><detail> Thyroiditis - thyroglobulin antibody</detail><detail> Hypothyroidism - thyroglobulin antibody</detail><detail> Thyroiditis - thyroglobulin antibody</detail><detail> Graves disease - thyroglobulin antibody</detail><detail> Underactive thyroid - thyroglobulin antibody</detail>

item.title: Antithrombin III blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines may affect the results of the test. Your health care provider may tell you to stop taking certain medicines or reduce their dose before the test. Do not stop taking any medicine before speaking with your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have repeated blood clots or if blood thinning medicine does not work.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Lower-than-normal AT III may mean you have an increased risk for blood clotting. This can occur when there is not enough AT III in your blood, or when there is enough AT III in your blood, but the AT III does not function properly and is less active. </text><text>Abnormal results may not appear until you are an adult.</text><text>Examples of complications associated with increased blood clotting are:</text><detail> Deep venous thrombosis </detail><detail> Phlebitis (vein inflammation)</detail><detail> Pulmonary embolus (blood clot traveling to lung)</detail><detail>Thrombophlebitis (vein inflammation with clot formation) </detail><text>Lower than normal AT III may be due to:</text><detail>Bone marrow transplant</detail><detail> Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) </detail><detail>AT III deficiency, an inherited condition</detail><detail>Liver cirrhosis</detail><detail>Nephrotic syndrome </detail><text>Higher than normal AT III may be due to:</text><detail>Use of anabolic steroids </detail><detail>Bleeding disorder ( hemophilia )</detail><detail>Kidney transplant</detail><detail>Low level of vitamin K</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Antithrombin</detail><detail> AT III</detail><detail> AT 3</detail><detail> Functional antithrombin III</detail><detail> Clotting disorder - AT III</detail><detail> DVT - AT III</detail><detail> Deep vein thrombosis - AT III</detail>

item.title: Antistreptolysin O titer
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT eat for 6 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You will need the test if you have symptoms of a previous infection by group A streptococcus. Some illnesses caused by this bacteria are:</text><detail>Bacterial endocarditis, an infection of the inner lining of your heart</detail><detail>A kidney problem called glomerulonephritis </detail><detail> Rheumatic fever , which can affect the heart, joints, or bones</detail><detail> Scarlet fever </detail><detail>Strep throat</detail><text>The ASO antibody may be found in the blood weeks or months after the strep infection has gone away.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test result means that you do not have strep infection. Your health care provider may do the test again in 2 to 4 weeks. At times, a test that was negative the first time may be positive (meaning it finds ASO antibodies) when done again.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text> An abnormal or positive test result means you recently had a strep infection, even if you had no symptoms.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ASO titer</detail><detail> ASLO</detail>

item.title: Antiparietal cell antibody test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may use this test to help diagnose pernicious anemia. Pernicious anemia is a decrease in red blood cells that occurs when your intestines cannot properly absorb vitamin B12. Other tests are also used to help with the diagnosis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is called a negative result.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result is called a positive result. This may be due to:</text><detail>Atrophic gastritis (inflammation of the stomach lining)</detail><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail> Gastric ulcer </detail><detail>Pernicious anemia</detail><detail>Thyroid disease</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>APCA</detail><detail> Anti-gastric parietal cell antibody</detail><detail> Atrophic gastritis - anti-gastric parietal cell antibody</detail><detail> Gastric ulcer - anti-gastric parietal cell antibody</detail><detail> Pernicious anemia - anti-gastric parietal cell antibody</detail><detail> Vitamin B12 - anti-gastric parietal cell antibody</detail>

item.title: Antinuclear antibody panel
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed. However, certain drugs, including birth control pills, procainamide, and thiazide diurectics, affect the accuracy of this test. Make sure your provider knows about all the medicines you take.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have signs of an autoimmune disorder, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus . This test may be done if you have unexplained symptoms such as arthritis , rashes, or chest pain.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Some normal people have a low level of ANA. Thus, the presence of a low level of ANA is not always abnormal.</text><text>ANA is reported as a "titer". Low titers are in the range of 1:40 to 1:60. A positive ANA test is of much more importance if you also have antibodies against the double-stranded form of DNA.</text><text>The presence of ANA does not confirm a diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). However, a lack of ANA makes that diagnosis much less likely.</text><text>Although ANA are most often identified with SLE, a positive ANA test can also be a sign of other autoimmune diseases.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text><text>Further tests can be run on blood with a positive ANA test to get more information.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>To make the diagnosis of SLE, certain clinical features as well as ANA must be present. In addition, certain specific ANA antibodies help to confirm the diagnosis.</text><text>The presence of ANA in the blood may be due to several other disorders besides SLE. These include:</text><detail>Chronic liver disease </detail><detail> Collagen vascular disease </detail><detail> Drug-induced lupus erythematosus </detail><detail> Myositis (inflammatory muscle disease)</detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><detail> Sjögren syndrome </detail><detail> Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) </detail><detail>Thyroid disease</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ANA</detail><detail> ANA panel</detail><detail> ANA reflexive panel</detail><detail> SLE - ANA</detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus - ANA</detail>

item.title: Antimitochondrial antibody
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you not to eat or drink anything for up to 6 hours before the test (most often overnight).</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have signs of liver damage. This test is most often used to diagnose primary biliary cholangitis, formerly called primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC).</text><text>The test may also be used to tell the difference between bile system-related cirrhosis and liver problems due to other causes such as a blockage, viral hepatitis , or alcoholic cirrhosis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, there are no antibodies present.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>This test is important for diagnosing PBC. Almost all people with the condition will test positive. It is rare that a person without the condition will have a positive result.</text><text>Rarely, abnormal results may also be found. This may occur due to other kinds of liver disease and some autoimmune diseases.</text>

item.title: Antidiuretic hormone blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Talk to your health care provider about your medicines before the test. Many drugs can affect ADH level, including:</text><detail>Alcohol</detail><detail>Diuretics (water pills)</detail><detail>Blood pressure medicines</detail><detail>Insulin</detail><detail>Medicines for mental disorders</detail><detail>Nicotine</detail><detail>Steroids </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>ADH is a hormone that is produced in a part of the brain called the hypothalamus . It is then stored and released from the pituitary, a small gland at the base of the brain. ADH acts on the kidneys to control the amount of water excreted in the urine.</text><text>ADH blood test is ordered when your provider suspects you have a disorder that affects your ADH level such as:</text><detail>Buildup of fluids in your body that are causing swelling or puffiness ( edema )</detail><detail>Excessive amounts of urine</detail><detail>Low sodium (salt) level in your blood</detail><detail>Thirst that is intense or uncontrollable </detail><text>Certain diseases affect the normal release of ADH. The blood level of ADH must be tested to determine the cause of the disease. ADH may be measured as part of a water restriction test to find the cause of a disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values for ADH can range from 1 to 5 pg/mL (0.9 to 4.6 pmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level may occur when too much ADH is released, either from the brain where it is made, or from somewhere else in the body. This is called syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH). </text><text>Causes of SIADH include:</text><detail>Brain injury or trauma</detail><detail>Brain tumors</detail><detail>Fluid imbalance after surgery</detail><detail> Infection in the brain or the tissue that surrounds the brain </detail><detail> Infection in the lungs </detail><detail>Certain medicines, such as some seizure drugs and antidepressants</detail><detail> Small cell carcinoma lung cancer </detail><detail> Stroke </detail><text>A lower-than-normal level may indicate:</text><detail>Damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland</detail><detail> Central diabetes insipidus (condition in which the kidneys are not able to conserve water)</detail><detail>Excessive thirst ( polydipsia )</detail><detail>Too much fluid in the blood vessels (volume overload) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Arginine vasopressin</detail><detail> Antidiuretic hormone</detail><detail> AVP</detail><detail> Vasopressin</detail>

item.title: Antibody titer blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The antibody level (titer) in the blood tells your health care provider whether or not you have been exposed to an antigen , or something that the body thinks is foreign. The body uses antibodies to attack and remove foreign substances.</text><text>In some situations, your provider may check your antibody titer to see if you had an infection in the past (for example, chickenpox) or to decide which vaccines you need.</text><text>The antibody titer is also used to determine:</text><detail>The strength of an immune response to the body's own tissue in diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus ( SLE ) and other autoimmune disorders </detail><detail>If you need a booster vaccine</detail><detail>Whether a vaccine you had before helped your immune system protect you against the specific disease</detail><detail>If you have had a recent or past infection, such as mononucleosis or viral hepatitis </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values depend on the antibody being tested.</text><text>If the test is being done to look for antibodies against your own body tissues, the normal value would be zero or negative. In some cases, a normal level is below a specific number.</text><text>If the test is being done to see if a vaccine fully protects you against a disease, the normal result depends on the specific value for that immunization.</text><text>Negative antibody tests can help rule out certain infections.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results depend on which antibodies are being measured. </text><text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Autoimmune disease</detail><detail>Failure of a vaccine to fully protect you against a certain disease</detail><detail>Immune deficiency</detail><detail>Viral infections</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Titer - antibodies</detail><detail> Serum antibodies</detail>

item.title: Anti-insulin antibody test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be performed if:</text><detail>You have or are at risk for type 1 diabetes </detail><detail>You appear to have an allergic response to insulin</detail><detail>Insulin no longer seems to control your diabetes</detail><detail>Your blood sugar level varies a lot, with both high and low numbers that can't be explained</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, there are no antibodies against insulin in your blood if you have not been treated with insulin for diabetes.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If you have IgG and IgM antibodies against insulin, your body reacts as if the insulin in your body is a foreign protein that needs to be removed. This may make insulin less effective, or not effective at all. This is because the antibody prevents the insulin from working the right way in your cells. As a result, your blood sugar can be unusually high. Many people who are on insulin have detectable antibodies, but these antibodies do not cause symptoms.</text><text>The antibodies can also prolong the effect of insulin by releasing some insulin long after your meal has been absorbed. This can put you at risk for low blood sugar. </text><text>If the test shows a high level of IgE antibody against insulin, your body has developed an allergic response to the insulin. This could put you at risk for skin reactions where you inject insulin. You can also develop more severe reactions that affect your blood pressure or breathing. </text><text>Other medicines, such as antihistamines or low-dose injectable steroids, may help to lessen the reaction. If reactions have been severe, you may need a treatment process called desensitization or another treatment to remove the antibodies from your blood.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Insulin antibodies - serum</detail><detail> Insulin Ab test</detail><detail> Insulin resistance - insulin antibodies</detail><detail> Diabetes - insulin antibodies</detail>

item.title: Anti-glomerular basement membrane blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to diagnose certain kidney diseases, such as Goodpasture syndrome and anti-glomerular basement membrane disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, there are none of these antibodies in the blood. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Antibodies in the blood may mean any of the following:</text><detail>Anti-glomerular basement membrane disease</detail><detail> Goodpasture syndrome </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>GBM antibody test</detail><detail> Antibody to human glomerular basement membrane</detail><detail> Anti-GBM antibodies</detail>

item.title: Anti-DNase B blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to tell if you have previously had a strep infection and if you might have rheumatic fever or kidney problems ( glomerulonephritis ) due to that infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test is normal. Some people have low concentrations of antibodies, but they have not had a recent strep infection. Therefore, normal values in different age groups are:</text><detail>Adults: less than 85 units/milliliter (mL)</detail><detail>School-age children: less than 170 units/mL</detail><detail>Preschool children: less than 60 units/mL</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased levels of DNase B levels indicate exposure to group A streptococcus.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Strep throat - anti-DNase B test</detail><detail> Antideoxyribonuclease B titer</detail><detail> ADN-B test</detail>

item.title: Anoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Often, there is no preparation needed. Or, you may receive a laxative, enema, or other preparation to empty your bowel. You should empty your bladder before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be used to determine whether you have:</text><detail>Anal fissures</detail><detail> Anal polyps </detail><detail>Foreign object in the anus</detail><detail> Hemorrhoids </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Tumors </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The anal canal appears normal in size, color, and tone. There is no sign of: </text><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Polyps</detail><detail>Hemorrhoids</detail><detail>Other abnormal tissue</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean:
Abnormal results may include: Abscess Fissures Foreign object in the anus
HemorrhoidsInfectionInflammationPolyps (non-cancerous or cancerous)Tumors
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Anal fissures - anoscopy</detail><detail> Anal polyps - anoscopy</detail><detail> Foreign object in the anus - anoscopy</detail><detail> Hemorrhoids - anoscopy</detail><detail> Anal warts - anoscopy</detail>

item.title: Amylase - urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to diagnose pancreatitis and other diseases that affect the pancreas.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 2.6 to 21.2 international units per hour (IU/h).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement range for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased amount of amylase in the urine is called amylasuria. Increased urine amylase levels may be a sign of:</text><detail> Acute pancreatitis </detail><detail> Alcohol consumption </detail><detail> Cancer of the pancreas , ovaries, or lungs</detail><detail> Cholecystitis </detail><detail>Ectopic or ruptured tubal pregnancy </detail><detail>Gallbladder disease</detail><detail>Infection of the salivary glands (called sialoadenitis, may be caused by mumps or a blockage)</detail><detail> Intestinal obstruction </detail><detail> Pancreatic duct obstruction </detail><detail> Pelvic inflammatory disease </detail><detail> Perforated ulcer </detail><text>Decreased amylase levels may be due to:</text><detail>Damage to the pancreas</detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><detail> Toxemia of pregnancy </detail>

item.title: Amylase - blood
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed. However, you should avoid alcohol before the test. The health care provider may ask you to stop taking drugs that may affect the test. DO NOT stop taking any medicines without first talking to your provider.</text><text>Drugs that can increase amylase measurements include:</text><detail>Asparaginase</detail><detail>Aspirin</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Cholinergic medicines</detail><detail>Ethacrynic acid</detail><detail>Methyldopa</detail><detail>Opiates (codeine, meperidine, and morphine)</detail><detail>Thiazide diuretics</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis . It may also detect some digestive tract problems.</text><text>The test may also be done for the following conditions:</text><detail> Chronic pancreatitis </detail><detail> Pancreatic pseudocyst </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 40 to 140 units per liter (U/L) or 0.38 to 1.42 microkat/L (µkat/L).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased blood amylase levels may occur due to:</text><detail> Acute pancreatitis </detail><detail> Cancer of the pancreas , ovaries, or lungs</detail><detail> Cholecystitis </detail><detail>Gallbladder attack caused by disease</detail><detail>Gastroenteritis (severe)</detail><detail>Infection of the salivary glands (such as mumps ) or a blockage</detail><detail> Intestinal blockage </detail><detail> Macroamylasemia </detail><detail>Pancreatic or bile duct blockage </detail><detail> Perforated ulcer </detail><detail> Tubal pregnancy (may have burst open)</detail><text>Decreased amylase levels may occur due to:</text><detail>Cancer of the pancreas</detail><detail>Damage to the pancreas</detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail> Toxemia of pregnancy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pancreatitis - blood amylase</detail>

item.title: Amniocentesis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your bladder may need to be full for the ultrasound. Check with your provider about this.</text><text>Before the test, blood may be taken to find out your blood type and Rh factor. You may get a shot of medicine called Rho(D) Immune Globulin (RhoGAM and other brands) if you are Rh negative.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Amniocentesis is usually offered to women who are at increased risk of having a child with birth defects. This includes women who:</text><detail>Will be 35 or older when they give birth</detail><detail>Had a screening test that shows there may be a birth defect or other problem</detail><detail>Have had babies with birth defects in other pregnancies</detail><detail>Have a family history of genetic disorders </detail><text>Genetic counseling is recommended before the procedure. This will allow you to:</text><detail>Learn about other prenatal tests</detail><detail>Make an informed decision about options for prenatal diagnosis </detail><text>This test:</text><detail>Is a diagnostic test, not a screening test</detail><detail>Is greater than 99% accurate for diagnosing Down syndrome</detail><detail>Is most often done between 15 to 20 weeks, but can be performed at any time between 15 to 40 weeks</detail><text>Amniocentesis can be used to diagnose many different gene and chromosome problems in the baby, including:</text><detail> Anencephaly (when the baby is missing a large portion of the brain)</detail><detail>Down syndrome</detail><detail>Rare metabolic disorders that are passed down through families</detail><detail>Other genetic problems, like trisomy 18 </detail><detail>Infections in the amniotic fluid</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means:</text><detail>No genetic or chromosome problems were found in your baby.</detail><detail>Bilirubin and alpha-fetoprotein levels appear normal. </detail><detail>No signs of infection were found.</detail><text>Note: Amniocentesis typically is the most accurate test for genetic conditions and malformation, Although rare, a baby may still have genetic or other types of birth defects, even if amniocentesis results are normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may mean your baby has:</text><detail>A gene or chromosome problem, such as Down syndrome </detail><detail>Birth defects that involve the spine or brain, such as spina bifida </detail><text>Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results. Ask your provider:</text><detail>How the condition or defect may be treated during or after your pregnancy</detail><detail>What special needs your child may have after birth</detail><detail>What other options you have about maintaining or ending your pregnancy</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - amniotic fluid</detail><detail> Culture - amniotic cells</detail><detail> Alpha-fetoprotein - amniocentesis</detail>

item.title: Ammonia blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may ask you to stop taking certain drugs that may affect test results. These include:</text><detail>Alcohol</detail><detail>Acetazolomide</detail><detail>Narcotics</detail><detail>Valproic acid </detail><text>You should not smoke before your blood is drawn.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Ammonia (NH3) is produced by cells throughout the body, especially the intestines, liver, and kidneys. Most of the ammonia produced in the body is used by the liver to produce urea. Urea is also a waste product, but it is much less toxic than ammonia. Ammonia is especially toxic to the brain. It can cause confusion, low energy, and sometimes coma.</text><text>This test may be done if you have, or your provider thinks you have, a condition that may cause a toxic buildup of ammonia. It is most commonly used to diagnose and monitor hepatic encephalopathy , a severe liver disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 15 to 45 µ/dL (11 to 32 µmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean you have increased ammonia levels in your blood. This may be due to any of the following:</text><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail> Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding , usually in the upper GI tract</detail><detail>Genetic diseases of the urea cycle</detail><detail>High body temperature (hyperthermia)</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Liver failure</detail><detail> Low blood potassium level </detail><detail>Severe muscle exertion </detail><text>A high-protein diet can also raise the blood ammonia level.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum ammonia</detail><detail> Encephalopathy - ammonia</detail><detail> Cirrhosis - ammonia</detail><detail> Liver failure - ammonia</detail>

item.title: Aminoaciduria
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time, you do not need to take special steps before this test. Make sure your provider knows all of the medicines you recently used. If this test is being done on an infant who is breast-feeding, make sure the provider knows what medicines the nursing mother is taking.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to measure amino acid levels in the urine. There are many different types of amino acids. It is common for some of each kind to be found in the urine. Increased levels of individual amino acids can be a sign of a problem with metabolism.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The specific value is measured in mmol/mol creatinine. The values below represent normal ranges in 24 hours urine for adults.</text><text>Alanine: 9 to 98</text><text>Arginine: 0 to 8</text><text>Asparagine: 10 to 65</text><text> Aspartic acid : 5 to 50</text><text>Citrulline: 1 to 22</text><text>Cystine: 2 to 12</text><text>Glutamic acid: 0 to 21</text><text>Glutamine: 11 to 42</text><text>Glycine: 17 to 146</text><text>Histidine: 49 to 413</text><text>Isoleucine: 30 to 186</text><text>Leucine: 1 to 9</text><text>Lysine: 2 to 16</text><text>Methionine: 2 to 53</text><text>Ornithine: 1 to 5</text><text> Phenylalanine : 1 to 5</text><text>Proline: 3 to 13</text><text>Serine: 0 to 9</text><text>Taurine: 18 to 89</text><text>Threonine: 13 to 587</text><text>Tyrosine: 3 to 14</text><text>Valine: 3 to 36</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased total urine amino acids may be due to:</text><detail>Alkaptonuria</detail><detail>Canavan disease</detail><detail>Cystinosis</detail><detail>Cystathioninuria</detail><detail>Fructose intolerance</detail><detail> Galactosemia </detail><detail>Hartnup disease</detail><detail>Homocystinuria</detail><detail>Hyperammonemia</detail><detail> Hyperparathyroidism </detail><detail>Maple syrup urine disease</detail><detail> Methylmalonic acidemia </detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><detail>Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency</detail><detail> Osteomalacia </detail><detail>Propionic acidemia</detail><detail> Rickets </detail><detail>Tyrosinemia type 1</detail><detail>Tyrosinemia type 2</detail><detail>Viral hepatitis </detail><detail> Wilson disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Amino acids - urine</detail><detail> Urine amino acids</detail>

item.title: Alpha-1 antitrypsin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is helpful in identifying a rare form of emphysema in adults and a rare form of liver disease (cirrhosis) in children and adults caused by an A1AT deficiency . A1AT deficiency is passed down through families. The condition causes the liver to make too little of a protein that protects the lungs and liver from damage.</text><text>Everyone has two copies of the gene that makes A1AT. Most people with a lower-than-normal level of A1AT have one normal gene for A1AT, and one abnormal gene. People with two abnormal copies of the gene have more severe disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A lower-than-normal level of A1AT may be associated with:</text><detail> Damage of the large airways in the lungs ( bronchiectasis )</detail><detail> Scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis )</detail><detail> Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</detail><detail> Liver tumors </detail><detail> Yellowing of the skin and eyes due to blocked bile flow ( obstructive jaundice )</detail><detail>High blood pressure in the large vein leads to the liver (portal hypertension )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>A1AT test</detail>

item.title: ALP isoenzyme test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink anything for 10 to 12 hours before the test, unless your health care provider tells you to do so.</text><text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>When the ALP test result is high, you may need to have the ALP isoenzyme test. This test will help determine what part of the body is causing higher ALP levels.</text><text>This test may be used to diagnose or monitor:</text><detail>Bone disease</detail><detail> Liver , gallbladder, or bile duct disease</detail><detail>Pain in the abdomen</detail><detail>Parathyroid gland disease</detail><detail> Vitamin D deficiency </detail><text>It may also be done to check liver function and to see how medicines you take may affect your liver.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal value is 20 to 140 international units per liter (IU/L) or 33.400 to 233.800 microkat per liter (µKat/L).</text><text>Adults have lower levels of ALP than children. Bones that are still growing produce higher levels of ALP. During some growth spurts, levels can be as high as 500 IU/L or 835 µKat/L. For this reason, the test is usually not done in children, and abnormal results refer to adults.</text><text>The isoenzyme test results can reveal whether the increase is in "bone" ALP or "liver" ALP.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement range for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal ALP levels:</text><detail>Biliary obstruction</detail><detail>Bone disease</detail><detail>Eating a fatty meal if you have blood type O or B</detail><detail>Healing fracture</detail><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail> Hyperparathyroidism </detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Lymphoma</detail><detail>Osteoblastic bone tumors</detail><detail>Osteomalacia</detail><detail> Paget disease </detail><detail>Rickets</detail><detail>Sarcoidosis </detail><text>Lower-than-normal levels of ALP:</text><detail>Hypophosphatasia</detail><detail> Malnutrition </detail><detail> Protein deficiency</detail><detail> Wilson disease </detail><text>Levels that are only slightly higher than normal may not be a problem unless there are other signs of a disease or medical problem.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Alkaline phosphatase isoenzyme test</detail>

item.title: ALP - blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not to eat or drink anything for 6 hours before the test, unless your health care provider tells you otherwise. </text><text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Reasons the test may be done include:</text><detail>To diagnose liver or bone disease</detail><detail>To check, if treatments for those diseases are working</detail><detail>As part of a routine liver function test </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 44 to 147 international units per liter (IU/L) or 0.73 to 2.45 microkatal per liter (µkat/L).</text><text>Normal values may vary slightly from laboratory to laboratory. They also can vary with age and gender. High levels of ALP are normally seen in children undergoing growth spurts and in pregnant women.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
