item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to the following conditions:</text><text>Higher-than-normal ALP levels</text><detail> Biliary obstruction </detail><detail>Bone conditions</detail><detail> Osteoblastic bone tumors , osteomalacia , a fracture that is healing</detail><detail>Liver disease or hepatitis </detail><detail>Eating a fatty meal if you have blood type O or B</detail><detail> Hyperparathyroidism </detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Lymphoma</detail><detail> Paget disease </detail><detail> Rickets </detail><detail>Sarcoidosis </detail><text>Lower-than-normal ALP levels</text><detail>Hypophosphatasia</detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail> Protein deficiency</detail><detail>Wilson disease </detail><text>Other conditions for which the test may be done:</text><detail> Alcoholic liver disease (hepatitis/cirrhosis) </detail><detail> Alcoholism </detail><detail> Biliary stricture </detail><detail>Gallstones</detail><detail> Giant cell (temporal, cranial) arteritis </detail><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) II </detail><detail>Pancreatitis</detail><detail> Renal cell carcinoma </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Alkaline phosphatase</detail>

item.title: Allergy testing - skin
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before any allergy testing, the provider will ask about: </text><detail>Illnesses</detail><detail>Where you live and work</detail><detail>Lifestyle</detail><detail>Foods and eating habits</detail><text>Allergy medicines can change the results of skin tests. Your provider will tell you which medicines to avoid and when to stop taking them before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Allergy tests are done to find out which substances are causing your allergy symptoms.</text><text>Your provider may order allergy skin tests if you have:</text><detail>Hay fever ( allergic rhinitis ) and asthma symptoms that are not well controlled with medicine</detail><detail>Hives and angioedema </detail><detail> Food allergies </detail><detail>Skin rashes ( dermatitis ), in which the skin becomes red, sore, or swollen after contact with the substance</detail><detail>Penicillin allergy</detail><detail>Venom allergy</detail><text>Allergies to penicillin and related medicines are the only drug allergies that can be tested using skin tests. Skin tests for allergies to other drugs can be dangerous.</text><text>The skin prick test may also be used to diagnose food allergies. Intradermal tests are not used to test for food allergies because of high false-positive results and the danger of causing a severe allergic reaction.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative test result means there were no skin changes in response to the allergen. This negative reaction most often means that you are not allergic to the substance.</text><text>In rare cases, a person may have a negative allergy test and still be allergic to the substance.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive result means you reacted to a substance. Your provider will see a red, raised area called a wheal.</text><text>Often, a positive result means the symptoms you're having are due to exposure to that substance. A stronger response means you are likely more sensitive to the substance.</text><text>People can have a positive response to a substance with allergy skin testing, but not have any problems with that substance in everyday life.</text><text>Skin tests are usually accurate. But, if the dose of allergen is large, even people who are not allergic will have a positive reaction.</text><text>Your provider will consider your symptoms and the results of your skin test to suggest lifestyle changes you can make to avoid substances that may be causing your symptoms.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Patch tests - allergy</detail><detail> Scratch tests - allergy</detail><detail> Skin tests - allergy</detail><detail> RAST test</detail><detail> Allergic rhinitis - allergy testing</detail><detail> Asthma - allergy testing</detail><detail> Eczema - allergy testing</detail><detail> Hayfever - allergy testing</detail><detail> Dermatitis - allergy testing</detail><detail> Allergy testing</detail><detail> Intradermal allergy testing</detail>

value.img_name: Allergy skin prick or scratch test
Skin testing, PPD (R arm) and Candida (L)

item.title: Aldosterone blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may ask you to stop taking certain medicines a few days before the test so that they don't affect the test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>High blood pressure medicines</detail><detail>Heart medicines</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail>Antacid and ulcer medicines</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics)</detail><text>Do not stop taking any medicine before talking to your doctor. Your provider may recommend that you eat no more than 3 grams of salt (sodium) per day for at least 2 weeks before the test.</text><text>Or, your provider will recommend that you eat your usual amount of salt and also test the amount of sodium in your urine .</text><text>At other times, the aldosterone blood test is done right before and after you receive a salt solution (saline) through the vein (IV) for 2 hours. Be aware that other factors can affect aldosterone measurements, including:</text><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>High- or low-sodium diet</detail><detail>Strenuous exercise</detail><detail>Stress</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is ordered for the following conditions:</text><detail>Certain fluid and electrolyte disorders, most often low or high blood sodium or low potassium </detail><detail>Hard to control blood pressure</detail><detail> Low blood pressure upon standing (orthostatic hypotension) </detail><text>Aldosterone is a hormone released by the adrenal glands . It helps the body regulate blood pressure. Aldosterone increases the reabsorption of sodium and water and the release of potassium in the kidneys. This action raises blood pressure.</text><text>Aldosterone blood test is often combined with other tests, such as the renin hormone test , to diagnose over- or under-production of aldosterone.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal levels vary:</text><detail>Between children, teens, and adults</detail><detail>Depending on whether you were standing, sitting, or lying down when the blood was drawn </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level of aldosterone may be due to</text><detail> Bartter syndrome (group of rare conditions that affect the kidneys)</detail><detail>Adrenal glands release too much aldosterone hormone ( primary hyperaldosteronism - usually due to a benign nodule in the adrenal gland)</detail><detail>Very low-sodium diet </detail><text>A lower than normal level of aldosterone may be due to:</text><detail>Adrenal gland disorders, including not releasing enough aldosterone, and a condition called primary adrenal insufficiency ( Addison disease )</detail><detail>Very high-sodium diet </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Aldosterone - serum</detail><detail> Addison disease - serum aldosterone</detail><detail> Primary hyperaldosteronism - serum aldosterone</detail><detail> Bartter syndrome - serum aldosterone </detail>

item.title: Aldolase blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be told not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 12 hours before the test. You may be also told to avoid vigorous exercise for 12 hours before the test. Your health care provider will tell you if it is necessary to stop taking any medicines that may interfere with this test. Tell your provider about all the medicines you are taking, both prescription and nonprescription.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to diagnose or monitor muscle or liver damage.</text><text>Other tests that may be ordered to check for liver damage include:</text><detail> ALT (alanine aminotransferase) test </detail><detail> AST (aspartate aminotransferase) test </detail><text>Other tests that may be ordered to check for muscle cell damage include:</text><detail> CPK (creatine phosphokinase) test </detail><detail> LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) test </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results range between 1.0 to 7.5 units per liter (0.02 to 0.13 microkat/L). There is a slight difference between men and women.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level may be due to:</text><detail>Damage to skeletal muscles</detail><detail> Heart attack </detail><detail>Liver, pancreatic, or prostate cancer</detail><detail>Muscle disease such as dermatomyositis , muscular dystrophy , polymyositis </detail><detail>Swelling and inflammation of the liver ( hepatitis )</detail><detail>Viral infection called mononucleosis </detail>

item.title: Albumin - blood (serum)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines that can affect the test. Drugs that can increase albumin levels include:</text><detail>Anabolic steroids </detail><detail>Androgens </detail><detail> Growth hormone </detail><detail>Insulin</detail><text>Do not stop taking any of your medicines without talking to your provider first.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Albumin helps move many small molecules through the blood, including bilirubin , calcium, progesterone, and medicines. It plays an important role in keeping the fluid in the blood from leaking into the tissues.</text><text>This test can help determine if you have liver disease or kidney disease, or if your body is not absorbing enough protein .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 3.4 to 5.4 g/dL (34 to 54 g/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Lower-than-normal level of serum albumin may be a sign of:</text><detail>Kidney diseases</detail><detail>Liver disease (for example, hepatitis , or cirrhosis that may cause ascites )</detail><text>Decreased blood albumin may occur when your body does not get or absorb enough nutrients, such as with:</text><detail>After weight-loss surgery</detail><detail> Crohn disease (inflammation of the digestive tract)</detail><detail>Low-protein diets</detail><detail> Celiac disease (damage of the lining of the small intestine due to eating gluten)</detail><detail> Whipple disease (condition that prevents the small intestine from allowing nutrients to pass into the rest of the body)</detail><text>Increased blood albumin may be due to:</text><detail>Dehydration</detail><detail>High protein diet</detail><detail>Having a tourniquet on for a long time when giving a blood sample</detail><text>Drinking too much water (water intoxication) may also cause abnormal albumin results. </text><text>Other conditions for which the test may be performed:</text><detail>Burns (widespread)</detail><detail> Wilson disease (condition in which there is too much copper in the body)</detail>

item.title: Alanine transaminase (ALT) blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>ALT is an enzyme found in a high level in the liver. Injury to the liver results in release of ALT into the blood.</text><text>This test is used to determine if a person has liver damage.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is:</text><detail>Male: 10 to 40 U/L (0.17 to 0.67 µkat/L)</detail><detail>Female: 4 to 19 U/L (0.07 to 0.32 µkat/L)</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased ALT level is often a sign of liver disease. Liver disease is even more likely when the levels of substances checked by other liver blood tests have also increased.</text><text>An increased ALT level may be due to any of the following:</text><detail>Scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis )</detail><detail>Death of liver tissue </detail><detail>Swollen and inflamed liver ( hepatitis )</detail><detail>Too much iron in the body ( hemochromatosis )</detail><detail>Too much fat in the liver (fatty liver)</detail><detail>Lack of blood flow to the liver (liver ischemia)</detail><detail>Liver tumor or cancer</detail><detail>Use of drugs that are toxic to the liver</detail><detail> Mononucleosis ("mono")</detail><detail>Swollen and inflamed pancreas (pancreatitis)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>SGPT</detail><detail> Serum glutamate pyruvate transaminase</detail><detail> Alanine transaminase</detail><detail> Alanine aminotransferase</detail>

item.title: ACTH stimulation test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may need to limit activities and eat foods that are high in carbohydrates 12 to 24 hours before the test. You may be asked to fast for 6 hours before the test. Sometimes, no special preparation is needed. You may be asked to temporarily stop taking medicines, such as hydrocortisone, which can interfere with the cortisol blood test. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test can help determine whether your adrenal and pituitary glands are normal. It is most often used when your health care provider thinks you have an adrenal gland problem, such as Addison disease or pituitary insufficiency . It is also used to see if your pituitary and adrenal glands have recovered from prolonged use of glucocorticoid medicines, such as prednisone.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>An increase in cortisol after stimulation by ACTH is expected. Cortisol level after ACTH stimulation should be higher than 18 to 20 mcg/dL or 497 to 552 nmol/L, depending on the dose of ACTH used.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>This test is helpful in finding out if you have:</text><detail> Acute adrenal crisis (life-threatening condition that occurs when there is not enough cortisol)</detail><detail>Addison disease (adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol)</detail><detail> Hypopituitarism (pituitary gland is not producing enough hormones such as ACTH) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Test of adrenal reserve</detail><detail> Cosyntropin stimulation test</detail><detail> Cortrosyn stimulation test</detail><detail> Synacthen stimulation test</detail><detail> Tetracosactide stimulation test</detail>

item.title: ACTH blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your doctor will likely ask you to have the test done early in the morning. This is important, because cortisol level varies throughout the day.</text><text>You may also be told to stop taking medicines that can affect the test results. These medicines include glucocorticoids such as prednisone, hydrocortisone, or dexamethasone.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The main function of ACTH is to regulate the glucocorticoid (steroid) hormone cortisol. Cortisol is released by the adrenal gland . It regulates blood pressure and blood sugar.</text><text>This test can help find the causes of certain hormone problems.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values for a blood sample taken early in the morning are 9 to 52 pg/mL (2 to 11 pmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level of ACTH may indicate:</text><detail>Adrenal glands not producing enough cortisol ( Addison disease )</detail><detail>Adrenal glands not producing enough hormones ( congenital adrenal hyperplasia )</detail><detail>One or more of the endocrine glands are overactive or have formed a tumor ( multiple endocrine neoplasia type I )</detail><detail>Pituitary is making too much ACTH ( Cushing disease ), which is usually caused by a non-cancerous tumor of the pituitary gland</detail><detail>Rare type of tumor (lung, thyroid, or pancreas) making too much ACTH ( ectopic Cushing syndrome ) </detail><text>A lower-than-normal level of ACTH may indicate:</text><detail>Pituitary gland not producing enough hormones, such as ACTH ( hypopituitarism )</detail><detail> Tumor of the adrenal gland that produces too much cortisol</detail><detail>Glucocorticoid medicines are suppressing ACTH production </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum adrenocorticotropic hormone</detail><detail> Adrenocorticotropic hormone</detail><detail> Highly-sensitive ACTH</detail>

item.title: Acid-fast stain
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Preparation depends on how the sample is collected. Your provider will tell you how to prepare.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test can tell if you are likely infected with the bacteria that cause TB and related infections. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no acid-fast bacteria were found on the stained sample.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to: </text><detail>TB</detail><detail> Leprosy </detail><detail> Nocardia infections (also caused by a bacteria) </detail>

item.title: Acid mucopolysaccharides
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to diagnose a rare group of genetic disorders called mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS). These include, Hurler, Scheie, and Hurler/Scheie syndromes (MPS I), Hunter syndrome (MPS II), Sanfilippo syndrome (MPS III), Morquio syndrome (MPS IV), Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome (MPS VI), and Sly syndrome (MPS VII).</text><text>Most of the time, this test is done in infants who may have a symptom or family history of one of these disorders.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal levels vary with age and from lab to lab. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormally high levels could be consistent with a type of mucopolysaccharidosis. Further tests are needed to determine the specific type of mucopolysaccharidosis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>AMP</detail><detail> Dermatan sulfate - urine</detail><detail> Urine heparan sulfate</detail><detail> Urine dermatan sulfate</detail><detail> Heparan sulfate - urine</detail>

item.title: Acid loading test (pH)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you to take ammonium chloride capsules by mouth for 3 days before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see how well your kidneys control the body's acid-base balance.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Urine with a pH less than 5.3 is normal.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The most common disorder associated with an abnormal result is renal tubular acidosis .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Renal tubular acidosis - acid loading test</detail>

item.title: Acetylcholine receptor antibody
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time you do not need to take special steps before this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to help diagnose myasthenia gravis .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, there is no acetylcholine receptor antibody (or less than 0.05 nmol/L) in the bloodstream.</text><text>Note: nmol = nanomole</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means acetylcholine receptor antibody has been detected in your blood. It confirms the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis in people who have symptoms. Nearly one half of people with myasthenia gravis that is limited to their eye muscles (ocular myasthenia gravis) have this antibody in their blood.</text><text>However, the lack of this antibody does not rule out myasthenia gravis. About 1 in 5 people with myasthenia gravis do not have signs of this antibody in their blood. Your provider may also consider testing you for the muscle specific kinase (MuSK) antibody.</text>

value.img_name: Central nervous system and peripheral nervous system

item.title: ACE blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your health care provider's instructions for not eating or drinking for up to 12 hours before the test. If you are on steroid medicine, ask your provider if you need to stop the medicine before the test, because steroids can decrease ACE levels. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be commonly ordered to help diagnose and monitor a disorder called sarcoidosis . People with sarcoidosis may have their ACE level tested regularly to check how severe the disease is and how well treatment is working. </text><text>This test also helps confirm Gaucher disease and leprosy .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values vary based on your age and the test method used. Adults have an ACE level less than 40 micrograms/L.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher than normal ACE level may be a sign of sarcoidosis. ACE levels may rise or fall as sarcoidosis worsens or improves.</text><text>A higher than normal ACE level may also be seen in several other diseases and disorders, including:</text><detail>Cancer of the lymph tissue ( Hodgkin disease )</detail><detail> Diabetes mellitus</detail><detail>Liver swelling and inflammation ( hepatitis ) due to alcohol use</detail><detail>Lung disease such as asthma , cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease , or tuberculosis </detail><detail>Kidney disorder called nephrotic syndrome </detail><detail>Multiple sclerosis</detail><detail>Adrenal glands do not make enough hormones ( Addison disease )</detail><detail>Stomach ulcer</detail><detail>Overactive thyroid ( hyperthyroidism ) </detail><detail>Overactive parathyroid glands ( hyperparathyroidism )</detail><text>Lower than normal ACE level may indicate:</text><detail>Chronic liver disease</detail><detail>Chronic kidney failure</detail><detail>Eating disorder called anorexia nervosa </detail><detail>Steroid therapy (usually prednisone)</detail><detail>Therapy for sarcoidosis</detail><detail>Underactive thyroid ( hypothyroidism ) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum angiotensin-converting enzyme</detail><detail> SACE</detail>

item.title: Abdominal x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before having the x-ray, tell your provider the following:</text><detail>If you are pregnant or think you could be pregnant</detail><detail>Have an IUD inserted</detail><detail>Have had a barium contrast x-ray in the last 4 days</detail><detail>If you have taken any medicines such as Pepto Bismol in the last 4 days (this type of medicine can interfere with the x-ray) </detail><text>You wear a hospital gown during the x-ray procedure. You must remove all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test to:</text><detail>Diagnose a pain in the abdomen or unexplained nausea </detail><detail>Identify suspected problems in the urinary system, such as a kidney stone </detail><detail>Identify blockage in the intestine </detail><detail>Locate an object that has been swallowed</detail><detail>Help diagnose diseases, such as tumors or other conditions </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The x-ray will show normal structures for a person your age.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal findings include:</text><detail>Abdominal masses</detail><detail> Buildup of fluid in the abdomen</detail><detail>Certain types of gallstones </detail><detail>Foreign object in the intestines</detail><detail>Hole in the stomach or intestines</detail><detail>Injury to the abdominal tissue</detail><detail>Intestinal blockage</detail><detail>Kidney stones</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Abdominal film</detail><detail> X-ray - abdomen</detail><detail> Flat plate</detail><detail> KUB x-ray</detail>

item.title: Abdominal wall fat pad biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is usually necessary. However, follow any specific instructions your provider gives you.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The procedure is done most often to test for amyloidosis. Diagnosing the disease in this way may avoid the need for a biopsy of an organ, which is a more difficult procedure.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The fat pad tissues are normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In the case of amyloidosis, abnormal results mean there is amyloid. This is a protein that collects in tissues and impairs organ and tissue function.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Amyloidosis - abdominal wall fat pad biopsy</detail><detail> Abdominal wall biopsy</detail><detail> Biopsy - abdominal wall fat pad</detail>

item.title: Abdominal ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>How you will prepare for the test depends on the problem. You will likely be asked not to eat or drink for several hours before the exam. Your provider will go over what you need to do. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test to: </text><detail>Find the cause of abdominal pain</detail><detail>Find the cause of kidney infections</detail><detail>Diagnose and monitor tumors and cancers</detail><detail>Diagnose or treat ascites </detail><detail>Learn why there is swelling of an abdominal organ</detail><detail>Look for damage after an injury</detail><detail>Look for stones in the gallbladder or kidney</detail><detail>Look for the cause of abnormal blood tests such as liver function tests or kidney tests</detail><detail>Look for the cause of a fever </detail><text>The reason for the test will depend on your symptoms.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The organs examined appear normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The meaning of abnormal results depends on the organ being examined and the type of problem. Talk to your provider if you have any questions or concerns.</text><text>An abdominal ultrasound can indicate conditions such as:</text><detail> Abdominal aortic aneurysm </detail><detail> Abscess </detail><detail> Appendicitis </detail><detail> Cholecystitis </detail><detail> Gallstones </detail><detail> Hydronephrosis </detail><detail> Kidney stones </detail><detail>Pancreatitis (inflammation in pancreas)</detail><detail>Spleen enlargement ( splenomegaly )</detail><detail>Portal hypertension</detail><detail>Liver tumors</detail><detail>Obstruction of bile ducts</detail><detail> Cirrhosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ultrasound - abdomen</detail><detail> Abdominal sonogram</detail><detail> Right upper quadrant sonogram</detail>

item.title: Abdominal tap
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Let your provider know if you:</text><detail>Have any allergies to medicines or numbing medicine</detail><detail>Are taking any medicines (including herbal remedies)</detail><detail>Have any bleeding problems</detail><detail>Might be pregnant </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Normally, the abdominal cavity contains only a small amount of fluid. In certain conditions, large amounts of fluid can build up in this space.</text><text>An abdominal tap can help diagnose the cause of fluid buildup or the presence of an infection. It may also be done to remove a large amount of fluid to reduce belly pain.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, there should be little or no fluid in the abdominal space.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An exam of abdominal fluid may show:</text><detail>Cancer that has spread to the abdominal cavity ( most often cancer of the ovaries )</detail><detail> Cirrhosis of the liver </detail><detail>Damaged bowel</detail><detail> Heart disease </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail>Pancreatic disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Peritoneal tap</detail><detail> Paracentesis</detail><detail> Ascites - abdominal tap</detail><detail> Cirrhosis - abdominal tap</detail><detail> Malignant ascites - abdominal tap</detail>

item.title: Abdominal MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may also suggest an open MRI, in which the machine is not as close to your body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner. Avoid carrying items such as:</text><detail>Pocketknives, pens, and eyeglasses</detail><detail>Watches, credit cards, jewelry, and hearing aids</detail><detail>Hairpins, metal zippers, pins, and similar items</detail><detail>Removable dental implants </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>An abdominal MRI provides detailed pictures of the belly area from many views. It is often used to clarify findings from earlier x-rays or CT scans.</text><text>This test may be used to look at:</text><detail>Blood flow in the abdomen</detail><detail>Blood vessels in the abdomen</detail><detail>The cause of abdominal pain or swelling</detail><detail>The cause of abnormal blood test results, such as liver or kidney problems</detail><detail>Lymph nodes in the abdomen</detail><detail>Masses in the liver, kidneys, adrenals, pancreas, or spleen </detail><text>MRI can distinguish tumors from normal tissues. This can help the doctor know more about the tumor such as size, severity, and spread. This is called staging.</text><text>In some cases it can give better information about masses in the abdomen than CT.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may be due to:</text><detail>Abdominal aortic aneurysm</detail><detail> Abscess </detail><detail> Cancer or tumors that involves the adrenal glands, liver, gallbladder, pancreas , kidneys, ureters, intestines</detail><detail> Enlarged spleen or liver</detail><detail>Gallbladder or bile duct problems</detail><detail> Hemangiomas </detail><detail> Hydronephrosis (kidney swelling from the backflow of urine)</detail><detail>Kidney infection</detail><detail>Kidney damage or diseases</detail><detail>Kidney stones</detail><detail>Enlarged lymph nodes</detail><detail> Obstructed vena cava </detail><detail>Portal vein obstruction (liver)</detail><detail>Blockage or narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys</detail><detail> Renal vein thrombosis </detail><detail>Kidney or liver transplant rejection </detail><detail> Cirrhosis of the liver </detail><detail>Spread of cancers that began outside the belly </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Nuclear magnetic resonance - abdomen</detail><detail> NMR - abdomen</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - abdomen</detail><detail> MRI of the abdomen</detail>

item.title: Abdominal CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You need to have a special dye, called contrast, put into your body before some exams. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays. Contrast can be administered in various ways. Such as:</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>You may have to drink the contrast before the exam. When you drink it will depend on the type of exam being done. Contrast has a chalky taste, although some are flavored so they taste a little better. The contrast you drink will pass out of your body through your stools and is harmless. </detail><text>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test to safely receive this substance. </text><text>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin. People taking this medicine may have to stop taking it for a while before the test. </text><text>Let your provider know if you have any kidney problems. The IV contrast can worsen kidney function. </text><text>Too much weight can damage the scanner. Find out if the CT machine has a weight limit if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kg). </text><text>You will need to take off your jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>An abdominal CT scan makes detailed pictures of the structures inside your belly very quickly.</text><text>This test may be used to look for:</text><detail>Blood in the urine</detail><detail>Cause of abdominal pain or swelling</detail><detail>Cause of abnormal blood test results such as liver or kidney problems</detail><detail>Hernia</detail><detail>Cause of a fever</detail><detail>Masses and tumors, including cancer</detail><detail>Infections or injury</detail><detail> Kidney stones </detail><detail> Appendicitis </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The abdominal CT scan may show some cancers, including:</text><detail> Cancer of the renal pelvis or ureter </detail><detail>Colon cancer</detail><detail> Hepatocellular carcinoma </detail><detail> Lymphoma </detail><detail>Melanoma</detail><detail>Ovarian cancer</detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><detail> Pheochromocytoma </detail><detail> Renal cell carcinoma (kidney cancer)</detail><detail>Spread of cancers that began outside the belly </detail><text>The abdominal CT scan may show problems with the gallbladder, liver, or pancreas, including:</text><detail> Acute cholecystitis </detail><detail>Alcoholic liver disease</detail><detail> Cholelithiasis </detail><detail> Pancreatic abscess </detail><detail> Pancreatic pseudocyst </detail><detail>Pancreatitis</detail><detail>Blockage of bile ducts </detail><text>The abdominal CT scan may reveal the following kidney problems:</text><detail>Blockage of the kidneys</detail><detail> Hydronephrosis (kidney swelling from the backflow of urine)</detail><detail>Kidney infection</detail><detail>Kidney stones</detail><detail>Kidney or ureter damage</detail><detail> Polycystic kidney disease </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail> Abdominal aortic aneurysm </detail><detail> Abscesses </detail><detail> Appendicitis </detail><detail> Bowel wall thickening </detail><detail>Crohn disease</detail><detail>Renal artery stenosis</detail><detail> Renal vein thrombosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Computed tomography scan - abdomen</detail><detail> CT scan - abdomen</detail><detail> CT abdomen and pelvis</detail>

value.img_name: Neuroblastoma in the liver - CT scan
Peritoneal and ovarian cancer, CT scan

item.title: A1C test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed. The food you have recently eaten does not affect the A1C test, so you do not need to fast to prepare for this blood test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have diabetes . It shows how well you are controlling your diabetes. </text><text>The test may also be used to screen for diabetes.</text><text>Ask your provider how often you should have your A1C level tested. Usually, testing every 3 or 6 months is recommended.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The following are the results when A1C is being used to diagnose diabetes:</text><detail>Normal (no diabetes): Less than 5.7%</detail><detail>Pre-diabetes: 5.7% to 6.4%</detail><detail>Diabetes: 6.5% or higher </detail><text>If you have diabetes, you and your provider will discuss the correct range for you. For many people, the goal is to keep the level below 7%. </text><text>The test result may be incorrect in people with anemia, kidney disease, or certain blood disorders ( thalassemia ). Talk to your provider if you have any of these conditions. Certain medicines can also result in a false A1C level.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that you have had a high blood sugar level over a period of weeks to months.</text><text>If your A1C is above 6.5% and you do not already have diabetes, you may be diagnosed with diabetes.</text><text>If your level is above 7% and you have diabetes, it often means that your blood sugar is not well controlled. You and your provider should determine your target A1C.</text><text>The higher your A1C, the higher the risk that you will develop problems such as:</text><detail> Eye disease </detail><detail>Heart disease</detail><detail> Kidney disease </detail><detail> Nerve damage </detail><detail>Stroke </detail><text>If your A1C stays high, talk to your provider about how to best manage your blood sugar .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>HbA1C test</detail><detail> Glycated hemoglobin test</detail><detail> Glycohemoglobin test</detail><detail> Hemoglobin A1C</detail><detail> Diabetes - A1C</detail><detail> Diabetic - A1C</detail>

item.title: BUN - blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The BUN test is often done to check kidney function.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal result is generally 6 to 20 mg/dL.</text><text>Note: Normal values may vary among different labs. Talk to your provider about your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal level may be due to:</text><detail> Congestive heart failure </detail><detail>Excessive protein level in the gastrointestinal tract</detail><detail> Gastrointestinal bleeding </detail><detail> Hypovolemia (dehydration)</detail><detail>Heart attack</detail><detail>Kidney disease, including glomerulonephritis , pyelonephritis, and acute tubular necrosis </detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail> Shock </detail><detail> Urinary tract obstruction </detail><text>Lower-than-normal level may be due to:</text><detail>Liver failure</detail><detail>Low protein diet</detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail>Over-hydration</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Blood urea nitrogen</detail><detail> Renal insufficiency - BUN</detail><detail> Renal failure - BUN</detail><detail> Renal disease - BUN</detail>

item.title: Buccal smear
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Rinse and wash the mouth as instructed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to get cells for chromosome or DNA analysis, most often for genetic testing.</text><text>This test may also help establish sexual identity. When the test is used in this way, it's called the sex chromatin test.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Sex chromatin test</detail><detail> Buccal swab</detail>

item.title: Bronchoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions on how to prepare for the test. You will likely be told:</text><detail>Not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 12 hours before your test.</detail><detail>Not to take aspirin, ibuprofen, or other blood-thinning drugs before your procedure. Ask the provider who will do your bronchoscopy when to stop taking these drugs.</detail><detail>Arrange for a ride to and from the hospital.</detail><detail>Arrange for help with work, child care, or other tasks, as you will likely need to rest the next day. </detail><text>Usually, the test is done as an outpatient procedure and you will go home the same day. Some people may need to stay overnight in the hospital.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have a bronchoscopy to help your provider diagnose lung problems. Your provider will be able to inspect your airways or take a biopsy sample .</text><text>Common reasons to do a bronchoscopy for diagnosis are:</text><detail>An imaging test showed abnormal changes of your lung, such as a growth or tumor, changes or scarring of lung tissue, or collapse of one area of your lung.</detail><detail>To biopsy lymph nodes near your lungs.</detail><detail>To see why you are coughing up blood.</detail><detail>To explain shortness of breath or low oxygen levels.</detail><detail>To see if there is a foreign object in your airway.</detail><detail>You have a cough that has lasted more than 3 months without any clear cause.</detail><detail>You have an infection in your lungs and major airways (bronchi) that cannot be diagnosed any other way or need a certain type of diagnosis.</detail><detail>You inhaled a toxic gas or chemical.</detail><detail>To see if a lung rejection after a lung transplant is occurring. </detail><text>You may also have a bronchoscopy to treat a lung or airway problem. For example, it may be done to:</text><detail>Remove fluid or mucus plugs from your airways</detail><detail>Remove a foreign object from your airways</detail><detail>Widen (dilate) an airway that is blocked or narrowed</detail><detail>Drain an abscess </detail><detail>Treat cancer using a number of different techniques</detail><detail>Wash out an airway </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results mean normal cells and fluids are found. No foreign substances or blockages are seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Many disorders can be diagnosed with bronchoscopy, including:</text><detail>Infections from bacteria, viruses, fungi, parasites, or tuberculosis.</detail><detail> Lung damage related to allergic-type reactions . </detail><detail> Lung disorders in which the deep lung tissues become inflamed due to the immune system response, and then damaged. For example, changes from sarcoidosis or rheumatoid arthritis may be found.</detail><detail> Lung cancer , or cancer in the area between the lungs.</detail><detail>Narrowing (stenosis) of the trachea or bronchi.</detail><detail>Acute rejection after a lung transplant. </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Fiberoptic bronchoscopy</detail><detail> Lung cancer - bronchoscopy</detail><detail> Pneumonia - bronchoscopy</detail><detail> Chronic lung disease - bronchoscopy</detail>

item.title: Bronchoscopic culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text> Follow your health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for bronchoscopy.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A bronchoscopic culture is done to find infection in the lung that cannot be accurately detected by a sputum culture . The procedure may find the following things, such as:</text><detail>Abnormal secretions</detail><detail>Abnormal lung tissue</detail><detail> Abscesses </detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Obstructive lesions, such as cancer or foreign bodies</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>No organisms are seen on the culture.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal culture results usually indicate a respiratory infection. The infection may be caused by bacteria, viruses, parasites, mycobacteria, or fungi. The results of the culture will help determine the best treatment.</text><text>Not all organisms found with bronchoscopic culture need to be treated. Your provider will tell you more about this if needed.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - bronchoscopic</detail>

item.title: Breath alcohol test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Wait 15 minutes after drinking an alcoholic beverage and 1 minute after smoking before starting the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>When you drink alcohol, the amount of alcohol in your blood goes up. This is called your blood-alcohol level. </text><text>When the amount of alcohol in the blood reaches 0.02% to 0.03%, you may feel a relaxing "high."</text><text>When that percentage reaches 0.05% to 0.10%, you have: </text><detail>Reduced muscle coordination</detail><detail>A longer reaction time</detail><detail>Impaired judgment and responses</detail><text>Driving and operating machinery when you're "high" or drunk (intoxicated) is dangerous. A person with an alcohol level of 0.08% and above is considered legally drunk in most states. (Some states have lower levels than others.)</text><text>The alcohol content of exhaled air accurately reflects the alcohol content of the blood.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal is when the blood alcohol level is not elevated.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>With the balloon method:</text><detail>1 green band means that the blood-alcohol level is 0.05% or lower</detail><detail>2 green bands mean a level between 0.05% and 0.10%</detail><detail>3 green bands mean a level between 0.10% and 0.15%</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Alcohol test - breath</detail>

item.title: Breast ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may want to wear a two-piece outfit, so you do not have to completely undress. </text><text>On the day of your test, DO NOT use any lotion or powder on your breasts. DO NOT use deodorant under your arms. Remove jewelry from your neck and chest area.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Breast ultrasound is usually ordered when more information is needed after other tests are done or as a stand-alone test. These tests may include mammogram or breast MRI .</text><text>Your provider may order this test if you have:</text><detail>A breast lump found during a breast exam</detail><detail>An abnormal mammogram</detail><detail>Clear or bloody nipple discharge </detail><text>A breast ultrasound can:</text><detail>Help tell the difference between a solid mass or a cyst </detail><detail>Help look for a growth if you have clear or bloody fluid coming from your nipple</detail><detail>Guide a needle during a breast biopsy </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the breast tissue appears normal. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Ultrasound can help show noncancerous growths such as:</text><detail>Cysts, which are, fluid-filled sacs</detail><detail> Fibroadenomas , which are, noncancerous solid growths</detail><detail>Lipomas, which are, noncancerous fatty lumps that can occur anywhere in the body, including the breasts </detail><text> Breast cancers can also be seen with ultrasound. </text><text>Follow-up tests to determine whether treatment may be needed include:</text><detail> Breast lump removal (excisional breast biopsy)</detail><detail>Open (surgical) breast biopsy</detail><detail> Stereotactic breast biopsy (needle biopsy performed using a machine like a mammogram)</detail><detail> Ultrasound-guided breast biopsy (needle biopsy performed using ultrasound)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ultrasonography of the breast</detail><detail> Sonogram of the breast</detail><detail> Breast lump - ultrasound</detail>

item.title: Breast MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of tight spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Also, your provider may suggest an "open" MRI. The machine is not as close to the body in this type of test.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail> Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive the IV contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>MRI provides detailed pictures of the breast. It also provides clear pictures of parts of the breast that are hard to see clearly on an ultrasound or mammogram.</text><text>Breast MRI may also be performed to:</text><detail>Check for more cancer in the same breast or the other breast after breast cancer has been diagnosed</detail><detail>Distinguish between scar tissue and tumors in the breast</detail><detail>Evaluate a breast lump (most often after a biopsy)</detail><detail>Evaluate an abnormal result on a mammogram or breast ultrasound</detail><detail>Evaluate for possible rupture of breast implants</detail><detail>Find any cancer that remains after surgery or chemotherapy </detail><detail>Show blood flow through the breast area</detail><detail>Guide a biopsy (not usually done)</detail><text>An MRI of the breast may also be done after a mammogram to screen for breast cancer in women who:</text><detail>Are at very high risk for breast cancer (those with a strong family history or genetic markers for breast cancer)</detail><detail>Have very dense breast tissue</detail><text>Before having a breast MRI, talk to your provider about the pros and cons of having the test. Ask about:</text><detail>Your risk for breast cancer </detail><detail>Whether screening decreases your chance of dying from breast cancer</detail><detail>Whether there is any harm from breast cancer screening, such as side effects from testing or overtreatment of cancer when discovered</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Breast cancer </detail><detail> Cysts </detail><detail>Leaking or ruptured breast implants</detail><detail>Abnormal breast tissue that is not cancer</detail><detail>Scar tissue </detail><text>Consult your provider if you have any questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI - breast</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - breast</detail><detail> Breast cancer - MRI</detail><detail> Breast cancer screening - MRI</detail>

item.title: Breast biopsy - ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The provider will ask about your medical history and perform a manual breast exam.</text><text>If you take blood thinning medicines (including aspirin, supplements, or herbs), ask your doctor whether you need to stop taking these before the biopsy.</text><text>Tell your doctor if you may be pregnant.</text><text>DO NOT use lotion, perfume, powder, or deodorant underneath your arms or on your breasts.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>An ultrasound-guided breast biopsy may be done to evaluate abnormal findings on a mammogram , breast ultrasound , or MRI.</text><text>To determine whether someone has breast cancer, a biopsy must be done. Tissue from the abnormal area is removed and examined under a microscope.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there is no sign of cancer or other breast problems.</text><text>Your provider will let you know if and when you need a follow-up ultrasound, mammogram or other tests.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A biopsy can identify a number of breast conditions that are not cancer or precancer, including:</text><detail> Fibroadenoma (breast lump that usually isn't cancer)</detail><detail>Fat necrosis </detail><text>Biopsy results may show conditions such as:</text><detail>Atypical ductal hyperplasia</detail><detail>Atypical lobular hyperplasia</detail><detail>Flat epithelial atypia</detail><detail> Intraductal papilloma </detail><detail>Lobular carcinoma-in-situ</detail><detail>Radial scar </detail><text>Abnormal results may mean that you have breast cancer. Two main types of breast cancer may be found:</text><detail>Ductal carcinoma starts in the tubes (ducts) that move milk from the breast to the nipple. Most breast cancers are of this type.</detail><detail>Lobular carcinoma starts in parts of the breast called lobules, which produce milk. </detail><text>Depending on the biopsy results, you may need further surgery or treatment.</text><text>Your provider will discuss the meaning of the biopsy results with you.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - breast - ultrasound</detail><detail> Ultrasound-guided breast biopsy</detail><detail> Core needle breast biopsy - ultrasound</detail><detail> Breast cancer-breast biopsy - ultrasound</detail><detail> Abnormal mammogram - breast biopsy - ultrasound</detail>

item.title: Breast biopsy - stereotactic
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The provider will ask about your medical history. A breast exam may be done.</text><text>If you take medicines (including aspirin, supplements, or herbs), ask your doctor whether you need to stop taking these before the biopsy.</text><text>Tell your doctor if you may be pregnant.</text><text>DO NOT use lotion, perfume, powder, or deodorant underneath your arms or on your breasts.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Stereotactic breast biopsy is used when a small growth or an area of calcifications is seen on a mammogram, but cannot be seen using an ultrasound of the breast .</text><text>The tissue samples are sent to a pathologist to be examined.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there is no sign of cancer.</text><text>Your provider will let you know when you need a follow-up mammogram or other tests.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the biopsy shows benign breast tissue without cancer, you will likely not need surgery.</text><text>Sometimes the biopsy results show abnormal signs that are not cancer. In this case, a surgical biopsy might be recommended to remove the whole abnormal area for examination. </text><text>Biopsy results may show conditions such as:</text><detail>Atypical ductal hyperplasia</detail><detail>Atypical lobular hyperplasia</detail><detail> Intraductal papilloma </detail><detail>Flat epithelial atypia</detail><detail>Radial scar</detail><detail>Lobular carcinoma-in-situ </detail><text>Abnormal results may mean that you have breast cancer. Two main types of breast cancer may be found:</text><detail>Ductal carcinoma starts in the tubes (ducts) that move milk from the breast to the nipple. Most breast cancers are of this type.</detail><detail>Lobular carcinoma starts in parts of the breast called lobules, which produce milk. </detail><text>Depending on the biopsy results, you may need further surgery or treatment.</text><text>Your provider will discuss the meaning of the biopsy results with you.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - breast - stereotactic</detail><detail> Core needle breast biopsy - stereotactic</detail><detail> Stereotactic breast biopsy</detail><detail> Abnormal mammogram - stereotactic breast biopsy</detail><detail> Breast cancer - stereotactic breast biopsy</detail>

item.title: Brain PET scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan. You will be able to drink water.</text><text>Tell your provider if:</text><detail>You are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious.</detail><detail>You are pregnant or think you might be pregnant.</detail><detail>You have any allergies to injected dye (contrast).</detail><detail>You have taken insulin for diabetes. You will need special preparation. </detail><text>Always tell your provider about the medicines you are taking, including those bought without a prescription. Sometimes, medicines interfere with the test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A PET scan can show the size, shape, and function of the brain, so your doctor can make sure it is working as well as it should. It is most often used when other tests, such as MRI scan or CT scan, do not provide enough information.</text><text>This test can be used to:</text><detail>Diagnose cancer</detail><detail>Prepare for epilepsy surgery</detail><detail>Help diagnose dementia if other tests and exams do not provide enough information</detail><detail>Tell the difference between Parkinson disease and other movement disorders </detail><text>Several PET scans may be taken to determine how well you are responding to treatment for cancer or another illness.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There are no problems detected in the size, shape, or function of the brain. There are no areas in which the tracer has abnormally collected.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Alzheimer disease or dementia </detail><detail> Brain tumor </detail><detail> Epilepsy , and may identify where the seizures start in your brain</detail><detail>Movement disorders (such as Parkinson disease ) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Brain positron emission tomography</detail><detail> PET scan - brain</detail>

item.title: Brain natriuretic peptide test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have signs of heart failure. Symptoms include shortness of breath and swelling of your legs or abdomen. The test helps make sure the problems are due to your heart and not your lungs, kidneys, or liver. </text><text>It is unclear if repeated BNP tests are helpful in guiding treatment in those already diagnosed with heart failure.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In general, results of less than 100 picograms/milliliter (pg/mL) are a sign a person does not have heart failure.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>BNP levels go up when the heart cannot pump the way it should.</text><text>A result greater than 100 pg/mL is abnormal. The higher the number, the more likely heart failure is present and the more severe it is.</text><text>Sometimes other conditions can cause high BNP levels. These include: </text><detail>Kidney failure</detail><detail>Pulmonary embolism</detail><detail>Pulmonary hypertension</detail><detail>Severe infection (sepsis) </detail><detail>Lung problems</detail>

item.title: Bowel transit time
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>In most cases, you DO NOT need to prepare for this test. However, you should follow any diet or other directions from the health care provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test helps determine bowel function.</text><text>Your provider may ask you to record transit times as you introduce fiber into your diet. Your diet affects the bowel transit time. For example, if you eat a lot of foods rich in fiber (whole grains, vegetables, and fruits), you will have a more rapid transit time and a heavier, bulkier stool.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bowel transit time varies, even in the same person. The color should first appear in the stool about 12 to 14 hours after it is taken. The last of the color will appear within 36 to 48 hours.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the transit time is 72 hours or more, you may have slowed bowel function.</text>

item.title: Bone x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the health care provider if you are pregnant. You must remove all jewelry for the x-ray.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A bone x-ray is used to look for injuries or conditions affecting the bone.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal findings include:</text><detail>Fractures or broken bone</detail><detail> Bone tumors </detail><detail>Degenerative bone conditions</detail><detail> Osteomyelitis (inflammation of the bone caused by an infection)</detail><text>Additional conditions under which the test may be performed:</text><detail> Cystic fibrosis </detail><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) II </detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><detail> Osgood-Schlatter disease </detail><detail> Osteogenesis imperfecta </detail><detail> Osteomalacia </detail><detail> Paget's disease </detail><detail>Primary hyperparathyroidism</detail><detail> Rickets </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - bone</detail>

item.title: Bone scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must remove jewelry and other metal objects. You may be asked to wear a hospital gown.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are or may be pregnant.</text><text>DO NOT take any medicine with bismuth in it, such as Pepto-Bismol, for 4 days before the test.</text><text>Follow any other instructions you are given.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A bone scan is used to:</text><detail>Diagnose a bone tumor or cancer.</detail><detail>Determine if a cancer that began elsewhere in your body has spread to the bones. Common cancers that spread to the bones include breast, lung, prostate, thyroid, and kidney.</detail><detail>Diagnose a fracture, when it cannot be seen on a regular x-ray (most commonly hip fractures, stress fractures in the feet or legs, or spine fractures).</detail><detail>Diagnose a bone infection (osteomyelitis) .</detail><detail>Diagnose or determine the cause of bone pain, when no other cause has been identified.</detail><detail>Evaluate metabolic disorders, such as osteomalacia , primary hyperparathyroidism , osteoporosis , complex regional pain syndrome , and Paget disease .</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Test results are considered normal if the radiotracer is present evenly throughout all the bones.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal scan will show "hot spots" and/or "cold spots" as compared to surrounding bone. Hot spots are areas where there is an increased collection of the radioactive material. Cold spots are areas that have taken up less of the radioactive material.</text><text>Bone scan findings must be compared with other imaging studies, in addition to clinical information. Your provider will discuss any abnormal findings with you.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Scintigraphy - bone</detail>

item.title: Bone mineral density test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If you are or could be pregnant, tell your provider before this test is done.</text><text>DO NOT take calcium supplements for 24 hours before the test.</text><text>You'll be told to remove all metal items from your body, such as jewelry and buckles.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Bone mineral density (BMD) tests are used to:</text><detail>Diagnose bone loss and osteoporosis</detail><detail>See how well osteoporosis medicine is working</detail><detail>Predict your risk for future bone fractures </detail><text>Bone density testing is recommended for all women age 65 and older.</text><text>There is not full agreement on whether men should undergo this type of testing. Some groups recommend testing of men at age 70, while others state that the evidence is not clear enough to say whether men at this age benefit from screening.</text><text>Younger women, as well as men of any age, may also need bone density testing if they have risk factors for osteoporosis. These risk factors include:</text><detail>Fracturing a bone after age 50</detail><detail>Strong family history of osteoporosis</detail><detail>History of treatment for prostate cancer or breast cancer</detail><detail>History of medical conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis , diabetes, thyroid imbalances, or anorexia nervosa</detail><detail>Early menopause (either from natural causes or hysterectomy)</detail><detail>Long-term use of medications such as corticosteroids, thyroid hormone, or aromatase inhibitors</detail><detail>Low body weight (less than 127 pounds) or low body mass index (less than 21)</detail><detail>Significant loss of height</detail><detail>Long-term tobacco or excessive alcohol use </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The results of your test are usually reported as a T-score and Z-score:</text><detail>T-score compares your bone density with that of a healthy young woman.</detail><detail>Z-score compares your bone density with that of other people of your age, gender, and race.</detail><text>With either score, a negative number means you have thinner bones than average. The more negative the number, the higher your risk for a bone fracture.</text><text>A T-score is within the normal range if it is -1.0 or above.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Bone mineral density testing does not diagnose fractures. Along with other risk factors you may have, it helps predict your risk for having a bone fracture in the future. Your provider will help you understand the results.</text><text>If your T-score is:</text><detail>Between -1 and -2.5, you may have early bone loss (osteopenia)</detail><detail>Below -2.5, you likely have osteoporosis </detail><text>Treatment recommendation depends on your total fracture risk. This risk can be calculated using the FRAX score. Your provider can tell you more about this. You can also find information about FRAX online.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>BMD test</detail><detail> Bone density test</detail><detail> Bone densitometry</detail><detail> DEXA scan</detail><detail> DXA</detail><detail> Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry</detail><detail> p-DEXA</detail><detail> Osteoporosis - BMD</detail>

item.title: Bone marrow culture
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test if you have an unexplained fever or if your health care provider thinks you have an infection of the bone marrow.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No growth of bacteria, viruses, or fungi in the culture is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results suggest that you have an infection of the bone marrow. The infection may be from bacteria, viruses, or fungi.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - bone marrow</detail>

item.title: Bone marrow biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider:</text><detail> If you are allergic to any medicines </detail><detail> What medicines you are taking </detail><detail> If you have bleeding problems </detail><detail> If you are pregnant </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have abnormal types or numbers of red or white blood cells or platelets on a complete blood count (CBC).</text><text>This test is used to diagnose leukemia, infections, some types of anemia, and other blood disorders. It may also be used to help determine if a cancer has spread or responded to treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the bone marrow contains the proper number and types of blood-forming (hematopoietic) cells, fat cells, and connective tissues.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to cancers of the bone marrow (leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, or other cancers).</text><text>The results may detect the cause of anemia (too few red blood cells), abnormal white blood cells, or thrombocytopenia (too few platelets).</text><text>Specific conditions for which the test may be performed:</text><detail>A body-wide fungal infection ( disseminated coccidioidomycosis )</detail><detail>A white blood cell cancer called hairy cell leukemia </detail><detail>Cancer of the lymph tissue ( Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin lymphoma )</detail><detail>Bone marrow doesn't make enough blood cells ( aplastic anemia )</detail><detail>Blood cancer called multiple myeloma </detail><detail>Group of disorders in which not enough healthy blood cells are made (myelodysplastic syndrome; MDS)</detail><detail>A nerve tissue tumor called neuroblastoma </detail><detail>Bone marrow disease that leads to an abnormal increase in blood cells ( polycythemia vera )</detail><detail>Abnormal protein buildup in tissues and organs ( amyloidosis )</detail><detail>Bone marrow disorder in which the marrow is replaced by fibrous scar tissue ( myelofibrosis )</detail><detail>Bone marrow produces too many platelets ( thrombocythemia )</detail><detail>White blood cell cancer called Waldenström macroglobulinemia </detail><detail>Unexplained anemia, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) or leukopenia (low WBC count) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - bone marrow</detail>

item.title: Bone marrow aspiration
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider:</text><detail>If you are allergic to any medicines</detail><detail>If you are pregnant</detail><detail>If you have bleeding problems</detail><detail>What medicines you are taking</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order this test if you have abnormal types or numbers of red or white blood cells or platelets on a complete blood count. </text><text>This test is used to diagnose:</text><detail> Anemia (some types)</detail><detail>Infections</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Other blood cancers and disorders </detail><text>It may help determine whether cancers have spread or responded to treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bone marrow should contain the proper number and types of:</text><detail>Blood-forming cells</detail><detail>Connective tissues</detail><detail>Fat cells</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to cancers of the bone marrow, including:</text><detail> Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL)</detail><detail> Acute myelogenous leukemia (AML)</detail><detail> Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)</detail><detail> Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to other causes, such as:</text><detail>Bone marrow doesn't make enough blood cells (aplastic anemia)</detail><detail>Bacterial or fungal infections that have spread throughout the body</detail><detail>Cancer of the lymph tissue (Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin lymphoma )</detail><detail>A bleeding disorder called idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)</detail><detail>Blood cancer called ( multiple myeloma )</detail><detail>Disorder in which the bone marrow is replaced by scar tissue ( myelofibrosis )</detail><detail>Disorder in which not enough healthy blood cells are made (myelodysplastic syndrome; MDS)</detail><detail>Abnormally low amount of platelets, which help blood to clot (primary thrombocytopenia )</detail><detail>White blood cell cancer called Waldenström macroglobulinemia </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Iliac crest tap</detail><detail> Sternal tap</detail><detail> Leukemia - bone marrow aspiration</detail><detail> Aplastic anemia - bone marrow aspiration</detail><detail> Myelodysplastic syndrome - bone marrow aspiration</detail><detail> Thrombocytopenia - bone marrow aspiration</detail><detail> Myelofibrosis - bone marrow aspiration </detail>

item.title: Bone lesion biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your provider's instructions on how to prepare. This may include not eating and drinking for several hours before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The most common reasons for bone lesion biopsy are to tell the difference between cancerous and noncancerous bone tumors and to identify other bone problems. It may be performed on people with bone pain and tenderness, particularly if x-ray , CT scan, or other testing reveals a problem.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No abnormal bone tissue is found.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may be any of the following problems.</text><text>Benign (noncancerous) bone tumors, such as:</text><detail>Bone cyst </detail><detail>Fibroma</detail><detail> Osteoblastoma </detail><detail> Osteoid osteoma </detail><text>Cancerous tumors, such as:</text><detail> Ewing sarcoma </detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><detail> Osteosarcoma </detail><detail>Other types of cancer that may have spread to the bone </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail> Osteitis fibrosa (weak and deformed bone)</detail><detail> Osteomalacia (softening of the bones)</detail><detail> Osteomyelitis (bone infection) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Bone biopsy</detail><detail> Biopsy - bone</detail>

item.title: Blood sugar test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The test may be done in the following ways: </text><detail>After you have not eaten anything for at least 8 hours (fasting)</detail><detail>At any time of the day (random)</detail><detail>Two hours after you drink a certain amount of glucose ( oral glucose tolerance test ) </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order this test if you have signs of diabetes . More than likely, the doctor will order a fasting blood sugar test.</text><text>The blood glucose test is also used to monitor people who already have diabetes. </text><text>The test may also be done if you have:</text><detail>An increase in how often you need to urinate</detail><detail>Recently gained a lot of weight</detail><detail>Blurred vision</detail><detail>Confusion or a change in the way you normally talk or behave</detail><detail>Fainting spells</detail><detail>Seizures (for the first time) </detail><detail>Unconsciousness or coma</detail><text>SCREENING FOR DIABETES</text><text>This test may also be used to screen a person for diabetes.</text><text>High blood sugar and diabetes may not cause symptoms in the early stages. A fasting blood sugar test is almost always done to screen for diabetes.</text><text>If you are over age 45, you should be tested every 3 years.</text><text>If you're overweight (body mass index, or BMI, of 25 or higher) and have any of the risk factors below, ask your health care provider about getting tested at an earlier age and more often:</text><detail>High blood sugar level on a previous test</detail><detail>Blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg or higher, or unhealthy cholesterol levels</detail><detail>History of heart disease</detail><detail>Member of a high-risk ethnic group (African American, Latino, Native American, Asian American, or Pacific Islander)</detail><detail>Woman who has been diagnosed with gestational diabetes</detail><detail>Polycystic ovary disease (condition in which a woman has an imbalance of female sex hormones causing cysts in the ovaries)</detail><detail>Close relative with diabetes (such as a parent, brother, or sister)</detail><detail>Not physically active </detail><text>Children age 10 and older who are overweight and have at least two of the risk factors listed above should be tested for type 2 diabetes every 3 years, even if they have no symptoms.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>If you had a fasting blood glucose test, a level between 70 and 100 mg/dL (3.9 and 5.6 mmol/L) is considered normal.</text><text>If you had a random blood glucose test, a normal result depends on when you last ate. Most of the time, the blood glucose level will be below 125 mg/dL (6.9 mmol/L).</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If you had a fasting blood glucose test: </text><detail>A level of 100 to 125 mg/dL (5.6 to 6.9 mmol/L) means you have impaired fasting glucose, a type of prediabetes. This increases your risk of developing type 2 diabetes.</detail><detail>A level of 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) and higher usually means you have diabetes. </detail><text>If you had a random blood glucose test:</text><detail>A level of 200 mg/dL (11 mmol/L) or higher often means you have diabetes.</detail><detail>Your provider will order a fasting blood glucose, A1C test , or glucose tolerance test , depending on your random blood glucose test result.</detail><detail>In someone who has diabetes, an abnormal result on the random blood glucose test may mean that the diabetes is not well controlled. </detail><text>Other medical problems can also cause a higher-than-normal blood glucose level, including:</text><detail> Overactive thyroid gland </detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><detail>Swelling and inflammation of the pancreas ( pancreatitis )</detail><detail>Stress due to trauma, stroke, heart attack, or surgery</detail><detail>Rare tumors, including pheochromocytoma , acromegaly , Cushing syndrome , or glucagonoma </detail><text>A lower-than-normal blood glucose level ( hypoglycemia ) may be due to:</text><detail> Hypopituitarism (a pituitary gland disorder)</detail><detail> Underactive thyroid gland or adrenal gland</detail><detail>Tumor in the pancreas ( insulinoma - very rare)</detail><detail>Too little food</detail><detail>Too much insulin or other diabetes medicines</detail><detail>Liver or kidney disease</detail><detail>Weight loss after weight loss surgery</detail><detail>Vigorous exercise </detail><text>Some medicines can raise or lower your blood glucose level. Before having the test, tell your provider about all the medicines you are taking.</text><text>For some thin young women, a fasting blood sugar level below 70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L) may be normal.</text>
