item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Random blood sugar</detail><detail> Blood sugar level</detail><detail> Fasting blood sugar</detail><detail> Glucose test</detail><detail> Diabetic screening - blood sugar test</detail><detail> Diabetes - blood sugar test</detail>

item.title: Blood smear
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done as part of a general health exam to help diagnose many illnesses. Or, your health care provider may recommend this test if you have signs of:</text><detail>Any known or suspected blood disorder</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><text>A blood smear may also be done to monitor the side effects of chemotherapy or to help diagnose an infection, such as malaria.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Red blood cells normally are the same size and color and are a lighter color in the center. The blood smear is considered normal if there is:</text><detail>Normal appearance of cells</detail><detail>Normal white blood cell differential </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean the size, shape, color, or coating of the red blood cells (RBCs) is not normal.</text><text>Some abnormalities may be graded on a 4-point scale:</text><detail>1+ means one quarter of cells are affected</detail><detail>2+ means one half of cells are affected</detail><detail>3+ means three quarters of cells are affected</detail><detail>4+ means all of the cells are affected </detail><text>Presence of cells called target cells may be due to:</text><detail>Deficiency of an enzyme called lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase</detail><detail>Abnormal hemoglobin , the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen (hemoglobinopathies)</detail><detail>Iron deficiency</detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail>Spleen removal </detail><text>Presence of sphere-shaped cells may be due to:</text><detail>Low number of RBCs due to the body destroying them ( immune hemolytic anemia )</detail><detail>Low number of RBCs due to some red blood cells shaped like spheres ( hereditary spherocytosis )</detail><detail>Increased breakdown of RBCs </detail><text>Presence of RBCs with an oval shape may be a sign of hereditary elliptocytosis or hereditary ovalocytosis . These are conditions in which RBCs are abnormally shaped.</text><text>Presence of fragmented cells may be due to:</text><detail>Artificial heart valve</detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become overactive ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail>Infection in the digestive system producing toxic substances that destroy red blood cells, causing kidney injury ( hemolytic uremic syndrome )</detail><detail>Blood disorder that causes blood clots to form in small blood vessels around the body and leads to a low platelet count ( thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura ) </detail><text>Presence of a type of immature red blood cells called normoblasts may be due to:</text><detail>Cancer that has spread to bone marrow</detail><detail>Blood disorder called erythroblastosis fetalis that affects a fetus or newborn</detail><detail>Tuberculosis that has spread from the lungs to other parts of the body through the blood ( miliary tuberculosis )</detail><detail>Disorder of the bone marrow in which the marrow is replaced by fibrous scar tissue ( myelofibrosis )</detail><detail>Removal of spleen</detail><detail>Severe breakdown of RBCs ( hemolysis )</detail><detail>Disorder in which there is excessive breakdown of hemoglobin ( thalassemia ) </detail><text>The presence of cells called burr cells may indicate:</text><detail>Abnormally high level of nitrogen waste products in the blood ( uremia ) </detail><text>The presence of cells called spur cells may indicate:</text><detail>Inability to fully absorb dietary fats through the intestines ( abetalipoproteinemia )</detail><detail>Severe liver disease </detail><text>The presence of teardrop-shaped cells may indicate:</text><detail>Myelofibrosis</detail><detail>Severe iron deficiency</detail><detail>Thalassemia major</detail><detail>Cancer in the bone marrow</detail><detail>Anemia caused by bone marrow not producing normal blood cells due to toxins or tumor cells (myelophthisic process) </detail><text>The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies (a type of granule) may indicate:</text><detail>Bone marrow does not produce enough healthy blood cells (myelodysplasia)</detail><detail> Spleen has been removed </detail><detail> Sickle cell anemia </detail><text>The presence of Heinz bodies (bits of altered hemoglobin) may indicate:</text><detail>Alpha thalassemia</detail><detail>Congenital hemolytic anemia</detail><detail>Disorder in which red blood cells break down when the body is exposed to certain drugs or is stressed because of infection ( G6PD deficiency )</detail><detail>Unstable form of hemoglobin </detail><text>The presence of slightly immature red blood cells may indicate:</text><detail>Anemia with bone marrow recovery</detail><detail>Hemolytic anemia</detail><detail>Hemorrhage </detail><text>The presence of basophilic stippling (a spotted appearance) may indicate:</text><detail> Lead poisoning </detail><detail>Disorder of the bone marrow in which the marrow is replaced by fibrous scar tissue (myelofibrosis) </detail><text>The presence of sickle cells may indicate sickle cell anemia.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Peripheral smear</detail><detail> Complete blood count - peripheral</detail><detail> CBC - peripheral </detail>

value.img_name: Red blood cells, multiple sickle cells
Malaria, microscopic view of cellular parasites
Red blood cells, sickle and Pappenheimer

item.title: Blood pressure measurement
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before you measure your blood pressure:</text><detail>Rest for at least 5 minutes, 10 minutes is better, before blood pressure is taken.</detail><detail>DO NOT take your blood pressure when you are under stress, have had caffeine or used tobacco in the past 30 minutes, or have exercised recently.</detail><text>Take 2 or 3 readings at a sitting. Take the readings 1 minute apart. Remain seated. When checking your blood pressure on your own, note the time of the readings. Your provider may suggest that you do your readings at certain times of the day.</text><detail>You may want to take your blood pressure in the morning and at night for a week.</detail><detail>This will give you at least 14 readings and will help your provider make decisions about your blood pressure treatment.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>High blood pressure has no symptoms so you may not know if you have this problem. High blood pressure is often discovered during a visit to the provider for another reason (such as a routine physical exam).</text><text>Finding high blood pressure and treating it early can help prevent heart disease, stroke, eye problems, or chronic kidney disease . </text><text>All adults over the age of 18 should have their blood pressure checked every year . More frequent measurement may be needed for those with a history of high blood pressure readings or those with risk factors for high blood pressure.</text><text>Your provider may recommend more frequent screenings based on your blood pressure levels and other health conditions.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Blood pressure readings are usually given as two numbers. For example, your provider might tell you that your blood pressure is 120 over 80 (written as 120/80 mm Hg). One or both of these numbers can be too high.</text><text>Normal blood pressure is when the top number (systolic blood pressure) is below 120 most of the time, and the bottom number (diastolic blood pressure) is below 80 most of the time (written as 120/80 mm Hg).</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If your blood pressure is between 120/80 and 130/80 mm Hg, you have elevated blood pressure. </text><text>If your blood pressure is higher than 130/80 but lower than 140/90 mm Hg, you have Stage 1 high blood pressure. </text><text>If your blood pressure is higher than 140/90 mm Hg, you have Stage 2 high blood pressure. </text><text>If you have diabetes, heart disease, or kidney problems, or if you had a stroke, your provider may want your blood pressure to be lower.</text><text>The most commonly used blood pressure targets for people with these medical problems are below 130 to 140/80 mm Hg.</text><text>Most of the time, high blood pressure does not cause symptoms.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Diastolic blood pressure</detail><detail> Systolic blood pressure</detail><detail> Blood pressure reading</detail><detail> Measuring blood pressure</detail><detail> Hypertension - blood pressure measurement</detail><detail> High blood pressure - blood pressure measurement</detail><detail> Sphygmomanometry</detail>

item.title: Blood gases
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation. If you are on oxygen therapy, the oxygen concentration must remain constant for 20 minutes before the test.</text><text>Tell your provider if you are taking any blood-thinning medicines (anticoagulants), including aspirin.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is used to evaluate respiratory diseases and conditions that affect the lungs. It helps determine the effectiveness of oxygen therapy. The test also provides information about the body's acid/base balance, which can reveal important clues about lung and kidney function and the body's general metabolic state .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Values at sea level:</text><detail>Partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2): 75 to 100 mm Hg (10.5 to 13.5 kPa)</detail><detail>Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2): 38 to 42 mm Hg (5.1 to 5.6 kPa)</detail><detail>Arterial blood pH: 7.38 to 7.42</detail><detail>Oxygen saturation (SaO2): 94% to 100%</detail><detail>Bicarbonate - (HCO3): 22 to 28 mEq/L</detail><text>Note: mEq/L = milliequivalents per liter; mmHg = millimeters of mercury</text><text>At altitudes of 3,000 feet (900 meters) and higher, the oxygen value is lower.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to lung, kidney, or metabolic diseases. Head or neck injuries or other injuries that affect breathing can also lead to abnormal results.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Arterial blood gas analysis</detail><detail> ABG</detail><detail> Hypoxia - ABG</detail><detail> Respiratory failure - ABG</detail>

item.title: Blood differential test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to diagnose an infection, anemia , or leukemia . It may also be used to monitor one of these conditions, or to see if treatment is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The different types of white blood cells are given as a percentage: </text><detail>Neutrophils: 40% to 60%</detail><detail>Lymphocytes: 20% to 40%</detail><detail>Monocytes: 2% to 8%</detail><detail>Eosinophils: 1% to 4%</detail><detail>Basophils: 0.5% to 1%</detail><detail>Band (young neutrophil): 0% to 3% </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Any infection or acute stress increases your number of white blood cells. High white blood cell counts may be due to inflammation, an immune response, or blood diseases such as leukemia.</text><text>It is important to realize that an abnormal increase in one type of white blood cell can cause a decrease in the percentage of other types of white blood cells.</text><text>An increased percentage of neutrophils may be due to:</text><detail>Acute infection</detail><detail>Acute stress</detail><detail> Eclampsia (seizures or coma in a pregnant woman)</detail><detail> Gout (type of arthritis due to uric acid buildup in the blood)</detail><detail> Myelocytic leukemia (a bone marrow cancer)</detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><detail> Rheumatic fever (disease due to an infection with group A streptococcus bacteria)</detail><detail> Thyroiditis (a thyroid disease)</detail><detail>Trauma </detail><text>A decreased percentage of neutrophils may be due to:</text><detail> Aplastic anemia </detail><detail> Chemotherapy </detail><detail> Influenza (flu)</detail><detail> Radiation therapy or exposure</detail><detail>Viral infection</detail><detail>Widespread severe bacterial infection </detail><text>An increased percentage of lymphocytes may be due to:</text><detail> Chronic bacterial infection</detail><detail> Infectious hepatitis (liver swelling and inflammation from bacteria or viruses)</detail><detail> Infectious mononucleosis , or mono (viral infection that causes fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph glands)</detail><detail> Lymphocytic leukemia (a type of blood cancer)</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma (a type of blood cancer)</detail><detail>Viral infection (such as mumps or measles ) </detail><text>A decreased percentage of lymphocytes may be due to:</text><detail>Chemotherapy</detail><detail>HIV/AIDS infection</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Radiation therapy or exposure</detail><detail> Sepsis (severe, inflammatory response to bacteria or other germs)</detail><detail>Steroid use </detail><text>An increased percentage of monocytes may be due to:</text><detail>Chronic inflammatory disease</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Parasitic infection</detail><detail> Tuberculosis , or TB (bacterial infection that involves the lungs)</detail><detail>Viral infection (for example, infectious mononucleosis, mumps, measles) </detail><text>An increased percentage of eosinophils may be due to:</text><detail> Addison disease (adrenal glands do not produce enough hormones)</detail><detail> Allergic reaction </detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail> Chronic myelogenous leukemia </detail><detail>Collagen vascular disease</detail><detail>Hypereosinophilic syndromes</detail><detail>Parasitic infection </detail><text>An increased percentage of basophils may be due to:</text><detail>After splenectomy</detail><detail>Allergic reaction</detail><detail> Chronic myelogenous leukemia (a type of bone marrow cancer)</detail><detail> Collagen vascular disease </detail><detail>Myeloproliferative diseases (group of bone marrow diseases)</detail><detail>Chickenpox </detail><text>A decreased percentage of basophils may be due to:</text><detail>Acute infection</detail><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Severe injury </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Differential</detail><detail> Diff</detail><detail> White blood cell differential count</detail>

item.title: Blood culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: Your health care provider may order this test if you have symptoms of a serious infection, also known as sepsis . Symptoms of sepsis can include high fever, chills, rapid breathing and heart rate, confusion, and low blood pressure.The blood culture helps identify the type of bacteria causing the infection. This helps your provider determine how best to treat the infection.
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value means that no bacteria or other germs were seen in your blood sample.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) result means that germs were identified in your blood. The medical term for this is bacteremia. This can be the result of sepsis. Sepsis is a medical emergency and you will be admitted to a hospital for treatment.</text><text>Other types of germs, such as a fungus or a virus, may also be found in a blood culture.</text><text>Sometimes, an abnormal result can be due to contamination. This means bacteria may be found, but it came from your skin or from the lab equipment, instead of your blood. This is called a false-positive result. It means you do not have a true infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - blood </detail>

item.title: Bleeding time
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines can change blood test results.</text><detail>Tell your health care provider about all the medicines you take.</detail><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to temporarily stop taking any medicines before you have this test. This may include dextran and aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your doctor first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test helps diagnose bleeding problems .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Bleeding normally stops within 1 to 9 minutes. However, values may vary from lab to lab. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Longer-than-normal bleeding time may be due to:</text><detail>Blood vessel defect</detail><detail> Platelet aggregation defect </detail><detail> Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count)</detail>

item.title: Bladder biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You must sign an informed consent form before you have a bladder biopsy. In most cases, you are asked to urinate just before the procedure. You may also be asked to take an antibiotic before the procedure.</text><text>For infants and children, the preparation you can provide for this test depends on your child's age, previous experiences, and level of trust. For general information regarding how you can prepare your child, see the following topics:</text><detail> Infant test or procedure preparation (birth to 1 year)</detail><detail> Toddler test or procedure preparation (1 to 3 years)</detail><detail> Preschooler test or procedure preparation (3 to 6 years)</detail><detail> School age test or procedure preparation (6 to 12 years)</detail><detail> Adolescent test or procedure preparation (12 to 18 years) </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to check for cancer of the bladder or urethra.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bladder wall is smooth. The bladder is of a normal size, shape, and position. There are no blockages , growths, or stones .</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The presence of cancer cells indicates bladder cancer. The type of cancer can be determined from the biopsy sample.</text><text>Other abnormalities may include:</text><detail>Bladder diverticula </detail><detail> Cysts </detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail> Ulcers </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - bladder</detail>

item.title: Biopsy - polyps
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If the biopsy is in the nose or another surface that is open or can be seen, no special preparation is needed. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to not eat or drink anything (fast) before the biopsy.</text><text>More preparation is needed for biopsies inside the body. For example, if you have a biopsy of the stomach, you should not eat anything for several hours before the procedure. If you are having a colonoscopy, a solution to clean your bowels is needed before the procedure.</text><text>Follow your provider's preparation instructions exactly. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to determine if the growth is cancerous (malignant). The procedure may also be done to relieve symptoms, such as with the removal of nasal polyps.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Examination of the biopsy sample shows the polyp to be benign (not cancerous).</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Cancer cells are present and may be a sign of a cancerous tumor . Further tests may be needed. Often, the polyp may need more treatment to ensure it is completely removed.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Polyp biopsy</detail>

item.title: Biopsy - biliary tract
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may not be able to eat or drink 8 to 12 hours or more before the test. Your health care provider will tell you ahead of time what you need to do.</text><text>Make sure you have someone to drive you home.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A biliary tract biopsy can determine if a tumor started in the liver or spread from another location. It also can determine if the tumor is cancerous.</text><text>This test may be done:</text><detail>After a physical exam, x-ray , MRI , CT scan , or ultrasound shows abnormal growths in your biliary tract</detail><detail>To test for diseases or infection </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there are no signs of cancer, disease, or infection in the biopsy sample.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Cancer of the bile ducts ( cholangiocarcinoma )</detail><detail>Cysts in the liver</detail><detail>Liver cancer</detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><detail>Swelling and scarring of the bile ducts ( primary sclerosing cholangitis )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cytology analysis - biliary tract</detail><detail> Biliary tract biopsy</detail>

item.title: Biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before scheduling the biopsy, tell your health care provider about any medicines you are taking, including herbs and supplements. You may be asked to stop taking some for a while, particularly those that can make you bleed. Such medicines include aspirin, warfarin (Coumadin), clopidogrel (Plavix), and NSAIDs.</text><text>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A biopsy is most often done to examine tissue for disease. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The tissue removed is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal biopsy means that the tissue or cells have an unusual structure, shape, size, or condition.</text><text>This may mean you have a disease, such as cancer, but it depends on your biopsy.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Tissue sampling</detail>

item.title: Bilirubin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for at least 4 hours before the test. Your health care provider may instruct you to stop taking medicines that affect the test.</text><text>Many drugs may change the bilirubin level in your blood. Make sure your provider knows which medicines you are taking.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A small amount of older red blood cells are replaced by new blood cells every day. Bilirubin is left after these older blood cells are removed. The liver helps break down bilirubin so that it can be removed from the body in the stool.</text><text>A high level of bilirubin in the blood can lead to jaundice . Jaundice is a yellow color in the skin, mucus membranes, or eyes.</text><text>Jaundice is the most common reason to check bilirubin level. The test will likely be ordered when:</text><detail>The provider is concerned about a newborn's jaundice (most newborns have some jaundice)</detail><detail>Jaundice develops in older infants, children, and adults</detail><text>A bilirubin test is also ordered when the provider suspects a person has liver or gallbladder problems.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>It is normal to have some bilirubin in the blood. A normal level is:</text><detail>Direct (also called conjugated) bilirubin: less than 0.3 mg/dL (less than 5.1 µmol/L)</detail><detail>Total bilirubin: 0.1 to 1.2 mg/dL (1.71 to 20.5 µmol/L)</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In newborns, bilirubin level is higher for the first few days of life. Your child's provider must consider the following when deciding whether your baby's bilirubin level is too high:</text><detail>How fast the level has been rising</detail><detail>Whether the baby was born early</detail><detail>The baby's age</detail><text>Jaundice can also occur when more red blood cells than normal are broken down. This can be caused by:</text><detail>A blood disorder called erythroblastosis fetalis </detail><detail>A red blood cell disorder called hemolytic anemia </detail><detail> Transfusion reaction in which red blood cells that were given in a transfusion are destroyed by the person's immune system</detail><text>The following liver problems may also cause jaundice or a high bilirubin level:</text><detail>Scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis )</detail><detail>Swollen and inflamed liver ( hepatitis )</detail><detail>Other liver disease</detail><detail>Disorder in which bilirubin is not processed normally by the liver ( Gilbert disease )</detail><text>The following problems with gallbladder or bile ducts may cause higher bilirubin levels:</text><detail>Abnormal narrowing of the common bile duct ( biliary stricture )</detail><detail> Cancer of the pancreas or gallbladder</detail><detail>Gallstones</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Total bilirubin - blood</detail><detail> Unconjugated bilirubin - blood</detail><detail> Indirect bilirubin - blood</detail><detail> Conjugated bilirubin - blood</detail><detail> Direct bilirubin - blood</detail>

item.title: Bilirubin - urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without first talking to your provider. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to diagnose liver or gallbladder problems.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Bilirubin is not normally found in the urine.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased levels of bilirubin in the urine may be due to:</text><detail>Biliary tract disease</detail><detail> Cirrhosis </detail><detail> Gallstones in the biliary tract </detail><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail> Tumors of the liver or gallbladder </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Conjugated bilirubin - urine</detail><detail> Direct bilirubin - urine</detail>

item.title: Bile culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Preparation depends on the specific method used to obtain the bile sample. Follow your health care provider's instructions exactly.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to detect infection within the biliary system . The biliary system creates, moves, stores, and releases bile to help in digestion.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test result is normal if no bacteria, virus, or fungus grew in the laboratory dish.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means bacteria, fungus, or a virus grew in the laboratory dish. This may be a sign of infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - bile</detail>

item.title: Beta-carotene blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your health care provider's instructions about not eating or drinking anything for up to 8 hours before the test. You may also be asked not to eat anything with vitamin A (carotene) for 48 hours before the test.</text><text>Your provider may also tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines, such as retinol, which may interfere with test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Beta-carotene is found in certain foods. It breaks down to become vitamin A in the body. </text><text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs that your vitamin A level may be too low, such as:</text><detail>Bones or teeth that do not develop correctly</detail><detail>Dry or inflamed eyes</detail><detail>Feeling more irritable</detail><detail>Hair loss</detail><detail>Loss of appetite</detail><detail>Recurring infections</detail><detail>Skin rashes</detail><detail>Problems seeing at night </detail><text>The test can also be used to help measure how well your body absorbs fats.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 50 to 300 mcg/dL or 0.93 to 5.59 micromol/L.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level may be due to taking too much vitamin A ( hypervitaminosis A ).</text><text>Beta-carotene deficiency may occur if you are malnourished. It can also occur if your body has trouble absorbing fats through the digestive tract such as with:</text><detail>Long-term (chronic) lung disease called cystic fibrosis </detail><detail>Pancreas problems such as swelling and inflammation ( pancreatitis ) or the organ not producing enough enzymes (pancreatic insufficiency)</detail><detail>Small intestine disorder called celiac disease </detail><text>This test plays a valuable role in diagnosing vitamin A deficiency. But the test results must be evaluated along with other clinical findings.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Carotene test</detail>

item.title: Bernstein test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be asked not to eat or drink anything for 8 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test tries to reproduce symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux (stomach acids coming back up into the esophagus). It is done to see if you have the condition. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test results will be negative.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test shows that your symptoms are caused by esophageal reflux of acid from the stomach.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Acid perfusion test</detail>

item.title: Basic metabolic panel
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for 8 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to evaluate:</text><detail>Kidney function</detail><detail>Blood acid/base balance</detail><detail>Blood sugar levels</detail><text>In some cases, the test also is used to check blood levels of calcium and a protein called albumin.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The following are normal ranges for the blood chemicals tested:</text><detail> BUN : 7 to 20 mg/dL (2.50 to 7.14 mmol/L)</detail><detail> CO2 (carbon dioxide) : 20 to 29 mmol/L</detail><detail> Creatinine : 0.8 to 1.2 mg/dL (70.72 to 106.08 micromol/L)</detail><detail> Glucose : 64 to 100 mg/dL (3.55 to 5.55 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Serum chloride : 101 to 111 mmol/L</detail><detail> Serum potassium : 3.7 to 5.2 mEq/L (3.7 to 5.2 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Serum sodium : 136 to 144 mEq/L (136 to 144 mmol/L)</detail><text>Key to abbreviations:</text><detail>L = liter</detail><detail>dL = deciliter = 0.1 liter</detail><detail>mg = milligram</detail><detail>mmol = millimole</detail><detail>mEq = milliequivalents </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results can be due to a variety of different medical conditions, including kidney failure, breathing problems, diabetes or diabetes-related complications, and medicine side effects. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your results from each test.</text><text>The basic metatabolic panel typically measures these substances in a sample of blood:</text><detail> BUN (blood urea nitrogen)</detail><detail> Creatinine </detail><detail> CO2 (carbon dioxide)</detail><detail> Glucose </detail><detail> Serum chloride </detail><detail> Serum potassium </detail><detail> Serum sodium </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>SMAC7</detail><detail> Sequential multi-channel analysis with computer-7</detail><detail> SMA7</detail><detail> Metabolic panel 7</detail><detail> CHEM-7</detail>

item.title: Barium enema
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your bowels need to be completely empty for the exam. If they are not empty, the test may miss a problem in your large intestine.</text><text>You will be given instructions for cleansing your bowel using an enema or laxatives. This is also called bowel preparation. Follow the instructions exactly.</text><text>For 1 to 3 days before the test, you need to be on a clear liquid diet. Examples of clear liquids are:</text><detail>Clear coffee or tea</detail><detail>Fat-free bouillon or broth</detail><detail>Gelatin</detail><detail>Sports drinks without added color</detail><detail>Strained fruit juices</detail><detail>Water </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Barium enema is used to: </text><detail>Detect or screen for colon cancer </detail><detail>Diagnose or monitor ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease </detail><detail>Diagnose the cause of blood in stools, diarrhea, or very hard stools (constipation) </detail><text>The barium enema test is used much less often than in the past. Colonoscopy is done more often now.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Barium should fill the colon evenly, showing normal bowel shape and position and no blockages.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal test results may be a sign of:</text><detail>Blockage of the large intestine</detail><detail>Narrowing of the colon above the rectum ( Hirschsprung disease in infants)</detail><detail>Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis</detail><detail>Cancer in the colon or rectum</detail><detail>Sliding of one part of the intestine into another ( intussusception )</detail><detail>Small growths that stick out of the lining of the colon, called polyps </detail><detail>Small, bulging sacs or pouches of the inner lining of the intestine, called diverticula </detail><detail>Twisted loop of the bowel ( volvulus ) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Lower gastrointestinal series</detail><detail> Lower GI series</detail><detail> Colorectal cancer - lower GI series</detail><detail> Colorectal cancer - barium enema</detail><detail> Crohn disease - lower GI series</detail><detail> Crohn disease - barium enema</detail><detail> Intestinal blockage - lower GI series</detail><detail> Intestinal blockage - barium enema</detail>

item.title: BAER - brainstem auditory evoked response
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked to wash your hair the night before the test.</text><text>Young children often need medicine to help them relax (sedation) so they can stay still during the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to:</text><detail>Help diagnose nervous system problems and hearing loss (especially in newborns and children)</detail><detail>Find out how well the nervous system works</detail><detail>Check hearing ability in people who cannot do other hearing tests</detail><text>This test may also be performed during surgery to decrease the risk for injury to the hearing nerve and brain.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results vary. Results will depend on the person and the instruments used to perform the test.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal test results may be a sign of hearing loss , multiple sclerosis , acoustic neuroma , or stroke.</text><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail>Brain injury</detail><detail>Brain malformation</detail><detail>Brain tumor</detail><detail> Central pontine myelinolysis </detail><detail>Speech disorders</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Evoked auditory potentials</detail><detail> Brainstem auditory evoked potentials</detail><detail> Evoked response audiometry</detail><detail> Auditory brainstem response</detail><detail> ABR</detail><detail> BAEP</detail>

item.title: B and T cell screen
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your health care provider if you have had any of the following, which might affect your T and B cell count:</text><detail> Chemotherapy </detail><detail>HIV/AIDS</detail><detail>Radiation therapy</detail><detail>Recent or current infection</detail><detail>Steroid therapy</detail><detail> Stress </detail><detail>Surgery</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of certain diseases that weaken the immune system. It may also be used to distinguish between cancerous and noncancerous disease, particularly cancers that involve the blood and bone marrow.</text><text>The test may also be used to determine how well treatment for certain conditions is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal T and B cell counts suggest a possible disease. Further testing is needed to confirm a diagnosis.</text><text>An increased T cell count may be due to:</text><detail> Cancer of white blood cell called a lymphoblast ( acute lymphoblastic leukemia )</detail><detail> Cancer of white blood cells called lymphocytes ( chronic lymphocytic leukemia )</detail><detail> A viral infection called infectious mononucleosis </detail><detail> Blood cancer that starts in the plasma cells in the bone marrow ( multiple myeloma )</detail><detail>Syphilis, an STD</detail><detail>Toxoplasmosis, an infection due to a parasite</detail><detail>Tuberculosis </detail><text>An increased B cell count may be due to:</text><detail>Chronic lymphocytic leukemia</detail><detail>DiGeorge syndrome</detail><detail>Multiple myeloma</detail><detail> Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia </detail><text>A decreased T cell count may be due to:</text><detail>Congenital T-cell deficiency disease, such as Nezelof syndrome, DiGeorge syndrome, or Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome</detail><detail>Acquired T-cell deficiency states, such as HIV infection or HTLV-1 infection</detail><detail>B cell proliferative disorders, such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia or Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia </detail><text>A decreased B cell count may be due to:</text><detail> HIV/AIDS </detail><detail>Acute lymphoblastic leukemia</detail><detail> Immunodeficiency disorders </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>E-rosetting</detail><detail> T and B lymphocyte assays</detail><detail> B and T lymphocyte assays</detail>

item.title: Cytology exam of urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to detect cancer of the urinary tract. It is often done when blood is seen in the urine.</text><text>It is also useful for monitoring people who have a history of urinary tract cancer. The test may sometimes be ordered for people who are at high risk for bladder cancer.</text><text>This test can also detect cytomegalovirus and other viral diseases.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The urine shows normal cells.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal cells in the urine may be a sign of inflammation of the urinary tract or cancer of the kidney , ureters, bladder, or urethra.</text><text>Be aware that cancer or inflammatory disease cannot be diagnosed with this test alone. The results need to be confirmed with other tests or procedures.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine cytology</detail><detail> Bladder cancer - cytology</detail><detail> Urethral cancer - cytology</detail><detail> Renal cancer - cytology</detail>

item.title: Cytology exam of pleural fluid
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed before the test. A chest x-ray will likely be done before and after the test.</text><text>DO NOT cough, breathe deeply, or move during the test to avoid injury to the lung.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A cytology exam is used to look for cancer and precancerous cells. It may also be done for other conditions, such as identifying systemic lupus erythematosus cells.</text><text>Your doctor may order this test if you have signs of fluid buildup in the pleural space. This condition is called pleural effusion . The test may also be done if you have signs of lung cancer.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal cells are seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In an abnormal test, there are cancerous (malignant) cells. This may mean there is a cancerous tumor . This test most often detects:</text><detail> Breast cancer </detail><detail> Lymphoma </detail><detail> Lung cancer </detail><detail>Ovarian cancer</detail><detail>Stomach cancer</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Pleural fluid cytology</detail><detail> Lung cancer - pleural fluid</detail>

item.title: Cystoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Ask your provider if you should stop taking any medicines that could thin your blood.</text><text>The procedure may be done in a hospital or surgery center. In that case, you will need to have someone take you home afterward.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to:</text><detail>Check for cancer of the bladder or urethra</detail><detail>Diagnose the cause of blood in the urine</detail><detail>Diagnose the cause of problems passing urine</detail><detail>Diagnose the cause of repeated bladder infections</detail><detail>Help determine the cause of pain during urination </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bladder wall should look smooth. The bladder should be of normal size, shape, and position. There should be no blockages, growths, or stones.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The abnormal results could indicate:</text><detail> Bladder cancer </detail><detail> Bladder stones (calculi)</detail><detail>Bladder wall decompression</detail><detail>Chronic urethritis or cystitis</detail><detail>Scarring of the urethra (called a stricture)</detail><detail>Congenital (present at birth) abnormality</detail><detail> Cysts </detail><detail> Diverticula of the bladder or urethra</detail><detail>Foreign material in the bladder or urethra </detail><text>Some other possible diagnoses may be:</text><detail> Irritable bladder </detail><detail>Polyps</detail><detail>Prostate problems, such as bleeding, enlargement , or blockage</detail><detail> Traumatic injury of the bladder and urethra </detail><detail> Ulcer </detail><detail> Urethral strictures </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cystourethroscopy</detail><detail> Endoscopy of the bladder</detail>

item.title: Cystometric study
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparations are needed for this test.</text><text>For infants and children, preparation depends on the child's age, past experiences, and level of trust. For general information regarding how you can prepare your child, see the following topics:</text><detail> Preschooler test or procedure preparation (3 to 6 years)</detail><detail> School age test or procedure preparation (6 to 12 years)</detail><detail> Adolescent test or procedure preparation (12 to 18 years)</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test will help determine the cause of bladder voiding dysfunction.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results vary and should be discussed with your provider.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Enlarged prostate </detail><detail> Multiple sclerosis </detail><detail>Overactive bladder</detail><detail>Reduced bladder capacity</detail><detail> Spinal cord injury </detail><detail> Stroke </detail><detail> Urinary tract infection </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CMG</detail><detail> Cystometrogram</detail>

item.title: Culture - joint fluid
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you how to prepare for the procedure. No special preparation is needed. But, tell your provider if you're taking a blood thinner, such as aspirin, warfarin (Coumadin) or clopidogrel (Plavix). These medicines can affect test results or your ability to take the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have unexplained pain and inflammation of a joint or a suspected joint infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test result is considered normal if no organisms (bacteria, fungi, or viruses) grow in the laboratory dish.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results are a sign of infection in the joint. Infections may include:</text><detail> Bacterial arthritis </detail><detail> Fungal arthritis </detail><detail> Gonococcal arthritis </detail><detail>Turberculous arthritis</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Joint fluid culture</detail>

item.title: Culture - duodenal tissue
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>This is a test done in a lab. The sample is collected during an upper endoscopy and biopsy procedure (esophagogastroduodenoscopy). Ask your health care provider how to prepare for this procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A culture of duodenal tissue is done to check for bacteria or viruses that may lead to certain illnesses and conditions.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No harmful bacteria or viruses are found.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal finding means that harmful bacteria or a virus has been found in the tissue sample. Bacteria may include: </text><detail>Campylobacter</detail><detail>Helicobacter pylori (H pylori)</detail><detail>Salmonella </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Duodenal tissue culture</detail>

item.title: Culture - colonic tissue
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no specific preparation needed for a culture.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs or symptoms of a large intestine infection. A culture is often done when other tests such as a stool culture could not identify the cause of infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means that no disease-causing organisms have grown in the lab dish.</text><text>Some "healthy" bacteria, called bowel flora, are normally found in the gut. The growth of such bacteria during this test does not mean there is an infection.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that disease-causing organisms have grown in the lab dish. These organisms may include:</text><detail>Clostridium difficile bacteria</detail><detail>Cytomegalovirus </detail><detail>Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria</detail><detail> Salmonella bacteria </detail><detail>Shigella bacteria </detail><text>These organisms may lead to diarrhea or colon infections.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Colonic tissue culture</detail>

item.title: Culdocentesis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked to walk or sit for a short time before the test is done.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This procedure is rarely done today because a transvaginal ultrasound can show fluid behind the uterus. </text><text>It may be done when:</text><detail>You have pain in the lower abdomen and pelvis, and other tests suggest there is fluid in the area.</detail><detail>You may have a ruptured ectopic pregnancy or ovarian cyst . </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>No fluid in the cul-de-sac, or a very small amount of clear fluid, is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Fluid may still be present, even if not seen with this test. You may need other tests. </text><text>A sample of fluid may be taken and tested for infection. </text><text>If blood is found in the fluid sample, you may need emergency surgery. </text>

item.title: CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into your body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><text>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to avoid another reaction.</text><text>Contrast can be given several ways, depending on the type of CT being performed.</text><detail>It may be delivered through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm.</detail><detail>You might drink the contrast before your scan. When you drink the contrast depends on the type of exam being done. The contrast liquid may taste chalky, although some are flavored. The contrast passes out of your body through your stools.</detail><detail>Rarely, the contrast may be given into your rectum using an enema.</detail><text>If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</text><text>Before receiving IV contrast, tell your health care provider if you take the diabetes medication metformin (Glucophage). People taking this medicine may need to stop temporarily. Also let your provider know if you have any problems with your kidneys. The IV contrast can worsen kidney function.</text><text>Find out if the CT machine has a weight limit if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms). Too much weight can damage the scanner.</text><text>You will need to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A CT scan creates detailed pictures of the body, including the brain, chest, spine, and abdomen. The test may be used to:</text><detail>Diagnose an infection</detail><detail>Guide a surgeon to the right area during a biopsy</detail><detail>Identify masses and tumors, including cancer</detail><detail>Study blood vessels </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if the organs and structures being examined are normal in appearance.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results depend on the part of the body being studied. Talk to your provider about questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan</detail>

item.title: CT angiography - head and neck
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive it.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra precautions.</detail><text>The contrast can worsen kidney function problems in people with poorly functioning kidneys. Talk to your provider if you have a history of kidney problems.</text><text>Too much weight can damage the scanner. If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), talk to your provider about the weight limit before the test.</text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text> CTA of the head may be done to look for the cause of:</text><detail>Changes in thinking or behavior</detail><detail>Difficulty pronouncing words</detail><detail> Dizziness or vertigo </detail><detail>Double vision or vision loss</detail><detail> Fainting </detail><detail>Headache, when you have certain other signs or symptoms</detail><detail>Hearing loss (in some people)</detail><detail>Numbness or tingling, most often on the face or scalp</detail><detail>Swallowing problems</detail><detail>Stroke</detail><detail>Transient ischemic attack (TIA)</detail><detail>Weakness in one part of your body</detail><text>CTA of the neck may also be done: </text><detail>After trauma to the neck to look for damage to blood vessels</detail><detail>For planning before carotid artery surgery </detail><detail>For planning for brain tumor surgery </detail><detail>For suspected vasculitis (inflammation of the blood vessel walls)</detail><detail>For suspected abnormal blood vessels in the brain </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abnormal blood vessels (arteriovenous malformation).</detail><detail>Bleeding in the brain (for example, subdural hematoma or an area of bleeding).</detail><detail>Brain tumor or other growth (mass).</detail><detail> Stroke . </detail><detail> Narrowed or blocked carotid arteries . (The carotid arteries provide the main blood supply to your brain. They are located on each side of your neck.)</detail><detail> Narrowed or blocked vertebral artery in the neck . (The vertebral arteries provide blood flow to the back of the brain.)</detail><detail>A tear in the wall of an artery (dissection).</detail><detail>A weak area in the wall of a blood vessel that causes the blood vessel to bulge or balloon out ( aneurysm ).</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Computed tomography angiography - brain</detail><detail> CTA - skull</detail><detail> CTA - cranial</detail><detail> TIA-CTA head</detail><detail> Stroke-CTA head</detail><detail> Computed tomography angiography - neck</detail><detail> CTA - neck</detail><detail> Vertebral artery - CTA</detail><detail> Carotid artery stenosis - CTA</detail><detail> Vertebrobasilar - CTA</detail><detail> Posterior circulation ischemia - CTA</detail><detail> TIA - CTA neck</detail><detail> Stroke - CTA neck</detail>

item.title: CT angiography - chest
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medications before the test in order to safely receive it.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medication metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra precautions.</detail><text>The contrast can worsen kidney function problems in people with poorly functioning kidneys. Talk to your provider if you have a history of kidney problems.</text><text>Too much weight can damage the scanner. If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), talk to your provider about the weight limit before the test.</text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A chest CT angiogram may be done:</text><detail>For symptoms that suggest blood clots in the lungs, such as chest pain, rapid breathing, or shortness of breath</detail><detail>After a chest injury or trauma</detail><detail>Before surgery in the lung or chest</detail><detail>To look for a possible site to insert a catheter for hemodialysis</detail><detail>For swelling of the face or upper arms that cannot be explained</detail><detail>To look for a suspected birth defect of the aorta or other blood vessels in the chest</detail><detail>To look for a balloon dilation of an artery (aneurysm)</detail><detail>To look for a tear in an artery (dissection)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A chest CT may show many disorders of the heart, lungs, or chest area, including:</text><detail>Suspected blockage of the superior vena cava : This large vein moves blood from the upper half of the body to the heart.</detail><detail> Blood clot(s) in the lungs .</detail><detail>Abnormalities of the blood vessels in the lungs or chest, such as aortic arch syndrome .</detail><detail> Aortic aneurysm (in the chest area) .</detail><detail>Narrowing of part of the major artery leading out of the heart (aorta). </detail><detail>Tear in the wall of an artery (dissection).</detail><detail>Inflammation of the blood vessel walls (vasculitis).</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Computed tomography angiography - thorax</detail><detail> CTA - lungs</detail><detail> Pulmonary embolism - CTA chest</detail><detail> Thoracic aortic aneurysm - CTA chest</detail><detail> Venous thromboembolism - CTA lung</detail><detail> Blood clot - CTA lung</detail><detail> Embolus - CTA lung</detail><detail> CT pulmonary angiogram</detail>

item.title: CT angiography - arms and legs
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Some exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be injected into your body before the test. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you also may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test to avoid this problem.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps if you are taking this medicine.</detail><text>The contrast can worsen kidney function problems in people with poorly functioning kidneys. Talk to your provider if you have a history of kidney problems.</text><text>Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), talk to your doctor about the weight limit before the test.</text><text>You will need to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the CT exam.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have symptoms of a narrowed or blocked blood vessel in the arms, hands, legs, or feet.</text><text>The test may also be done to diagnose:</text><detail>Abnormal widening or ballooning of part of an artery (aneurysm)</detail><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Swelling or inflammation of the blood vessels (vasculitis)</detail><detail>Leg pain during walking or exercise (claudication)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: An abnormal result is commonly due to narrowing and hardening of the arteries in the arms or legs from plaque buildup in the artery walls .The x-ray may show a blockage in the vessels caused by:Abnormal widening or ballooning of part of an artery ( aneurysm ) Blood clots Other diseases of the arteriesAbnormal results may also be due to:Inflammation of the blood vesselsInjury to the blood vessels Buerger disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) , a rare disease in which blood vessels of the hands and feet become blocked
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Computed tomography angiography - peripheral</detail><detail> CTA - peripheral</detail><detail> CTA - Runoff</detail>

item.title: CT angiography - abdomen and pelvis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You need to have a special dye, called contrast, put into your body before some exams. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you also may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</detail><detail>You may also have to drink a different contrast before the exam. When you drink it will depend on the type of exam being done.Contrast has a chalky taste, although some have flavors so that they taste a little better. The contrast will pass out of your body through your stools.</detail><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.</detail><detail>Before receiving the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medication metformin (Glucophage). People taking this medicine may have to stop taking it for a while before the test.</detail><text>The contrast can worsen kidney function problems in patients with poorly functioning kidneys. Talk to your provider if you have a history of kidney problems.</text><text>Too much weight can damage the scanner. If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), talk to your provider about the weight limit before the test.</text><text>You will need to take off your jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A CT angiography scan quickly makes detailed pictures of the blood vessels inside your belly or pelvis.</text><text>This test may be used to look for: </text><detail>Abnormal widening or ballooning of part of an artery (aneurysm)</detail><detail>The source of bleeding that starts in the intestines or elsewhere in the belly or pelvis</detail><detail>Masses and tumors in the abdomen or pelvis, including cancer, when needed to help plan treatment</detail><detail>Cause of pain in the abdomen thought to be due to narrowing or blockage of one or more of the arteries that supply the small and large intestines </detail><detail>Pain in the legs thought to be due to narrowing of blood vessels that supply the legs and feet </detail><detail>High blood pressure due to narrowing of the arteries that carry blood to the kidneys </detail><text>The test also may be used before:</text><detail>Surgery on blood vessels of liver</detail><detail> Kidney transplant </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if no problems are seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The abdominal results may show:</text><detail>The source of bleeding inside the belly or pelvis</detail><detail>Narrowing of the artery that supplies the kidneys</detail><detail>Narrowing of arteries that supply the intestines</detail><detail>Narrowing of arteries that supply the legs </detail><detail>Ballooning or swelling of an artery (aneurysm), including the aorta </detail><detail>A tear in the wall of the major artery carrying blood out of the heart (aorta) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Computed tomography angiography - abdomen and pelvis</detail><detail> CTA - abdomen and pelvis</detail><detail> Renal artery - CTA</detail><detail> Aortic - CTA</detail><detail> Mesenteric CTA</detail>

item.title: CSF-VDRL test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow the health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The CSF-VDRL test is done to diagnose syphilis in the brain or spinal cord. Brain and spinal cord involvement is often a sign of late-stage syphilis.</text><text>Blood screening tests ( VDRL and RPR ) are better at detecting middle-stage (secondary) syphilis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative result is normal.</text><text>False-negatives can occur. This means you can have syphilis even if this test is normal. Therefore, a negative test does not always rule out the infection. Other signs and tests may be used to diagnose neurosyphilis.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive result is abnormal and is a sign of neurosyphilis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Venereal disease research laboratory slide test - CSF</detail><detail> Neurosyphilis - VDRL</detail>

item.title: CSF total protein
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test to help diagnose:</text><detail>Tumors</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Inflammation of several groups of nerve cells</detail><detail>Vasculitis </detail><detail>Blood in the spinal fluid</detail><detail>Multiple sclerosis (MS)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal protein range varies from lab to lab, but is typically about 15 to 60 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or 0.15 to 0.6 milligrams per milliliter (mg/mL).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal protein level in the CSF suggests a problem in the central nervous system.</text><text>Increased protein level may be a sign of a tumor, bleeding, nerve inflammation, or injury. A blockage in the flow of spinal fluid can cause the rapid buildup of protein in the lower spinal area.</text><text>A decrease in protein level can mean your body is rapidly producing spinal fluid.</text>

item.title: CSF smear
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions on how to prepare for a spinal tap .</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs of an infection that affects the brain or nervous system. The test helps identify what is causing the infection. This will help your provider decide on the best treatment</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result means there are no signs of an infection. This is also called a negative result. However, a normal result doesn't mean that there is no infection. The spinal tap and CSF smear may need to be done again.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Bacteria or other germs found in the sample may be a sign of meningitis. This is an infection of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. The infection can be caused by bacteria , fungi, or viruses.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Spinal fluid smear</detail><detail> Cerebrospinal fluid smear</detail>

item.title: CSF oligoclonal banding
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test helps support the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS). However, it does not confirm the diagnosis. Oligoclonal bands in the CSF can also be seen in other illnesses.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, one or no bands should be found in the CSF.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>There are two or more bandings found in the CSF and not in the blood. This may be a sign of multiple sclerosis or other inflammation.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cerebrospinal fluid - immunofixation</detail>

item.title: CSF myelin basic protein
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see if myelin is breaking down. Multiple sclerosis is the most common cause for this, but other causes may include:</text><detail>Bleeding of the central nervous system</detail><detail> Central nervous system trauma </detail><detail>Certain brain diseases (encephalopathies)</detail><detail>Infection of the central nervous system</detail><detail> Stroke </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>In general, there should be less than 4 ng/mL of myelin basic protein in the CSF.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement result for this test. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Myelin basic protein levels between 4 and 8 ng/mL may be a sign of a long-term ( chronic ) breakdown of myelin. It may also indicate recovery from an acute episode of myelin breakdown.</text><text>If the myelin basic protein level is greater than 9 ng/mL, myelin is actively breaking down.</text>

item.title: CSF glucose test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to diagnose:</text><detail>Tumors</detail><detail>Infections</detail><detail>Inflammation of the central nervous system</detail><detail>Delirium</detail><detail>Other neurological and medical conditions</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The glucose level in the CSF should be 50 to 80 mg/100 mL (or greater than 2/3 of the blood sugar level).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results include higher and lower glucose levels. Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Infection (bacterial or fungus)</detail><detail>Inflammation of the central nervous system</detail><detail>Tumor </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Glucose test - CSF</detail><detail> Cerebrospinal fluid glucose test</detail>

item.title: CSF coccidioides complement fixation test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for the test. Expect to be in the hospital for several hours afterward.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test checks if your central nervous system has an active infection from coccidioides.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The absence of fungus (a negative test) is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the test is positive for fungus, there may be an active infection in the central nervous system.</text><text>An abnormal spinal fluid test means that the central nervous system is infected. During the early stage of an illness, few antibodies may be detected. Antibody production increases during the course of an infection. For this reason, this test may be repeated several weeks after the first test.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Coccidioides antibody test - spinal fluid</detail>

item.title: CSF cell count
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The CSF cell count may help detect:</text><detail> Meningitis and infection of the brain or spinal cord</detail><detail> Tumor , abscess , or area of tissue death (infarct)</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Bleeding into the spinal fluid (secondary to subarachnoid hemorrhage)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal white blood cell count is between 0 and 5. The normal red blood cell count is 0.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increase of white blood cells indicates infection, inflammation, or bleeding into the cerebrospinal fluid. Some causes include:</text><detail>Abscess</detail><detail>Encephalitis</detail><detail>Hemorrhage</detail><detail>Meningitis</detail><detail> Multiple sclerosis </detail><detail>Other infections</detail><detail>Stroke</detail><detail>Tumor </detail><text>Finding red blood cells in the CSF may be a sign of bleeding. However, red blood cells in the CSF may also be due to the spinal tap needle hitting a blood vessel.</text><text>Additional conditions which this test may help diagnose include:</text><detail> Arteriovenous malformation (cerebral) </detail><detail> Cerebral aneurysm </detail><detail> Delirium </detail><detail> Guillain-Barre syndrome </detail><detail>Stroke</detail><detail> Neurosyphilis </detail><detail> Primary lymphoma of the brain </detail><detail>Seizure disorders, including epilepsy</detail><detail> Spinal tumor </detail>

item.title: CSF analysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you how to prepare for lumbar puncture . </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed:
Analysis of CSF can help detect certain conditions and diseases. All of the following can be, but are not always, measured in a sample of CSF:Antibodies and DNA of common virusesBacteria (including that which causes syphilis, using a  VDRL test ) Cell count Chloride Cryptococcal antigen Glucose Glutamine Lactate dehydrogenase Oligoclonal banding to look for specific proteinsMyelin basic protein 
 Total protein Whether there are cancerous cells presentOpening pressure
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results include:</text><detail>Antibodies and DNA of common viruses: None</detail><detail>Bacteria: No bacteria grows in a lab culture</detail><detail>Cancerous cells: No cancerous cells present</detail><detail>Cell count: less than 5 white blood cells (all mononuclear) and 0 red blood cells</detail><detail>Chloride: 110 to 125 mEq/L (110 to 125 mmol/L)</detail><detail>Fungus: None</detail><detail>Glucose: 50 to 80 mg/dL or 2.77 to 4.44 mmol/L (or greater than two-thirds of blood sugar level)</detail><detail>Glutamine: 6 to 15 mg/dL (410.5 to 1,026 micromol/L)</detail><detail>Lactate dehydrogenase: less than 2.0 to 7.2 U/mL (0.3 to 0.12 microkat/L)</detail><detail>Oligoclonal bands: 0 or 1 bands that are not present in a matched serum sample</detail><detail> Protein : 15 to 60 mg/dL (0.15 to 0.6 g/L)</detail><detail>Opening pressure: 10 to 25 cm of CSF</detail><detail>Myelin basic protein: Less than 4ng/mL</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal CSF analysis result may be due to many different causes, including:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail> Encephalitis (such as West Nile and Eastern Equine)</detail><detail> Hepatic encephalopathy </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail> Reye syndrome </detail><detail> Meningitis due to bacteria, fungus, tuberculosis, or a virus</detail><detail>Multiple sclerosis (MS)</detail><detail>Alzheimer disease</detail><detail>Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cerebrospinal fluid analysis</detail>

item.title: Cryoglobulins
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may want to call ahead to ask to have your blood drawn by a lab technician who has experience collecting blood for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done when a person has symptoms of a condition associated with cryoglobulins. Cryoglobulins are associated with cryoglobulinemia. They also occur in other conditions that affect the skin, joints, kidneys, and nervous system.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, there are no cryoglobulins.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test may indicate:</text><detail>Hepatitis (especially hepatitis C)</detail><detail> Infectious mononucleosis </detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail> Lymphoma </detail><detail> Macroglobulinemia -- primary </detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus </detail><text>Additional conditions under which the test may be performed includes nephrotic syndrome .</text>

item.title: Creatinine urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines that may affect test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Antibiotics such as cefoxitin or trimethoprim</detail><detail>Cimetidine </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Creatinine is a chemical waste product of creatine. Creatine is a chemical the body makes to supply energy, mainly to muscles.</text><text>This test is done to see how well your kidneys work. Creatinine is removed by the body entirely by the kidneys. If kidney function is not normal, creatinine level in your urine decreases.</text><text>This test can be used for the following:</text><detail>To evaluate how well the kidneys are working</detail><detail>As part of the creatinine clearance test</detail><detail>To provide information on other chemicals in the urine, such as albumin or protein </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Urine creatinine (24-hour sample) values can range from 500 to 2000 mg/day (4420 to 17680 mmol/day). Results depend on your age and amount of lean body mass.</text><text>Another way of expressing the normal range for test results is: </text><detail>14 to 26 mg per kg of body mass per day for men ( 123.8 to 229.8 µmol/kg/day)</detail><detail>11 to 20 mg per kg of body mass per day for women (97.2 to 176.8 µmol/kg/day) </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results of urine creatinine may be due to any of the following: </text><detail>High meat diet</detail><detail>Kidney problems, such as damage to the tubule cells </detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail>Too little blood flow to the kidneys, damage to filtering units </detail><detail>Kidney infection (pyelonephritis)</detail><detail>Muscle breakdown ( rhabdomyolysis ), or loss of muscle tissue ( myasthenia gravis )</detail><detail> Urinary tract obstruction </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine creatinine test</detail>

item.title: Creatinine clearance test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may ask you to temporarily stop any medicines that may affect the test results. These include some antibiotics and stomach acid medicines. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. </text><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Creatinine is a chemical waste product of creatine. Creatine is a chemical the body makes to supply energy, mainly to muscles.</text><text>By comparing the creatinine level in urine with the creatinine level in blood , this test estimates the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) . GFR is a measure of how well the kidneys are working, especially the kidneys' filtering units. These filtering units are called glomeruli.</text><text>Creatinine is removed, or cleared, from the body entirely by the kidneys. If kidney function is abnormal, creatinine level increases in the blood because less creatinine is released through the urine. </text>
