item.NormalResults: <text>Clearance is often measured as milliliters per minute (mL/min) or milliliters per second (mL/s). Normal values are:</text><detail>Male: 97 to 137 mL/min (1.65 to 2.33 mL/s).</detail><detail>Female: 88 to 128 mL/min (14.96 to 2.18 mL/s). </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor to know about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results (lower than normal creatinine clearance) may indicate:</text><detail> Kidney problems, such as damage to the tubule cells </detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail>Too little blood flow to the kidneys</detail><detail> Damage to the filtering units of the kidneys </detail><detail>Loss of body fluids (dehydration)</detail><detail>Bladder outlet obstruction</detail><detail> Heart failure </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum creatinine clearance</detail><detail> Kidney function - creatinine clearance</detail><detail> Renal function - creatinine clearance</detail>

item.title: Creatinine blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines that can affect the test. These medicines include:</text><detail>Cimetidine, famotidine, and ranitidine</detail><detail>Certain antibiotics, such as trimethoprim </detail><text>Tell your provider about all the medicines you take.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Creatinine is a chemical waste product of creatine. Creatine is a chemical made by the body and is used to supply energy mainly to muscles.</text><text>This test is done to see how well your kidneys work. Creatinine is removed from the body entirely by the kidneys. If kidney function is not normal, the creatinine level in your blood will increase. This is because less creatinine is released through your urine.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is 0.7 to 1.3 mg/dL (61.9 to 114.9 µmol/L) for men and 0.6 to 1.1 mg/dL (53 to 97.2 µmol/L) for women.</text><text>Women usually have a lower creatinine level than men. This is because women usually have less muscle mass than men. Creatinine level varies based on a person's size and muscle mass.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level may be due to:</text><detail>Blocked urinary tract</detail><detail>Kidney problems, such as kidney damage or failure, infection, or reduced blood flow</detail><detail>Loss of body fluid (dehydration)</detail><detail>Muscle problems, such as breakdown of muscle fibers ( rhabdomyolysis ) </detail><detail>Problems during pregnancy, such as seizures caused by eclampsia or high blood pressure caused by preeclampsia </detail><text>A lower than normal level may be due to:</text><detail>Conditions involving the muscles and nerves that lead to decreased muscle mass</detail><detail> Malnutrition </detail><text>There are many other conditions for which the test may be ordered, such as high blood pressure, diabetes, or medicine overdose. Your provider will tell you more, if needed. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum creatinine</detail><detail> Kidney function - creatinine</detail><detail> Renal function - creatinine</detail>

item.title: Creatine phosphokinase test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed most of the time.</text><text>Tell your health care provider about any medicines you are taking. Drugs that can increase CPK measurements include amphotericin B, certain anesthetics, statins, fibrates, dexamethasone, alcohol, and cocaine.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>When the total CPK level is very high, it most often means there has been injury or stress to muscle tissue, the heart, or the brain. </text><text>Muscle tissue injury is most likely. When a muscle is damaged, CPK leaks into the bloodstream. Finding which specific form of CPK is high helps determine which tissue has been damaged.</text><text>This test may be used to:</text><detail>Diagnose heart attack </detail><detail>Evaluate cause of chest pain </detail><detail>Determine if or how badly a muscle is damaged</detail><detail>Detect dermatomyositis , polymyositis , and other muscle diseases</detail><detail>Tell the difference between malignant hyperthermia and postoperative infection </detail><text>The pattern and timing of a rise or fall in CPK levels can be significant in making a diagnosis. This is particularly true if a heart attack is suspected. </text><text>In most cases other tests are used instead of or with this test to diagnose a heart attack. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Total CPK normal values: </text><detail>10 to 120 micrograms per liter (mcg/L) </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High CPK levels may be seen in people who have:</text><detail>Brain injury or stroke</detail><detail> Convulsions </detail><detail>Delirium tremens</detail><detail>Dermatomyositis or polymyositis</detail><detail> Electric shock </detail><detail>Heart attack</detail><detail>Inflammation of the heart muscle (myocarditis)</detail><detail>Lung tissue death (pulmonary infarction)</detail><detail>Muscular dystrophies</detail><detail>Myopathy</detail><detail> Rhabdomyolysis </detail><text>Other conditions that may give positive test results include:</text><detail> Hypothyroidism </detail><detail>Hyperthyroidism</detail><detail> Pericarditis following a heart attack </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CPK test</detail>

item.title: CPK isoenzymes test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed in most cases.</text><text>Tell your provider about all the medicines you are taking. Some drugs can interfere with test results. Drugs that can increase CPK measurements include the following:</text><detail>Alcohol</detail><detail>Amphotericin B</detail><detail>Certain anesthetics</detail><detail>Cocaine</detail><detail>Fibrate drugs</detail><detail>Statins</detail><detail>Steroids, such as dexamethasone </detail><text>This list is not all-inclusive.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done if a CPK test shows that your total CPK level is elevated. CPK isoenzyme testing can help find the exact source of the damaged tissue.</text><text>CPK is made of three slightly different substances:</text><detail>CPK-1 (also called CPK-BB) is found mostly in the brain and lungs</detail><detail>CPK-2 (also called CPK-MB) is found mostly in the heart</detail><detail>CPK-3 (also called CPK-MM) is found mostly in skeletal muscle </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal CPK-1 levels:</text><text>Because CPK-1 is found mostly in the brain and lungs, injury to either of these areas can increase CPK-1 levels. Increased CPK-1 levels may be due to:</text><detail> Brain cancer </detail><detail> Brain injury (due to any type of injury including, stroke, or bleeding in the brain)</detail><detail>Electroconvulsive therapy</detail><detail>Pulmonary infarction</detail><detail> Seizure </detail><text>Higher-than-normal CPK-2 levels:</text><text>CPK-2 levels rise 3 to 6 hours after a heart attack . If there is no further heart muscle damage, the level peaks at 12 to 24 hours and returns to normal 12 to 48 hours after tissue death.</text><text>Increased CPK-2 levels may also be due to:</text><detail>Electrical injuries</detail><detail>Heart defibrillation (purposeful shocking of the heart by medical personnel)</detail><detail>Heart injury (for instance, from a car accident)</detail><detail>Inflammation of the heart muscle usually due to a virus (myocarditis)</detail><detail>Open heart surgery </detail><text>Higher-than-normal CPK-3 levels are most often a sign of muscle injury or muscle stress. They may be due to:</text><detail> Crush injuries </detail><detail>Muscle damage due to drugs or being immobile for a long time ( rhabdomyolysis )</detail><detail> Muscular dystrophy </detail><detail> Myositis (skeletal muscle inflammation)</detail><detail>Receiving many intramuscular injections</detail><detail>Recent nerve and muscle function testing (electromyography)</detail><detail>Recent seizures</detail><detail>Recent surgery</detail><detail>Strenuous exercise </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Creatine phosphokinase - isoenzymes</detail><detail> Creatine kinase - isoenzymes</detail><detail> CK - isoenzymes</detail><detail> Heart attack - CPK</detail><detail> Crush - CPK</detail>

item.title: Cortisol urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to do any vigorous exercising the day before the test.</text><text>You may also be told to temporarily stop taking medicines that can affect the test, including:</text><detail>Anti-seizure drugs</detail><detail>Estrogen</detail><detail>Human-made (synthetic) glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, prednisone and prednisolone</detail><detail>Androgens </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to check for increased or decreased cortisol production. Cortisol is a glucocorticoid (steroid) hormone released from the adrenal gland in response to adrenocorticotropic hormone ( ACTH ). This is a hormone released from the pituitary gland in the brain. Cortisol affects many different body systems. It plays a role in:</text><detail>Bone growth</detail><detail>Blood pressure control</detail><detail>Immune system function</detail><detail>Metabolism of fats, carbohydrates, and protein</detail><detail>Nervous system function</detail><detail>Stress response</detail><text>Different diseases, such as Cushing syndrome and Addison disease , can lead to either too much or too little production of cortisol. Measuring urine cortisol level can help diagnose these conditions.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal range is 4 to 40 mcg/24 hours or 11 to 110 nmol/day.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level may indicate:</text><detail> Cushing disease , in which the pituitary gland makes too much ACTH because of excess growth of the pituitary gland or a tumor in the pituitary gland</detail><detail> Ectopic Cushing syndrome , in which a tumor outside the pituitary or adrenal glands makes too much ACTH</detail><detail>Severe depression</detail><detail> Tumor of the adrenal gland that is producing too much cortisol </detail><detail>Severe stress</detail><detail>Rare genetic disorders</detail><text>A lower than normal level may indicate:</text><detail>Addison disease in which the adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol</detail><detail> Hypopituitarism in which the pituitary gland does not signal the adrenal gland to produce enough cortisol</detail><detail>Suppression of normal pituitary or adrenal function by glucocorticoid medicines including pills, skin creams, eyedrops, inhalers, joint injections, chemotherapy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>24-hour urinary free cortisol (UFC)</detail>

item.title: Cortisol blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your doctor will likely have you do the test early in the morning. This is important, because cortisol level varies throughout the day.</text><text>You may be asked not to do any vigorous exercising the day before the test.</text><text>You may also be told to temporarily stop taking medicines that can affect the test, including:</text><detail>Anti-seizure drugs</detail><detail>Estrogen</detail><detail>Human-made (synthetic) glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, prednisone and prednisolone</detail><detail>Androgens</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to check for increased or decreased cortisol production. Cortisol is a glucocorticoid (steroid) hormone released from the adrenal gland in response to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH is a hormone released from the pituitary gland in the brain.</text><text>Cortisol affects many different body systems. It plays a role in:</text><detail>Bone growth</detail><detail>Blood pressure control</detail><detail>Immune system function</detail><detail>Metabolism of fats, carbohydrates, and protein</detail><detail>Nervous system function</detail><detail>Stress response </detail><text>Different diseases, such as Cushing syndrome and Addison disease , can lead to either too much or too little production of cortisol. Measuring blood cortisol level can help diagnose these conditions. It is also measured to evaluate how well the pituitary and adrenal glands are working.</text><text>The test is often done before and 1 hour after injection of a medicine called ACTH. This part of the test is called an ACTH stimulation test . It is an additional test that helps check the function of the pituitary and adrenal glands.</text><text>Other conditions for which the test may be ordered include:</text><detail> Acute adrenal crisis , a life-threatening condition that occurs when there is not enough cortisol</detail><detail> Sepsis , an illness in which the body has a severe response to bacteria or other germs</detail><detail> Low blood pressure </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values for a blood sample taken at 8 in the morning are 5 to 25 mcg/dL or 140 to 690 nmol/L.</text><text>Normal values depend on the time of day and the clinical context. Normal ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level may indicate:</text><detail> Cushing disease , in which the pituitary gland makes too much ACTH because of excess growth of the pituitary gland or a tumor in the pituitary gland</detail><detail> Ectopic Cushing syndrome , in which a tumor outside the pituitary or adrenal glands makes too much ACTH</detail><detail>Tumor of the adrenal gland that is producing too much cortisol </detail><text>A lower than normal level may indicate:</text><detail>Addison disease, in which the adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol</detail><detail> Hypopituitarism , in which the pituitary gland does not signal the adrenal gland to produce enough cortisol</detail><detail>Suppression of normal pituitary or adrenal function by glucocorticoid medicines including pills, skin creams, eyedrops, inhalers, joint injections, chemotherapy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum cortisol</detail>

item.title: Coronary angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink anything for 8 hours before the test starts. You may need to stay in the hospital the night before the test. Otherwise, you will check in to the hospital the morning of the test.</text><text>You will wear a hospital gown. You must sign a consent form before the test. Your health care provider will explain the procedure and its risks.</text><text>Tell your provider if you: </text><detail>Are allergic to any medicines or if you have had a bad reaction to contrast material in the past</detail><detail>Are taking Viagra</detail><detail>Might be pregnant </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Coronary angiography may be done if: </text><detail>You have angina for the first time.</detail><detail>Your angina that is becoming worse, not going away, occurring more often, or happening at rest (called unstable angina ).</detail><detail>You have aortic stenosis or another valve problem.</detail><detail>You have atypical chest pain, when other tests are normal.</detail><detail>You had an abnormal heart stress test.</detail><detail>You are going to have surgery on your heart and you are at high risk for coronary artery disease.</detail><detail>You have heart failure .</detail><detail>You have been diagnosed as having a heart attack.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>There is a normal supply of blood to the heart and no blockages.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may mean you have a blocked artery. The test can show how many coronary arteries are blocked, where they are blocked, and the severity of the blockages.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Cardiac angiography</detail><detail> Angiography - heart</detail><detail> Angiogram - coronary</detail><detail> Coronary artery disease - angiography</detail><detail> CAD - angiography</detail><detail> Angina - angiography</detail><detail> Heart disease - angiography</detail>

item.title: Cord blood testing
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Cord blood testing is done to measure the following in your baby's blood:</text><detail> Bilirubin level</detail><detail> Blood culture (if an infection is suspected)</detail><detail>Blood gases (including oxygen, carbon dioxide, and pH levels)</detail><detail>Blood sugar level</detail><detail> Blood type and Rh</detail><detail>Complete blood count ( CBC )</detail><detail>Platelet count </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values mean that all items checked are within normal range.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A low pH (less than 7.04 to 7.10) means there are higher levels of acids in the baby's blood. This might occur when the baby does not get enough oxygen during labor. One reason for this could be that the umbilical cord was compressed during labor or delivery.</text><text>A blood culture that is positive for bacteria means your baby has a blood infection.</text><text>High level of blood sugar (glucose) in the cord blood may be found if the mother has diabetes. The newborn will be watched for hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) after delivery.</text><text> High level of bilirubin in the newborn has many causes, which could be due to infections the baby gets.</text><text> Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>

item.title: Coombs test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>There are two types of the Coombs test:</text><detail>Direct</detail><detail>Indirect</detail><text>The direct Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that are stuck to the surface of red blood cells. Many diseases and drugs can cause this to happen. These antibodies sometimes destroy red blood cells and cause anemia . Your health care provider may recommend this test if you have signs or symptoms of anemia or jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes).</text><text>The indirect Coombs test looks for antibodies that are floating in the blood. These antibodies could act against certain red blood cells. This test is most often done to determine if you may have a reaction to a blood transfusion.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is called a negative result. It means there was no clumping of cells and you have no antibodies to red blood cells.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) direct Coombs test means you have antibodies that act against your red blood cells. This may be due to:</text><detail> Autoimmune hemolytic anemia </detail><detail> Chronic lymphocytic leukemia or similar disorder</detail><detail> Blood disease in newborns called erythroblastosis fetalis (also called hemolytic disease of the newborn)</detail><detail> Infectious mononucleosis </detail><detail>Mycoplasma infection</detail><detail>Syphilis</detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus </detail><detail> Transfusion reaction , such as one due to improperly matched units of blood </detail><text>The test result may also be abnormal without any clear cause, especially among the older people.</text><text>An abnormal (positive) indirect Coombs test means you have antibodies that will act against red blood cells that your body views as foreign. This may suggest:</text><detail>Erythroblastosis fetalis</detail><detail>Incompatible blood match (when used in blood banks) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Direct antiglobulin test</detail><detail> Indirect antiglobulin test</detail><detail> Anemia - hemolytic</detail>

item.title: Cone biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked to not eat or drink for 6 to 8 hours before the test. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Cone biopsy is done to detect cervical cancer or early changes that lead to cancer. A cone biopsy is done if a test called colposcopy cannot find the cause of an abnormal Pap smear.</text><text>Cone biopsy may also be used to treat:</text><detail>Moderate to severe types of abnormal cell changes (called CIN II or CIN III)</detail><detail>Very early stage cervical cancer (stage 0 or IA1) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there are no precancerous or cancerous cells in the cervix.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Most often, abnormal results mean that there are precancerous or cancerous cells in the cervix. These changes are called cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). The changes are divided into 3 groups:</text><detail>CIN I -- mild dysplasia</detail><detail>CIN II -- moderate to marked dysplasia</detail><detail>CIN III -- severe dysplasia to carcinoma in situ </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to cervical cancer. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - cone</detail><detail> Cervical conization</detail><detail> CKC</detail><detail> Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia - cone biopsy</detail><detail> CIN - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Precancerous changes of the cervix - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Cervical cancer - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Squamous intraepithelial lesion - cone biopsy</detail><detail> LSIL - cone biopsy</detail><detail> HSIL - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Low-grade cone biopsy</detail><detail> High-grade cone biopsy</detail><detail> Carcinoma in situ-cone biopsy</detail><detail> CIS - cone biopsy</detail><detail> ASCUS - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Atypical glandular cells - cone biopsy</detail><detail> AGUS - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Atypical squamous cells - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Pap smear - cone biopsy</detail><detail> HPV - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Human papilloma virus - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Cervix - cone biopsy</detail><detail> Colposcopy - cone biopsy</detail>

item.title: Comprehensive metabolic panel
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for 8 hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test gives your health care provider information about:</text><detail>How your kidneys and liver are working</detail><detail>Blood sugar, cholesterol, and calcium levels</detail><detail>Sodium, potassium, and chloride levels (called electrolytes )</detail><detail>Protein levels </detail><text>Your provider may order this test during a yearly exam or routine checkup.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values for the panel tests are:</text><detail> Albumin : 3.4 to 5.4 g/dL (34 to 54 g/L)</detail><detail> Alkaline phosphatase : 44 to 147 IU/L (0.73 to 2.45 µkat/L)</detail><detail> ALT (alanine aminotransferase): 7 to 40 IU/L (0.12 to 0.67 µkat/L)</detail><detail> AST (aspartate aminotransferase): 10 to 34 IU/L (0.17 to 0.57 µkat/L)</detail><detail> BUN (blood urea nitrogen): 6 to 20 mg/dL (2.14 to 7.14 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Calcium : 8.5 to 10.2 mg/dL (2.13 to 2.55 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Chloride : 96 to 106 mEq/L (96 to 106 mmol/L)</detail><detail> CO2 (carbon dioxide): 23 to 29 mEq/L (23 to 29 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Creatinine : 0.6 to 1.3 mg/dL (53 to 114.9 µmol/L)</detail><detail> Glucose : 70 to 100 mg/dL (3.9 to 5.6 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Potassium : 3.7 to 5.2 mEq/L (3.70 to 5.20 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Sodium : 135 to 145 mEq/L (135 to 145 mmol/L)</detail><detail> Total bilirubin : 0.3 to 1.9 mg/dL (5.0 to 32.5 µmol/L)</detail><detail> Total protein : 6.0 to 8.3 g/dL (60 to 83 g/L)</detail><text>Normal values for creatinine can vary with age.</text><text>Normal value ranges for all tests may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results can be due to a variety of different medical conditions. These may include kidney failure, liver disease, breathing problems, and diabetes complications.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Metabolic panel - comprehensive</detail><detail> Chem-20</detail><detail> SMA20</detail><detail> Sequential multi-channel analysis with computer-20</detail><detail> SMAC20</detail><detail> Metabolic panel 20</detail>

item.title: Complement fixation test to C burnetii
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to detect Q fever.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Absence of antibodies to C burnetii is normal. It means you do not have Q fever now or in the past.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means you have a current infection with C burnetii, or that you have been exposed to the bacteria in the past. People with past exposure may have antibodies, even if they are not aware that they were exposed. Further testing may be needed to distinguish between current, previous, and long-term (chronic) infection.</text><text>During the early stage of an illness, few antibodies may be detected. Antibody production increases during the course of an infection. For this reason, this test may be repeated several weeks after the first test.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Q fever - complement fixation test</detail><detail> Coxiella burnetii - complement fixation test</detail><detail> C burnetii - complement fixation test</detail>

item.title: Complement component 4
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>C3 and C4 are the most commonly measured complement components. When the complement system is turned on during inflammation, levels of complement proteins may go down. Complement activity may be measured to determine how severe a disease is or if treatment is working.</text><text>A complement test may be used to monitor people with an autoimmune disorder . For example, people with active systemic lupus erythematosus may have lower-than-normal levels of the complement proteins C3 and C4 .</text><text>Complement activity varies throughout the body. In people with rheumatoid arthritis , complement activity may be normal or higher-than-normal in the blood, but much lower-than-normal in the joint fluid.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal ranges for C4 is 15 to 45 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) (0.15 to 0.45 g/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased complement activity may be seen in:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail> Ulcerative colitis </detail><text>Decreased complement activity may be seen in:</text><detail>Bacterial infections (especially Neisseria)</detail><detail> Cirrhosis </detail><detail> Glomerulonephritis </detail><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail> Hereditary angioedema </detail><detail> Kidney transplant rejection</detail><detail> Lupus nephritis </detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail> Systemic lupus erythematosus </detail><detail>Rare inherited complement deficiencies</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>C4</detail>

item.title: Complement component 3 (C3)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>C3 and C4 are the most commonly measured complement components.</text><text>A complement test may be used to monitor people with an autoimmune disorder . It is done to see if treatment for their condition is working. When the complement system is turned on during inflammation, levels of complement proteins may go down. For example, people with active lupus erythematosus may have lower-than-normal levels of the complement proteins C3 and C4 .</text><text>Complement activity varies throughout the body. For example, in people with rheumatoid arthritis , complement activity in the blood may be normal or higher-than-normal, but much lower-than-normal in the joint fluid.</text><text>The test may also be done for the following conditions: </text><detail>Fungal infections</detail><detail>Gram negative septicemia </detail><detail>Parasitic infections, such as malaria </detail><detail> Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) </detail><detail> Shock </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 88 to 201 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) (0.88 to 2.01 g/L).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: Increased complement activity may be seen in:Cancer Ulcerative colitis Decreased complement activity may be seen in:Bacterial infections (especially Neisseria) Cirrhosis Glomerulonephritis Hepatitis Hereditary angioedema Kidney transplant rejection Lupus nephritis MalnutritionSystemic lupus erythematosusRare inherited complement deficiencies
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>C3</detail>

item.title: Complement
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Total complement activity (CH50, CH100) looks at the overall activity of the complement system. In most cases, other tests that are more specific for the suspected disease are done first. C3 and C4 are the complement components measured most often.</text><text>A complement test may be used to monitor people with an autoimmune disorder . It is also used to see if treatment for their condition is working. For example, people with active lupus erythematosus may have lower-than-normal levels of the complement proteins C3 and C4 .</text><text>Complement activity varies throughout the body. For example, in people with rheumatoid arthritis , complement activity in the blood may be normal or higher-than-normal, but much lower-than-normal in the joint fluid.</text><text>People with gram negative septicemia and shock often have very low C3 and components of what's known as the alternative pathway. C3 is often also low in fungal infections and some parasitic infections such as malaria .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal results for this test are:</text><detail>Total blood complement level: 41 to 90 hemolytic units</detail><detail>C1 level: 14.9 to 22.1 mg/dL</detail><detail>C3 levels: 88 to 201 mg/dL</detail><detail>C4 levels: 15 to 45 mg/dL</detail><text>Note: mg/dL = milligrams per deciliter.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased complement activity may be seen in:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Certain infections</detail><detail> Ulcerative colitis </detail><text>Decreased complement activity may be seen in:</text><detail> Cirrhosis </detail><detail> Glomerulonephritis </detail><detail> Hereditary angioedema </detail><detail> Hepatitis </detail><detail> Kidney transplant rejection</detail><detail> Lupus nephritis </detail><detail>Malnutrition</detail><detail>Systemic lupus erythematosus</detail><detail>Rare inherited complement deficiencies</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Complement assay</detail><detail> Complement proteins</detail>

item.title: Colposcopy - directed biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation. You may be more comfortable if you empty your bladder and bowel before the procedure.</text><text>Before the exam:</text><detail>DO NOT douche (this is never recommended).</detail><detail>DO NOT place any products into the vagina.</detail><detail>DO NOT have sex for 24 hours before the exam.</detail><detail>Tell your provider if you are pregnant or could be pregnant.</detail><text>This test should not be done during a heavy period, unless it is abnormal. Keep your appointment if you are:</text><detail>At the very end or beginning of your regular period</detail><detail>Having abnormal bleeding </detail><text>You may be able to take ibuprofen or acetaminophen (Tylenol) before the colposcopy. Ask your provider if this is OK, and when and how much you should take.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Colposcopy is done to detect cervical cancer and changes that may lead to cervical cancer.</text><text>It is most often done when you have had an abnormal Pap smear or HPV test. It may also be recommended if you have bleeding after sexual intercourse.</text><text>Colposcopy may also be done when your provider sees abnormal areas on your cervix during a pelvic exam. These may include:</text><detail>Any abnormal growth on the cervix, or elsewhere in the vagina</detail><detail> Genital warts or HPV</detail><detail>Irritation or inflammation of the cervix ( cervicitis )</detail><text>The colposcopy may be used to keep track of HPV, and to look for abnormal changes that can come back after treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A smooth, pink surface of the cervix is normal.</text><text>If the colposcopy or biopsy does not show why the Pap smear was abnormal, your provider may suggest that you have a cold knife cone biopsy.</text><text>A specialist called a pathologist will examine the tissue sample from the cervical biopsy and send a report to your doctor. Biopsy results most often take 1 to 2 weeks. A normal result means there is no cancer and no abnormal changes were seen.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Your provider should be able to tell you if anything abnormal was seen during the test, including:</text><detail>Abnormal patterns in the blood vessels</detail><detail>Areas that are swollen, worn away, or wasted away (atrophic)</detail><detail> Cervical polyps </detail><detail>Genital warts</detail><detail>Whitish patches on the cervix </detail><text>Abnormal biopsy results may be due to changes that can lead to cervical cancer. These changes are called dysplasia, or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). </text><detail>CIN I is mild</detail><detail>CIN II is moderate</detail><detail>CIN III is severe dysplasia or very early cervical cancer called carcinoma in situ </detail><text>Abnormal biopsy results may be due to:</text><detail>Cervical cancer</detail><detail> Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (precancerous tissue changes that are also called cervical dysplasia)</detail><detail>Cervical warts (infection with human papilloma virus , or HPV) </detail><text>If the biopsy does not determine the cause of abnormal results, you may need a procedure called a cold knife cone biopsy.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - colposcopy - directed</detail><detail> Biopsy - cervix - colposcopy</detail><detail> Endocervical curettage</detail><detail> ECC</detail><detail> Cervical punch biopsy</detail><detail> Biopsy - cervical punch</detail><detail> Cervical biopsy</detail><detail> Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia - colposcopy</detail><detail> CIN - colposcopy</detail><detail> Precancerous changes of the cervix - colposcopy</detail><detail> Cervical cancer - colposcopy</detail><detail> Squamous intraepithelial lesion - colposcopy</detail><detail> LSIL - colposcopy</detail><detail> HSIL - colposcopy</detail><detail> Low-grade colposcopy</detail><detail> High-grade colposcopy</detail><detail> Carcinoma in situ - colposcopy</detail><detail> CIS - colposcopy</detail><detail> ASCUS - colposcopy</detail><detail> Atypical glandular cells - colposcopy</detail><detail> AGUS - colposcopy</detail><detail> Atypical squamous cells - colposcopy</detail><detail> Pap smear - colposcopy</detail><detail> HPV - colposcopy</detail><detail> Human papilloma virus - colposcopy</detail><detail> Cervix - colposcopy</detail><detail> Colposcopy</detail>

item.title: Color vision test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If your child is having this test performed, it may be helpful to explain how the test will feel, and to practice or demonstrate on a doll. Your child will feel less anxious about the test if you explain what will happen and why.</text><text>Usually there is a sample card of multicolored dots that almost everyone can identify, even people with color vision problems.</text><text>If you or your child normally wears glasses, wear them during the test.</text><text>Small children may be asked to tell the difference between a red bottle cap and caps of a different color.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to determine whether you have any problems with your color vision.</text><text>Color vision problems often fall into two categories:</text><detail>Present from birth (congenital) problems in the light-sensitive cells (cones) of the retina (the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye) -- the color cards are used in this case.</detail><detail>Diseases of the optic nerve (the nerve that carries visual information from the eye to the brain) -- the bottle caps are used in this case. </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, you will be able to distinguish all colors.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>This test can determine the following congenital (present from birth) color vision problems:</text><detail>Achromatopsia -- complete color blindness , seeing only shades of gray</detail><detail>Deuteranopia -- difficulty telling the difference between red/purple and green/purple</detail><detail>Protanopia -- difficulty telling the difference between blue/green and red/green</detail><detail>Tritanopia -- difficulty telling the difference between yellow/green and blue/green </detail><text>Problems in the optic nerve can show up as a loss of color intensity, although the color card test may be normal.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Eye test - color</detail><detail> Vision test - color</detail><detail> Ishihara color vision test</detail>

item.title: Colonoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your bowel needs to be completely empty and clean for the exam. A problem in your large intestine that needs to be treated may be missed if your intestines are not cleaned out. </text><text>Your health care provider will give you the steps for cleansing your bowel. This is called bowel preparation. Steps may include: </text><detail>Using enemas</detail><detail>Not eating solid foods for 1 to 3 days before the test</detail><detail>Taking laxatives </detail><text>You need to drink plenty of clear liquids for 1 to 3 days before the test. Examples of clear liquids are:</text><detail>Clear coffee or tea</detail><detail>Fat-free bouillon or broth</detail><detail>Gelatin</detail><detail>Sports drinks without added color</detail><detail>Strained fruit juices</detail><detail>Water </detail><text>You will likely be told to stop taking aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen, or other blood-thinning medicines for several days before the test. Keep taking your other medicines unless your doctor tells you otherwise. </text><text>You will need to stop taking iron pills or liquids a few days before the test, unless your provider tells you it is OK to continue. Iron can make your stool dark black. This makes it harder for the doctor to view inside your bowel. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Colonoscopy may be done for the following reasons:</text><detail>Abdominal pain, changes in bowel movements, or weight loss</detail><detail>Abnormal changes (polyps) found on sigmoidoscopy or x-ray tests ( CT scan or barium enema )</detail><detail> Anemia due to low iron (usually when no other cause has been found)</detail><detail> Blood in the stool , or black, tarry stools</detail><detail>Follow-up of a past finding, such as polyps or colon cancer </detail><detail>Inflammatory bowel disease ( ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease )</detail><detail> Screening for colorectal cancer </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal findings are healthy intestinal tissues.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal test results may mean any of the following:</text><detail>Abnormal pouches on the lining of the intestines, called diverticulosis </detail><detail>Areas of bleeding</detail><detail>Cancer in the colon or rectum</detail><detail>Colitis (a swollen and inflamed intestine) due to Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis, infection, or lack of blood flow </detail><detail>Small growths called polyps on the lining of your colon (which can be removed through the colonoscope during the exam) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Colon cancer - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Colorectal cancer - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Colonoscopy - screening</detail><detail> Colon polyps - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Ulcerative colitis - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Crohn disease - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Diverticulitis - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Diarrhea - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Anemia - colonoscopy</detail><detail> Blood in stool - colonoscopy</detail>

item.title: Coccidioides precipitin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The precipitin test is one of several tests that can be done to determine if you are infected with coccidioides, which causes the disease coccidioidomycosis.</text><text>Antibodies are specialized proteins that defend the body against bacteria, viruses, and fungi. These and other foreign substances are called antigens . When you are exposed to antigens, your body produces antibodies.</text><text>The precipitin test helps check if the body has produced antibodies to a specific antigen, in this case, the coccidioides fungus.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is when no precipitins are formed. This means the blood test did not detect the antibody to coccidioides.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) result means the antibody to coccidioides has been detected.</text><text>In this case, another test is done to confirm that you have an infection. Your doctor can tell you more.</text><text>During the early stage of an illness, few antibodies may be detected. Antibody production increases during the course of an infection. For this reason, this test may be repeated several weeks after the first test.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Coccidioidomycosis antibody test</detail><detail> Coccidioides blood test</detail><detail> Valley fever blood test</detail>

item.title: Coccidioides complement fixation
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to detect infection with the fungus that causes coccidioidomycosis, or valley fever. This condition can cause lung or widespread (disseminated) infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no Coccidioides immitis antibodies are detected in the blood sample.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean that Coccidioides immitis antibodies are present. This can mean that you have a current or past infection.</text><text>The test may be repeated after several weeks to detect a rise in titer (antibody concentration), which confirms an active infection.</text><text>In general, the worse the infection, the higher is the titer, except in people with a weakened immune system.</text><text>There can be false positive tests in people with other fungal diseases such as histoplasmosis and blastomycosis , and false negative tests in people with single lung masses from coccidioidomycosis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Coccidioides antibody test</detail><detail> Coccidioidomycosis blood test </detail>

item.title: CO2 blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The CO2 test is most often done as part of an electrolyte or basic metabolic panel. Changes in your CO2 level may suggest that you are losing or retaining fluid. This may cause an imbalance in your body's electrolytes.</text><text>CO2 levels in the blood are affected by kidney and lung function. The kidneys help maintain the normal bicarbonate levels.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 23 to 29 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L) or 23 to 29 millimoles per liter (mmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement range of results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal levels may be due to the following problems:</text><text>Lower-than-normal levels</text><detail> Addison disease </detail><detail> Diarrhea </detail><detail>Ethylene glycol poisoning</detail><detail> Ketoacidosis </detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail>Lactic acidosis </detail><detail> Metabolic acidosis </detail><detail>Methanol poisoning</detail><detail>Salicylate toxicity (such as aspirin overdose) </detail><text>Higher-than-normal levels</text><detail>Breathing disorders</detail><detail> Cushing syndrome </detail><detail> Hyperaldosteronism </detail><detail>Vomiting </detail><text>The following conditions may also alter bicarbonate levels:</text><detail> Alkalosis </detail><detail> Delirium </detail><detail> Dementia </detail><detail> Renal tubular acidosis; distal </detail><detail> Renal tubular acidosis; proximal </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Bicarbonate test</detail><detail> HCO3-</detail><detail> Carbon dioxide test</detail><detail> TCO2</detail><detail> Total CO2</detail><detail> CO2 test - serum</detail><detail> Acidosis - CO2</detail><detail> Alkalosis - CO2</detail>

item.title: CMV blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed to detect current active CMV infection , or past CMV infection in people who are at risk of reactivation of infection (such as organ transplant recipients and people with a suppressed immune system). The test may also be performed to detect CMV infection in newborns .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>People who have never been infected with CMV have no detectable antibodies to CMV.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The presence of antibodies to CMV indicates a current or past infection with CMV. If the number of antibodies (called the antibody titer) rises over a few weeks, it may mean that you have a current or recent infection.</text><text>Long-term (chronic) CMV infection (in which the antibody count stays about the same over time) can reactivate in a person with a suppressed immune system.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CMV antibody tests</detail>

item.title: Clean catch urine sample
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine culture - clean catch</detail><detail> Urinalysis - clean catch</detail><detail> Clean catch urine specimen</detail><detail> Urine collection - clean catch</detail><detail> UTI - clean catch</detail><detail> Urinary tract infection - clean catch</detail><detail> Cystitis - clean catch</detail>

item.title: Citric acid urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test. But the results are affected by your diet, and this test is usually done while you are on a normal diet. Ask your provider for more information.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is used to diagnose renal tubular acidosis and evaluate kidney stone disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 320 to 1,240 mg per 24 hours.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A low level of citric acid may mean renal tubular acidosis and a tendency to form calcium kidney stones.</text><text>The following may decrease urine citric acid levels:</text><detail>Long-term (chronic) kidney failure</detail><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail>Excessive muscle activity</detail><detail>Medicines called angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors</detail><detail>Parathyroid glands do not produce enough of its hormone ( hypoparathyroidism )</detail><detail>Too much acid in the body fluids ( acidosis )</detail><text>The following may increase urine citric acid levels:</text><detail>A high carbohydrate diet</detail><detail>Estrogen therapy</detail><detail> Vitamin D </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine - citric acid test</detail><detail> Renal tubular acidosis - citric acid test</detail><detail> Kidney stones - citric acid test</detail><detail> Urolithiasis - citric acid test</detail>

item.title: Chromium - blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should stop taking mineral supplements and multivitamins for at least several days before the test. Ask your health care provider if there are other medicines you should stop taking before testing. Also, let your provider know if you have recently had contrast agents containing gadolinium or iodine as part of an imaging study. These substances can interfere with testing. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to diagnose chromium poisoning or deficiency.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Serum chromium level normally is less than or equal to 1.4 micrograms/milliliter (µg/mL) or 26924.80 nanomoles/L (nmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased chromium level may result if you are overexposed to the substance. This may happen if you work in the following industries:</text><detail>Leather tanning</detail><detail>Electroplating</detail><detail>Steel manufacturing </detail><text>Decreased chromium level only occurs in people who receive all of their nutrition by vein (total parenteral nutrition or TPN) and do not get enough chromium.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum chromium</detail>

item.title: Chorionic villus sampling
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will explain the procedure, its risks, and alternative procedures such as amniocentesis .</text><text>You will be asked to sign a consent form before this procedure. You may be asked to wear a hospital gown.</text><text>The morning of the procedure, you may be asked to drink fluids and refrain from urinating. Doing so fills your bladder, which helps your provider see where to best guide the needle.</text><text>Tell your provider if you are allergic to iodine or shellfish, or if you have any other allergies.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is used to identify any genetic disease in your unborn baby. It is very accurate, and it can be done very early in a pregnancy.</text><text>Genetic problems can occur in any pregnancy. However, the following factors increase the risk:</text><detail>An older mother</detail><detail>Past pregnancies with genetic problems</detail><detail>Family history of genetic disorders </detail><text> Genetic counseling is recommended before the procedure. This will allow you to make an unhurried, informed decision about options for prenatal diagnosis.</text><text>CVS can be done sooner in pregnancy than amniocentesis, most often at about 10 to 12 weeks. </text><text>CVS does not detect:</text><detail>Neural tube defects (these involve the spinal column or brain)</detail><detail> Rh incompatibility (this occurs when a pregnant woman has Rh-negative blood and her unborn baby has Rh-positive blood)</detail><detail>Birth defects </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there are no signs of genetic defects in the developing baby. Even though the test results are very accurate, no test is 100% accurate at testing for genetic problems in a pregnancy.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>This test can help detect hundreds of genetic disorders. Abnormal results may be due to many different genetic conditions, including:</text><detail> Down syndrome </detail><detail> Hemoglobinopathies </detail><detail> Tay-Sachs disease </detail><text>Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results. Ask your provider:</text><detail>How the condition or defect may be treated either during or after the pregnancy</detail><detail>What special needs your child may have after birth</detail><detail>What other options you have about maintaining or ending your pregnancy</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CVS</detail><detail> Pregnancy - CVS</detail><detail> Genetic counseling - CVS</detail>

item.title: Cholinesterase - blood
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test if you may have been exposed to chemicals called organophosphates. These chemicals are used in pesticides. This test can help determine your risk of poisoning.</text><text>Less often, this test may be done:</text><detail>To diagnose liver disease </detail><detail>Before you receive anesthesia with succinylcholine, which may be given before certain procedures or treatments, including electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Typically, normal pseudocholinesterase values range between 8 and 18 units per milliliter (U/mL) or 8 and 18 kilounits per liter (kU/L).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased pseudocholinesterase levels may be due to:</text><detail> Acute infection</detail><detail> Chronic malnutrition</detail><detail>Heart attack</detail><detail>Liver damage</detail><detail> Metastasis </detail><detail>Obstructive jaundice</detail><detail>Poisoning from organophosphates (chemicals found in some pesticides)</detail><detail>Inflammation that accompanies some diseases</detail><text>Smaller decreases may be due to:</text><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>Use of birth control pills </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Acetylcholinesterase</detail><detail> RBC (or erythrocyte) cholinesterase</detail><detail> Pseudocholinesterase</detail><detail> Plasma cholinesterase</detail><detail> Butyrylcholinesterase</detail><detail> Serum cholinesterase</detail>

item.title: Chloride test - blood
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test if you have signs that your body's fluid level or acid-base balance is disturbed.</text><text>This test is most often ordered with other blood tests, such as a basic or comprehensive metabolic panel.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A typical normal range is 96 to 106 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L) or 96 to 106 millimoles per liter (millimol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurement range for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A greater-than-normal level of chloride is called hyperchloremia. It may be due to:</text><detail>Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (used to treat glaucoma)</detail><detail>Diarrhea</detail><detail> Metabolic acidosis </detail><detail> Respiratory alkalosis (compensated)</detail><detail> Renal tubular acidosis </detail><text>A lower-than-normal level of chloride is called hypochloremia. It may be due to:</text><detail> Addison disease </detail><detail> Bartter syndrome </detail><detail>Burns</detail><detail> Congestive heart failure </detail><detail>Dehydration</detail><detail>Excessive sweating</detail><detail> Hyperaldosteronism </detail><detail>Metabolic alkalosis</detail><detail> Respiratory acidosis (compensated)</detail><detail>Syndrome of inappropriate diuretic hormone secretion ( SIADH )</detail><detail>Vomiting </detail><text>This test may also be done to help rule out or diagnose:</text><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) II </detail><detail>Primary hyperparathyroidism </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum chloride test</detail>

item.title: Chloride - urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will ask you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that may affect the test result. Tell your provider about all the medicines you take, including:</text><detail>Acetazolamide</detail><detail>Corticosteroids</detail><detail>Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretic medicines) </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of a condition that affects body fluids or acid-base balance.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 110 to 250 mEq/L per day. This range depends on the amount of salt and fluid you take in.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal urine chloride level may be due to:</text><detail>Low function of the adrenal glands </detail><detail>Inflammation of the kidney that results in salt loss (salt-losing nephropathy)</detail><detail>Production of an unusually large amount of urine (polyuria)</detail><detail>Too much salt in the diet </detail><text>Decreased urine chloride level may be due to:</text><detail>Body holding in too much salt (sodium retention)</detail><detail>Cushing syndrome</detail><detail>Decreased salt intake</detail><detail>Fluid loss that occurs with diarrhea, vomiting, sweating, and gastric suction </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urinary chloride</detail>

item.title: Chest x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the health care provider if you are pregnant. Chest x-rays are generally not done during the first 6 months of pregnancy. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order a chest x-ray if you have any of the following symptoms:</text><detail>A persistent cough</detail><detail> Chest pain from a chest injury (with a possible rib fracture or lung complication) or from heart problems</detail><detail> Coughing up blood </detail><detail>Difficulty breathing</detail><detail>Fever</detail><text>It may also be done if you have signs of tuberculosis , lung cancer , or other chest or lung diseases .</text><text>A serial chest x-ray is one that is repeated. It may be done to monitor changes found on a past chest x-ray.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to many things, including:</text><text>In the lungs:</text><detail> Collapsed lung </detail><detail> Collection of fluid around the lung </detail><detail>Lung tumor (noncancerous or cancerous) </detail><detail> Malformation of the blood vessels </detail><detail> Pneumonia </detail><detail>Scarring of lung tissue</detail><detail>Tuberculosis </detail><text>In the heart:</text><detail>Problems with the size or shape of the heart</detail><detail>Problems with the position and shape of the large arteries </detail><detail>Evidence of heart failure</detail><text>In the bones:</text><detail> Fractures or other problems of the ribs and spine</detail><detail> Osteoporosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Chest radiography</detail><detail> Serial chest x-ray</detail><detail> X-ray - chest</detail>

value.img_name: Pulmonary nodule - front view chest x-ray
Pulmonary mass - side view chest x-ray
Lung nodule, right middle lobe - chest x-ray
Lung mass, right upper lung - chest x-ray
Lung nodule - front view chest x-ray

item.title: Cervical spine CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Some exams use a special dye, called contrast that is put into your body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays.</text><text>Contrast can be given in different ways:</text><detail>It may be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm.</detail><detail>It may be given as an injection into the space around the spinal cord.</detail><text>If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test.</text><text>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast. You may need to take medicines before the test to avoid this problem.</text><text>Before having the contrast, tell your provider if you take the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage). You may need to take extra steps before the test if you take this drug.</text><text>Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. Find out if the CT machine has a weight limit if you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms).</text><text>You will wear a hospital gown during the study. You will need to take off all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT makes detailed pictures of the body very quickly. The test may help look for:</text><detail>Birth defects of the cervical spine in children</detail><detail>Spine problems, when a spine MRI cannot be used</detail><detail>Injury to the upper spine</detail><detail>Bone tumors and cancers</detail><detail>Broken bone</detail><detail>Disk herniations and compression of the spinal cord</detail><detail>Healing problems or scar tissue following surgery</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if the cervical spine looks OK.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Birth defects of the cervical spine</detail><detail>Bone problems</detail><detail>Fracture</detail><detail>Osteoarthritis</detail><detail>Disk herniation</detail><detail>Healing problems or growth of scar tissue after surgery</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan of cervical spine</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan of cervical spine</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan of cervical spine</detail><detail> CT scan of cervical spine</detail><detail> Neck CT scan</detail>

item.title: Cervical MRI scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of closed spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious. Your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The most common reasons for this test are:</text><detail>Severe neck, shoulder, or arm pain that does not get better after treatment</detail><detail>Neck pain along with leg weakness, numbness, or other symptoms </detail><text>A cervical MRI scan may also be done for:</text><detail>Birth defects of the spine</detail><detail>Infection that involves your spine</detail><detail>Injury or trauma to the spine</detail><detail>Multiple sclerosis</detail><detail>Severe scoliosis</detail><detail>Tumor or cancer in the spine</detail><detail>Arthritis in the spine </detail><text>MRI works better than CT scan in diagnosing these problems most of the time.</text><text>A cervical MRI may also be done before spinal surgery.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the part of the spine that runs through your neck and nearby nerves appears normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The most common reasons for an abnormal result are:</text><detail> Herniated or "slipped" disk (cervical radiculopathy)</detail><detail>Narrowing of the cervical spine ( spinal stenosis )</detail><detail>Abnormal wear of the bones and cartilage in the neck ( cervical spondylosis ) </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail>Bone infection ( osteomyelitis )</detail><detail>Disk inflammation ( diskitis )</detail><detail>Infection of the spine</detail><detail> Multiple sclerosis </detail><detail> Spinal cord injury or compression </detail><detail>Spinal fracture</detail><detail> Spinal tumor </detail><text>Talk to your provider about your questions and concerns.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>MRI - cervical spine</detail><detail> MRI - neck</detail>

item.title: Ceruloplasmin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Ceruloplasmin is made in the liver. Ceruloplasmin stores and transports copper in the blood to parts of the body that need it.</text><text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs or symptoms of a copper metabolism or copper storage disorder.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range for adults is 14 to 40 mg/dL (0.93 to 2.65 µmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean:
A lower-than-normal ceruloplasmin levels may be due to:Long-term liver diseaseProblem absorbing nutrients from food ( intestinal malabsorption ) Malnutrition Disorder in which cells in the body can absorb copper, but are unable to release it ( Menkes syndrome )Group of disorders that damage the kidneys ( nephrotic syndrome )Inherited disorder in which there is too much copper in the body's tissues ( Wilson disease )A higher-than-normal ceruloplasmin levels may be due to: Acute and chronic infections Cancer (breast or  lymphoma )Heart disease, including heart attack
 Overactive thyroid  
Pregnancy Rheumatoid arthritis Use of birth control pills
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CP - serum</detail>

item.title: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions on how to prepare for a spinal tap .</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test if you have signs of an infection that affects the brain or nervous system. The test helps identify what is causing the infection. This will help your provider decide on the best treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no bacteria, viruses, or fungi grew in the laboratory dish. This is called a negative result. However, a normal result doesn't mean that there is no infection. The spinal tap and CSF smear may need to be done again.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Bacteria or other germs found in the sample may be a sign of meningitis. This is an infection of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. The infection can be caused by bacteria , fungi, or viruses.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - CSF</detail><detail> Spinal fluid culture</detail><detail> CSF culture</detail>

item.title: Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) collection
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need to give the health care team your consent before the test. Tell your provider if you are on any blood-thinning medicines such as warfarin (Coumadin), Lovenox, aspirin, or Plavix.</text><text>Afterward, you should plan to rest for several hours, even if you feel fine. This is to prevent fluid from leaking around the site of the puncture. You will not need to lie flat on your back the entire time.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to measure pressures within the CSF and to collect a sample of the fluid for further testing.</text><text>CSF analysis can be used to diagnose certain neurologic disorders. These may include infections (such as meningitis) and brain or spinal cord damage. A spinal tap may also be done to establish the diagnosis of normal pressure hydrocephalus. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values typically range as follows:</text><detail>Pressure: 70 to 180 mm H<sub>2</sub>O</detail><detail>Appearance: clear, colorless</detail><detail> CSF total protein : 15 to 60 mg/100 mL</detail><detail>Gamma globulin: 3% to 12% of the total protein </detail><detail> CSF glucose : 50 to 80 mg/100 mL (or greater than two thirds of blood sugar level)</detail><detail> CSF cell count : 0 to 5 white blood cells (all mononuclear), and no red blood cells</detail><detail>Chloride: 110 to 125 mEq/L</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the CSF looks cloudy, it could mean there is an infection or a buildup of white blood cells or protein.</text><text>If the CSF looks bloody or red, it may be a sign of bleeding or spinal cord obstruction. If it is brown, orange, or yellow, it may be a sign of increased CSF protein or previous bleeding (more than 3 days ago). There may be blood in the sample that came from the spinal tap itself. This makes it harder to interpret the test results.</text><text>CSF PRESSURE</text><detail>Increased CSF pressure may be due to increased intracranial pressure (pressure within the skull).</detail><detail>Decreased CSF pressure may be due to spinal cord tumor, shock, fainting, or diabetic coma .</detail><text>CSF PROTEIN</text><detail>Increased CSF protein may be due to blood in the CSF, diabetes , polyneuritis, tumor, injury, or any inflammatory or infectious condition.</detail><detail>Decreased protein is a sign of rapid CSF production.</detail><text>CSF GLUCOSE</text><detail>Increased CSF glucose is a sign of high blood sugar.</detail><detail>Decreased CSF glucose may be due to hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), bacterial or fungal infection (such as meningitis ), tuberculosis, or certain other types of meningitis.</detail><text>BLOOD CELLS IN CSF</text><detail>Increased white blood cells in the CSF may be a sign of meningitis, acute infection, beginning of a long-term (chronic) illness, tumor, abscess , stroke , or demyelinating disease (such as multiple sclerosis).</detail><detail>Red blood cells in the CSF sample may be a sign of bleeding into the spinal fluid or the result of a traumatic lumbar puncture.</detail><text>OTHER CSF RESULTS</text><detail>Increased CSF gamma globulin levels may be due to diseases such as multiple sclerosis , neurosyphilis , or Guillain-Barré syndrome .</detail><text>Additional conditions under which the test may be performed:</text><detail> Chronic inflammatory polyneuropathy </detail><detail> Dementia due to metabolic causes </detail><detail> Encephalitis </detail><detail> Epilepsy </detail><detail> Febrile seizure (children) </detail><detail> Generalized tonic-clonic seizure </detail><detail> Hydrocephalus </detail><detail>Inhalation anthrax</detail><detail> Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) </detail><detail> Pituitary tumor </detail><detail> Reye syndrome </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Spinal tap</detail><detail> Ventricular puncture</detail><detail> Lumbar puncture</detail><detail> Cisternal puncture</detail><detail> Cerebrospinal fluid culture</detail>

item.title: Cerebral angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before the procedure, your provider will examine you and order blood tests. </text><text>Tell the provider if you:</text><detail>Have a history of bleeding problems or take medicines that are blood thinners</detail><detail>Have had an allergic reaction to x-ray contrast dye or any iodine substance</detail><detail>May be pregnant</detail><detail>Have kidney function problems </detail><text>You may be told not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 8 hours before the test.</text><text>When you arrive at the testing site, you will be given a hospital gown to wear. You must remove all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Cerebral angiography is most often used to identify or confirm problems with the blood vessels in the brain.</text><text>Your provider may order this test if you have symptoms or signs of:</text><detail>Abnormal blood vessels (vascular malformation)</detail><detail> Aneurysm </detail><detail>Narrowing of the arteries in the brain</detail><detail>Vasculitis </detail><text>It is sometimes used to:</text><detail>Look at blood flow to a tumor</detail><detail>Evaluate the arteries of the head and neck before surgery</detail><detail>Find a clot that may have caused a stroke </detail><text>In some cases, this procedure may be used to get more detailed information after something abnormal has been detected by an MRI or CT scan of the head .</text><text>This test may also be done in preparation for medical treatment ( interventional radiology procedures ) by way of certain blood vessels.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Contrast dye flowing out of the blood vessel may be a sign of bleeding.</text><text>Narrowed arteries may suggest: </text><detail>Cholesterol deposits</detail><detail>A spasm of a brain artery</detail><detail>Inherited disorders </detail><text>Out of place blood vessels may be due to: </text><detail>Brain tumors</detail><detail>Bleeding within the skull</detail><detail>Bulging of a blood vessel in the brain ( aneurysm )</detail><detail>Abnormal connection between the arteries and veins in the brain ( arteriovenous malformation ) </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail>Cancer that started in another part of the body and has spread to the brain ( metastatic brain tumor )</detail><detail>Syphilis infection of the brain ( neurosyphilis ) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Vertebral angiogram</detail><detail> Angiography - head</detail><detail> Carotid angiogram</detail><detail> Cervicocerebral catheter-based angiography</detail><detail> Intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography</detail><detail> IADSA</detail>

value.img_name: Carotid stenosis, x-ray of the left artery
Carotid stenosis, x-ray of the right artery

item.title: CEA blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Smoking may increase the CEA level. If you smoke, your doctor may tell you to avoid doing so for a short time before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to monitor the response to treatment and then to check for the return of colon and other cancers such as medullary thyroid cancer and cancers of the rectum, lung, breast, liver, pancreas, stomach, and ovaries.</text><text>It is not used as a screening test for cancer and should not be done unless a diagnosis of cancer has been made.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 0 to 2.5 ng/mL (0 to 2.5 µg/L). </text><text>In smokers, slightly higher values may be considered normal (0 to 5 ng/mL, or 0 to 5 µg/L).</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high CEA level in a person recently treated for certain cancers may mean the cancer has returned. A higher than normal level may be due to the following cancers:</text><detail> Breast cancer </detail><detail>Cancers of the reproductive and urinary tracts</detail><detail> Colon cancer </detail><detail> Lung cancer </detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><detail> Thyroid cancer </detail><text>Higher than normal CEA level alone cannot diagnose a new cancer. Further testing is needed.</text><text>An increased CEA level may also be due to:</text><detail>Liver and gallbladder problems, such as scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis ), or gallbladder inflammation ( cholecystitis )</detail><detail>Heavy smoking</detail><detail>Inflammatory bowel diseases (such as ulcerative colitis or diverticulitis )</detail><detail>Lung infection</detail><detail>Inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis)</detail><detail>Stomach ulcer </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Carcinoembryonic antigen blood test</detail>

item.title: CBC blood test
