item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A CBC is a commonly performed lab test. It can be used to detect or monitor many different health conditions. Your health care provider may order this test:</text><detail>As part of a routine check-up</detail><detail>If you are having symptoms, such as fatigue, weight loss, fever or other signs of an infection, weakness, bruising, bleeding, or any signs of cancer</detail><detail>When you are receiving treatments (medicines or radiation) that may change your blood count results</detail><detail>To monitor a long-term (chronic) health problem that may change your blood count results, such as chronic kidney disease </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Blood counts may vary with altitude. In general, normal results are: </text><text>RBC count:</text><detail>Male: 4.7 to 6.1 million cells/mcL </detail><detail>Female: 4.2 to 5.4 million cells/mcL </detail><text>WBC count: </text><detail>4,500 to 10,000 cells/mcL </detail><text>Hematocrit: </text><detail>Male: 40.7% to 50.3% </detail><detail>Female: 36.1% to 44.3% </detail><text>Hemoglobin: </text><detail>Male: 13.8 to 17.2 gm/dL </detail><detail>Female: 12.1 to 15.1 gm/dL </detail><text>Red blood cell indices:</text><detail>MCV: 80 to 95 femtoliter</detail><detail>MCH: 27 to 31 pg/cell</detail><detail>MCHC: 32 to 36 gm/dL </detail><text>Platelet count:</text><detail>150,000 to 450,000/dL </detail><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High RBC, hemoglobin, or hematocrit may be due to:</text><detail>A lack of enough water and fluids, such as from severe diarrhea, excessive sweating, or water pills used to treat high blood pressure</detail><detail>Kidney disease with high erythropoietin production</detail><detail>Low oxygen level in the blood for a long time, most often due to heart or lung disease</detail><detail> Polycythemia vera </detail><detail>Smoking</detail><text>Low RBC, hemoglobin, or hematacrit is a sign of anemia, which can result from:</text><detail> Blood loss (either sudden, or from problems such as heavy menstrual periods over a long time)</detail><detail>Bone marrow failure (for example, from radiation, infection, or tumor)</detail><detail>Breakdown of red blood cells ( hemolysis )</detail><detail>Cancer and cancer treatment</detail><detail>Certain long-term (chronic) medical conditions, such as chronic kidney disease, ulcerative colitis, or rheumatoid arthritis</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Long-term infections such as hepatitis </detail><detail>Poor diet and nutrition, causing too little iron, folate , vitamin B12 , or vitamin B6 </detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><text>A lower than normal white blood cell count is called leukopenia. A decreased WBC count may be due to:</text><detail>Alcohol abuse and liver damage</detail><detail>Autoimmune diseases (such as systemic lupus erythematosus )</detail><detail>Bone marrow failure (for example, due to infection, tumor, radiation, or fibrosis)</detail><detail>Chemotherapy medicines used to treat cancer</detail><detail>Disease of the liver or spleen</detail><detail>Enlarged spleen</detail><detail>Infections caused by viruses, such as mono or AIDS</detail><detail>Medicines</detail><text>A high WBC count is called leukocytosis. It can result from:</text><detail>Certain medicines, such as corticosteroids</detail><detail>Infections</detail><detail>Diseases such as lupus, rheumatoid arthritis , or allergy </detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Severe emotional or physical stress</detail><detail>Tissue damage (such as from burns or a heart attack)</detail><text>A high platelet count may be due to:</text><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Diseases such as cancer</detail><detail>Iron deficiency</detail><detail>Problems with the bone marrow</detail><text>A low platelet count may be due to:</text><detail>Disorders where platelets are destroyed</detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>Enlarged spleen</detail><detail>Bone marrow failure (for example, due to infection, tumor, radiation, or fibrosis)</detail><detail>Chemotherapy medicines used to treat cancer</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Complete blood count</detail><detail> Anemia - CBC</detail>

value.img_name: Megaloblastic anemia - view of red blood cells
Red blood cells, multiple sickle cells
Malaria, microscopic view of cellular parasites
Red blood cells, sickle and Pappenheimer

item.title: Catecholamines - urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text> Stress and heavy exercise may affect the test results.</text><text>Some foods can increase catecholamines in your urine. You may need to avoid the following foods and beverages for several days before the test:</text><detail>Coffee</detail><detail>Tea</detail><detail>Bananas</detail><detail>Chocolate</detail><detail>Cocoa</detail><detail>Citrus fruits</detail><detail>Vanilla </detail><text>Many medicines can interfere with test results.</text><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is usually done to diagnose an adrenal gland tumor called pheochromocytoma . It may also be used to diagnose neuroblastoma . Urine catecholamine levels are increased in most people with neuroblastoma.</text><text>The urine test for catecholamines may also be used to monitor those who are receiving treatment for these conditions.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>All of the catecholamines are broken down into inactive substances that appear in the urine:</text><detail>Dopamine becomes homovanillic acid (HVA)</detail><detail>Norepinephrine becomes normetanephrine and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)</detail><detail>Epinephrine becomes metanephrine and VMA </detail><text>The following normal values are the amount of the substance found in the urine over a 24-hour period:</text><detail>Dopamine: 65 to 400 micrograms (mcg)/24 hours (425 to 2610 nmol/24 hours)</detail><detail>Epinephrine: 0.5 to 20 mcg/24 hours</detail><detail>Metanephrine: 24 to 96 mcg/24 hours (some laboratories give the range as 140 to 785 mcg/24 hours)</detail><detail>Norepinephrine: 15 to 80 mcg/24 hours (89 to 473 nmol/24 hours)</detail><detail>Normetanephrine: 75 to 375 mcg/24 hours</detail><detail>Total urine catecholamines: 14 to 110 mcg/24 hours</detail><detail>VMA: 2 to 7 milligrams (mg)/24 hours (10.09 mcmol/24 hours)</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Elevated levels of urinary catecholamines may indicate:</text><detail>Acute anxiety </detail><detail> Ganglioneuroblastoma (very rare)</detail><detail> Ganglioneuroma (very rare)</detail><detail>Neuroblastoma (rare)</detail><detail>Pheochromocytoma (rare)</detail><detail>Severe stress </detail><text>The test may also be performed for:</text><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) II </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Dopamine - urine test</detail><detail> Epinephrine - urine test</detail><detail> Adrenalin - urine test</detail><detail> Urine metanephrine</detail><detail> Normetanephrine</detail><detail> Norepinephrine - urine test</detail><detail> Urine catecholamines</detail><detail> VMA</detail><detail> HVA</detail><detail> Metanephrine</detail><detail> Homovanillic acid (HVA)</detail>

item.title: Catecholamine blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will likely be told not to eat anything (fast) for 10 hours before the test. You may be allowed to drink water during this time.</text><text>The accuracy of the test can be affected by certain foods and medicines. Foods that can increase catecholamine levels include:</text><detail>Coffee</detail><detail>Tea</detail><detail>Bananas</detail><detail>Chocolate</detail><detail>Cocoa</detail><detail>Citrus fruits</detail><detail>Vanilla </detail><text>You should not eat these foods for several days before the test. This is especially true if both blood and urine catecholamines are to be measured.</text><text>You should also avoid stressful situations and vigorous exercise. Both can affect the accuracy of the test results. </text><text>Medicines and substances that can increase catecholamine measurements include:</text><detail>Acetaminophen</detail><detail>Albuterol</detail><detail>Aminophylline</detail><detail>Amphetamines</detail><detail>Buspirone</detail><detail>Caffeine</detail><detail>Calcium channel blockers</detail><detail>Cocaine</detail><detail>Cyclobenzaprine</detail><detail>Levodopa</detail><detail>Methyldopa</detail><detail> Nicotinic acid (large doses)</detail><detail>Phenoxybenzamine</detail><detail>Phenothiazines</detail><detail>Pseudoephedrine</detail><detail>Reserpine</detail><detail>Tricyclic antidepressants </detail><text>Medicines that can decrease catecholamine measurements include:</text><detail>Clonidine</detail><detail>Guanethidine</detail><detail>MAO inhibitors </detail><text>If you take any of the above medicines, check with your health care provider before the blood test about whether you should stop taking your medicine.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Catecholamines are released into the blood when a person is under physical or emotional stress. The main catecholamines are dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine (which used to be called adrenalin).</text><text>This test is used to diagnose or rule out certain rare tumors, such as pheochromocytoma or neuroblastoma . It may also be done in patients with those conditions to determine if treatment is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range for epinephrine is 0 to 140 pg/mL (764.3 pmol/L).</text><text>The normal range for norepinephrine is 70 to 1700 pg/mL (413.8 to 10048.7 pmol/L).</text><text>The normal range for dopamine is 0 to 30 pg/mL (195.8 pmol/L). </text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal levels of blood catecholamines may suggest:</text><detail>Acute anxiety</detail><detail> Ganglioblastoma (very rare tumor)</detail><detail> Ganglioneuroma (very rare tumor)</detail><detail> Neuroblastoma (rare tumor)</detail><detail> Pheochromocytoma (rare tumor)</detail><detail>Severe stress </detail><text>Additional conditions under which the test may be performed include multiple system atrophy .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Norepinephrine - blood</detail><detail> Epinephrine - blood</detail><detail> Adrenalin - blood</detail><detail> Dopamine - blood</detail>

item.title: Carpal tunnel biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions for not eating or drinking anything for a few hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is often done to see if you have a condition called amyloidosis . It is not usually done to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome . However, a person with amyloidosis can have carpal tunnel syndrome.</text><text>Carpal tunnel syndrome is a condition in which there is excessive pressure on the median nerve. This is the nerve in the wrist that allows feeling and movement to parts of the hand. Carpal tunnel syndrome can lead to numbness, tingling, weakness, or muscle damage in the hand and fingers.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No abnormal tissues are found.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that you have amyloidosis.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - carpal tunnel</detail>

item.title: Carotid duplex
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test checks blood flow in the carotid arteries. It can detect:</text><detail>Blood clotting (thrombosis)</detail><detail>Narrowing in the arteries (stenosis)</detail><detail>Other causes of blockage in the carotid arteries </detail><text>Your doctor may order this test if:</text><detail>You have had a stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)</detail><detail>You need a follow-up test because your carotid artery was found to be narrowed in the past or you have had surgery on the artery</detail><detail>Your doctor hears an abnormal sound called a bruit over the carotid neck arteries. This may mean the artery is narrowed. </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The results will tell your doctor how open or narrowed your carotid arteries are. For example, the arteries may be 10% narrowed, 50% narrowed, or 75% narrowed.</text><text>A normal result means there is no problem with the blood flow in the carotid arteries. The artery is free of any significant blockage, narrowing, or other problem.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means the artery may be narrowed, or something is changing the blood flow in the carotid arteries. This is a sign of atherosclerosis or other blood vessel conditions.</text><text>In general, the more narrowed the artery is, the higher your risk of stroke.</text><text>Depending on the results, your doctor may want you to:</text><detail>Consider surgery </detail><detail>Have additional tests (such as cerebral angiography , CT angiography, and magnetic resonance angiography )</detail><detail>Follow a healthy diet and lifestyle to prevent hardening of the arteries </detail><detail>Repeat the test again in the future </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Scan - carotid duplex</detail><detail> Carotid ultrasound</detail><detail> Carotid artery ultrasound</detail><detail> Ultrasound - carotid</detail><detail> Vascular ultrasound - carotid</detail><detail> Ultrasound - vascular - carotid</detail><detail> Stroke - carotid duplex</detail><detail> TIA - carotid duplex</detail><detail> Transient ischemic attack - carotid duplex</detail>

value.img_name: Carotid stenosis, x-ray of the left artery
Carotid stenosis, x-ray of the right artery

item.title: Cardiac event monitors
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your provider if you are allergic to any tape or other adhesives.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Most often, in people with frequent symptoms, a test called Holter monitoring , which lasts 1 to 2 days, will be performed before using a cardiac event monitor. The event monitor is ordered only if no diagnosis is reached. The event monitor is also used for people who have symptoms that occur less often, such as weekly to monthly.</text><text>Cardiac event monitoring may be used: </text><detail>To assess someone with palpitations . Palpitations are feelings that your heart is pounding or racing or beating irregularly. They can be felt in your chest, throat, or neck.</detail><detail>To identify the reason for a fainting or near fainting episode .</detail><detail>To diagnose heartbeats in patients with risk factors for arrhythmias.</detail><detail>To monitor your heart after a heart attack or when starting or stopping a heart medicine.</detail><detail>To check if a pacemaker or an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is working properly.</detail><detail>To look for the cause of a stroke when the cause cannot be easily found with other tests. </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal variations in heart rate occur with activities. A normal result is no significant changes in heart rhythms or pattern.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may include various arrhythmias. Changes may mean that the heart is not getting enough oxygen.</text><text>It may be used to diagnose:</text><detail> Atrial fibrillation or flutter </detail><detail> Multifocal atrial tachycardia </detail><detail> Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia </detail><detail> Ventricular tachycardia </detail><detail>Slow heart rate (bradycardia)</detail><detail> Heart block </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ambulatory electrocardiography</detail><detail> Electrocardiography (ECG) - ambulatory</detail><detail> Continuous electrocardiograms (EKGs)</detail><detail> Holter monitors</detail><detail> Transtelephonic event monitors</detail>

item.title: Cardiac catheterization
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for 6 to 8 hours before the test. The test takes place in a hospital and you will be asked to wear a hospital gown. Sometimes, you will need to spend the night before the test in the hospital. Otherwise, you will come to the hospital the morning of the procedure.</text><text>Your provider will explain the procedure and its risks. A witnessed, signed consent form for the procedure is required.</text><text>Tell your provider if you:</text><detail>Are allergic to seafood or any medicines</detail><detail>Have had a bad reaction to contrast dye or iodine in the past</detail><detail>Take any medicines, including Viagra or other drugs for erectile dysfunction </detail><detail>Might be pregnant </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This procedure is most often done to get information about the heart or its blood vessels. It may also be done to treat some types of heart conditions, or to find out if you need heart surgery.</text><text>Your doctor may perform cardiac catheterization to diagnose or evaluate:</text><detail>Causes of congestive heart failure or cardiomyopathy </detail><detail> Coronary artery disease </detail><detail> Heart defects that are present at birth (congenital)</detail><detail>High blood pressure in the lungs ( pulmonary hypertension )</detail><detail>Problems with the heart valves </detail><text>The following procedures may also be done using cardiac catheterization:</text><detail>Repair certain types of heart defects</detail><detail>Open a narrowed (stenotic) heart valve</detail><detail>Open blocked arteries or grafts in the heart ( angioplasty with or without stenting) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Catheterization - cardiac</detail><detail> Heart catheterization</detail><detail> Angina - cardiac catheterization</detail><detail> CAD - cardiac catheterization</detail><detail> Coronary artery disease - cardiac catheterization</detail><detail> Heart valve - cardiac catheterization</detail><detail> Heart failure - cardiac catheterization</detail>

item.title: Capsule endoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your provider's instructions. If you do not follow instructions carefully, the test may have to be done a different day.</text><text>Your provider may ask you to: </text><detail>Take medicine to clear your bowels before this test</detail><detail>Have only clear liquids for 24 hours before this test</detail><detail>Have nothing to eat or drink, including water, for about 12 hours before you swallow the capsule </detail><text>DO NOT smoke for 24 hours before this test.</text><text>Be sure to tell your doctor:</text><detail>About all the medicine and drugs you take, including prescription medicine, over-the-counter (OTC) medicine, vitamins, minerals, supplements, and herbs. You may be asked to not take some medicines during this test, because they could interfere with the camera.</detail><detail>If you are allergic to any medicine.</detail><detail>If you have ever had any blockages of the bowel.</detail><detail>About any medical conditions, such as problems swallowing or heart or lung disease.</detail><detail>If you have a pacemaker, defibrillator, or other implanted device.</detail><detail>If you have had abdominal surgery or any problems with your bowel. </detail><text>On the day of the test, go to the provider's office wearing loose fitting, two-piece clothing. </text><text>While the capsule is in your body you should not have an MRI.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Capsule endoscopy is a way for the doctor to see inside your digestive system.</text><text>There are many problems it can look for, including:</text><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Ulcers</detail><detail>Polyps</detail><detail>Tumors or cancer</detail><detail>Inflammatory bowel disease</detail><detail>Crohn disease</detail><detail>Celiac disease </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The camera takes thousands of color photos of your digestive tract during this test. These pictures are downloaded to a computer and software turns them into a video. Your provider watches the video to look for problems. It may take up to a week for you to learn the results. If no problems are found, your results are normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Your provider will tell you if they find a problem with your digestive tract, what it means, and how it can be treated.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Capsule enteroscopy</detail><detail> Wireless capsule endoscopy</detail><detail> Video capsule endoscopy (VCE)</detail><detail> Small bowel capsule endoscopy (SBCE)</detail>

item.title: Capillary sample
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Blood transports oxygen, food, waste products, and other materials within the body. It also helps regulate body temperature. Blood is made up of cells and a fluid called plasma. Plasma contains various dissolved substances. The cells are mainly red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets .</text><text>Because blood has many functions, tests on the blood or its components provide valuable clues in the diagnosis of medical conditions.</text><text>Capillary blood sampling has several advantages over drawing blood from a vein:</text><detail>It is easy to obtain (it can be difficult to obtain blood from the veins, especially in infants).</detail><detail>There are several collection sites on the body, and these sites can be rotated.</detail><detail>Testing can be done at home and with little training. For example, persons with diabetes must check their blood sugar several times a day using capillary blood sampling. </detail><text>Disadvantages to capillary blood sampling include:</text><detail>Only a limited amount of blood can be drawn using this method.</detail><detail>The procedure has some risks (see below).</detail><detail>Capillary blood sampling may result in inaccurate results, such as falsely elevated sugar, electrolyte, and blood count values. </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Results vary depending on the test done. Your health care provider can tell you more.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Blood sample - capillary</detail><detail> Fingerstick</detail><detail> Heelstick</detail>

item.title: Capillary nail refill test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Remove colored nail polish before this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Tissues need oxygen to survive. Oxygen is carried to various parts of the body by the blood (vascular) system.</text><text>This test measures how well the vascular system works in your hands and feet -- the parts of your body that are farthest from the heart. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>If there is good blood flow to the nail bed, a pink color should return in less than 2 seconds after pressure is removed.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Blanch times that are greater than 2 seconds may indicate:</text><detail>Dehydration</detail><detail> Shock </detail><detail> Peripheral vascular disease (PVD)</detail><detail> Hypothermia </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Nail blanch test</detail><detail> Capillary refill time</detail>

item.title: Campylobacter serology test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test detects the presence of antibodies to campylobacter in the blood. Campylobacter infection can cause diarrheal illness. A blood test is rarely done to diagnose campylobacter diarrheal illness. It is used if your health care provider thinks you are having complications from this infection, such as reactive arthritis or Guillain-Barré syndrome .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test result means no antibodies to campylobacter are present. This is called a negative result. </text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) result means that antibodies against campylobacter have been detected. This means you have come in contact with the bacteria.</text><text>Tests are often repeated during the course of an illness to detect a rise in antibody levels. This rise helps to confirm an active infection. A low level may be a sign of a previous infection rather than current disease.</text>

item.title: Caloric stimulation
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT eat a heavy meal before the test. Avoid the following at least 24 hours before the test, because they can affect the results:</text><detail>Alcohol</detail><detail>Allergy medicines</detail><detail>Caffeine</detail><detail>Sedatives </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking your regular medicines without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be used to find the cause of:</text><detail>Dizziness or vertigo</detail><detail> Hearing loss that may be due to certain antibiotics or other drugs </detail><text>It may also be done to look for brain damage in people who are in a coma .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Rapid, side-to-side eye movements should occur when cold or warm water is placed into the ear. The eye movements should be similar on both sides.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the rapid, side-to-side eye movements do not occur even after ice cold water is given, there may be damage to the:</text><detail>Nerve of the inner ear</detail><detail>Balance sensors of the inner ear</detail><detail>Brain </detail><text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Poor blood supply to the ear</detail><detail>Bleeding (hemorrhage)</detail><detail>Blood clot</detail><detail>Brain or brain stem damage</detail><detail> Cholesteatoma (a type of skin cyst in the middle ear and mastoid bone in the skull)</detail><detail>Birth defects of the ear structure or brain</detail><detail>Damage to the ear nerves</detail><detail>Poisoning</detail><detail> Rubella that damages the acoustic nerve</detail><detail>Trauma </detail><text>The test may also be done to diagnose or rule out:</text><detail> Acoustic neuroma (tumor of the acoustic nerve)</detail><detail> Benign positional vertigo (a type of dizziness)</detail><detail> Labyrinthitis (irritation and swelling of the inner ear)</detail><detail> Meniere disease (inner ear disorder that affects balance and hearing)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Caloric test</detail><detail> Bithermal caloric testing</detail><detail> Cold water calorics</detail><detail> Warm water calorics</detail><detail> Air caloric testing</detail>

item.title: Calcium blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines that can affect the test. These medicines may include:</text><detail>Calcium salts (may be found in nutritional supplements or antacids)</detail><detail>Lithium</detail><detail>Thiazide diuretics (water pills)</detail><detail>Thyroxine</detail><detail>Vitamin D </detail><text>Drinking too much milk (2 or more quarts or 2 liters a day or a large amount of other dairy products) or taking too much vitamin D as a dietary supplement can also increase blood calcium levels.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>All cells need calcium in order to work. Calcium helps build strong bones and teeth. It is important for heart function, and helps with muscle contraction, nerve signaling, and blood clotting.</text><text>Your doctor may order this test if you have signs or symptoms of: </text><detail>Certain bone diseases</detail><detail>Certain cancers, such as multiple myeloma, a cancer of the breast, lung, neck, and kidney</detail><detail> Chronic kidney disease </detail><detail> Chronic liver disease </detail><detail>Disorders of the parathyroid glands (hormone made by these glands controls calcium and vitamin D levels in the blood)</detail><detail>Disorders that affect how your intestines absorb nutrients</detail><detail>Overactive thyroid gland or taking too much thyroid hormone medicine</detail><detail>Abnormal vitamin D level </detail><text>Your doctor may also order this test if you have been on bed rest for a long time. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values range from 8.5 to 10.2 mg/dL (2.13 to 2.55 millimol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher than normal level may be due to a number of health conditions. Common causes include:</text><detail>Being on bed rest for a long time.</detail><detail>Consuming too much calcium or vitamin D.</detail><detail> Hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid glands make too much of their hormone; often associated with a low vitamin D level).</detail><detail>Infections that cause granulomas such as tuberculosis and certain fungal and mycobacterial infections.</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma , T cell lymphoma and certain other cancers.</detail><detail> Metastatic bone tumor (bone cancer that has spread).</detail><detail>Overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism) or too much thyroid hormone replacement medicine.</detail><detail> Paget disease . Abnormal bone destruction and regrowth, causing deformity of the affected bones.</detail><detail> Sarcoidosis . Lymph nodes, lungs, liver, eyes, skin, or other tissues become swollen or inflamed.</detail><detail>Tumors producing a parathyroid hormone-like substance.</detail><detail>Use of certain medicines such as lithium, tamoxifen, and thiazides. </detail><text>A lower than normal levels may be due to:</text><detail>Disorders that affect absorption of nutrients from the intestines</detail><detail> Hypoparathyroidism (parathyroid glands do not make enough of their hormone)</detail><detail>Kidney failure</detail><detail>Low blood level of albumin</detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Magnesium deficiency</detail><detail>Pancreatitis</detail><detail>Vitamin D deficiency </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ca+2</detail><detail> Serum calcium</detail><detail> Ca++</detail><detail> Hyperparathyroidism - calcium level</detail><detail> Osteoporosis - calcium level</detail><detail> Hypercalcemia - calcium level</detail><detail> Hypocalcemia - calcium level</detail>

item.title: Calcium - urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without first talking to your provider. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Urine calcium level can help your provider:</text><detail>Decide on the best treatment for the most common type of kidney stone , which is made of calcium. This type of stone may occur when the kidney leaks too much calcium into the urine.</detail><detail>Monitor someone who has a problem with the parathyroid gland , which helps control calcium level in the blood and urine.</detail><detail>Diagnose the cause of problems with your blood calcium level or bones.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>If you are eating a normal diet, the expected amount of calcium in the urine is 100 to 300 milligrams per day (mg/day) or 2.50 to 7.50 millimoles per 24 hours (mmol/24 hours). If you are eating a diet low in calcium, the amount of calcium in the urine will be 50 to 150 mg/day or 1.25 to 3.75 mmol/24 hours.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A high level of urine calcium (above 300 mg/day) may be due to:</text><detail>Chronic kidney disease</detail><detail>High vitamin D level</detail><detail>Leaking of calcium from the kidneys into the urine, which causes calcium kidney stones</detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail><detail>Taking too much calcium</detail><detail>Too much production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands in the neck (hyperparathyroidism)</detail><detail>Use of loop diuretics </detail><text>A low level of urine calcium may be due to:</text><detail>Disorders in which the body does not absorb nutrients from food well</detail><detail>Disorders in which the kidney handles calcium abnormally</detail><detail>Parathyroid glands in the neck do not produce enough PTH (hypoparathyroidism)</detail><detail>Use of a thiazide diuretic</detail><detail>Very low level of vitamin D </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urinary Ca+2</detail><detail> Kidney stones - calcium in urine</detail><detail> Renal calculi - calcium in your urine</detail><detail> Parathyroid - calcium in urine</detail>

item.title: Calcium - ionized
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for at least 6 hours before the test. </text><text>Many medicines can interfere with blood test results.</text><detail>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of kidney or parathyroid disease. The test may also be done to monitor progress and treatment of these diseases.</text><text>Most of the time, blood tests measure your total calcium level. This looks at both ionized calcium and calcium attached to proteins. You may need to have a separate ionized calcium test if you have factors that increase or decrease total calcium levels. These may include abnormal blood levels of albumin or immunoglobulins.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results generally fall in these ranges:</text><detail>Children: 4.8 to 5.3 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or 1.20 to 1.32 millimoles per liter (millimol/L)</detail><detail>Adults: 4.8 to 5.6 mg/dL or 1.20 to 1.40 millimol/L</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher-than-normal levels of ionized calcium may be due to:</text><detail>Decreased levels of calcium in the urine from an unknown cause</detail><detail> Hyperparathyroidism </detail><detail>Hyperthyroidism</detail><detail> Milk-alkali syndrome </detail><detail> Multiple myeloma </detail><detail> Paget disease </detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail><detail>Thiazide diuretics</detail><detail>Thrombocytosis (high platelet count)</detail><detail>Tumors</detail><detail>Vitamin A excess</detail><detail> Vitamin D excess </detail><text>Lower-than-normal levels may be due to:</text><detail> Hypoparathyroidism </detail><detail> Malabsorption </detail><detail> Osteomalacia </detail><detail>Pancreatitis</detail><detail> Renal failure </detail><detail> Rickets </detail><detail>Vitamin D deficiency </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Free calcium</detail><detail> Ionized calcium</detail>

item.title: Calcitonin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is usually no special preparation needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Calcitonin is a hormone produced in C cells of the thyroid gland. The thyroid gland is located inside the front of your lower neck. Calcitonin helps control the breakdown and rebuilding of bone.</text><text>A common reason to have the test is if you have had surgery to remove a thyroid tumor called medullary cancer. The test allows your health care provider to evaluate if the tumor has spread (metastasized) or has come back (tumor recurrence).</text><text>Your provider may also order a calcitonin test when you have symptoms of medullary cancer of the thyroid or multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome, or a family history of these conditions. Calcitonin may also be higher in other tumors, such as:</text><detail> Insulinoma (tumor in the pancreas that produces too much insulin)</detail><detail>Lung cancer</detail><detail> VIPoma (cancer that usually grows from islet cells in the pancreas)</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value is less than 10 pg/mL.</text><text>Women and men can have different normal values, with men having higher values.</text><text>Sometimes, calcitonin in the blood is checked several times after you are given a shot (injection) of a special medicine that stimulates calcitonin production. </text><text>You will need this extra test if your baseline calcitonin is normal, but your provider suspects you have medullary cancer of the thyroid.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal level may indicate:</text><detail>Insulinoma</detail><detail>Lung cancer</detail><detail>Medullary cancer of thyroid (most common)</detail><detail>VIPoma </detail><text>Higher-than-normal levels of calcitonin can also occur in people with kidney disease, smokers, and higher body weight. Also, it increases when taking certain medicines to stop stomach acid production.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum calcitonin</detail>

item.title: C1 esterase inhibitor
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have signs of hereditary or acquired angioedema. Both forms of angioedema are caused by low levels of C1-INH.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Your health care provider will also measure the functional activity level of your C1 esterase inhibitor. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Low levels of C1-INH may cause certain types of angioedema.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>C1 inhibiting factor</detail><detail> C1-INH</detail>

item.title: C-reactive protein
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The CRP test is a general test to check for inflammation in the body. It is not a specific test. That means it can reveal that you have inflammation somewhere in your body, but it cannot pinpoint the exact location. The CRP test is often done with the ESR or sedimentation rate test which also looks for inflammation.</text><text>You may have this test to:</text><detail>Check for flare-ups of inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis , lupus, or vasculitis.</detail><detail>Determine if anti-inflammatory medicine is working to treat a disease or condition.</detail><text>However, a low CRP level does not always mean that there is no inflammation present. Levels of CRP may not be increased in people with rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. The reason for this is unknown.</text><text>A more sensitive CRP test, called a high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) assay, is available to determine a person's risk for heart disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal CRP values vary from lab to lab. Generally, there are low levels of CRP detectable in the blood. The levels often increase slightly with age, female gender and in African Americans.</text><text>Increased serum CRP is related to traditional cardiovascular risk factors and may reflect the role of these risk factors in causing vascular inflammation.</text><text>According to the American Heart Association, results of the hs-CRP in determining the risk for heart disease can be interpreted as follows: </text><detail>You are at low risk of developing cardiovascular disease if your hs-CRP level is lower than 1.0 mg/L.</detail><detail>You are at average risk of developing cardiovascular disease if your levels are between 1.0 mg/L and 3.0 mg/L.</detail><detail>You are at high risk for cardiovascular disease if your hs-CRP level is higher than 3.0 mg/L. </detail><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test means you have inflammation in the body. This may be due to a variety of conditions, including:</text><detail> Cancer </detail><detail>Connective tissue disease</detail><detail> Heart attack </detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)</detail><detail> Lupus </detail><detail>Pneumococcal pneumonia </detail><detail>Rheumatoid arthritis</detail><detail> Rheumatic fever </detail><detail> Tuberculosis </detail><text>This list is not all inclusive.</text><text>Note: Positive CRP results also occur during the last half of pregnancy or with the use of birth control pills (oral contraceptives).</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CRP</detail><detail> High-sensitivity C-reactive protein</detail><detail> hs-CRP</detail>

item.title: Duplex ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Usually, there is no preparation for this test.</text><text>If you are having an ultrasound of your stomach area, you may be asked not to eat or drink after midnight. Tell the person doing the ultrasound exam if you are taking any medicines, such as blood thinners. These might affect the results of the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A duplex ultrasound can show how blood flows to many parts of the body. It can also tell the width of a blood vessel and reveal any blockages. This test is a less invasive option than arteriography and venography .</text><text>A duplex ultrasound can help diagnose the following conditions:</text><detail> Abdominal aneurysm </detail><detail> Arterial occlusion </detail><detail>Blood clot</detail><detail>Carotid occlusive disease (See: Carotid duplex )</detail><detail> Renal vascular disease </detail><detail> Varicose veins </detail><detail> Venous insufficiency </detail><text>A renal duplex ultrasound can also be used after transplant surgery. This shows how well a new kidney is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is normal blood flow through the veins and arteries. There is normal blood pressure and no sign of a narrowing or blockage of a blood vessel.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result depends on the specific area being examined. An abnormal result may be due to a blood clot or plaque buildup in a blood vessel.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Vascular ultrasound</detail><detail> Peripheral vascular ultrasound</detail>

item.title: Doppler ultrasound exam of an arm or leg
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need to remove clothes from the arm or leg being examined.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done as the first step to look at arteries and veins. Sometimes, arteriography and venography may be needed later. The test is done to help diagnose:</text><detail> Arteriosclerosis of the arms or legs </detail><detail> Blood clot (deep vein thrombosis)</detail><detail> Venous insufficiency </detail><text>The test may also be used to:</text><detail>Look at injury to the arteries </detail><detail>Monitor arterial reconstruction and bypass grafts</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the blood vessels show no signs of narrowing, clots, or closure, and the arteries have normal blood flow.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Blockage in an artery by a blood clot </detail><detail>Blood clot in a vein (DVT)</detail><detail>Narrowing or widening of an artery</detail><detail>Spastic arterial disease (arterial contractions brought on by cold or emotion)</detail><detail>Venous occlusion (closing of a vein) </detail><detail>Venous reflux (blood flow going the wrong direction in veins)</detail><detail>Arterial occlusion from atherosclerosis</detail><text>This test may also be done to help assess the following conditions:</text><detail> Arteriosclerosis of the extremities </detail><detail> Deep venous thrombosis </detail><detail> Superficial thrombophlebitis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Peripheral vascular disease - Doppler</detail><detail> PVD - Doppler</detail><detail> PAD - Doppler</detail><detail> Blockage of leg arteries - Doppler</detail><detail> Intermittent claudication - Doppler</detail><detail> Arterial insufficiency of the legs - Doppler</detail><detail> Leg pain and cramping - Doppler</detail><detail> Calf pain - Doppler</detail><detail> Venous Doppler - DVT</detail>

item.title: Donath-Landsteiner test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to confirm a diagnosis of paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test is considered normal if no Donath-Landsteiner antibodies are present. This is called a negative result.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean Donath-Landsteiner antibodies are present. This is a sign of paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Anti-P antibody</detail><detail> Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria - Donath-Landsteiner</detail>

item.title: Digoxin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Ask your health care provider whether you should take your usual medicines before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The main purpose of this test is to determine the best dosage of digoxin and prevent side effects.</text><text>It is important to monitor the level of digitalis medicines such as digoxin. That is because the difference between a safe treatment level and a harmful level is small.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In general, normal values range from 0.5 to 1.9 nanograms per milliliter of blood. But the right level for some people may vary depending on the situation.</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean you are getting too little or too much digoxin.</text><text>A very high value could mean that you have or are likely to develop a digoxin overdose (toxicity).</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Heart failure - digoxin test</detail>

item.title: Digital rectal exam
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>For the test, the provider will ask you to:</text><detail>Try to relax</detail><detail>Take a deep breath during the insertion of the finger into your rectum </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is performed for many reasons. It may be done: </text><detail>As part of a routine yearly physical exam in both men and women</detail><detail>When your provider suspects you are bleeding somewhere in your digestive tract</detail><detail>When men are having symptoms that suggest the prostate is enlarged or you may have a prostate infection </detail><text>In men, the test can be used to check the size of the prostate and to look for abnormal bumps or other changes of the prostate gland.</text><text>A digital rectal exam may be done to collect stool for testing for fecal occult (hidden) blood as part of screening for cancer of the rectum or colon.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal finding means the provider did not detect any problem during the exam. However, this test does not rule out all problems.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may be due to:</text><detail>A prostate problem, such as an enlarged prostate gland , prostate infection , or prostate cancer </detail><detail>Bleeding anywhere in the digestive tract</detail><detail>Cancer of the rectum or colon</detail><detail> Small split or tear in the thin moist tissue lining of the anus (called anal fissure)</detail><detail>An abscess , when pus collects in the area of the anus and rectum </detail><detail> Hemorrhoids , swollen veins in the anus or lower part of the rectum</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>DRE</detail>

item.title: Diagnostic laparoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions on not eating and drinking before surgery.</text><text>You may need to stop taking medicines, including narcotic pain relievers, on or before the day of the exam. Do not change or stop taking any medicines without first talking to your health care provider.</text><text>Follow any other instructions for how to prepare for the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Diagnostic laparoscopy is often done for the following:</text><detail>Find the cause of pain or a growth in the abdomen and pelvic area when x-ray or ultrasound results aren't clear.</detail><detail>After an accident to see if there is injury to the abdomen.</detail><detail>Before procedures to treat cancer to find out if the cancer has spread. If so, treatment will change.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The laparoscopy is normal if there is no blood in the abdomen, no hernias, no intestinal obstruction, and no cancer in any visible organs. The uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries are of normal size, shape, and color. The liver is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to a number of different conditions, including:</text><detail> Scar tissue inside the abdomen or pelvis ( adhesions )</detail><detail>Appendicitis</detail><detail>Cells from inside the uterus grow in other areas ( endometriosis )</detail><detail>Inflammation of the gallbladder (cholecystitis)</detail><detail> Ovarian cysts or cancer of the ovary</detail><detail>Infection of the the womb, ovaries, or fallopian tubes ( pelvic inflammatory disease )</detail><detail>Signs of injury</detail><detail>Spread of cancer</detail><detail>Tumors</detail><detail>Noncancerous tumors of the womb ( uterine fibroids )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Laparoscopy - diagnostic</detail><detail> Exploratory laparoscopy</detail>

item.title: DHEA-sulfate test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary. However, tell your health care provider if you are taking any vitamins or supplements that contain DHEA or DHEA-sulfate.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check the function of the two adrenal glands . One of these glands sits above each kidney. They are one of the major sources of androgens in women.</text><text>Although DHEA-sulfate is the most abundant hormone in the body, its exact function is still not known.</text><detail>In men, the male hormone effect may not be important if testosterone level is normal.</detail><detail>In women, DHEA contributes to normal libido and sexual satisfaction.</detail><detail>DHEA may also have effects on the immune system. </detail><text>The DHEA-sulfate test is often done in women who show signs of having excess male hormones. Some of these signs are male body changes, excess hair growth, oily skin, acne, irregular periods, or problems becoming pregnant.</text><text>It may also be done in women who are concerned about low libido or decreased sexual satisfaction who have pituitary or adrenal gland disorders.</text><text>The test is also done in children who are maturing too early (precocious puberty).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal blood levels of DHEA-sulfate can differ by sex and age.</text><text>Typical normal ranges for females are:</text><detail>Ages 18 to 19: 145 to 395 micrograms per deciliter (µg/dL) or 3.92 to 10.66 micromoles per liter (µmol/L)</detail><detail>Ages 20 to 29: 65 to 380 µg/dL or 1.75 to 10.26 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 30 to 39: 45 to 270 µg/dL or 1.22 to 7.29 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 40 to 49: 32 to 240 µg/dL or 0.86 to 6.48 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 50 to 59: 26 to 200 µg/dL or 0.70 to 5.40 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 60 to 69: 13 to 130 µg/dL or 0.35 to 3.51 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 69 and older: 17 to 90 µg/dL or 0.46 to 2.43 µmol/L</detail><text>Typical normal ranges for males are:</text><detail>Ages 18 to 19: 108 to 441 µg/dL or 2.92 to 11.91 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 20 to 29: 280 to 640 µg/dL or 7.56 to 17.28 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 30 to 39: 120 to 520 µg/dL or 3.24 to 14.04 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 40 to 49: 95 to 530 µg/dL or 2.56 to 14.31 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 50 to 59: 70 to 310 µg/dL or 1.89 to 8.37 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 60 to 69: 42 to 290 µg/dL or 1.13 to 7.83 µmol/L</detail><detail>Ages 69 and older: 28 to 175 µg/dL or 0.76 to 4.72 µmol/L</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different specimens. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increase in DHEA-sulfate may be due to:</text><detail>A common genetic disorder called congenital adrenal hyperplasia .</detail><detail>A tumor of the adrenal gland, which can be benign or be a cancer.</detail><detail>A common problem in women younger than 50, called polycystic ovary syndrome .</detail><detail> Body changes of a girl in puberty happening earlier than normal. </detail><text>A decrease in DHEA sulfate may be due to:</text><detail> Adrenal gland disorders that produce lower than normal amounts of adrenal hormones, including adrenal insufficiency and Addison disease </detail><detail>The pituitary gland not producing normal amounts of its hormones ( hypopituitarism )</detail><detail>Taking glucocorticoid medicines </detail><text>DHEA levels normally decline with age in both men and women. There is no reliable evidence that taking DHEA supplements prevents aging-related conditions.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum DHEA-sulfate</detail><detail> Dehydroepiandrosterone-sulfate test</detail><detail> DHEA-sulfate - serum</detail>

item.title: Dexamethasone suppression test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The provider may tell you to stop taking certain medicines that can affect the test, including:</text><detail>Antibiotics</detail><detail>Anti-seizure drugs</detail><detail>Medicines that contain corticosteroids, such as hydrocortisone, prednisone</detail><detail>Estrogen</detail><detail>Oral birth control (contraceptives)</detail><detail>Water pills (diuretics) </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done when the provider suspects that your body is producing too much cortisol. It is done to help diagnose Cushing syndrome and identify the cause.</text><text>The low-dose test can help tell whether your body is producing too much ACTH. The high-dose test can help determine whether the problem is in the pituitary gland ( Cushing disease ).</text><text>Dexamethasone is a man-made (synthetic) steroid that is similar to cortisol. It reduces ACTH release in normal people. Therefore, taking dexamethasone should reduce ACTH level and lead to a decreased cortisol level.</text><text>If your pituitary gland produces too much ACTH, you will have an abnormal response to the low-dose test. But you can have a normal response to the high-dose test.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Cortisol level should decrease after you receive dexamethasone.</text><text>Low dose:</text><detail>Overnight -- 8 a.m. plasma cortisol lower than 1.8 micrograms per deciliter (mcg/dL) or 50 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L)</detail><detail>Standard -- Urinary free cortisol on day 3 lower than 10 micrograms per day (mcg/day) or 280 nmol/L</detail><text>High dose:</text><detail>Overnight -- greater than 50% reduction in plasma cortisol</detail><detail>Standard -- greater than 90% reduction in urinary free cortisol </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal response to the low-dose test may mean that you have abnormal release of cortisol (Cushing syndrome). This could be due to:</text><detail> Adrenal tumor that produces cortisol</detail><detail> Pituitary tumor that produces ACTH</detail><detail>Tumor in the body that produces ACTH ( ectopic Cushing syndrome )</detail><text>The high-dose test can help tell a pituitary cause (Cushing disease) from other causes. An ACTH blood test may also help identify the cause of high cortisol.</text><text>Abnormal results vary based on the condition causing the problem.</text><text>Cushing syndrome caused by an adrenal tumor:</text><detail>Low-dose test -- no decrease in blood cortisol</detail><detail>ACTH level -- low</detail><detail>In most cases, the high-dose test is not needed </detail><text>Ectopic Cushing syndrome:</text><detail>Low-dose test -- no decrease in blood cortisol</detail><detail>ACTH level -- high</detail><detail>High-dose test -- no decrease in blood cortisol</detail><text>Cushing syndrome caused by a pituitary tumor (Cushing disease)</text><detail>Low-dose test -- no decrease in blood cortisol</detail><detail>High-dose test -- expected decrease in blood cortisol</detail><text>False test results can occur due to many reasons, including different medicines, obesity, depression, and stress.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>DST</detail><detail> ACTH suppression test</detail><detail> Cortisol suppression test</detail>

item.title: Dental x-rays
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation. You need to remove any metal objects in the area of the x-ray exposure. A lead apron may be placed over your body. Tell your dentist if you might be pregnant.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Dental x-rays help diagnose disease and injury of the teeth and gums as well as help planning the appropriate treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal x-rays show a normal number, structure, and position of the teeth and jaw bones. There are no cavities or other problems.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Dental x-rays may be used to identify the following:</text><detail>The number, size, and position of teeth</detail><detail>Partially or fully impacted teeth </detail><detail>The presence and severity of tooth decay (called cavities or dental caries)</detail><detail>Bone damage (such as from gum disease called periodontitis )</detail><detail> Abscessed teeth </detail><detail> Fractured jaw </detail><detail>Problems in the way the upper and lower teeth fit together ( malocclusion )</detail><detail>Other abnormalities of the teeth and jaw bones </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - teeth</detail><detail> Radiograph - dental</detail><detail> Bitewings</detail><detail> Periapical film</detail><detail> Panoramic film</detail><detail> Cephalometric x-ray</detail><detail> Digital image</detail>

item.title: Dental plaque identification at home
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Brush and floss your teeth thoroughly.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test helps identify missed plaque. It can encourage you to improve your brushing and flossing so that you remove more plaque from your teeth. Plaque that remains on your teeth can cause tooth decay or make your gums bleed easily and become red or swollen.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No plaque or food debris will be seen on your teeth.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The tablets will stain areas of plaque dark red.</text><text>The plaque light solution will color the plaque a bright orange-yellow.</text><text>The colored areas show where brushing and flossing was not sufficient. These areas need to be brushed again to get rid of the stained plaque.</text>

item.title: Delta-ALA urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking any medicines that can affect test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Penicillin (an antibiotic)</detail><detail>Barbiturates (medicines to treat anxiety)</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Griseofulvin (medicine to treat fungal infections)</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test looks for an increased level of delta-ALA. It may be used to help diagnose a condition called porphyria .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value range for adults is 1.0 to 7.0 mg (7.6 to 53.3 mol/L) over 24 hours.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly from one lab to another. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased level of urinary delta-ALA may indicate:</text><detail>Lead poisoning</detail><detail>Porphyria (several types)</detail><text> A decreased level may occur with chronic (long-term) liver disease .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Delta-aminolevulinic acid</detail>

item.title: D-xylose absorption
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Do not eat or drink anything (even water) for 8 to 12 hours before the test. Your provider will ask you to rest during the test. A failure to restrict activity may affect test results.</text><text>Your provider may tell you to stop taking certain medicines that can affect test results. Medicines that can affect test results include aspirin, atropine, indomethacin, isocarboxazid, and phenelzine. DO NOT stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have:</text><detail>Persistent diarrhea</detail><detail>Signs of malnutrition</detail><detail>Unexplained weight loss </detail><text>This test is primarily used to check if nutrient absorption problems are due to a disease of the intestines.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result depends on how much D-xylose is given. In most cases, the test results are either positive or negative. A positive result means that D-xylose is found in the blood or urine and is therefore being absorbed by the intestines.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Lower than normal values may be seen in:</text><detail> Celiac disease (sprue) </detail><detail> Crohn disease </detail><detail> Giardia lamblia infestation</detail><detail> Hookworm infestation</detail><detail> Lymphatic obstruction </detail><detail> Radiation enteropathy </detail><detail>Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth</detail><detail> Viral gastroenteritis </detail><detail> Whipple disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Xylose tolerance test</detail><detail> Diarrhea - xylose</detail><detail> Malnutrition - xylose</detail><detail> Sprue - xylose</detail><detail> Celiac - xylose</detail>

item.title: D-dimer test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order a D-dimer test if you are showing symptoms of blood clots, such as:</text><detail>Swelling, pain, warmth, and changes in skin color of your leg</detail><detail>Sharp chest pain, trouble breathing, coughing up blood, and fast heart beat</detail><detail>Bleeding gums, nausea and vomiting, seizures, severe stomach and muscle pain, and decreased urine</detail><text>Your provider may also use the D-dimer test to see if treatment for DIC is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test is negative. This means that you probably do not have problems with blood clotting.</text><text>If you are getting the D-dimer test to see if treatment is working for DIC, a normal or decreasing level of D-dimer means the treatment is working.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test means that you may be making blood clots. The test does not tell where the clots are or why you are making clots. Your provider may order other tests to see where clots are located.</text><text>A positive test may be caused by other factors, and you may not have any clots. D-dimer levels can be positive due to:</text><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Recent surgery or trauma</detail><detail>High lipid or triglyceride levels</detail><detail>Heart disease</detail><detail>Being over 80 years old</detail><text>This makes the test mostly useful when it is negative, when many of the above causes can be ruled out.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Fragment D-dimer</detail><detail> Fibrin degradation fragment</detail><detail> DVT - D-dimer</detail><detail> PE - D-dimer</detail><detail> Deep vein thrombosis - D-dimer</detail><detail> Pulmonary embolism - D-dimer</detail><detail> Blood clot to the lungs - D-dimer</detail>

item.title: Eye and orbit ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have cataracts or other eye problems.</text><text>An A-scan ultrasound measures the eye to determine the right power of a lens implant before cataract surgery .</text><text>A B-scan is done to look at the inside part of the eye or the space behind the eye that cannot be seen directly. This may occur when you have cataracts or other conditions that make it hard for the doctor to see into the back of your eye. The test may help diagnose retinal detachment , tumors, or other disorders.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>For an A-scan, measurements of the eye are in the normal range.</text><text>For a B-scan, the structures of the eye and orbit appear normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A B-scan may show:</text><detail>Bleeding into the clear gel (vitreous) that fills the back of the eye (vitreous hemorrhage)</detail><detail>Cancer of the retina ( retinoblastoma ), under the retina, or in other parts of the eye (such as melanoma )</detail><detail>Damaged tissue or injuries in the bony socket (orbit) that surrounds and protects the eye</detail><detail>Foreign bodies</detail><detail>Pulling away of the retina from the back of the eye ( retinal detachment )</detail><detail>Swelling (inflammation) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Echography - eye orbit</detail><detail> Ultrasound - eye orbit</detail><detail> Ocular ultrasonography</detail><detail> Orbital ultrasonography</detail>

item.title: Extremity x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your provider if you are pregnant. Remove all jewelry from the area being imaged.</text><text>In general, there is no discomfort. You may be slightly uncomfortable while the leg or arm is put in place for the x-ray.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of:</text><detail>A fracture </detail><detail>Tumor</detail><detail> Arthritis (inflammation of the joints) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The x-ray shows normal structures for the age of the person.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Bone conditions that get worse over time (degenerative)</detail><detail> Bone tumor </detail><detail>Broken bone (fracture)</detail><detail>Dislocated bone</detail><detail> Osteomyelitis (infection) </detail><detail>Arthritis</detail><text>Other conditions for which the test may be performed:</text><detail> Clubfoot </detail><detail>To detect foreign objects in the body </detail>

item.title: Extremity angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test.</text><text>You may be told to stop taking certain medicines, such as aspirin or other blood thinners for a short while before the test. Never stop taking any medicines unless told to do so by your provider.</text><text>Make sure your provider knows about all the medicines you take, including those you bought without a prescription. This includes herbs and supplements.</text><text>Tell your provider if you:</text><detail>Are pregnant</detail><detail>Are allergic to any medicines</detail><detail>Have ever had an allergic reaction to x-ray contrast material, shellfish, or iodine substances</detail><detail>Have ever had any bleeding problems </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may need this test if you have symptoms of a narrowed or blocked blood vessel in the arms, hands, legs, or feet.</text><text>The test may also be done to diagnose:</text><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Swelling or inflammation of the blood vessels (vasculitis) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The x-ray shows normal structures for your age.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result is commonly due to narrowing and hardening of the arteries in the arms or legs from plaque buildup ( hardening of the arteries ) in the artery walls.</text><text>The x-ray may show a blockage in the vessels caused by:</text><detail> Aneurysms (abnormal widening or ballooning of part of an artery)</detail><detail> Blood clots </detail><detail>Other diseases of the arteries </detail><text>Abnormal results may also be due to:</text><detail>Inflammation of the blood vessels</detail><detail>Injury to the blood vessels</detail><detail> Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger disease)</detail><detail> Takayasu disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Angiography of the extremity</detail><detail> Peripheral angiography</detail><detail> Lower extremity angiogram</detail><detail> Peripheral angiogram</detail><detail> Arteriography of the extremity</detail><detail> PAD - angiography</detail><detail> Peripheral artery disease - angiography</detail>

item.title: Extraocular muscle function testing
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is performed to evaluate weakness or other problem in the extraocular muscles. These problems may result in double vision or rapid, uncontrolled eye movements .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal movement of the eyes in all directions.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Eye movement disorders may be due to abnormalities of the muscles themselves. They may also be due to problems in the sections of the brain that control these muscles. Your provider will talk to you about any abnormalities that may be found.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>EOM</detail><detail> Extraocular movement</detail><detail> Ocular motility examination</detail>

item.title: Exercise stress test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Wear comfortable shoes and loose clothing to allow you to exercise.</text><text>Ask your provider if you should take any of your regular medicines on the day of the test. Some medicines may interfere with test results. Never stop taking any medicine without first talking to your doctor.</text><text>Tell your doctor if you are taking sildenafil citrate (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis), or vardenafil (Levitra) and have taken a dose within the past 24 to 48 hours.</text><text>You must not eat, smoke, or drink beverages containing caffeine or alcohol for 3 hours (or more) before the test. In most cases, you will be asked to avoid caffeine for 24 hours before the test. This includes:</text><detail>Tea and coffee</detail><detail>All sodas, even ones that are labeled caffeine-free</detail><detail>Chocolates</detail><detail>Certain pain relievers that contain caffeine </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Reasons why an exercise stress test may be performed include:</text><detail>You are having chest pain (to check for coronary artery disease, narrowing of the arteries that feed the heart muscle).</detail><detail>Your angina is getting worse or is happening more often.</detail><detail>You have had a heart attack.</detail><detail>You have had angioplasty or heart bypass surgery .</detail><detail>You are going to start an exercise program and you have heart disease or certain risk factors, such as diabetes.</detail><detail>To identify heart rhythm changes that may occur during exercise.</detail><detail>To further test for a heart valve problem (such as aortic valve or mitral valve stenosis ). </detail><text>There may be other reasons why your provider asks for this test.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal test will most often mean that you were able to exercise as long as or longer than most people of your age and gender. You also did not have symptoms or concerning changes in blood pressure or your ECG.</text><text>The meaning of your test results depends on the reason for the test, your age, and your history of heart and other medical problems.</text><text>It may be hard to interpret the results of an exercise-only stress test in some people.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Abnormal heart rhythms during exercise</detail><detail>Changes in your ECG that may mean there is a blockage in the arteries that supply your heart ( coronary artery disease ) </detail><text>When you have an abnormal exercise stress test, you may have other tests performed on your heart such as:</text><detail> Cardiac catheterization </detail><detail> Nuclear stress test </detail><detail> Stress echocardiography </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Exercise ECG</detail><detail> ECG - exercise treadmill</detail><detail> EKG - exercise treadmill</detail><detail> Stress ECG</detail><detail> Exercise electrocardiography</detail><detail> Stress test - exercise treadmill</detail><detail> CAD - treadmill</detail><detail> Coronary artery disease - treadmill</detail><detail> Chest pain - treadmill</detail><detail> Angina - treadmill</detail><detail> Heart disease - treadmill</detail>

item.title: Euglobulin lysis time
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow the instructions that tell you how long before the test you need to stop exercising. Heavy exercise can cause a shorter-than-normal ELT time.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This is one of the best tests to tell the difference between primary fibrinolysis and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Primary fibrinolysis is the normal breakdown of blood clots. DIC is disease that prevents blood from clotting normally.</text><text>The test can also be used to monitor people who are taking streptokinase or urokinase after a heart attack. These are medicines that prevent blood clots.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value will range from 90 minutes to 6 hours. Euglobulin clot lysis is normally complete within 2 to 4 hours.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A longer-than-normal ELT time may be due to:</text><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail> Prematurity (baby being born too early) </detail><text>A shorter-than-normal ELT time may be due to:</text><detail>Blood vessel injury or surgery</detail><detail> Cancer of the prostate </detail><detail>Liver cirrhosis </detail><detail> Fibrinogen deficiency (fibrinogen is a protein in the blood that helps it clot)</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Pregnancy complications (for example, antepartum hemorrhage, hydatidiform mole , amniotic embolism )</detail><detail> Shock </detail><detail>A bleeding disorder called thrombocytopenia purpura </detail><text>The test may also be done to diagnose or rule out:</text><detail> Miscarriage</detail><detail>A bone marrow disorder called primary thrombocythemia </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Euglobulin clot lysis</detail><detail> Fibrinolysis/euglobulin lysis</detail><detail> ELT</detail>

item.title: Ethylene glycol blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is ordered when a health care provider thinks someone has been poisoned by ethylene glycol. Drinking ethylene glycol is a medical emergency. Ethylene glycol can damage the brain, liver, kidneys, and lungs. The poisoning disturbs the body's chemistry and can lead to condition called metabolic acidosis . In severe cases, shock, organ failure, and death can result.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There should be no ethylene glycol present in the blood.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results are a sign of possible ethylene glycol poisoning.</text>

item.title: Estradiol blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking certain medicines that may affect test results. Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include:</text><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Antibiotics such as ampicillin or tetracycline</detail><detail>Corticosteroids</detail><detail>DHEA (a supplement)</detail><detail>Estrogen</detail><detail>Medicine to manage mental disorders (such as phenothiazine)</detail><detail>Testosterone </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your doctor.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>In women, most estradiol is released from the ovaries and adrenal glands. It is also released by the placenta during pregnancy. Estradiol is also produced in other body tissues, such as skin, fat, cells bone, brain, and liver. Estradiol plays a role in: </text><detail>Growth of the womb (uterus), fallopian tubes, and vagina</detail><detail>Breast development</detail><detail>Changes of the outer genitals</detail><detail>Distribution of body fat</detail><detail>Menopause </detail><text>In men, a small amount of estradiol is mainly released by the testes.
