Estradiol helps prevent sperm from dying too early. </text><text>This test may be ordered to check:</text><detail>How well your ovaries, placenta, or adrenal glands work</detail><detail>If you have signs of an ovarian tumor</detail><detail>If male or female body characteristics are not developing normally</detail><detail>If your periods have stopped (levels of estradiol vary, depending on the time of month) </detail><text>The test may also be ordered to check if:</text><detail>Hormone therapy is working for women in menopause </detail><detail>A woman is responding to fertility treatment </detail><text>The test may also be used to monitor people with hypopituitarism and women on certain fertility treatments.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The results may vary, depending on the person's gender and age.</text><detail>Male - 10 to 50 pg/mL (36.7 to 183.6 pmol/L)</detail><detail>Female (premenopausal) - 30 to 400 pg/mL (110 to 1468.4 pmol/L)</detail><detail>Female (postmenopausal) - 0 to 30 pg/mL (0 to 110 pmol/L) </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Disorders that are associated with abnormal estradiol results include:</text><detail> Early (precocious) puberty in girls</detail><detail>Growth of abnormally large breasts in men ( gynecomastia )</detail><detail>Lack of periods in women ( amenorrhea )</detail><detail>Reduced function of the ovaries ( ovarian hypofunction )</detail><detail>Problem with genes, such as Klinefelter syndrome , Turner syndrome </detail><detail>Rapid weight loss or low body fat </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>E2 test</detail>

item.title: ESR
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There are no special steps needed to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Reasons why a "sed rate" may be done include:</text><detail>Unexplained fevers</detail><detail>Certain types of arthritis</detail><detail>Muscle symptoms</detail><detail>Other vague symptoms that cannot be explained</detail><text>This test may also be used to monitor whether an illness is responding to treatment. </text><text>This test can be used to monitor inflammatory diseases or cancer. It is not used to diagnose a specific disorder.</text><text>However, the test is useful for detecting and monitoring:</text><detail>Autoimmune disorders</detail><detail>Bone infections</detail><detail>Certain forms of arthritis</detail><detail>Inflammatory diseases that cause vague symptoms</detail><detail>Tissue death</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>For adults (Westergren method):</text><detail>Men under 50 years old: less than 15 mm/hr</detail><detail>Men over 50 years old: less than 20 mm/hr</detail><detail>Women under 50 years old: less than 20 mm/hr</detail><detail>Women over 50 years old: less than 30 mm/hr </detail><text>For children (Westergren method):</text><detail>Newborn: 0 to 2 mm/hr</detail><detail>Newborn to puberty: 3 to 13 mm/hr </detail><text>Note: mm/hr = millimeters per hour</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal ESR may help with a diagnosis, but it does not prove that you have a certain condition. Other tests are almost always needed.</text><text>An increased ESR rate may be due to:</text><detail> Anemia </detail><detail>Cancers such as lymphoma or multiple myeloma </detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>Thyroid disease </detail><text>The immune system helps protect the body against harmful substances. An autoimmune disorder is when the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys healthy body tissue. ESR is often higher than normal in people with an autoimmune disorder.</text><text>Common autoimmune disorders include:</text><detail> Lupus </detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis in adults or children </detail><text>Very high ESR levels occur with less common autoimmune disorders, including:</text><detail>Allergic vasculitis</detail><detail> Giant cell arteritis </detail><detail>Hyperfibrinogenemia (increased fibrinogen levels in the blood)</detail><detail> Macroglobulinemia - primary </detail><detail> Necrotizing vasculitis </detail><detail> Polymyalgia rheumatica </detail><text>An increased ESR rate may be due to some infections, including:</text><detail>Bodywide (systemic) infection</detail><detail> Bone infections </detail><detail> Infection of the heart or heart valves </detail><detail> Rheumatic fever </detail><detail>Severe skin infections, such as erysipelas </detail><detail>Tuberculosis</detail><text>Lower-than-normal levels occur with:</text><detail> Congestive heart failure </detail><detail> Hyperviscosity </detail><detail> Hypofibrinogenemia (decreased fibrinogen levels)</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Low plasma protein (due to liver or kidney disease)</detail><detail> Polycythemia </detail><detail> Sickle cell anemia </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate</detail><detail> Sed rate</detail><detail> Sedimentation rate</detail>

item.title: Esophageal pH monitoring
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will ask you to not eat or drink after midnight before the test. You should also avoid smoking.</text><text>Some medicines may change the test results. Your provider may ask you to not take these for between 24 hours and 2 weeks (or more) before the test. You also may be told to avoid alcohol. Medicines that you may need to stop include:</text><detail>Adrenergic blockers</detail><detail>Antacids</detail><detail>Anticholinergics</detail><detail>Cholinergics</detail><detail>Corticosteroids</detail><detail>H<sub>2</sub> blockers</detail><detail>Proton pump inhibitors </detail><text>DO NOT stop taking any medicine unless told to do so by your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Esophageal pH monitoring is used to check how much stomach acid is entering the esophagus. It also checks how well the acid is cleared downward into the stomach. It is a test for gastroesophageal reflux disease ( GERD ).</text><text>In infants, this test is also used to check for GERD and other problems related to excessive crying . </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary depending on the lab doing the test. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased acid in the esophagus may be related to: </text><detail> Barrett esophagus </detail><detail> Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) </detail><detail>Esophageal scarring</detail><detail>Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)</detail><detail> Heartburn </detail><detail>Reflux esophagitis </detail><text>You may need to have the following tests if your provider suspects esophagitis : </text><detail> Barium swallow </detail><detail> Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (also called upper GI endoscopy) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>pH monitoring - esophageal</detail><detail> Esophageal acidity test</detail>

item.title: Esophageal manometry
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not have anything to eat or drink for 8 hours before the test. If you have the test in the morning, DO NOT eat or drink after midnight.</text><text>Tell your health care provider about all medicines you are taking. These include vitamins, herbs, and other over-the-counter medicines and supplements.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The esophagus is the tube that carries food from your mouth into the stomach. When you swallow, muscles in your esophagus squeeze (contract) to push food toward the stomach. Valves, or sphincters, inside the esophagus open to let food and liquid through. They then close to prevent food, fluids, and stomach acid from moving backward. The sphincter at the bottom of the esophagus is called the lower esophageal sphincter, or LES.</text><text>Esophageal manometry is done to see if the esophagus is contracting and relaxing properly. The test helps diagnose swallowing problems. During the test, the doctor can also check the LES to see if it opens and closes properly. </text><text>The test may be ordered if you have symptoms of:</text><detail>Heartburn or nausea after eating ( gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD )</detail><detail>Problems swallowing (feeling like food is stuck behind the breast bone) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The LES pressure and muscle contractions are normal when you swallow.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate:</text><detail>A problem with the esophagus that affects its ability to move food toward the stomach ( achalasia )</detail><detail>A weak LES, which causes heartburn (GERD)</detail><detail>Abnormal contractions of the esophagus muscles that do not effectively move food to the stomach ( esophageal spasm )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Esophageal motility studies</detail><detail> Esophageal function studies </detail>

item.title: Esophageal culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your health care provider's instructions on how to prepare for EGD.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order this test if you have signs or symptoms of an esophageal infection or disease. You may also have the test if an ongoing infection does not get better with treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means that no germs grew in the laboratory dish.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means germs grew in the laboratory dish. This is a sign of an infection of the esophagus, which may be due to bacteria, a virus, or a fungus.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - esophageal</detail>

item.title: Erythropoietin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be used to help determine the cause of anemia, polycythemia (high red blood cell count) or other bone marrow disorders.</text><text>A change in red blood cells will affect the release of EPO. For example, people with anemia have too few red blood cells, so more EPO is produced.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 2.6 to 18.5 milliunits per milliliter (mU/mL).</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased EPO level may be due to secondary polycythemia. This is an overproduction of red blood cells that occurs in response to an event such as low blood oxygen level. The condition may occur at high altitudes or, rarely, because of a tumor that releases EPO.</text><text>Lower-than-normal EPO level may be seen in chronic kidney failure , anemia of chronic disease , or polycythemia vera .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum erythropoietin</detail><detail> EPO</detail>

item.title: Epstein-Barr virus antibody test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to detect an infection with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). EBV causes mononucleosis or mono. The EBV antibody test detects not only a recent infection, but also one that occurred in the past. It can be used to tell the difference between a recent or previous infection.</text><text>Another test for mononucleosis is called the spot test . It is done when a person has current symptoms of mononucleosis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no antibodies to EBV were seen in your blood sample. This result means you have never been infected with EBV.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive result means there are antibodies to EBV in your blood. This indicates a current or prior infection with EBV.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>EBV antibody test</detail><detail> EBV serology</detail>

item.title: Eosinophil count - absolute
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time, adults do not need to take special steps before this test. Tell your provider the medicines you are taking, including the ones without a prescription. Some drugs may change the test results.</text><text>Medicines that may cause you to have an increase in eosinophils include:</text><detail>Amphetamines (appetite suppressants)</detail><detail>Certain laxatives containing psyllium</detail><detail>Certain antibiotics</detail><detail>Interferon</detail><detail>Tranquilizers</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You will have this test to see if you have abnormal results from a blood differential test. This test may also be done if the provider thinks you may have a specific disease.</text><text>This test may help diagnose:</text><detail>Acute hypereosinophilic syndrome (a rare, but sometimes fatal leukemia-like condition)</detail><detail>An allergic reaction (can also reveal how severe the reaction is)</detail><detail>Early stages of Cushing disease </detail><detail>Infection by a parasite </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal eosinophil count is less than 500 cells per microliter (cells/mcL).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The example above shows the common measurements for results of these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean:
A high number of eosinophils (eosinophilia) are often linked to a variety of disorders. A high eosinophil count may be due to:Allergic diseaseParasite infection, such as wormsCertain fungus infections Asthma Autoimmune diseases Eczema Hay fever Leukemia and other blood disordersHypereosinophilic syndrome
A lower-than-normal eosinophil count may be due to:Alcohol intoxicationOverproduction of certain steroids in the body (such as cortisol)
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Eosinophils</detail><detail> Absolute eosinophil count</detail>

item.title: Enteroscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Do not take products containing aspirin for 1 week before the procedure. Tell your health care provider if you take blood thinners such as warfarin (Coumadin) or clopidogrel (Plavix), because these may interfere with the test. Do NOT stop taking any medicine unless told to do so by your provider.</text><text>Do not eat any solid foods or milk products after midnight the day of your procedure. You may have clear liquids until 4 hours before your exam.</text><text>You must sign a consent form.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often performed to help diagnose diseases of the small intestines. It may be done if you have:</text><detail>Abnormal x-ray results</detail><detail>Tumors in the small intestines</detail><detail>Unexplained diarrhea</detail><detail>Unexplained gastrointestinal bleeding</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>In a normal test result, the provider will not find sources of bleeding in the small bowel, and will not find any tumors or other abnormal tissue.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean:
Signs may include:Abnormalities of the tissue lining the small intestine (mucosa) or the tiny, finger-like projections on the surface of the small intestine (villi)Abnormal lengthening of blood vessels (angiectasis) in the intestinal liningImmune cells called PAS-positive macrophages Polyps or cancer Radiation enteritis Swollen or enlarged lymph nodes or lymphatic vesselsUlcersChanges found on enteroscopy may be signs of disorders and conditions, including: Amyloidosis Celiac sprue Crohn disease Folate or vitamin B12 deficiency Giardiasis Infectious gastroenteritis Lymphangiectasia Lymphoma Small intestinal angiectasiaSmall intestinal cancer
 Tropical sprue Whipple disease
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Small bowel biopsy</detail><detail> Push enteroscopy</detail><detail> Double-balloon enteroscopy</detail><detail> Capsule enteroscopy</detail>

item.title: Enteroclysis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow your provider's instructions on how to prepare for the test, which may include:</text><detail>Drinking clear liquids for at least 24 hours before the test.</detail><detail>Not eating or drinking anything for several hours before the test. Your provider will tell you exactly how many hours.</detail><detail>Taking laxatives to clear the bowels.</detail><detail>Not taking certain medicines. Your provider will tell you which ones. Do NOT stop taking any medicines on your own. Ask your provider first.</detail><text>If you are anxious about the procedure, you may be given a sedative before it starts. You will be asked to remove all jewelry and wear a hospital gown. It is best to leave jewelry and other valuables at home. You will be asked to remove any removable dental work, such as appliances, bridges, or retainers.</text><text>If you are, or think you're pregnant, tell the provider before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is performed to examine the small bowel. It is the most complete way of telling if the small intestine is normal.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There are no problems seen with the size or shape of the small intestine. Contrast travels through the bowel at a normal rate without any sign of blockage.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Many problems of the small intestine can be found with enteroclysis. Some of these include:</text><detail>Inflammation of the small bowel (such as Crohn disease )</detail><detail> Small bowel isn't absorbing nutrients normally ( malabsorption )</detail><detail> Narrowing or stricture of the intestine </detail><detail> Small bowel blockage </detail><detail>Tumors of the small intestine </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Small bowel enema</detail><detail> CT enteroclysis</detail><detail> Small bowel follow-through</detail><detail> Barium enteroclysis</detail><detail> MR enteroclysis</detail>

item.title: Endoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Preparation for the procedure varies depending on the test. For example, there is no preparation needed for anoscopy. But a special diet and laxatives are needed to prepare for a colonoscopy. Follow your health care provider's instructions.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Each endoscopy test is done for different reasons. Endoscopy is often used to examine and treat parts of the digestive tract, such as:</text><detail> Anoscopy views the inside of the anus, the very lowest part of the colon.</detail><detail> Colonoscopy views the inside of the colon (large intestine) and rectum.</detail><detail> Enteroscopy views the small intestine (small bowel).</detail><detail> ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) views the biliary tract, small tubes that drain the gallbladder, liver, and pancreas.</detail><detail> Sigmoidoscopy views the inside the sigmoid colon and rectum.</detail><detail> Upper endoscopy (or EGD) views the lining of the esophagus, stomach, and first part of the small intestine.</detail><detail> Bronchoscopy is used to look in the airways and lungs.</detail><detail> Cystoscopy is used to view the inside of the bladder. The scope is passed through the opening of the urethra.</detail><detail> Laparoscopy is used to look directly at the ovaries, appendix, or other abdominal organs. The scope is inserted through small surgical cuts in the pelvic or belly area. Tumors or organs in the abdomen or pelvis can be removed. </detail><text>Arthroscopy is used to look directly in the joints, such as the knee . The scope is inserted through small surgical cuts around the joint. Problems with bones, tendons, ligaments can be treated.</text>

item.title: Endoscopic ultrasound
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you what to do. You will be told when to stop drinking and eating before the test.</text><text>Give your provider a list of all the medicines you take (prescription and over-the-counter), herbs, and supplements. You will be told when you can take these. Some need to be stopped a week before the test. Ask your provider which medicines you should take on the morning of surgery. </text><text>Since you will not be able to drive or return to work on the day of this test, you will need someone to take you home.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test to:</text><detail>Find the cause of abdominal pain </detail><detail>Find the cause of weight loss </detail><detail>Diagnose diseases of the pancreas, bile duct, and gallbladder</detail><detail>Guide a biopsy of tumors, lymph nodes, and other tissue</detail><detail>Look at cysts, tumors, and cancers</detail><detail>Look for stones in the bile duct </detail><text>This test can also stage cancers of the:</text><detail> Esophagus </detail><detail> Stomach </detail><detail> Pancreas </detail><detail> Rectum </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The organs will appear normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The results depend on what is found during the test. If you DO NOT understand the results, or have questions or concerns, talk to your provider.</text>

item.title: Endometrial biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Before the test:</text><detail>Tell your provider about all the medicines you take. These include blood thinners such as warfarin, clopidogrel, and aspirin.</detail><detail>You may be asked to have a test to make sure you are not pregnant.</detail><detail>In the 2 days before the procedure, do not use creams or other medicines in the vagina.</detail><detail>Do NOT douche. (You should never douche. Douching can cause infection of the vagina or uterus.)</detail><detail>Ask your provider if you should take pain medicine, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, just before the procedure. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to find the cause of:</text><detail>Abnormal menstrual periods (heavy, prolonged, or irregular bleeding)</detail><detail>Bleeding after menopause </detail><detail>Bleeding from taking hormone therapy medicines</detail><detail>Thickened uterine lining seen on ultrasound</detail><detail> Endometrial cancer </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The biopsy is normal if the cells in the sample are not abnormal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal menstrual periods may be caused by:</text><detail> Uterine fibroids </detail><detail>Fingerlike growths in the uterus (uterine polyps)</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Hormone imbalance</detail><detail>Endometrial cancer or precancer ( hyperplasia )</detail><text>Other conditions under which the test may be performed:</text><detail>Abnormal bleeding if a woman is taking the breast cancer medicine tamoxifen</detail><detail>Abnormal bleeding due to changes in hormone levels ( anovulatory bleeding )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - endometrium</detail>

item.title: Endocervical Gram stain
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT douche for 24 hours before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to detect and identify abnormal bacteria in the cervix area. If you develop signs of an infection or think that you have a sexually transmitted disease (such as gonorrhea), this test can help confirm the diagnosis. It can also identify the germ that is causing the infection. </text><text>This test is rarely done because it has been replaced with more accurate ones.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no abnormal bacteria are seen in the sample. </text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal result may indicate:</text><detail>Bacterial vaginosis</detail><detail> Chlamydia </detail><detail> Gonorrhea </detail><detail> Yeast infection </detail><text>The test may also be performed for gonococcal arthritis , to determine the site of the initial infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gram stain of cervix</detail><detail> Gram stain of cervical secretions</detail>

item.title: Endocervical culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>In the 2 days before the procedure: </text><detail>Do NOT use creams or other medicines in the vagina. </detail><detail>Do NOT douche. (You should never douche. Douching can cause infection of the vagina or uterus.)</detail><detail>Empty your bladder and bowel.</detail><detail>At your provider’s office, follow instructions for preparing for the vaginal exam.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test may be done to determine the cause of vaginitis , pelvic pain, an unusual vaginal discharge , or other signs of infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Organisms that are usually present in the vagina are there in the expected amounts.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results indicate the presence of an infection in the genital tract or urinary tract in women, such as:</text><detail> Genital herpes </detail><detail>Chronic swelling and irritation of the urethra ( urethritis )</detail><detail>Sexually transmitted infections, such as gonorrhea or chlamydia </detail><detail> Pelvic inflammatory disaese (PID) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Vaginal culture</detail><detail> Female genital tract culture</detail><detail> Culture - cervix</detail>

item.title: ELISA blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is often used to see if you have been exposed to viruses or other substances that cause infection. It is also used to screen for current or past infections.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values depend on the type of substance being identified. Some laboratories use different measurements or test different samples. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal values depend on the type of substance being identified. In some people, a positive result may be normal.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Enzyme-linked immunoassay</detail><detail> EIA</detail>

item.title: Electroretinography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to detect disorders of the retina. It is also useful for determining if retinal surgery is recommended.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal test results will show a normal A and B pattern in response to each flash.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The following conditions may cause abnormal results:</text><detail> Arteriosclerosis with damage to the retina</detail><detail>Congenital night blindness</detail><detail>Congenital retinoschisis (splitting of the retinal layers)</detail><detail> Giant cell arteritis </detail><detail>Medicines (chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine)</detail><detail> Mucopolysaccharidosis </detail><detail> Retinal detachment </detail><detail>Rod-cone dystrophy (retinitis pigmentosa) </detail><detail>Trauma</detail><detail> Vitamin A deficiency </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ERG</detail><detail> Electrophysiologic testing</detail>

item.title: Electronystagmography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time, you do not need to take special steps before this test.</text><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines before you have this test.</detail><detail>DO NOT stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is used to determine whether a balance or nerve disorder is the cause of dizziness or vertigo.</text><text>You may have this test if you have:</text><detail>Dizziness or vertigo</detail><detail>Hearing loss</detail><detail>Possible damage to the inner ear from certain medicines </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Certain eye movements should occur after the warm or cold water or air is placed into your ears.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign of damage to the nerve of the inner ear or other parts of the brain that control eye movements.</text><text>Any disease or injury that damages the acoustic nerve can cause vertigo. This may include:</text><detail>Blood vessel disorders with bleeding (hemorrhage), clots, or atherosclerosis of the blood supply of the ear</detail><detail> Cholesteatoma and other ear tumors </detail><detail>Congenital disorders</detail><detail>Injury</detail><detail>Medicines that are toxic to the ear nerves, including aminoglycoside antibiotics, some antimalarial drugs, loop diuretics, and salicylates</detail><detail>Multiple sclerosis</detail><detail>Movement disorders such as progressive supranuclear palsy</detail><detail> Rubella </detail><detail>Some poisons </detail><text>Additional conditions under which the test may be performed:</text><detail> Acoustic neuroma </detail><detail> Benign positional vertigo </detail><detail> Labyrinthitis </detail><detail> Meniere disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ENG</detail>

item.title: Electromyography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is usually necessary. Avoid using any creams or lotions on the day of the test.</text><text>Body temperature can affect the results of this test. If it is extremely cold outside, you may be told to wait in a warm room for a while before the test is performed.</text><text>If you are taking blood thinners or anticoagulants, inform the provider performing the test before it is done.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>EMG is most often used when a person has symptoms of weakness, pain, or abnormal sensation. It can help tell the difference between muscle weakness caused by the injury of a nerve attached to a muscle, and weakness due to nervous system disorders, such as muscle diseases.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There is normally very little electrical activity in a muscle while at rest. Inserting the needles can cause some electrical activity, but once the muscles quiet down, there should be little electrical activity detected.</text><text>When you flex a muscle, activity begins to appear. As you contract your muscle more, the electrical activity increases and a pattern can be seen. This pattern helps your doctor determine if the muscle is responding as it should.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An EMG can detect problems with your muscles during rest or activity. Disorders or conditions that cause abnormal results include the following:</text><detail> Alcoholic neuropathy (damage to nerves from drinking too much alcohol)</detail><detail> Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS; disease of the nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord that control muscle movement)</detail><detail> Axillary nerve dysfunction (damage of the nerve that controls shoulder movement and sensation)</detail><detail> Becker muscular dystrophy (muscle weakness of the legs and pelvis)</detail><detail> Brachial plexopathy (problem affecting the set of nerves that leave the neck and enter the arm)</detail><detail> Carpal tunnel syndrome (problem affecting the median nerve in the wrist and hand)</detail><detail> Cubital tunnel syndrome (problem affecting the ulnar nerve in the elbow)</detail><detail> Cervical spondylosis (neck pain from wear on the disks and bones of the neck)</detail><detail> Common peroneal nerve dysfunction (damage of the peroneal nerve leading to loss of movement or sensation in the foot and leg)</detail><detail>Denervation (reduced nerve stimulation of a muscle)</detail><detail> Dermatomyositis (muscle disease that involves inflammation and a skin rash)</detail><detail> Distal median nerve dysfunction (problem affecting the median nerve in the arm)</detail><detail> Duchenne muscular dystrophy (inherited disease that involves muscle weakness)</detail><detail> Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (Landouzy-Dejerine; disease of muscle weakness and loss of muscle tissue)</detail><detail> Familial periodic paralysis (disorder that causes muscle weakness and sometimes a lower than normal level of potassium in the blood)</detail><detail> Femoral nerve dysfunction (loss of movement or sensation in parts of the legs due to damage to the femoral nerve)</detail><detail> Friedreich ataxia (inherited disease that affects areas in the brain and spinal cord that control coordination, muscle movement, and other functions)</detail><detail> Guillain-Barré syndrome (autoimmune disorder of the nerves that leads to muscle weakness or paralysis)</detail><detail> Lambert-Eaton syndrome (autoimmune disorder of the nerves that causes muscle weakness)</detail><detail> Multiple mononeuropathy (a nervous system disorder that involves damage to at least 2 separate nerve areas)</detail><detail> Mononeuropathy (damage to a single nerve that results in loss of movement, sensation, or other function of that nerve)</detail><detail>Myopathy (muscle degeneration caused by a number of disorders, including muscular dystrophy )</detail><detail> Myasthenia gravis (autoimmune disorder of the nerves that causes weakness of the voluntary muscles)</detail><detail> Peripheral neuropathy (damage of nerves away from the brain and spinal cord)</detail><detail> Polymyositis (muscle weakness, swelling, tenderness, and tissue damage of the skeletal muscles)</detail><detail> Radial nerve dysfunction (damage of the radial nerve causing loss of movement or sensation in the back of the arm or hand)</detail><detail> Sciatic nerve dysfunction (injury to or pressure on the sciatic nerve that causes weakness, numbness, or tingling in the leg)</detail><detail> Sensorimotor polyneuropathy (condition that causes a decreased ability to move or feel because of nerve damage)</detail><detail> Shy-Drager syndrome (nervous system disease that causes bodywide symptoms)</detail><detail> Thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (muscle weakness from high levels of thyroid hormone)</detail><detail> Tibial nerve dysfunction (damage of the tibial nerve causing loss of movement or sensation in the foot)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>EMG</detail><detail> Myogram</detail><detail> Electromyogram</detail>

item.title: EGD - esophagogastroduodenoscopy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will not be able to eat anything for 6 to 12 hours before the test. Follow instructions about stopping aspirin and other blood-thinning medicines before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>EGD may be done if you have symptoms that are new, cannot be explained, or are not responding to treatment, such as:</text><detail>Black or tarry stools or vomiting blood </detail><detail>Bringing food back up (regurgitation)</detail><detail>Feeling full sooner than normal or after eating less than usual</detail><detail>Feeling like food is stuck behind the breastbone</detail><detail> Heartburn </detail><detail>Low blood count ( anemia ) that cannot be explained</detail><detail>Pain or discomfort in the upper abdomen</detail><detail>Swallowing problems or pain with swallowing</detail><detail>Weight loss that cannot be explained</detail><detail>Nausea or vomiting that does not go away </detail><text>Your doctor may also order this test if you:</text><detail>Have cirrhosis of the liver, to look for swollen veins (called varices) in the walls of the lower part of the esophagus, which may begin to bleed</detail><detail>Have Crohn disease </detail><detail>Need more follow-up or treatment for a condition that has been diagnosed </detail><text>The test may also be used to take a piece of tissue for biopsy.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The esophagus, stomach, and duodenum should be smooth and of normal color. There should be no bleeding, growths, ulcers, or inflammation.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal EGD may be the result of:</text><detail> Celiac disease (damage to the lining of the small intestine from a reaction to eating gluten)</detail><detail>Esophageal varices (swollen veins in the lining of the esophagus caused by liver cirrhosis )</detail><detail> Esophagitis (lining of the esophagus becomes inflamed or swollen)</detail><detail> Gastritis (lining of the stomach and duodenum is inflamed or swollen)</detail><detail> Gastroesophageal reflux disease (a condition in which food or liquid from the stomach leaks backwards into the esophagus)</detail><detail> Hiatal hernia (a condition in which part of the stomach sticks up into the chest through an opening in the diaphragm)</detail><detail> Mallory-Weiss syndrome (tear in the esophagus)</detail><detail>Narrowing of the esophagus, such as from a condition called esophageal ring </detail><detail>Tumors or cancer in the esophagus, stomach, or duodenum (first part of small intestine)</detail><detail> Ulcers , gastric (stomach) or duodenal (small intestine) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Esophagogastroduodenoscopy</detail><detail> Upper endoscopy</detail><detail> Gastroscopy</detail>

item.title: EEG
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Wash your hair the night before the test. DO NOT use conditioner, oils, sprays, or gel on your hair. If you have a hair weave, ask your health care provider for special instructions.</text><text>Your provider may want you to stop taking certain medicines before the test. DO NOT change or stop taking any medicines without first talking to your provider. Bring a list of your medicines with you.</text><text>Avoid all food and drinks containing caffeine for 8 hours before the test.</text><text>You may need to sleep during the test. If so, you may be asked to reduce your sleep time the night before. If you are asked to sleep as little as possible before the test, DO NOT eat or drink any caffeine, energy drinks, or other products that help you stay awake.</text><text>Follow any other specific instructions you are given.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Brain cells communicate with each other by producing tiny electrical signals, called impulses. An EEG measures this activity. It can be used to diagnose or monitor the following health conditions:</text><detail> Seizures and epilepsy </detail><detail>Abnormal changes in body chemistry that affect the brain</detail><detail>Brain diseases, such as Alzheimer disease </detail><detail> Confusion </detail><detail>Fainting spells or periods of memory loss that cannot be explained otherwise</detail><detail> Head injuries </detail><detail>Infections</detail><detail>Tumors </detail><text>EEG is also used to:</text><detail>Evaluate problems with sleep ( sleep disorders )</detail><detail>Monitor the brain during brain surgery </detail><text>An EEG may be done to show that the brain has no activity, in the case of someone who is in a deep coma. It can be helpful when trying to decide if a person is brain dead.</text><text>EEG cannot be used to measure intelligence.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Brain electrical activity has a certain number of waves per second (frequencies) that are normal for different levels of alertness. For example, brain waves are faster when you are awake, and slower in certain stages of sleep.</text><text>There are also normal patterns to these waves. </text><text>Note: A normal EEG does not mean that a seizure did not occur.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results on an EEG test may be due to:</text><detail>Abnormal bleeding (hemorrhage)</detail><detail>An abnormal structure in the brain (such as a brain tumor )</detail><detail>Tissue death due to a blockage in blood flow (cerebral infarction)</detail><detail>Drug or alcohol abuse</detail><detail>Head injury</detail><detail>Migraines (in some cases)</detail><detail>Seizure disorder (such as epilepsy)</detail><detail>Sleep disorder (such as narcolepsy )</detail><detail>Swelling of the brain (edema) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Electroencephalogram</detail><detail> Brain wave test</detail><detail> Epilepsy - EEG</detail><detail> Seizure - EEG</detail>

item.title: Echocardiogram - children
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You can take these steps to prepare your child before the procedure:</text><detail>Do not allow your child to eat or drink anything prior to having a TEE.</detail><detail>Do not use any cream or oil on your child before the exam.</detail><detail>Explain the test in detail to older children so they understand that they should remain still during the test.</detail><detail>Younger children less than 4 years of age may need medicine (sedation) to help them stay still for clearer pictures.</detail><detail>Give children older than 4 a toy to hold or have them watch videos to help them stay calm and still during the test.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to examine the function, heart valves, major blood vessels, and chambers of a child's heart from outside of the body.</text><detail>Your child may have signs or symptoms of heart problems.</detail><detail>These may include shortness of breath, poor growth, leg swelling, heart murmur, bluish color around the lips when crying, chest pains, unexplained fever, or germs growing in a blood culture test.</detail><text>Your child may have an increased risk for heart problems due to an abnormal genetic test or other birth defects that are present.</text><text>The provider may recommend a TEE if:</text><detail>The TTE is unclear. Unclear results may be due to the shape of the child's chest, lung disease, or excess body fat.</detail><detail>An area of the heart needs to be looked at in more detail.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means that there are no defects in the heart valves or chambers and there is normal heart wall movement.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal echocardiogram in a child can mean many things. Some abnormal findings are very minor and do not pose major risks. Others are signs of serious heart disease. In this case, the child will need more tests by a specialist. It is very important to talk about the results of the echocardiogram with your child's provider.</text><text>The echocardiogram can help detect:</text><detail>Abnormal heart valves</detail><detail>Abnormal heart rhythms</detail><detail> Birth defects of the heart </detail><detail>Inflammation ( pericarditis ) or fluid in the sac around the heart (pericardial effusion)</detail><detail> Infection on or around the heart valves </detail><detail> High blood pressure in the blood vessels to the lungs </detail><detail>How well the heart can pump</detail><detail>Source of a blood clot after a stroke or TIA </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) - children</detail><detail> Echocardiogram - transthoracic - children</detail><detail> Doppler ultrasound of the heart - children</detail><detail> Surface echo - children</detail>

item.title: Echocardiogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are needed before a TTE test. If you are having a TEE, you will not be able to eat or drink for several hours before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to evaluate the valves and chambers of the heart from the outside of your body. The echocardiogram can help detect:</text><detail>Abnormal heart valves</detail><detail>Abnormal heart rhythms</detail><detail> Congenital heart disease </detail><detail>Damage to the heart muscle from a heart attack</detail><detail>Heart murmurs</detail><detail>Inflammation ( pericarditis ) or fluid in the sac around the heart (pericardial effusion)</detail><detail>Infection on or around the heart valves (infectious endocarditis)</detail><detail> Pulmonary hypertension </detail><detail>Ability of the heart to pump (for people with heart failure )</detail><detail>Source of a blood clot after a stroke or TIA </detail><text>Your provider may recommend a TEE if:</text><detail>The regular (or TTE) is unclear. Unclear results may be due to the shape of your chest, lung disease, or excess body fat.</detail><detail>An area of the heart needs to be looked at in more detail.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal echocardiogram reveals normal heart valves and chambers and normal heart wall movement.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal echocardiogram can mean many things. Some abnormalities are very minor and do not pose major risks. Other abnormalities are signs of serious heart disease. You will need more tests by a specialist in this case. It is very important to talk about the results of your echocardiogram with your provider.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE)</detail><detail> Echocardiogram - transthoracic</detail><detail> Doppler ultrasound of the heart</detail><detail> Surface echo</detail>

item.title: Ear examination
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No preparation is needed for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>An ear exam may be done if you have an earache, ear infection , hearing loss , or other ear symptoms.</text><text>Examining the ear also helps the provider see if treatment for an ear problem is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The ear canal differs in size, shape, and color from person to person. Normally, the canal is skin-colored and has small hairs. Yellowish-brown earwax may be present. The eardrum is a light-gray color or a shiny pearly-white. Light should reflect off the eardrum surface.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Ear infections are a common problem, especially with small children. A dull or absent light reflex from the eardrum may be a sign of a middle ear infection or fluid. The eardrum may be red and bulging if there is an infection. Amber liquid or bubbles behind the eardrum are often seen if fluid collects in the middle ear.</text><text>Abnormal results may also be due to an external ear infection . You might feel pain when the outer ear is pulled or wiggled. The ear canal may be red, tender, swollen, or filled with yellowish-green pus.</text><text>The test may also be done for the following conditions: </text><detail> Cholesteatoma </detail><detail>External ear infection - chronic</detail><detail>Head injury</detail><detail> Ruptured or perforated eardrum </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Otoscopy </detail>

value.img_name: Medical findings based on ear anatomy

item.title: Ear drainage culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You do not need to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test may be done if you or your child has:</text><detail>An ear infection that is not getting better with treatment</detail><detail>An infection of the outer ear ( otitis externa )</detail><detail>An ear infection with a ruptured eardrum and draining fluid </detail><text>It may also be done as a routine part of myringotomy .</text><text>Note: Ear infections are diagnosed based on symptoms rather than using a culture.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test is normal if there is no growth on the culture.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be a sign of an infection. The infection can be caused by bacteria, virus, or fungus.</text><text>The test results may show which organism is causing the infection. It will help your provider decide on the right treatment.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - ear drainage</detail>

value.img_name: Medical findings based on ear anatomy

item.title: FTA-ABS blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done routinely to confirm whether a positive screening test for syphilis (either VDRL or RPR ) means you have a current syphilis infection.</text><text>It may also be done when other syphilis tests are negative, to rule out a possible false-negative result.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative or nonreactive result means that you do not have a current or past infection with syphilis.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive FTA-ABS is often a sign of a syphilis infection. This test result will remain positive for life even if syphilis has been adequately treated. Therefore, it cannot be used to monitor the treatment of syphilis or determine that you have active syphilis.</text><text>Other illnesses, such as yaws and pinta (two other kinds of skin diseases), may also result in positive FTA-ABS results. Sometimes, there can be a false-positive result, most often in women with lupus .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test</detail>

item.title: Free T4 test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines that may affect the test result. In general, test results are not affected by other medicines you may be taking. However, certain supplements including biotin (vitamin B7) can affect the results. Tell your provider if you are taking biotin.</text><text>Pregnancy and some diseases, including kidney and liver disease, can also affect the results of this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may recommend this test if you have signs of a thyroid disorder, including:</text><detail>Abnormal findings of other thyroid blood tests, such as TSH or T3 </detail><detail>Symptoms of an overactive thyroid </detail><detail>Symptoms of an underactive thyroid </detail><detail>Hypopituitarism (the pituitary gland does not produce enough of its hormones)</detail><detail> Lump or nodule in the thyroid</detail><detail>Enlarged or irregular thyroid gland</detail><detail>Problems becoming pregnant </detail><text>This test is also used to monitor people who are being treated for thyroid problems.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A typical normal range is 0.9 to 2.3 nanograms per deciliter (ng/dL), or 12 to 30 picomoles per liter (pmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>To fully understand results of the free T4 test, results of other thyroid blood tests, such as TSH or T3, may be needed.</text><text>Test results may also be affected by pregnancy, estrogen level, liver problems, more severe body-wide illnesses, and inherited changes in a protein that binds T4.</text><text>A higher than normal level of T4 may be due to conditions that involve an overactive thyroid, including:</text><detail> Graves disease </detail><detail>Taking too much thyroid hormone medicine</detail><detail>Thyroiditis</detail><detail>Toxic goiter or toxic thyroid nodules</detail><detail>Some tumors of the testes or ovaries (rare)</detail><detail>Getting medical imaging tests with contrast dye that contains iodine (rare, and only if there is a problem with the thyroid)</detail><detail>Eating a lot of foods that contain iodine (very rare, and only if there is a problem with the thyroid) </detail><text>A lower than normal level of T4 may be due to:</text><detail> Hypothyroidism (including Hashimoto disease and other disorders involving an underactive thyroid)</detail><detail>Severe acute illness</detail><detail> Malnutrition or fasting</detail><detail>Use of certain medicines </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thyroxine test</detail><detail> Total T4 test</detail>

item.title: Fractional excretion of sodium
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Eat your normal foods with a normal amount of salt, unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider.</text><text>If needed, you may be told to temporarily stop medicines that interfere with test results. For example, some diuretic medicines (water pills) can affect test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is usually done for people who are very ill with acute kidney disease . The test helps determine if the drop in urine production is due to reduced blood flow to the kidney or to kidney damage itself.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A meaningful interpretation of the test can be made only when your urine volume has dropped to less than 500 mL/day.</text><text>FENa of lower than 1% indicates decreased blood flow to the kidney. This can occur with kidney damage due to dehydration or heart failure .</text><text>FENa higher than 1% suggests damage to the kidney itself.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>FE sodium</detail><detail> FENa</detail>

item.title: Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If you are a woman of childbearing age, your health care provider may want you to have the test done on certain days of your menstrual cycle.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>In women, FSH helps manage the menstrual cycle and stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs. The test is used to help diagnose or evaluate:</text><detail> Menopause </detail><detail>Women who have polycystic ovary syndrome , ovarian cysts </detail><detail>Abnormal vaginal or menstrual bleeding</detail><detail>Problems becoming pregnant, or infertility </detail><text>In men, FSH stimulates production of sperm. The test is used to help diagnose or evaluate:</text><detail>Problems becoming pregnant, or infertility </detail><detail>Men who do not have testicles or whose testicles are underdeveloped</detail><text>In children, FSH is involved with the development of sexual features. The test is ordered for children:</text><detail>Who develop sexual features at a very young age</detail><detail>Who are delayed in starting puberty</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal FSH levels will differ, depending on a person's age and sex.</text><text>Male:</text><detail>Before puberty - 0 to 5.0 mIU/mL (0 to 5.0 IU/L)</detail><detail>During puberty - 0.3 to 10.0 mIU/mL (0.3 to 10.0 IU/L)</detail><detail>Adult - 1.5 to 12.4 mIU/mL (1.5 to 12.4 IU/L) </detail><text>Female:</text><detail>Before puberty - 0 to 4.0 mIU/mL (0 to 4.0 IU/L)</detail><detail>During puberty - 0.3 to 10.0 mIU/mL (0.3 to 10.0 IU/L)</detail><detail>Women who are still menstruating - 4.7 to 21.5 mIU/mL (4.5 to 21.5 IU/L)</detail><detail>After menopause - 25.8 to 134.8 mIU/mL (25.8 to 134.8 IU/L) </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High FSH levels in women may be present:</text><detail>During or after menopause, including premature menopause</detail><detail>When receiving hormone therapy</detail><detail>Due to certain types of tumor in the pituitary gland </detail><detail> Due to Turner syndrome </detail><text>Low FSH levels in women may be present due to: </text><detail>Being very underweight or having had recent rapid weight loss</detail><detail>Not producing eggs (not ovulating)</detail><detail>Parts of the brain (the pituitary gland or hypothalamus ) not producing normal amounts of some or all of its hormones </detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail><text>High FSH levels in men may mean the testicles are not functioning correctly due to: </text><detail>Advancing age (male menopause)</detail><detail>Damage to testicles caused by alcohol abuse, chemotherapy, or radiation</detail><detail>Problems with genes, such as Klinefelter syndrome </detail><detail>Treatment with hormones</detail><detail>Certain tumors in the pituitary gland</detail><text>Low FSH levels in men may mean parts of the brain (the pituitary gland or hypothalamus) do not produce normal amounts of some or all of its hormones.</text><text>High FSH levels in boys or girls may mean that puberty is about to start. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Follicle stimulating hormone</detail><detail> Menopause - FSH</detail><detail> Vaginal bleeding - FSH</detail>

item.title: Folic acid - test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You should not eat or drink for 6 hours before the test. Your provider may tell you to stop taking any drugs that may interfere with test results, including folic acid supplements.</text><text>Drugs that can decrease folic acid measurements include: </text><detail>Alcohol</detail><detail>Aminosalicylic acid</detail><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Estrogens</detail><detail>Tetracyclines</detail><detail>Ampicillin</detail><detail>Chloramphenicol</detail><detail>Erythromycin</detail><detail>Methotrexate</detail><detail>Penicillin</detail><detail>Aminopterin</detail><detail>Phenobarbital</detail><detail>Phenytoin</detail><detail>Drugs to treat malaria</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check for folic acid deficiency .</text><text>Folic acid helps form red blood cells and produce DNA that stores genetic codes. Taking the right amount of folic acid before and during pregnancy helps prevent neural tube defects, such as spina bifida.</text><text>Women who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant should take at least 600 micrograms (mcg) of folic acid every day. Some women may need to take more if they have a history of neural tube defects in earlier pregnancies. Ask your provider how much you need.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 2.7 to 17.0 nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL) or 6.12 to 38.52 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different labs. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Lower-than-normal folic acid levels may indicate:</text><detail>Poor diet</detail><detail> Malabsorption syndrome (for example, celiac sprue )</detail><detail> Malnutrition </detail><text>The test may also be done in cases of:</text><detail> Anemia due to folate deficiency </detail><detail>Megaloblastic anemia</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Folate - test</detail>

item.title: Flushable reagent stool blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Some medicines may interfere with this test.</text><text>Check with your provider about changes in your medicines you may need to make. Never stop taking a medicine or change how you take it without first talking to your provider.</text><text>Check test package to see if there are any foods you need to stop eating before doing the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is mainly performed for colorectal cancer screening. It may also be done in the case of low levels of red blood cells (anemia).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A negative result is normal.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different labs. Talk to your provider about your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results of the flushable pad mean there is bleeding present somewhere in the digestive tract, which may be caused by:</text><detail>Swollen, fragile blood vessels in the colon that may result in blood loss </detail><detail>Colon cancer </detail><detail>Colon polyps </detail><detail>Enlarged veins, called varices, in the walls of the esophagus (the tube that connects your throat to your stomach) that bleed </detail><detail>When the lining of the stomach or the esophagus becomes inflamed or swollen </detail><detail>Infections in the stomach and intestines </detail><detail>Hemorrhoids </detail><detail>Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis </detail><detail>Ulcer in the stomach or first part of the intestines </detail><text>Other causes of a positive test, which do not indicate a problem in the gastrointestinal tract, include:</text><detail>Coughing up and then swallowing blood </detail><detail>Nose bleed</detail><text>Abnormal test results require follow-up with your doctor.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Stool occult blood test - flushable home test</detail><detail> Fecal occult blood test - flushable home test</detail>

item.title: Fluorescein eye stain
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need to remove your eyeglasses or contact lenses before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is to:</text><detail>Find scratches or other problems with the surface of the cornea </detail><detail>Reveal foreign bodies on the eye surface </detail><detail>Determine if there is irritation of the cornea after contacts are prescribed</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>If the test result is normal, the dye remains in the tear film on the surface of the eye and does not stick to the eye itself.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may point to:</text><detail>Abnormal tear production (dry eye)</detail><detail> Blocked tear duct </detail><detail> Corneal abrasion (a scratch on the surface of the cornea)</detail><detail>Foreign bodies, such as eyelashes or dust ( foreign object in eye )</detail><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Injury or trauma</detail><detail>Severe dry eye associated with arthritis (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) </detail>

item.title: Fluorescein angiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will need someone to drive you home. Your vision may be blurry for up to 12 hours after the test.</text><text>You may be told to stop taking medicines that could affect the test results. Tell your provider about any allergies, particularly reactions to iodine.</text><text>You must sign an informed consent form. You must remove contact lenses before the test.</text><text>Tell the provider if you may be pregnant.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see if there is proper blood flow in the blood vessels in the two layers in the back of your eye (the retina and choroid). </text><text>It can also be used to diagnose problems in the eye or to determine how well certain eye treatments are working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means the vessels appear a normal size, there are no new abnormal vessels, and there are no blockages or leakages.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If blockage or leakage is present, the pictures will map the location for possible treatment.</text><text>An abnormal value on a fluorescein angiography may be due to:</text><detail>Blood flow (circulatory) problems, such as blockage of the arteries or veins</detail><detail> Cancer </detail><detail>Diabetic or other retinopathy</detail><detail>High blood pressure</detail><detail>Inflammation or edema </detail><detail> Macular degeneration </detail><detail>Microaneurysms -- enlargement of capillaries in the retina</detail><detail> Tumors </detail><detail>Swelling of the optic disc </detail><text>The test may also be done if you have: </text><detail> Retinal detachment </detail><detail> Retinitis pigmentosa </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Retinal photography</detail><detail> Eye angiography</detail><detail> Retinopathy - fluorescein</detail>

item.title: Fine needle aspiration of the thyroid
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell your provider if you have drug allergies , bleeding problems, or are pregnant. Also, make sure your provider has a current list of all medicines you take, including herbal remedies and over-the-counter drugs.</text><text>A few days to a week before your biopsy, you may be asked to temporarily stop taking blood-thinning medicines. The drugs you may need to stop taking include:</text><detail>Aspirin</detail><detail>Clopidogrel (Plavix)</detail><detail>Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin)</detail><detail>Naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn)</detail><detail>Warfarin (Coumadin)</detail><text>Be sure to talk with your provider before stopping any drugs.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This is a test to diagnose thyroid disease or thyroid cancer . It is often used to find out if thyroid nodules that your provider can feel or seen on an ultrasound are noncancerous or cancerous.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result shows the thyroid tissue looks normal and the cells do not appear to be cancer under a microscope.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean:</text><detail> Thyroid disease such as goiter or thyroiditis</detail><detail>Noncancerous tumors</detail><detail> Thyroid cancer </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Thyroid nodule fine needle aspirate biopsy</detail><detail> Biopsy - thyroid - skinny-needle</detail><detail> Skinny-needle thyroid biopsy</detail><detail> Thyroid nodule - aspiration</detail><detail> Thyroid cancer - aspiration</detail>

item.title: Fibrinopeptide A blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to help diagnose severe problems with blood clotting such as disseminated intravascular coagulation ( DIC ). Certain types of leukemia are associated with DIC.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In general, the level of fibrinopeptide A should range from 0.6 to 1.9 (mg/mL).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased fibrinopeptide A level may be a sign of:</text><detail> Cellulitis </detail><detail>DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) </detail><detail>Leukemia at the time of diagnosis, during early treatment, and during a relapse</detail><detail>Some infections</detail><detail>Systemic lupus erythematosus ( SLE )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>FPA</detail>

item.title: Fibrinogen blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your doctor may order this test if you have problems with blood clotting, such as excessive bleeding.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 200 to 400 mg/dL (2.0 to 4.0 g/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>The body using up too much fibrinogen, such as in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)</detail><detail>Fibrinogen deficiency (from birth, or acquired after birth)</detail><detail>Breakdown of fibrin ( fibrinolysis )</detail><detail>Too much bleeding (hemorrhage) </detail><text>The test may also be performed during pregnancy if the placenta separates from its attachment to the uterus wall ( placenta abruption ).</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum fibrinogen</detail><detail> Plasma fibrinogen</detail><detail> Factor I</detail><detail> Hypofibrinogenemia test</detail>

item.title: Fibrin degradation products blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines can change blood test results.</text><detail>Tell your health care provider about all the medicines you take.</detail><detail>Your provider will tell you if you need to temporarily stop taking any medicines before you have this test. This includes blood thinners such as aspirin, heparin, streptokinase, and urokinase, which make it hard for the blood to clot.</detail><detail>Do not stop or change your medicines without talking to your provider first.</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see if your clot-dissolving (fibrinolytic) system is working properly. Your provider may order this test if you have signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or another clot-dissolving disorder.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The result is normally less than 10 mcg/mL (10 mg/L).</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Increased FDPs may be a sign of primary or secondary fibrinolysis (clot-dissolving activity) due to a variety of causes, including:</text><detail>Blood clotting problems</detail><detail> Burns </detail><detail>Problem with the heart's structure and function that is present at birth ( congenital heart disease )</detail><detail>Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)</detail><detail>Low level of oxygen in the blood</detail><detail>Infections</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail>Problem during pregnancy such as preeclampsia, placenta abruptio , miscarriage</detail><detail>Recent blood transfusion</detail><detail>Recent surgery that involved a heart and lung bypass pump, or surgery to lower high blood pressure in the liver</detail><detail>Kidney disease</detail><detail> Transplant rejection </detail><detail> Transfusion reaction </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>FDPs</detail><detail> FSPs</detail><detail> Fibrin split products</detail><detail> Fibrin breakdown products</detail>

item.title: Fetal-maternal erythrocyte distribution blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text> Rh incompatibility is a condition that occurs when the mother's blood type is Rh-negative (Rh-) and her unborn baby's blood type is Rh-positive (Rh+). If the mother is Rh+, or if both parents are Rh-, there is no reason to worry about Rh incompatibility.</text><text>If the baby's blood is Rh+ and gets into the mother's Rh- bloodstream, her body will produce antibodies. These antibodies could pass back through the placenta and harm the developing baby's red blood cells. This can cause mild to serious anemia in the unborn baby.</text><text>This test determines the amount of blood that has been exchanged between the mother and fetus. All Rh- pregnant women should get this test if they have bleeding or a risk of bleeding during the pregnancy.</text><text>In a woman whose blood is Rh incompatible with her infant, this test helps find out how much Rh immune globulin (RhoGAM) she must receive to prevent her body from producing abnormal proteins that attack the unborn baby in future pregnancies.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In a normal value, no or few of the baby's cells are in the mother's blood. The standard dose of RhoGAM is enough in this case.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>In an abnormal test result, blood from the unborn baby is leaking into the mother's blood circulation. The more of the baby's cells there are, the more Rh immune globulin the mother must receive.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Kleihauer-Betke stain</detail><detail> Flow cytometry - fetal-maternal erythrocyte distribution</detail><detail> Rh incompatibility - erythrocyte distribution</detail>

item.title: Fetal scalp pH testing
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The health care provider will explain the procedure and its risks. There isn't always a separate consent form for this procedure because many hospitals consider it part of the general consent form you signed at admission.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Sometimes fetal heart monitoring doesn't provide enough information about the well-being of a baby. In these cases, testing the scalp pH can help the doctor decide whether the fetus is getting enough oxygen during labor. This helps determine whether the baby is healthy enough to continue labor, or if a forceps delivery or cesarean birth might be the best route of delivery.</text><text>Although the test is not uncommon, most deliveries do not involve fetal scalp pH testing.</text><text>This test is not recommended for mothers with infections such as HIV/AIDS or hepatitis C.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal fetal blood sample results are:</text><detail>Normal pH: 7.25 to 7.35</detail><detail>Borderline pH: 7.20 to 7.25</detail><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A fetal scalp blood pH level of less than 7.20 is considered abnormal.</text><text>In general, low pH suggests that the baby does not have enough oxygen. This may mean that the baby is not tolerating labor very well. The results of a fetal scalp pH sample need to be interpreted for each labor. The provider may feel that the results mean the baby needs to be delivered quickly, either by forceps or by C-section.</text><text>Fetal scalp pH testing may need to be repeated a few times during a complicated labor to keep checking on the baby.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Fetal scalp blood</detail><detail> Scalp pH testing</detail><detail> Fetal blood testing - scalp</detail><detail> Fetal distress - fetal scalp testing</detail><detail> Labor - fetal scalp testing</detail>

item.title: Fetal echocardiography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to detect a heart problem before the baby is born. It can provide a more detailed image of the baby's heart than a regular pregnancy ultrasound.</text><text>The test can show:</text><detail>Blood flow through the heart</detail><detail>Heart rhythm</detail><detail>Structures of the baby's heart </detail><text>The test may be done if:</text><detail>A parent, sibling or other close family member had a heart defect or heart disease.</detail><detail>A routine pregnancy ultrasound detected an abnormal heart rhythm or possible heart problem in the unborn baby.</detail><detail>The mother has diabetes (prior to pregnancy), lupus , or phenylketonuria .</detail><detail>The mother has rubella during the first trimester of pregnancy.</detail><detail>The mother has used medicines that can damage the baby's developing heart (such as some epilepsy drugs and prescription acne medicines).</detail><detail>An amniocentesis revealed a chromosome disorder. </detail><detail>There is some other reason to suspect that the baby is at higher risk for heart problems.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The echocardiogram finds no problems in the unborn baby's heart.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>A problem in the way the baby's heart has formed ( congenital heart disease )</detail><detail>A problem with the way the baby's heart works</detail><detail>Heart rhythm disturbances ( arrhythmias )</detail><text>The test may need to be repeated.</text>

item.title: Ferritin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may tell you not to eat anything (to fast) for 12 hours before the test. You may also be told to have the test done in the morning.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The amount of ferritin in the blood (serum ferritin level) is directly related to the amount of iron stored in your body. Iron is needed to make healthy red blood cells. These cells carry oxygen to body tissues.</text><text>Your provider may recommend this test if you have signs or symptoms of anemia due to low iron. Anemia is a condition in which the body does not have enough healthy red blood cells.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value range is:</text><detail>Male: 12 to 300 nanograms per millilter (ng/mL)</detail><detail>Female: 12 to 150 ng/mL</detail><text>The lower the ferritin level, even within the "normal" range, the more likely it is that the person does not have enough iron.</text><text>The number ranges above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A higher-than-normal ferritin level may be due to:</text><detail>Liver disease due to alcohol abuse</detail><detail>Any autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis</detail><detail>Frequent transfusion of red blood cells</detail><detail>Too much iron in the body ( hemochromatosis ) </detail><text>A lower-than-normal level of ferritin occurs if you have anemia caused by low iron levels in the body. This type of anemia may be due to:</text><detail>A diet too low in iron</detail><detail>Heavy bleeding from an injury</detail><detail>Heavy menstrual bleeding</detail><detail>Poor absorption of iron from food, medicines, or vitamins</detail><detail>Bleeding in the esophagus, stomach, or intestines </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serum ferritin level</detail><detail> Iron deficiency anemia - ferritin</detail>

item.title: Fecal smear
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no preparation needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have severe diarrhea that will not go away or that keeps returning. The test result may be used to select the correct antibiotic treatment.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means there are no disease-causing germs present.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different labs. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means that abnormal germs have been found in the stool sample. This may be due to an infection of the digestive tract.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Stool smear</detail>

item.title: Fecal fat
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Eat a normal diet containing about 100 grams (g) of fat per day for 3 days before starting the test. The health care provider may ask you to stop using drugs or food additives that could affect the test.</text>
