item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test evaluates fat absorption to tell how well the liver, gallbladder, pancreas, and intestines are working.</text><text>Fat malabsorption can cause a change in your stools called steatorrhea. To absorb fat normally, the body needs bile from the gallbladder (or liver if the gallbladder has been removed), enzymes from the pancreas, and normal intestines.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Less than 7 g of fat per 24 hours.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased fat absorption may be caused by:</text><detail>Biliary cancer </detail><detail> Biliary stricture </detail><detail> Celiac disease </detail><detail> Chronic pancreatitis </detail><detail> Crohn disease </detail><detail> Cystic fibrosis </detail><detail>Gallstones ( cholelithiasis )</detail><detail> Pancreatic cancer </detail><detail>Pancreatitis</detail><detail> Radiation enteritis </detail><detail> Short bowel syndrome (for example from surgery or an inherited problem)</detail><detail>Sprue</detail><detail> Whipple disease </detail><detail>Small bowel bacterial overgrowth </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Quantitative stool fat determination</detail><detail> Fat absorption</detail>

item.title: Fecal culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will get a collection container for the stool specimen. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed when your health care provider suspects that you may have a gastrointestinal infection. It may be done if you have severe diarrhea that does not go away or that keeps coming back.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>There are no abnormal bacteria or other organisms in the sample.</text><text>Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean you have an intestinal infection .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Stool culture</detail><detail> Culture - stool</detail><detail> Gastroenteritis fecal culture</detail>

item.title: Factor XII assay
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may want you to have this test if you had abnormal results on the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) blood-clotting test . You may also need the test if a family member is known to have factor XII deficiency .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value is 50% to 200% of the laboratory control or reference value.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased factor XII activity may indicate:</text><detail>Inherited (congenital) deficiency of factor XII</detail><detail> Liver disease </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Hageman factor assay</detail>

item.title: Factor X assay
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may need to stop taking some medicines before this test. Your health care provider will tell you which ones.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be used to find the cause of excessive bleeding (decreased blood clotting). The decreased clotting may be caused by an abnormally low level of factor X.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value is 50% to 200% of the laboratory control or reference value.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased factor X activity may be related to:</text><detail>Disorder in which abnormal proteins build up in tissues and organs ( amyloidosis )</detail><detail> Deficiency of factor X that is present at birth (congenital) </detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail>Fat malabsorption (not absorbing enough fat from your diet)</detail><detail>Heparin use</detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail> Vitamin K deficiency</detail><detail>Taking the blood thinning drug called warfarin (Coumadin)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Stuart-Prower factor</detail>

item.title: Factor VIII assay
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to find the cause of too much bleeding (decreased blood clotting). Or, it may be ordered if a family member is known to have hemophilia A . The test may also be done to see how well treatment for hemophilia A is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value is 50% to 200% of the laboratory control or reference value.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased factor VIII activity may be due to:</text><detail>Hemophilia A</detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)</detail><detail>Presence of a Factor VIII inhibitor (antibody)</detail><detail> Von Willebrand disease (another type of bleeding disorder) </detail><text>Increased activity may be due to:</text><detail>Older age</detail><detail>Diabetes</detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Pregnancy</detail><detail>Obesity </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Plasma factor VIII antigen</detail><detail> Antihemophilia factor</detail><detail> AHF</detail>

item.title: Factor VII assay
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may need to temporarily stop taking some medicines before this test. Your health care provider will tell you which ones.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to find the cause of abnormal bleeding (decreased blood clotting). This decreased clotting may be caused by an abnormally low level of factor VII.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal value is 50% to 200% of the laboratory control or reference value.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased factor VII activity may be related to:</text><detail> Deficiency of factor VII </detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail>Fat malabsorption (not absorbing enough fat from your diet)</detail><detail> Liver disease (such as cirrhosis )</detail><detail> Vitamin K deficiency</detail><detail>Taking the blood thinning drug called warfarin (Coumadin)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Stable factor</detail><detail> Proconvertin</detail><detail> Autoprothrombin I</detail>

item.title: Factor V assay
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to find the cause of too much bleeding (decreased blood clotting). This decreased clotting may be caused by an abnormally low level of factor V.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The value is normally 50% to 200% of the laboratory control or reference value.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased factor V activity may be related to:</text><detail> Deficiency of factor V </detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail> Liver disease (such as cirrhosis )</detail><detail>Abnormal breakdown of blood clots (secondary fibrinolysis)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Labile factor</detail><detail> Proaccelerin</detail><detail> Ac-globulin</detail>

item.title: Factor IX assay
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may need to stop taking some medicines before this test. Your health care provider will tell you which ones.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to find the cause of too much bleeding (decreased blood clotting). Or, it may be ordered if a family member is known to have hemophilia B . The test may also be done to see how well treatment for hemophilia B is working.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal value is 50% to 200% of the laboratory control or reference value.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased factor IX activity may be related to:</text><detail> Hemophilia B </detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail>Fat malabsorption (not absorbing enough fat from your diet)</detail><detail> Liver disease (such as cirrhosis )</detail><detail> Vitamin K deficiency</detail><detail>Taking the blood thinning drug called warfarin (Coumadin) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Christmas factor assay</detail><detail> Serum factor IX</detail><detail> Hemophilic factor B</detail><detail> Plasma thromboplastin component</detail><detail> PTC</detail>

item.title: Factor II assay
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to find the cause of too much bleeding (decreased blood clotting). This decreased clotting may be caused by an abnormally low level of factor II, a disorder called factor II deficiency .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The value should be 50% to 200% of the laboratory control or reference value.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Decreased factor II activity may be the result of:</text><detail> Deficiency of factor II </detail><detail>Disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become over active ( disseminated intravascular coagulation )</detail><detail>Fat malabsorption (not enough fat absorbed in the diet)</detail><detail> Liver disease (such as cirrhosis )</detail><detail> Vitamin K deficiency</detail><detail>Taking the blood thinning drug called warfarin (Coumadin)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Prothrombin assay</detail>

item.title: Gum biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be told not to eat for a few hours before the biopsy.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to look for the cause of abnormal gum tissue.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>This test is only done when gum tissue looks abnormal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate:</text><detail> Amyloid </detail><detail>Noncancerous mouth sores (the specific cause can be determined in many cases)</detail><detail> Oral cancer (for example, squamous cell carcinoma )</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Biopsy - gingiva (gums)</detail>

item.title: Growth hormone suppression test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT eat anything and limit physical activity for 10 to 12 hours before the test.</text><text>You may also be told to stop taking medicines that can affect the test results. These medicines include glucocorticoids such as prednisone, hydrocortisone, or dexamethasone. Check with your health care provider before stopping any medicines.</text><text>You will be asked to relax for at least 90 minutes before the test. This is because exercise or increased activity can change GH levels.</text><text>If your child is to have this test done, it may be helpful to explain how the test will feel and even demonstrate on a doll. The more familiar your child is with what will happen and why, the less anxiety the child will feel.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test checks for a high level of GH, a condition that leads to gigantism in children and acromegaly in adults. It is not used as a routine screening test. This test is only done if you show signs of increased GH.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal test results show a GH level of less than 1 ng/mL. In children, GH level may be increased due to reactive hypoglycemia .</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the GH level is not changed and stays high during the suppression test, the provider will suspect gigantism or acromegaly. You may need to be retested to confirm the test results.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>GH suppression test</detail><detail> Glucose loading test</detail><detail> Acromegaly - blood test</detail><detail> Gigantism - blood test</detail>

item.title: Growth hormone stimulation test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>DO NOT eat for 10 to 12 hours before the test. Eating food can change the test results.</text><text>Some medicines can affect the test results. Ask your provider if you should stop taking any of your medicines before the test.</text><text>If your child will have this test, explain how the test will feel. You may want to demonstrate on a doll. The more familiar your child is with what will happen and the purpose of the procedure, the less anxiety he or she will feel.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to find out whether a growth hormone deficiency (GH deficiency) is causing slowed growth.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results include:</text><detail>Normal peak value, at least 10 ng/mL (10 µg/L)</detail><detail>Indeterminate, 5 to 10 ng/mL (5 to 10 µg/L)</detail><detail>Subnormal, 5 ng/mL (5 µg/L)</detail><text>A normal value rules out hGH deficiency. In some laboratories, the normal level is 7 ng/mL (7 µg/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If this test does not raise GH levels, there is a reduced amount of hGH stored in the anterior pituitary.</text><text>In children, this results in GH deficiency. In adults, it may be linked to adult GH deficiency.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Arginine test</detail><detail> Arginine - GHRH test </detail>

item.title: Gram stain of urethral discharge
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>This test is often performed in the health care provider's office.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed when an abnormal urethral discharge is present. It may be performed if a sexually transmitted infection is suspected.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate gonorrhea or other infections.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urethral discharge Gram stain</detail><detail> Urethritis - Gram stain</detail>

item.title: Gram stain of tissue biopsy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>If the biopsy is included as part of a surgical procedure, you will be asked not to eat or drink anything the night before surgery. If the biopsy is of a superficial (on the surface of the body) tissue, you may be asked not to eat or drink for several hours before the procedure.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is performed when an infection of a body tissue is suspected.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Whether there are bacteria, and what type there are, depends on the tissue being biopsied. Some tissues in the body are sterile, such as the brain. Other tissues, such as the gut, normally contain bacteria.</text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results usually mean there is an infection in the tissue. More tests, such as culturing the tissue that was removed, are often needed to identify the type of bacteria.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Tissue biopsy - Gram stain</detail>

item.title: Gram stain of skin lesion
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No preparation is needed for the laboratory test. Tell your provider if you have a history of bleeding problems because you may bleed slightly during the biopsy.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of an infected skin sore. The test is done to determine which bacteria caused the infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test is normal if no bacteria are found.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results. Other tests may be done to help diagnose the problem.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result means bacteria have been found in the skin lesion. Further tests are needed to confirm the results. This allows your healthcare provider to prescribe the appropriate antibiotic or other treatment.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Skin lesion gram stain</detail>

item.title: Gram stain
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider will tell you what to do to prepare for the test. For some types of tests, you will not need to do anything.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test to diagnose an infection caused by bacteria. It can also identify the type of bacteria causing the infection.</text><text>This test can help find the cause of various health problems, including:</text><detail>Intestinal infection or illness</detail><detail>Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs)</detail><detail>Unexplained swelling or joint pain</detail><detail>Signs of a heart infection or fluid buildup in the thin sac that surrounds the heart (pericardium)</detail><detail>Signs of infection of the space around the lungs (pleural space)</detail><detail>Cough that will not go away, or if you are coughing up material with a foul odor or odd color</detail><detail>Infected skin sore</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means that no bacteria or only "friendly" bacteria were found. Some types of bacteria normally live in certain areas of the body, such as the intestines. Bacteria normally don't live in other areas, such as the brain or spinal fluid.</text><text>Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate an infection. You will need further tests, such as a culture, to find out more about the infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urethral discharge - Gram stain</detail><detail> Feces - Gram stain</detail><detail> Stool - Gram stain</detail><detail> Joint fluid - Gram stain</detail><detail> Pericardial fluid - Gram stain</detail><detail> Gram stain of urethral discharge</detail><detail> Gram stain of the cervix</detail><detail> Pleural fluid - Gram stain</detail><detail> Sputum - Gram stain</detail><detail> Skin lesion - Gram stain</detail><detail> Gram stain of skin lesion</detail><detail> Gram stain of tissue biopsy</detail>

item.title: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is usually necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may recommend this test if you have signs of G6PD deficiency . This means you do not have enough G6PD activity.</text><text>Too little G6PD activity leads to the destruction of red blood cells. This process is called hemolysis . When this process is actively occurring, it is called a hemolytic episode.</text><text>Hemolytic episodes can be triggered by infections, certain foods (such as fava beans), and certain medicines, including:</text><detail>Drugs used to reduce fever</detail><detail>Nitrofurantoin</detail><detail>Phenacetin</detail><detail>Primaquine</detail><detail>Sulfonamides</detail><detail>Thiazide diuretics</detail><detail>Tolbutamide</detail><detail>Quinidine</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text> Normal values vary and depend upon the laboratory used. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results mean you have a G6PD deficiency. This can cause hemolytic anemia in certain conditions.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>RBC G6PD test</detail><detail> G6PD screen</detail>

item.title: Glucose urine test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines can change the result of this test. Before the test, tell your provider which medicines you are taking. DO NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test was commonly used to test for and monitor diabetes in the past. Now, blood tests to measure glucose level in the blood are easy to do and are used instead of the glucose urine test.</text><text>The glucose urine test may be ordered when the doctor suspects renal glycosuria. This is a rare condition in which glucose is released from the kidneys into the urine, even when the blood glucose level is normal.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Glucose is not usually found in urine. If it is, further testing is needed.</text><text>Normal glucose range in urine: 0 to 0.8 mmol/l (0 to 15 mg/dL)</text><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher than normal levels of glucose may occur with:</text><detail> Diabetes : Small increases in urine glucose levels after a large meal are not always a cause for concern. </detail><detail>Pregnancy: Up to half of women have glucose in their urine at some time during pregnancy. Glucose in the urine may mean that a woman has gestational diabetes .</detail><detail>Renal glycosuria: A rare condition in which glucose is released from the kidneys into the urine, even when blood glucose levels are normal. </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine sugar test</detail><detail> Urine glucose test</detail><detail> Glucosuria test</detail><detail> Glycosuria test</detail>

item.title: Glucose screening tests during pregnancy
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>For either the two-step test or one-step test, eat your normal food in the days before your test. Ask your health care provider if any of the medicines you take can affect your test results. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test checks for gestational diabetes . Most pregnant women have a glucose screening test between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy. The test may be done earlier if you have a high glucose level in your urine during your routine prenatal visits, or if you have a high risk for diabetes.</text><text>Women who have a low risk for diabetes may not have the screening test. To be low-risk, all of these statements must be true:</text><detail>You have never had a test that showed your blood glucose was higher than normal.</detail><detail>Your ethnic group has a low risk for diabetes.</detail><detail>You DO NOT have any first-degree relatives (parent, sibling, or child) with diabetes.</detail><detail>You are younger than 25 years old and have a normal weight.</detail><detail>You have not had any bad outcomes during an earlier pregnancy. </detail>
item.NormalResults: TWO-STEP TESTINGMost of the time, a normal result for the glucose screening test is a blood sugar that is equal to or less than 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) 1 hour after drinking the glucose solution. A normal result means you DO NOT have gestational diabetes.Note: mg/dL means milligrams per deciliter and mmol/L means millimoles per liter. These are two ways to indicate how much glucose is in the blood.If your blood glucose is higher than 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L), the next step is the oral glucose tolerance test. This test will show if you have gestational diabetes. Most women (about 2 out of 3) who take this test DO NOT have gestational diabetes.ONE-STEP TESTINGIf your glucose level is lower than the abnormal results described below, you do not have gestational diabetes.
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>TWO-STEP TESTING</text><text>Abnormal blood values for a 3-hour 100-gram oral glucose tolerance test are:</text><detail>Fasting: greater than 95 mg/dL (5.3 mmol/L)</detail><detail>1 hour: greater than 180 mg/dL (10.0 mmol/L)</detail><detail>2 hour: greater than 155 mg/dL (8.6 mmol/L)</detail><detail>3 hour: greater than 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L)</detail><text>ONE-STEP TESTING</text><text>Abnormal blood values for a 2-hour 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test are:</text><detail>Fasting: greater than 92 mg/dL (5.1 mmol/L)</detail><detail>1 hour: greater than 180 mg/dL (10.0 mmol/L)</detail><detail>2 hour: greater than 153 mg/dL (8.5 mmol/L)</detail><text>If only one of your blood glucose results in the oral glucose tolerance test is higher than normal, your provider may simply suggest you change some of the foods you eat. Then, your provider may test you again after you have changed your diet.</text><text>If more than one of your blood glucose results is higher than normal, you have gestational diabetes.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Oral glucose tolerance test - pregnancy</detail><detail> OGTT - pregnancy</detail><detail> Glucose challenge test - pregnancy</detail><detail> Gestational diabetes - glucose screening</detail>

item.title: Glucagon blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider will tell you if you need to fast (not eat anything) for a period of time before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Glucagon stimulates the liver to release glucose. As the level of blood sugar decreases, the pancreas releases more glucagon. And as blood sugar increases, the pancreas releases less glucagon. </text><text>The provider may measure glucagon level if a person has symptoms of:</text><detail>Diabetes</detail><detail> Glucagonoma (rare tumor of the pancreas) with symptoms of a skin rash called necrotizing migratory erythema, weight loss, mild diabetes, anemia , stomatitis , glossitis </detail><detail> Growth hormone deficiency in children </detail><detail>Liver cirrhosis (scarring of the liver and poor liver function)</detail><detail>Low blood sugar ( hypoglycemia )</detail><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia type I (disease in which one or more of the endocrine glands are overactive or form a tumor)</detail><detail> Pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas) </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 50 to 100 pg/mL.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may indicate that the person may have a condition described above under Why the Test is Performed.</text><text>Some experts now believe that high glucagon levels in the blood contribute to the development of diabetes instead of just a low level of insulin. Medicines are being developed to decrease glucagon levels or block the signal from glucagon in the liver.</text><text>When your blood sugar is low, the level of glucagon in your blood should be high. If it is not increased, this can help identify people that are at higher risk of severe hypoglycemia that can be dangerous.</text><text>Glucagon can be increased by prolonged fasting.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Glucagonoma - glucagon test</detail><detail> Multiple endocrine neoplasia type I - glucagon test</detail><detail> Hypoglycemia - glucagon test</detail><detail> Low blood sugar - glucagon test </detail>

item.title: Glomerular filtration rate
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your health care provider may ask you to temporarily stop any medicines that may affect the test results. These include antibiotics and stomach acid medicines.</text><text>Be sure to tell your provider about all the medicines you take. Do not stop taking any medicine before talking to your doctor.</text><text>Tell your doctor if you are pregnant or think you might be. GFR is affected by pregnancy.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text> The GFR test measures how well your kidneys are filtering the blood. Your doctor may order this test if there are signs that your kidneys are not working well. It may also be done to see how far kidney disease has progressed.</text><text>The GFR test is recommended for people with chronic kidney disease. It is also recommended for persons who may develop kidney disease due to:</text><detail> Diabetes </detail><detail>Family history of kidney disease</detail><detail>Frequent urinary tract infections </detail><detail> Heart disease </detail><detail> High blood pressure </detail><detail>Urinary blockage</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>According to the National Kidney Foundation, normal results range from 90 to 120 mL/min/1.73 m<sup>2</sup>. Older people will have lower than normal GFR levels, because GFR decreases with age.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Levels below 60 mL/min/1.73 m<sup>2</sup> for 3 or more months are a sign of chronic kidney disease. A GFR lower than 15 mL/min/1.73 m<sup>2</sup> is a sign of kidney failure and requires immediate medical attention.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>GFR</detail><detail> Estimated GFR</detail><detail> eGFR</detail>

item.title: Gastrin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. Do NOT stop taking any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Medicines that can increase gastrin level include stomach acid reducers, such as antacids, H2 blockers (ranitidine and cimetidine), and proton pump inhibitors (omeprazole and pantoprazole).</text><text>Drugs that can decrease gastrin level include caffeine, corticosteroids, and the blood pressure drugs deserpidine, reserpine, and rescinnamine.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Gastrin is the main hormone that controls the release of acid in your stomach. When there is food in the stomach, gastrin is released into the blood. As the acid level rises in your stomach and intestines, your body normally makes less gastrin.</text><text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs or symptoms of a problem linked to an abnormal amount of gastrin. This includes peptic ulcer disease .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal values are generally less than 100 pg/mL (48.1 pmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Too much gastrin can causes severe peptic ulcer disease. A higher than normal level may also be due to:</text><detail>Chronic kidney disease</detail><detail>Long-term gastritis </detail><detail>Over-activity of the gastrin-producing cells in the stomach (G-cell hyperplasia)</detail><detail>Helicobacter pylori infection of the stomach</detail><detail>Use of antacids or medicines to treat heartburn</detail><detail> Zollinger-Ellison syndrome , a gastrin-producing tumor that may develop in the stomach or pancreas</detail><detail>Decreased acid production in the stomach</detail><detail>Previous stomach surgery</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Peptic ulcer - gastrin blood test</detail>

item.title: Gastric tissue biopsy and culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Follow instructions on how to prepare for the procedure. You will likely be asked not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 12 hours before the procedure. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to diagnose a stomach ulcer or the cause of other stomach symptoms. These symptoms may include:</text><detail>Loss of appetite or weight loss</detail><detail>Nausea and vomiting</detail><detail>Pain in the upper part of the belly</detail><detail>Black stools</detail><detail>Vomiting blood or coffee ground-like material </detail><text>A gastric tissue biopsy and culture can help detect:</text><detail>Cancer</detail><detail>Infections, most commonly Helicobacter pylori, the bacteria that can cause stomach ulcers </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A gastric tissue biopsy is normal if it does not show cancer, other damage to the lining of the stomach, or signs of organisms that cause infection.</text><text>A gastric tissue culture may be considered normal if it does not show certain bacteria. Stomach acids normally prevent too much bacteria from growing.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Stomach (gastric) cancer </detail><detail> Gastritis , when the lining of the stomach becomes inflamed or swollen</detail><detail>Helicobacter pylori infection </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - gastric tissue</detail><detail> Culture - stomach tissue</detail><detail> Biopsy - gastric tissue</detail><detail> Biopsy - stomach tissue</detail><detail> Upper endoscopy - gastric tissue biopsy</detail><detail> EGD - gastric tissue biopsy </detail>

item.title: Gastric suction
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>In an emergency, such as when a person has swallowed poison or is vomiting blood, no preparation is needed for gastric suction.</text><text>If gastric suction is being done for testing, your health care provider may ask you not to eat overnight or to stop taking certain medicines.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to:</text><detail>Remove poisons, harmful materials, or excess medicines from the stomach</detail><detail>Clean the stomach before an upper endoscopy ( EGD ) if you have been vomiting blood</detail><detail>Collect stomach acid</detail><detail>Relieve pressure if you have a blockage in the intestines </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gastric lavage</detail><detail> Stomach pumping</detail><detail> Nasogastric tube suction</detail><detail> Bowel obstruction - suction</detail>

item.title: Gastric culture
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your child will need to fast for 8 to 10 hours before the test. This means your child cannot eat and drink anything during that time. </text><text>The sample is collected in the morning. For this reason, your child will likely be admitted to the hospital the night before the test. The tube can then be placed in the evening, and the test done first thing in the morning.</text><text>How you prepare your child for this test depends on your child's age, past experience, and level of trust. Follow your provider's instructions on how to prepare your child.</text><text>Related topics include:</text><detail> Infant test or procedure preparation (birth to 1 year)</detail><detail> Toddler test or procedure preparation (1 to 3 years)</detail><detail> Preschooler test or procedure preparation (3 to 6 years)</detail><detail> School age test or procedure preparation (6 to 12 years)</detail><detail> Adolescent test or procedure preparation (12 to 18 years) </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test can help diagnose lung (pulmonary) TB in children. This method is used because children cannot cough up and spit out mucus until about age 8. They swallow the mucus, instead. (That is why young children only rarely spread TB to others.)</text><text>The test may also be done to help identify viruses, fungi, and bacteria in the gastric contents of people with cancer, AIDS, or other conditions that cause a weakened immune system.</text><text>The final results of the gastric culture test may take several weeks. Your provider will decide whether to start treatment before knowing the test results.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The bacteria that cause TB are not found in the stomach contents.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If the bacteria that cause TB grow from the gastric culture, TB is diagnosed. Because these bacteria grow slowly, it may take up to 6 weeks to confirm the diagnosis.</text><text>A test called a TB smear will be done first on the sample. If the results are positive, treatment may be started right away. Be aware that a negative TB smear result does not rule out TB.</text><text>This test can also be used to detect other forms of bacteria that do not cause TB.</text>

item.title: Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The health care provider may tell you to stop taking medicines that can affect the test.</text><text>Drugs that can increase GGT level include:</text><detail>Alcohol</detail><detail>Phenytoin</detail><detail>Phenobarbital</detail><text>Drugs that can decrease GGT level include:</text><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Clofibrate</detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>GGT is an enzyme found in high level in the liver, kidney, pancreas, heart, and brain. It is also found in lesser amount in other tissues. An enzyme is a protein that causes a specific chemical change in the body.</text><text>This test is used to detect diseases of the liver or bile ducts. It is also done with other tests (such as the ALT , AST , ALP , and bilirubin tests) to tell the difference between liver or bile duct disorders and bone disease.</text><text>It may also be done to screen for, or monitor, alcohol use.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range for adults is 0 to 30 U/L (0 to 0.5 µkat/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different specimens. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An increased GGT level may be due to any of the following:</text><detail>Alcohol use</detail><detail>Diabetes</detail><detail>Flow of bile from the liver is blocked ( cholestasis )</detail><detail> Heart failure </detail><detail>Swollen and inflamed liver ( hepatitis )</detail><detail>Lack of blood flow to the liver</detail><detail>Death of liver tissue</detail><detail>Liver cancer or tumor</detail><detail>Lung disease</detail><detail>Pancreas disease</detail><detail>Scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis )</detail><detail>Use of drugs that are toxic to the liver</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Gamma-GT</detail><detail> GGTP</detail><detail> GGT</detail><detail> Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase</detail>

item.title: Gallium scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Stool in the bowel can interfere with the test. You may need to take a laxative the night before you have the test. Or, you may get an enema 1 to 2 hours before the test. You may eat and drink liquids normally. </text><text>You will need to sign a consent form. You will need to take off all jewelry and metal objects before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to look for the cause of a fever that has lasted a few weeks without an explanation.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Gallium normally collects in bones, the liver, spleen, the large bowel, and breast tissue.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Gallium detected outside normal areas can be a sign of:</text><detail>Infection</detail><detail>Inflammation</detail><detail>Tumors, including Hodgkin disease or non-Hodgkin lymphoma </detail><text>The test may be done to look for lung conditions such as:</text><detail>Primary pulmonary hypertension </detail><detail> Pulmonary embolus </detail><detail>Respiratory infections, most often Pneumocystitis jirovecii pneumonia </detail><detail> Sarcoidosis </detail><detail> Scleroderma of the lung</detail><detail>Tumors in the lung </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Liver gallium scan</detail><detail> Bony gallium scan</detail>

item.title: Gallbladder radionuclide scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You need to eat something within a day of the test. However, you must stop eating or drinking 4 hours before the test starts.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is very good for detecting a sudden infection of the gallbladder or blockage of a bile duct. It is also helpful in determining whether there is rejection of a transplanted liver or a leak after the gallbladder has been surgically removed.</text><text>The test can also be used to detect long-term gallbladder problems.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Abnormal anatomy of the bile system (biliary anomalies)</detail><detail> Bile duct obstruction </detail><detail>Bile leaks or abnormal ducts</detail><detail> Cancer of the hepatobiliary system </detail><detail>Gallbladder infection ( cholecystitis )</detail><detail> Gallstones </detail><detail>Infection of the gallbladder, ducts, or liver</detail><detail> Liver disease </detail><detail> Transplant rejection (after liver transplant ) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Radionuclide - gallbladder</detail><detail> Gallbladder scan</detail><detail> Biliary scan</detail><detail> Cholescintigraphy</detail><detail> HIDA</detail><detail> Hepatobiliary nuclear imaging scan</detail>

item.title: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase blood test
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This is a screening test for galactosemia.</text><text>In normal diets, most galactose comes from the breakdown ( metabolism ) of lactose, which is found in milk and dairy products. One out of 65,000 newborns lack a substance (enzyme) called GALT. Without this substance, the body cannot break down galactose, and the substance builds up in the blood. Continued use of milk products can lead to:</text><detail>Clouding of the lens of the eye ( cataracts )</detail><detail>Scarring of the liver ( cirrhosis )</detail><detail> Failure to thrive </detail><detail>Yellow color of the skin or eyes ( jaundice )</detail><detail> Liver enlargement </detail><detail> Intellectual disability </detail><text>This can be a serious condition if not treated.</text><text>Every state in the United States requires newborn screening tests to check for this disorder.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 18.5 to 28.5 U/g Hb (units per gram of hemoglobin ).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result suggests galactosemia. Further tests must be done to confirm the diagnosis.</text><text>If your child has galactosemia, a genetics specialist should be consulted promptly. The child should be put on a no-milk diet right away. This means no breast milk and no animal milk. Soy milk and infant soy formulas are generally used as substitutes. </text><text>This test is very sensitive, so it does not miss many infants with galactosemia. But, false-positives can occur. If your child has an abnormal screening result, follow-up tests must be done to confirm the result.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Galactosemia screen</detail><detail> GALT</detail><detail> Gal-1-PUT</detail>

item.title: Hysterosalpingography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may give you antibiotics to take before and after the test. This helps prevent infections. You may also be given medicines to take the day of the procedure to help you relax.</text><text>The best time for this test is in the first half of the menstrual cycle. Doing it at this time enables the health care provider to see uterine cavity and tubes more clearly. It also reduces the risk for infection, and ensures that you are not pregnant.</text><text>Tell your provider if you have had an allergic reaction to contrast dye before. </text><text>You can eat and drink normally before the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to check for blockages in your fallopian tubes or other problems in the womb and tubes. It is often done as part of an infertility exam. It may also be done after you have your tubes tied to confirm that the tubes are fully blocked after you have had a hysteroscopic tubal occlusion procedure to prevent pregnancy. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means everything looks normal. There are no defects. </text><text>Note: Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Developmental disorders of the structures of the uterus or fallopian tubes</detail><detail>Scar tissue (adhesions) in the uterus or tubes</detail><detail>Blockage of the fallopian tubes</detail><detail>Presence of foreign bodies</detail><detail>Tumors or polyps in the uterus </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>HSG</detail><detail> Uterosalpingography</detail><detail> Hysterogram</detail><detail> Uterotubography</detail><detail> Infertility - hysterosalpingography</detail><detail> Blocked fallopian tubes - hysterosalpingography</detail>

item.title: Home vision tests
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You need a well-lit area at least 10 feet (3 meters) long for the distance vision test, and the following:</text><detail>Measuring tape or a yardstick</detail><detail>Eye charts</detail><detail>Tape or tacks to hang the eye charts on the wall</detail><detail>A pencil to record results</detail><detail>Another person to help (if possible)</detail><text>The vision chart needs to be tacked to the wall at eye level. Mark the floor with a piece of tape exactly 10 feet (3 meters) from the chart on the wall.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your vision may change gradually without you being aware of it.</text><text>Home vision tests can help detect eye and vision problems early. Home vision tests should be performed under the direction of your health care provider to detect changes that may occur between eye exams. They do not take the place of a professional eye exam.</text><text>People who are at risk of developing macular degeneration may be told by their ophthalmologist to perform the Amsler grid test more often. It is best to do this test once a week. Macular degeneration changes are gradual, and you can miss them if you test daily.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results for each of the tests are as follows:</text><detail>Amsler grid test: All lines appear straight and unbroken with no distorted or missing areas.</detail><detail>Distance vision test: All letters on the 20/20 line read correctly.</detail><detail>Near vision test: You are able to read the line labeled 20/20 or J-1. </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean you have a vision problem or eye disease and you should have a professional eye examination.</text><detail>Amsler grid test: If the grid appears distorted or broken, there may be a problem with the retina .</detail><detail>Distance vision test: If you do not read the 20/20 line correctly, it may be a sign of nearsightedness (myopia), farsightedness (hyperopia), astigmatism , or another eye abnormality.</detail><detail>Near vision test: Not being able to read the small type may be a sign of aging vision ( presbyopia ).</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Visual acuity test - home</detail><detail> Amsler grid test</detail>

item.title: Holter monitor (24h)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You DO NOT need to prepare for the test. </text><text>Your provider will start the monitor. You'll be told how to replace the electrodes if they fall off or get loose.</text><text>Tell your provider if you are allergic to any tape or other adhesives. Make sure you shower or bathe before you start the test. You will not be able to do so while you are wearing a Holter monitor.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Holter monitoring is used to determine how the heart responds to normal activity. The monitor may also be used:</text><detail>After a heart attack </detail><detail>To diagnose heart rhythm problems that may be causing symptoms such as palpitations or syncope (passing out/ fainting )</detail><detail>When starting a new heart medicine </detail><text>Heart rhythms which may be recorded include:</text><detail> Atrial fibrillation or flutter </detail><detail> Multifocal atrial tachycardia </detail><detail> Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia </detail><detail>Slow heart rate (bradycardia)</detail><detail> Ventricular tachycardia </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal variations in heart rate occur with activities. A normal result is no significant changes in heart rhythms or pattern.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may include various arrhythmias such as those listed above. Some changes may mean that the heart is not getting enough oxygen.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Ambulatory electrocardiography</detail><detail> Electrocardiography - ambulatory</detail><detail> Atrial fibrillation - Holter</detail><detail> Flutter - Holter</detail><detail> Tachycardia - Holter</detail><detail> Abnormal heart rhythm - Holter</detail><detail> Arrythmia - Holter</detail><detail> Syncope - Holter</detail><detail> Arrhythmia - Holter</detail>

item.title: HLA-B27 antigen
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>In most cases, no special steps are needed to prepare for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your health care provider may order this test to help determine the cause of joint pain, stiffness, or swelling. The test may be done along with other tests, including:</text><detail> C-reactive protein </detail><detail>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate ( ESR )</detail><detail> Rheumatoid factor </detail><detail>X-rays </detail><text> HLA testing is also used to match donated tissue with a person's tissue who is getting an organ transplant. For example, it may be done when a person needs a kidney transplant or bone marrow transplant .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal (negative) result means HLA-B27 is absent.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A positive test means HLA-B27 is present. It suggests a greater-than-average risk for developing or having certain autoimmune disorders. An autoimmune disorder is a condition that occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys healthy body tissue.</text><text>A positive result can help your provider make a diagnosis of a form of arthritis called spondyloarthritis. This kind of arthritis includes the following disorders:</text><detail> Ankylosing spondylitis </detail><detail>Arthritis related to Crohn disease or ulcerative colitis</detail><detail>Psoriatic arthritis (arthritis associated with psoriasis)</detail><detail> Reactive arthritis </detail><detail>Sacroiliitis (inflammation of the sacroiliac joint)</detail><detail> Uveitis </detail><text>If you have symptoms or signs of spondyloarthritis, a positive HLA-B27 test may help confirm the diagnosis. However, HLA-B27 is found in some normal people and does not always mean you have a disease.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Human leukocyte antigen B27</detail><detail> Ankylosing spondylitis-HLA</detail><detail> Psoriatic arthritis-HLA</detail><detail> Reactive arthritis-HLA</detail>

item.title: Histoplasma skin test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to determine if you have been exposed to the fungus that causes histoplasmosis.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>No reaction (inflammation) at the site of the test is normal. The skin test can rarely make histoplasmosis antibody tests turn positive.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A reaction means you have been exposed to Histoplasma capsulatum. It does not always mean you have an active infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Histoplasmosis skin test</detail>

item.title: Histoplasma complement fixation
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for the test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to detect histoplasmosis infection.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The absence of antibodies (negative test) is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may mean you have an active histoplasmosis infection.</text><text>During the early stage of an illness, few antibodies may be detected. Antibody production increases during the course of an infection. For this reason, this test may be repeated several weeks after the first test.</text><text>People who have been exposed to H capsulatum in the past may have antibodies to it, often at low levels. But they may not have shown signs of illness.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Histoplasma antibody test</detail>

item.title: Histocompatibility antigen test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You do not need to prepare for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The results from this test can be used to identify good matches for tissue grafts and organ transplants. These may include kidney transplant or bone marrow transplant .</text><text>It may also be used to:</text><detail>Diagnose certain autoimmune disorders</detail><detail>Determine relationships between children and parents when such relationships are in question</detail><detail>Monitor treatment with some medicines </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>You have a small set of HLAs that are passed down from your parents. Children, on average, will have half of their HLAs match half of their mother's and half of their HLAs match half of their father's. </text><text>It is unlikely that two unrelated people will have the same HLA makeup. However, identical twins may match each other. </text><text>Some HLA types are more common in certain autoimmune diseases . For example, HLA-B27 antigen is found in many people (but not all) with ankylosing spondylitis and Reiter syndrome .</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>HLA typing</detail><detail> Tissue typing</detail>

item.title: His bundle electrography
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be told not to eat or drink anything for 6 to 8 hours before the test. The test will be done in a hospital. Some people may need to check into the hospital the night before the test. Otherwise, you will check in the morning of the test. Although the test may take some time, most people DO NOT need to stay in the hospital overnight.</text><text>Your health care provider will explain the procedure and its risks. You must sign a consent form before the test starts.</text><text>About half an hour before the procedure, you will be given a mild sedative to help you relax. You will wear a hospital gown. The procedure may last from 1 to several hours.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test may be done to:</text><detail>Determine if you need a pacemaker or other treatment</detail><detail>Diagnose arrhythmias </detail><detail>Find the specific location where electrical signals through the heart are blocked</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The time it takes for the electrical signals to travel through the bundle of His is normal.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A pacemaker will be needed if the test results are abnormal.</text><text>Abnormal results may mean you have or had:</text><detail>Chronic conduction system disease</detail><detail>Carotid sinus pressure</detail><detail>Recent heart attack </detail><detail>Atrial disease</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>His bundle electrogram</detail><detail> HBE</detail><detail> His bundle recording</detail><detail> Electrogram - His bundle</detail><detail> Arrhythmia - His</detail><detail> Heart block - His</detail>

item.title: Herpes viral culture of lesion
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>The sample must be collected during the acute phase of infection. This is the worst part of an outbreak. It is also when the skin lesions are at their worst.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test is done to confirm herpes infection. Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes . It can also cause cold sores of the mouth and lips. Herpes zoster causes chickenpox and shingles .</text><text>The diagnosis is often made by physical examination (the provider looking at the sores). The cultures and other tests are used to confirm the diagnosis.</text><text>This test is most likely accurate when a person is newly infected, that is, during the first outbreak.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal (negative) result means that the herpes simplex virus did not grow in the laboratory dish and the skin sample used in the test did not contain any herpes virus.</text><text>Be aware that a normal (negative) culture does not always mean that you do not have a herpes infection or have not had one in the past. </text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal (positive) result may mean that you have an active infection with herpes simplex virus. Herpes infections include genital herpes , cold sores on the lips or in the mouth, or shingles. More blood tests will likely be needed to confirm the diagnosis or the exact cause.</text><text>If the culture is positive for herpes, you may have recently become infected. You may have become infected in the past and are currently having an outbreak. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Culture - herpes simplex virus</detail><detail> Herpes simplex virus culture</detail><detail> Herpes zoster virus culture</detail>

item.title: Hepatitis virus panel
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of hepatitis. It is used to:</text><detail>Detect current or previous hepatitis infection</detail><detail>Determine how contagious a person with hepatitis is</detail><detail>Monitor a person who is being treated for hepatitis </detail><text>The test may be performed for other conditions, such as:</text><detail>Chronic persistent hepatitis</detail><detail> Hepatitis D (delta agent) </detail><detail> Nephrotic syndrome </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result means no hepatitis antibodies are found in the blood sample. This is called a negative result.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly depending on the lab doing the test. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>There are different tests for hepatitis A and B. A positive test is considered abnormal.</text><text>A positive test may mean:</text><detail>You currently have a hepatitis infection. This may be a new infection (acute hepatitis), or it may be an infection that you have had for a long time ( chronic hepatitis).</detail><detail>You had a hepatitis infection in the past, but you no longer have the infection and can't spread it to others. </detail><text>Hepatitis A test results:</text><detail>IgM anti-hepatitis A virus (HAV) antibodies, you have had a recent infection with hepatitis A</detail><detail>Total (IgM and IgG) antibodies to hepatitis A, you have a previous or past infection, or immunity to hepatitis A </detail><text>Hepatitis B test results:</text><detail>Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg): you have an active hepatitis B infection, either recent or chronic (long-term)</detail><detail>Antibody to hepatitis B core antigen (Anti-HBc), you have a recent or past hepatitis B infection</detail><detail>Antibody to HBsAg (Anti-HBs): you have a past hepatitis B infection or you have received the hepatitis B vaccine and are unlikely to become infected</detail><detail>Hepatitis B type e antigen (HBeAg): you have a chronic hepatitis B infection and you are more likely to spread the infection to others through sexual contact or by sharing needles </detail><text>Antibodies to hepatitis C can most often be detected 4 to 10 weeks after you get the infection. Other types of tests may be done to decide on treatment and monitor the hepatitis C infection.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Hepatitis A antibody test</detail><detail> Hepatitis B antibody test</detail><detail> Hepatitis C antibody test</detail><detail> Hepatitis D antibody test</detail>

item.title: Hemoglobinuria test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test. If the collection is being taken from an infant, a couple of extra collection bags may be necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Hemoglobin is a molecule attached to red blood cells. Hemoglobin helps move oxygen and carbon dioxide through the body.</text><text>Red blood cells have an average life span of 120 days. After this time, they are broken down into parts that can make a new red blood cell. This breakdown takes place in the spleen, bone marrow, and liver. If the red blood cells break down in the blood vessels, their parts move freely in the bloodstream.</text><text>If the level of hemoglobin in the blood rises too high, then hemoglobin begins to appear in the urine. This is called hemoglobinuria.</text><text>This test may be used to help diagnose causes of hemoglobinuria.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, hemoglobin does not appear in the urine.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Hemoglobinuria may be a result of any of the following:</text><detail>A kidney disorder called acute glomerulonephritis </detail><detail>Burns</detail><detail>Crushing injury</detail><detail> Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) </detail><detail>Kidney infection</detail><detail> Kidney tumor </detail><detail> Malaria </detail><detail> Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria </detail><detail>Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria</detail><detail> Sickle cell anemia </detail><detail> Thalassemia </detail><detail>Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)</detail><detail>Transfusion reaction</detail><detail> Tuberculosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Urine - hemoglobin</detail>

item.title: Hemoglobin electrophoresis
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>You may have this test if your health care provider suspects that you have a disorder caused by abnormal forms of hemoglobin ( hemoglobinopathy ).</text><text>Many different types of hemoglobin (Hb) exist. The most common ones are HbA, HbA2, HbE, HbF, HbS, HbC, HbH, and HbM. Healthy adults only have significant levels of only HbA and HbA2.</text><text>Some people may also have small amounts of HbF. This is the main type of hemoglobin in an unborn baby's body. Certain diseases are associated with high HbF levels (when HbF is more than 2% of the total hemoglobin).</text><text>HbS is an abnormal form of hemoglobin associated with sickle cell anemia . In people with this condition, the red blood cells sometimes have a crescent or sickle shape. These cells easily break down or can block small blood vessels.</text><text>HbC is an abnormal form of hemoglobin associated with hemolytic anemia . The symptoms are much milder than they are in sickle cell anemia.</text><text>Other, less common, abnormal Hb molecules cause other types of anemia .</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>In adults, these are normal percentages of different hemoglobin molecules:</text><detail>HbA: 95% to 98% (0.95 to 0.98)</detail><detail>HbA2: 2% to 3% (0.02 to 0.03)</detail><detail>HbE: Absent</detail><detail>HbF: 0.8% to 2% (0.008 to 0.02) </detail><detail>HbS: Absent</detail><detail>HbC: Absent</detail><text>In infants and children, these are normal percentage of HbF molecules:</text><detail>HbF (newborn): 50% to 80% (0.5 to 0.8)</detail><detail>HbF (6 months): 8%</detail><detail>HbF (over 6 months): 1% to 2%</detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or may test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Significant levels of abnormal hemoglobins may indicate:</text><detail>Hemoglobin C disease</detail><detail>Rare hemoglobinopathy</detail><detail>Sickle cell anemia</detail><detail>Inherited blood disorder in which the body makes an abnormal form of hemoglobin ( thalassemia )</detail><text>You may have false normal or abnormal results if you have had a blood transfusion within 12 weeks of this test.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Hb electrophoresis</detail><detail> Hgb electrophoresis</detail><detail> Electrophoresis - hemoglobin</detail><detail> Thallasemia - electrophoresis</detail><detail> Sickle cell - electrophoresis</detail><detail> Hemoglobinopathy - electrophoresis</detail>

item.title: Hemoglobin derivatives
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text><text>For children, it may help to explain how the test will feel and why it is done. This may make the child feel less nervous.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to diagnose carbon monoxide poisoning . It is also used to detect changes in hemoglobin that may result from certain drugs. Some chemicals or drugs can change the hemoglobin so it no longer works properly.</text><text>Abnormal forms of hemoglobin include:</text><detail> Carboxyhemoglobin: An abnormal form of hemoglobin that has attached to carbon monoxide instead of oxygen or carbon dioxide. High amounts of this type of abnormal hemoglobin prevent the normal movement of oxygen by the blood.</detail><detail> Sulfhemoglobin: A rare abnormal form of hemoglobin that can't carry oxygen. It may result from certain medicines such as phenacetin, or sulfonamides.</detail><detail> Methemoglobin: A problem that occurs when the iron that is part of hemoglobin is changed so that it does not carry oxygen well. Certain drugs and other compounds such as nitrites introduced into the blood stream can cause this problem.</detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>The following values represent the percentage of hemoglobin derivatives based on total hemoglobin:</text><detail>Carboxyhemoglobin -- less than 1.5% (but may be as high as 9% in smokers)</detail><detail>Methemoglobin -- less than 2%</detail><detail>Sulfhemoglobin -- undetectable </detail><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text><text>The examples above show the common measurements for results for these tests. Some laboratories use different measurements or may test different specimens.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High levels of hemoglobin derivatives can lead to major health problems. The altered forms of hemoglobin do not allow oxygen to be moved properly through the body. This can lead to tissue death.</text><text>The following values, except sulfhemoglobin, represent the percentage of hemoglobin derivatives based on total hemoglobin.</text><text>Carboxyhemoglobin:</text><detail>10% to 20% -- symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning begin to appear</detail><detail>30% -- severe carbon monoxide poisoning present</detail><detail>50% to 80% -- results in potentially deadly carbon monoxide poisoning</detail><text>Methemoglobin:</text><detail>10% to 25% -- results in bluish skin color ( cyanosis )</detail><detail>35% to 40% -- results in shortness of breath and headache</detail><detail>Over 60% -- results in lethargy and stupor </detail><detail>Over 70% -- may result in death</detail><text>Sulfhemoglobin:</text><detail>Values of 10 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 6.2 millimoles per liter (mmol/L) cause bluish skin color due to lack of oxygen (cyanosis), but do not cause harmful effects most of the time.</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Methemoglobin</detail><detail> Carboxyhemoglobin</detail><detail> Sulfhemoglobin</detail>

item.title: Hemoglobin
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The hemoglobin test is a common test and is almost always done as part of a complete blood count (CBC). Reasons or conditions for ordering the hemoglobin test include:</text><detail>Symptoms such as fatigue, poor health, or unexplained weight loss</detail><detail>Signs of bleeding</detail><detail>Before and after major surgery</detail><detail>During pregnancy</detail><detail>Chronic kidney disease or many other chronic medical problems</detail><detail>Monitoring of anemia and its cause</detail><detail>Monitoring during treatment for cancer</detail><detail>Monitoring medicines that may cause anemia or low blood counts </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results for adults vary, but in general are:</text><detail>Male: 13.8 to 17.2 grams per deciliter (g/dL) or 138 to 172 grams per liter (g/L)</detail><detail>Female: 12.1 to 15.1 g/dL or 121 to 151 g/L</detail><text>Normal results for children vary, but in general are:</text><detail>Newborn: 14 to 24 g/dL or 140 to 240 g/L</detail><detail>Infant: 9.5 to 13 g/dL or 95 to 130 g/L</detail><text>The ranges above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>LOWER THAN NORMAL HEMOGLOBIN</text><text>Low hemoglobin level may be due to:</text><detail>Anemia caused by red blood cells dying earlier than normal ( hemolytic anemia )</detail><detail>Anemia (various types)</detail><detail> Bleeding from digestive tract or bladder, heavy menstrual periods</detail><detail>Chronic kidney disease</detail><detail>Bone marrow being unable to produce new red blood cells. This may be due to leukemia , other cancers, drug toxicity, radiation therapy, infection, or bone marrow disorders</detail><detail> Poor nutrition (including low level of iron, folate, vitamin B12, or vitamin B6)</detail><detail>Low level of iron, folate , vitamin B12 , or vitamin B6 </detail><detail>Other chronic illness, such as rheumatoid arthritis </detail><text>HIGHER THAN NORMAL HEMOGLOBIN</text><text>High hemoglobin level is most often caused by low oxygen levels in the blood (hypoxia), present over a long period of time. Common reasons include:</text><detail>Certain birth defects of the heart that are present at birth ( congenital heart disease )</detail><detail>Failure of the right side of the heart ( cor pulmonale )</detail><detail>Severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</detail><detail>Scarring or thickening of the lungs ( pulmonary fibrosis ) and other severe lung disorders </detail><text>Other reasons for high hemoglobin level includes:</text><detail>A rare bone marrow disease that leads to an abnormal increase in the number of blood cells ( polycythemia vera )</detail><detail>The body having too little water and fluids (dehydration) </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Hgb</detail><detail> Hb</detail><detail> Anemia - Hb</detail><detail> Polycythemia - Hb</detail>

item.title: Hematocrit
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The hematocrit is almost always done as part of a complete blood count ( CBC ).</text><text>Your health care provider may recommend this test if you have signs of or are at risk for anemia. These include having:</text><detail>Grumpiness or tiredness</detail><detail>Headaches</detail><detail>Problems concentrating</detail><detail>Poor nutrition</detail><detail>Heavy menstrual periods</detail><detail>Blood in your stools, or vomit (if you throw up)</detail><detail>Treatment for cancer</detail><detail>Leukemia or other problems in the bone marrow</detail><detail>Chronic medical problems, such as kidney disease or certain types of arthritis </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal results vary, but in general they are:</text><detail>Male: 40.7% to 50.3%</detail><detail>Female: 36.1% to 44.3%</detail><text>For babies, normal results are:</text><detail>Newborn: 45% to 61%</detail><detail>Infant: 32% to 42%</detail><text>The examples above are common measurements for results of these tests. Normal value ranges vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Low hematocrit may be due to:</text><detail> Anemia </detail><detail>Bleeding</detail><detail>Destruction of red blood cells</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail> Malnutrition </detail><detail>Too little iron, folate, vitamin B12, and vitamin B6 in the diet</detail><detail>Too much water in the body </detail><text>High hematocrit may be due to:</text><detail> Congenital heart disease </detail><detail>Failure of the right side of the heart</detail><detail>Too little water in the body ( dehydration )</detail><detail>Low levels of oxygen in the blood</detail><detail>Scarring or thickening of the lungs</detail><detail>Bone marrow disease that causes abnormal increase in red blood cells </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>HCT</detail>

item.title: Heart PET scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan. You will be able to drink water. Sometimes you may be given a special diet before the test.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if:</text><detail>You are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious.</detail><detail>You are pregnant or think you might be pregnant.</detail><detail>You have any allergies to injected dye (contrast).</detail><detail>You take insulin for diabetes. You will need special preparation. </detail><text>Always tell your provider about the medicines you are taking, including those bought without a prescription. Sometimes, medicines may interfere with the test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>A heart PET scan can reveal the size, shape, position, and some function of the heart.</text><text>It is most often used when other tests, such as echocardiogram (ECG) and cardiac stress tests do not provide enough information.</text><text>This test can be used to diagnose heart problems and show areas in which there is poor blood flow to the heart.</text><text>Several PET scans may be taken over time to determine how well you are responding to treatment for heart disease.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>If your test involved exercise, a normal test will usually mean that you were able to exercise for as long or longer than most people of your age and gender. You also did not have symptoms or changes in blood pressure or your ECG that caused concern.</text><text>There are no problems detected in the size, shape, or function of the heart. There are no areas in which the radiotracer has abnormally collected.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Coronary artery disease </detail><detail> Heart failure or cardiomyopathy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Heart nuclear medicine scan</detail><detail> Heart positron emission tomography</detail><detail> Myocardial PET scan</detail>

item.title: Heart MRI
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You may be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the scan.</text><text>Tell your health care provider if you are afraid of close spaces (have claustrophobia). You may be given a medicine to help you feel sleepy and less anxious, or your provider may suggest an "open" MRI, in which the machine is not as close to the body.</text><text>Before the test, tell your provider if you have:</text><detail>Brain aneurysm clips</detail><detail>Certain types of artificial heart valves</detail><detail>Heart defibrillator or pacemaker</detail><detail>Inner ear (cochlear) implants</detail><detail>Kidney disease or dialysis (you may not be able to receive contrast)</detail><detail>Recently placed artificial joints</detail><detail>Certain types of vascular stents </detail><detail>Worked with sheet metal in the past (you may need tests to check for metal pieces in your eyes) </detail><text>Because the MRI contains strong magnets, metal objects are not allowed into the room with the MRI scanner:</text><detail>Pens, pocketknives, and eyeglasses may fly across the room.</detail><detail>Items such as jewelry, watches, credit cards, and hearing aids can be damaged.</detail><detail>Pins, hairpins, metal zippers, and similar metallic items can distort the images.</detail><detail>Removable dental work should be taken out just before the scan. </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text> MRI provides detailed pictures of the heart and blood vessels from many views. Often, it is used when more information is needed after you have had an echocardiogram or heart CT scan. MRI is more accurate than CT scan or other tests for certain conditions, but less accurate for others.</text><text>Heart MRI may be used to evaluate or diagnose:</text><detail>Heart muscle damage after a heart attack</detail><detail>Birth defects of the heart</detail><detail>Heart tumors and growths</detail><detail>Weakening or other problems with the heart muscle</detail><detail>Symptoms of heart failure </detail>
