item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to many things, including:</text><detail>Heart valve disorders</detail><detail>Fluid in the sac-like covering around the heart ( pericardial effusion )</detail><detail>Tumor of the blood vessels or around the heart</detail><detail> Atrial myxoma or another growth or tumor in the heart</detail><detail>Congenital heart disease (heart problem that you are born with)</detail><detail>Damage or death to the heart muscle, seen after a heart attack </detail><detail>Inflammation of the heart muscle</detail><detail>Infiltration of the heart muscle by unusual substances</detail><detail>Weakening of the heart muscle, which can be caused by sarcoidosis or amyloidosis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Magnetic resonance imaging - cardiac</detail><detail> Magnetic resonance imaging - heart</detail><detail> Nuclear magnetic resonance - cardiac</detail><detail> NMR - cardiac</detail><detail> MRI of the heart</detail><detail> Cardiomyopathy - MRI</detail><detail> Heart failure - MRI</detail><detail> Congenital heart disease - MRI</detail>

item.title: Heart CT scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain exams require a special dye, called contrast, to be delivered into the body before the test starts. Contrast helps certain areas show up better on the x-rays. </text><detail>Contrast can be given through a vein (IV) in your hand or forearm. If contrast is used, you may also be asked not to eat or drink anything for 4 to 6 hours before the test. </detail><text>Before receiving the contrast:</text><detail>Let your health care provider know if you have ever had a reaction to contrast or any medicines. You may need to take medicines before the test in order to safely receive this substance.</detail><detail>Tell your provider about all your medicines, because you may be asked to hold some, such as the diabetes medicine metformin (Glucophage), prior to the test. </detail><detail>Let your provider know if you have kidney problems. The contrast material can cause kidney function to worsen.</detail><text>If you weigh more than 300 pounds (135 kilograms), find out if the CT machine has a weight limit. Too much weight can cause damage to the scanner's working parts. </text><text>You will be asked to remove jewelry and wear a hospital gown during the study.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>CT rapidly creates detailed pictures of the heart and its arteries. The test may diagnose or detect:</text><detail>Plaque build-up in the coronary arteries to determine your risk for heart disease</detail><detail> Congenital heart disease (heart problems that are present at birth)</detail><detail>Problems with the heart valves</detail><detail>Blockage of the arteries that supply the heart</detail><detail>Tumors or masses of the heart</detail><detail>Pumping function of the heart </detail>
item.NormalResults: <text>Results are considered normal if the heart and arteries being examined are normal in appearance.</text><text>Your "calcium score" is based on the amount of calcium found in the arteries of your heart.</text><detail>The test is normal (negative) if your calcium score is 0. This means the chance of having a heart attack over the next 2 to 5 years is very low. </detail><detail>If the calcium score is very low, you are unlikely to have coronary artery disease. </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail>Aneurysm</detail><detail>Congenital heart disease</detail><detail>Coronary artery disease</detail><detail>Heart valve problems</detail><detail>Inflammation of the covering around the heart (pericarditis)</detail><detail>Narrowing of one or more coronary arteries (coronary artery stenosis)</detail><detail>Tumors or other masses of the heart or surrounding areas</detail><text>If your calcium score is high:</text><detail>It means you have calcium buildup in the walls of your coronary arteries. This is usually a sign of atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries.</detail><detail>The higher your score, the more severe this problem may be.</detail><detail>Talk to your provider about lifestyle changes you can make to decrease the risk of heart disease.</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>CAT scan - heart</detail><detail> Computed axial tomography scan - heart</detail><detail> Computed tomography scan - heart</detail><detail> Calcium scoring</detail><detail> Multi-detector CT scan - heart</detail><detail> Electron beam computed tomography - heart</detail><detail> Agatston score</detail><detail> Coronary calcium scan</detail>

item.title: HCG in urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Urine HCG tests are a common method of determining if a woman is pregnant. The best time to test for pregnancy at home is after you miss your period.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test result will be reported as negative or positive.</text><detail>The test is negative if you are not pregnant.</detail><detail>The test is positive if you are pregnant. </detail><text>A pregnancy test, including a properly performed home pregnancy test, is considered to be very accurate. Positive results are more likely to be accurate than negative results. When the test is negative but pregnancy is still suspected, the test should be repeated in 1 week.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Beta-HCG - urine</detail><detail> Human chorionic gonadotropin - urine</detail><detail> Pregnancy test - hCG in urine</detail>

item.title: HCG blood test - quantitative
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>HCG appears in the blood and urine of pregnant women as early as 10 days after conception. Quantitative HCG measurement helps determine the exact age of the fetus. It can also diagnose abnormal pregnancies, such as ectopic pregnancies, molar pregnancies, and possible miscarriages. It is also used as part of a screening test for Down syndrome.</text><text>This test is also done to diagnose abnormal conditions not related to pregnancy that can raise HCG level.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>HCG level rises rapidly during the first trimester of pregnancy and then slightly declines.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Higher than normal level may indicate:</text><detail>Normal pregnancy</detail><detail>More than one fetus, for example, twins or triplets</detail><detail> Choriocarcinoma of the uterus</detail><detail> Hydatidiform mole of the uterus</detail><detail> Ovarian cancer </detail><detail> Testicular cancer (in men) </detail><text>Lower than normal levels may indicate:</text><detail> Fetal death </detail><detail>Incomplete miscarriage </detail><detail> Threatened spontaneous abortion (miscarriage)</detail><detail> Ectopic pregnancy </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Serial beta HCG</detail><detail> Repeat quantitative beta HCG</detail><detail> Human chorionic gonadotropin blood test - quantitative</detail><detail> Beta-HCG blood test - quantitative</detail><detail> Pregnancy test - blood - quantitative</detail>

item.title: HCG blood test - qualitative
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special preparation is needed.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Most often, this test is performed to determine if you are pregnant. HCG level in the blood may also be high in women with certain types of ovarian tumors or in men with testicular tumors.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The test result will be reported as negative or positive.</text><detail>The test is negative if you are not pregnant.</detail><detail>The test is positive if you are pregnant.</detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>If your blood HCG is positive and you DO NOT have a pregnancy properly implanted in the uterus, it may indicate:</text><detail> Ectopic pregnancy </detail><detail> Miscarriage </detail><detail> Testicular cancer (in men)</detail><detail> Trophoblastic tumor </detail><detail> Hydatidiform mole </detail><detail> Ovarian cancer </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Beta-HCG in blood serum - qualitative</detail><detail> Human chorionic gonadotrophin - serum - qualitative</detail><detail> Pregnancy test - blood - qualitative</detail><detail> Serum HCG - qualitative</detail><detail> HCG in blood serum - qualitative</detail>

item.title: Haptoglobin blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Certain medicines may affect the results of this test. Your health care provider will tell you if you need to stop taking any medicines. DO NOT stop any medicine before talking to your provider.</text><text>Drugs that can raise haptoglobin levels include:</text><detail>Androgens</detail><detail>Corticosteroids </detail><text>Drugs that can lower haptoglobin levels include:</text><detail>Birth control pills</detail><detail>Chlorpromazine</detail><detail>Diphenhydramine</detail><detail>Indomethacin</detail><detail>Isoniazid</detail><detail>Nitrofurantoin</detail><detail>Quinidine</detail><detail>Streptomycin </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is done to see how fast your red blood cells are destroyed. It may be done if your provider suspects you have a type of anemia that your immune system is causing.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>The normal range is 41 to 165 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or 410 to 1,650 milligrams per liter (mg/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>When red blood cells are actively being destroyed, haptoglobin disappears faster than it is created. As a result, the levels of haptoglobin in the blood drop.</text><text>Lower than normal levels may be due to:</text><detail>Immune hemolytic anemia</detail><detail>Long-term (chronic) liver disease</detail><detail>Blood buildup under the skin (hematoma)</detail><detail>Liver disease</detail><detail>Transfusion reaction </detail><text>Higher-than-normal levels may be due to:</text><detail> Blockage of the bile ducts </detail><detail>Joint or muscle inflammation, swelling, and pain that comes on suddenly</detail><detail> Peptic ulcer </detail><detail> Ulcerative colitis </detail><detail>Other inflammatory conditions </detail>

item.title: Hand x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the provider if you are pregnant or think you may be pregnant. Remove all jewelry from your hand and wrist.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Hand x-ray is used to detect fractures , tumors, foreign objects, or degenerative conditions of the hand. Hand x-rays may also be done to find out a child's "bone age." This can help determine if a health problem is preventing the child from growing properly or how much growth is left.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may include:</text><detail>Fractures</detail><detail> Bone tumors </detail><detail>Degenerative bone conditions</detail><detail> Osteomyelitis (inflammation of the bone caused by an infection)</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - hand</detail>

item.title: Intravenous pyelogram
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>As with all x-ray procedures, tell your provider if you:</text><detail>Are allergic to contrast material</detail><detail>Are pregnant</detail><detail>Have any drug allergies</detail><detail>Have kidney disease or diabetes</detail><text>Your provider will tell you if you can eat or drink before this test. You may be given a laxative to take the afternoon before the procedure to clear the intestines. This will help your kidneys to be seen clearly.</text><text>You must sign a consent form. You will be asked to wear a hospital gown and to remove all jewelry.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>An IVP can be used to evaluate:</text><detail>An abdominal injury</detail><detail>Bladder and kidney infections</detail><detail>Blood in the urine</detail><detail> Flank pain (possibly due to kidney stones )</detail><detail>Tumors </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The test may reveal kidney diseases, birth defects of the urinary system, tumors, kidney stones, or damage to the urinary system.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Excretory urography</detail><detail> IVP</detail>

item.title: Intracranial pressure monitoring
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time, this procedure is done when a person is in the hospital intensive care unit. If you are awake and aware, your health care provider will explain the procedure and the risks. You will have to sign a consent form.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often done to measure intracranial pressure. It may be done when there is a severe head injury or brain/nervous system disease. It also may be done after surgery to remove a tumor or fix damage to a blood vessel if the surgeon is worried about brain swelling.</text><text>High intracranial pressure can be treated by draining CSF through the catheter. It can also be treated by changing the ventilator settings for people who are on a respirator, or by giving certain medicines through a vein (intravenously).</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally, the ICP ranges from 1 to 20 mm Hg.</text><text>Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>High intracranial pressure means that both nervous system and blood vessel tissues are under pressure. If not treated, this can lead to permanent damage. In some cases, it can be life threatening.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>ICP monitoring</detail><detail> CSF pressure monitoring</detail>

item.title: Intracardiac electrophysiology study (EPS)
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>You will be told not to eat or drink for 6 to 8 hours before the test. </text><text>You will wear a hospital gown. You must sign a consent form for the procedure.</text><text>Your health care provider will tell you ahead of time if you need to make changes to the medicines you regularly take. DO NOT stop taking or change any medicines without first talking to your provider.</text><text>In most cases, you will be given medicine to help you feel calm before the procedure. The study can last from 1 hour up to several hours. You may not be able to drive home afterward, so you should plan for someone to drive you. </text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>Your provider may order this test if you have signs of an abnormal heart rhythm ( arrhythmia ).</text><text>You may need to have other tests before this study is done. </text><text>An EPS may be done to:</text><detail>Test the function of your heart's electrical system</detail><detail>Pinpoint a known abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia) that is starting in the heart</detail><detail>Decide the best therapy for an abnormal heart rhythm</detail><detail>Determine whether you are at risk for future heart events, especially sudden cardiac death</detail><detail>See if medicine is controlling an abnormal heart rhythm</detail><detail>See whether you need a pacemaker or implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) </detail>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to abnormal heart rhythms that are too slow or too fast. These may include:</text><detail> Atrial fibrillation or flutter</detail><detail>Heart block</detail><detail> Sick sinus syndrome </detail><detail> Supraventricular tachycardia (a collection of abnormal heart rhythms that start in the upper chambers of the heart)</detail><detail>Ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia </detail><detail> Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome </detail><text>There may be other causes that are not on this list.</text><text>The provider must find the location and type of heart rhythm problem in order to determine the proper treatment. </text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Electrophysiology study - intracardiac</detail><detail> EPS - intracardiac</detail><detail> Abnormal heart rhythms - EPS</detail><detail> Bradycardia - EPS</detail><detail> Tachycardia - EPS</detail><detail> Fibrillation - EPS</detail><detail> Arrhythmia - EPS</detail><detail> Heart block - EPS</detail>

item.title: Insulin C-peptide test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Preparation for the test depends on the reason for the C-peptide measurement. Ask your health care provider if you should not eat (fast) before the test. Your provider may ask you to stop taking medicines that can affect the test results.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>C-peptide is measured to tell the difference between insulin the body produces and insulin that is injected into the body.</text><text>Someone with type 1 or type 2 diabetes may have their C-peptide level measured to see if their body is still producing insulin. C-peptide is also measured in case of low blood sugar to see if the person's body is producing too much insulin.</text><text>The test is also often ordered to check certain medicines that can help the body produce more insulin, such as glucagon-like peptide 1 analogs (GLP-1) or DPP IV inhibitors.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal result is between 0.5 to 2.0 nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL), or 0.17 to 0.83 nanomoles per liter (nmol/L).</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Some labs use different measurements or test different samples. Talk to your provider about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>C-peptide level is based on blood sugar level. C-peptide is a sign that your body is producing insulin. A low level (or no C-peptide) indicates that your pancreas is producing little or no insulin.</text><detail>A low level may be normal if you have not eaten recently. Your blood sugar and insulin levels would naturally be low then.</detail><detail>A low level is abnormal if your blood sugar is high and your body should be making insulin at that time.</detail><text>People with type 2 diabetes, obesity, or insulin resistance may have a high C-peptide level. This means their body is producing a lot of insulin to keep their blood sugar normal.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>C-peptide</detail>

item.title: Indium-labelled WBC scan
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Most of the time you do not need special preparation. You will need to sign a consent form.</text><text>For the test, you will need to wear a hospital gown or loose clothing. You will need to take off all jewelry.</text><text>Tell your provider if you are pregnant. This procedure is NOT recommended if you are pregnant or trying to become pregnant. Women of childbearing age (before menopause) should use some form of birth control during the course of this procedure.</text><text>Tell your provider if you have or had any of the following medical conditions, procedures, or treatments, as they can interfere with test results:</text><detail> Gallium (Ga) scan within the past month</detail><detail> Hemodialysis </detail><detail> Hyperglycemia </detail><detail>Long-term antibiotic therapy</detail><detail>Steroid therapy</detail><detail>Total parenteral nutrition (through an IV) </detail>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The test may be done to look for an infection, often for a bone infection called osteomyelitis. It is also used to look for an abscess that may form after surgery or on its own. </text><text>Other times it can be used to look for an abscess. Symptoms of an abscess depend on where it is found, but may include:</text><detail>Fever that has lasted a few weeks without an explanation</detail><detail>Not feeling well (malaise)</detail><detail>Pain </detail><text>Often, other imaging tests such as an ultrasound or CT scan may be done first. </text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normal findings would show no abnormal gathering of white blood cells.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>A gathering of white blood cells outside of the normal areas is a sign of either an abscess or other type of inflammatory process.</text><text>Some types of abscess are:</text><detail> Abdominal abscess </detail><detail> Amebic liver abscess </detail><detail> Anorectal abscess </detail><detail> Bartholin abscess </detail><detail> Epidural abscess </detail><detail> Peritonsillar abscess </detail><detail> Pyogenic liver abscess </detail><detail> Skin abscess </detail><detail> Spinal cord abscess </detail><detail>Subcutaneous abscess</detail><detail> Tooth abscess </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Radioactive abscess scan</detail><detail> Abscess scan</detail><detail> Indium scan</detail><detail> Indium-labeled white blood cell scan</detail>

item.title: Immunofixation blood test
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often used to check the levels of antibodies associated with certain cancers and other disorders.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal (negative) result means that the blood sample had normal types of immunoglobulins. The level of one immunoglobulin was not higher than any other.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>An abnormal result may be due to:</text><detail> Amyloidosis (buildup of abnormal proteins in tissues and organs)</detail><detail> Leukemia or Waldenström macroglobulinemia (types of white blood cell cancers)</detail><detail>Lymphoma (cancer of the lymph tissue)</detail><detail>Monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance (MGUS)</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma (a type of blood cancer)</detail><detail>Other cancers</detail><detail>Infection</detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail> Serum immunofixation </detail>

item.title: Immunofixation - urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>No special steps are necessary for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often used to check for the presence of certain proteins called monoclonal immunoglobulins. These proteins are linked to multiple myeloma and Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia . The test is done with a blood test the check for a monoclonal immunoglobulin in the serum as well.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Having no monoclonal immunoglobulins in the urine is a normal result.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The presence of monoclonal proteins may indicate:</text><detail>Cancers that affect the immune system, such as multiple myeloma or Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia</detail><detail>Other cancers</detail>

item.title: Immunoelectrophoresis - urine
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Your provider may ask you to collect the first morning urine, which is the most concentrated.</text><text>If you are taking the collection from an infant, you may need extra collection bags.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is used to measure the amounts of various immunoglobulins in urine. Most often, it is done after a large amount of protein is found in the urine.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>Normally there is no protein, or only a small amount of protein in the urine. When there is protein in the urine, it normally consists of mainly albumin.</text><text>Normal value ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories. Talk to your doctor about the meaning of your specific test results.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Immunoglobulin in the urine can result from:</text><detail>An abnormal buildup of proteins in tissues and organs ( amyloidosis )</detail><detail>Leukemia</detail><detail>Blood cancer called multiple myeloma </detail><detail>Kidney disorders such as IgA nephropathy or IgM nephropathy</detail><text>Some people have monoclonal immunoglobulins, but do not have cancer. This is called monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance, or MGUS.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>Immunoglobulin electrophoresis - urine</detail><detail> Gamma globulin electrophoresis - urine</detail><detail> Urine immunoglobulin electrophoresis</detail><detail> IEP - urine</detail>

item.title: Immunoelectrophoresis - blood
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>There is no special preparation for this test.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>This test is most often used to check the levels of antibodies when certain cancers and other disorders are present or suspected.</text>
item.NormalResults: <text>A normal (negative) result means that the blood sample had normal types of immunoglobulins. The level of one immunoglobulin was not higher than any other.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>Abnormal results may be due to:</text><detail> Multiple myeloma (a type of blood cancer)</detail><detail> Chronic lymphocytic leukemia or Waldenström macroglobulinemia (types of white blood cell cancers)</detail><detail> Amyloidosis (buildup of abnormal proteins in tissues and organs)</detail><detail>Lymphoma (cancer of the lymph tissue)</detail><detail> Kidney failure </detail><detail>Infection</detail><text>Some people have monoclonal immunoglobulins, but do not have cancer. This is called monoclonal gammopathy of unknown significance, or MGUS.</text>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>IEP - serum</detail><detail> Immunoglobulin electrophoresis - blood</detail><detail> Gamma globulin electrophoresis</detail><detail> Serum immunoglobulin electrophoresis</detail><detail> Amyloidosis - electrophoresis serum</detail><detail> Multiple myeloma - serum electrophoresis</detail><detail> Waldenström - serum electrophoresis</detail>

item.title: Joint x-ray
item.HowtoPreparefortheTest: <text>Tell the health care provider if you are pregnant. Remove all jewelry before the x-ray.</text>
item.WhytheTestisPerformed: <text>The x-ray is used to detect fractures , tumors, or degenerative conditions of the joint.</text>
item.WhatAbnormalResultsMean: <text>The x-ray may show:</text><detail> Arthritis </detail><detail>Fractures</detail><detail> Bone tumors </detail><detail>Degenerative bone conditions</detail><detail> Osteomyelitis (inflammation of the bone caused by an infection) </detail><text>The test may also be performed to find out more about the following conditions:</text><detail> Acute gouty arthritis (gout) </detail><detail> Adult-Onset Still disease </detail><detail> Caplan syndrome </detail><detail> Chondromalacia patellae </detail><detail>Chronic gouty arthritis</detail><detail> Congenital dislocation of the hip </detail><detail> Fungal arthritis </detail><detail> Non-gonococcal (septic) bacterial arthritis </detail><detail> Osteoarthritis </detail><detail> Pseudogout </detail><detail> Psoriatic arthritis </detail><detail> Reiter syndrome </detail><detail> Rheumatoid arthritis </detail><detail> Runner's knee </detail><detail>Tuberculous arthritis </detail>
item.AlternativeNames: <detail>X-ray - joint</detail><detail> Arthrography</detail><detail> Arthrogram</detail>
